P: The patient is to be transferred to a specialized transplant center in Paris for a hepatic transplant. Active case finding is being conducted to identify others potentially exposed in the area where the patient lived. The patient is advised to follow up post-transplant for further care and monitoring. Passive epidemiological surveillance is in place to monitor potential spread among tourists and individuals engaging in outdoor activities.

S: The patient, a 41-year-old male with no comorbidities or history of alcohol, smoking, or regular medication use, reported symptoms beginning July 14, 2016, including fever, myalgia, anorexia, vomiting, jaundice, and dark urine. He experienced weakness, inability to eat, and significant vomiting with yellowing of the skin and eyes. After hospitalization and treatment, he initially improved but began experiencing daily high fever, appetite loss, sweating, and weight loss of about 8 kg, with symptoms worsening progressively 15 days post-discharge.

O: Initial blood tests showed hemoglobin at 13.2 g/dL, hematocrit at 39.6%, platelets at 343,000/mm3, white blood cells (leucocytes) at 5200/mm3, AST at 39.8 U/L, ALT at 40.1 U/L, GGT at 346 U/L, and alkaline phosphatase at 98.5 U/L. The NS1 dengue test was negative. Ultrasound showed mild/moderate steatosis. On August 6, 2016, new tests revealed hemoglobin at 10.2 g/dL, hematocrit at 30.7%, red blood cells at 4.16 million/mm3, platelets at 200,000/mm3, and anisocytosis. 

A: The patient was diagnosed with hepatitis, likely due to excessive paracetamol intake, resulting in liver changes and anemia suggested by anisocytosis and decreased hemoglobin levels.

P: The plan involves regular follow-ups to monitor the patient’s condition closely and adjust treatment as needed. The patient is advised to report any new or worsening symptoms promptly.

S: The patient, an 86-year-old retired male of African-Brazilian descent, was admitted for surgical correction of lumbar stenosis and has a history of arterial hypertension, stage 3 chronic kidney disease, benign prostatic hyperplasia, peripheral arterial disease, and arthrosis of the knees. He has been treated with enalapril, hydrochlorothiazide, nifedipine, aspirin, simvastatin, finasteride, cilostazol, and tamsulosin. Following surgery, he had a hypertensive emergency treated with intravenous nitroglycerin and developed cyanosis. He also experienced severe dyspnea and reported a decrease in hemoglobin levels. He has no history of anemia and quit smoking several years ago.

O: The patient experienced cyanosis confirmed by pulse oximetry, but arterial blood gas sampling showed different results. Laboratory results post-surgery include decreased hemoglobin from 11.1 g/dL to 6.1 g/dL, elevated reticulocyte count, macrocytosis, transient leukocytosis with 60% neutrophils, 30% lymphocytes, 8% monocytes, and 2% eosinophils. The patient has a normal platelet count of 250,000/mm3, hemoglobinuria, and positive markers for hemolysis. LDH was elevated at 4701 U/L, total bilirubin at 1.6 mg/dL, unconjugated bilirubin at 0.9 mg/dL, and haptoglobin was less than 6 mg/dL. A Coombs test was negative.

A: The patient exhibits signs of hemolysis following surgery, likely related to suspected methemoglobinemia and subsequent treatment. Differential diagnosis includes drug-induced hemolytic anemia.

P: The plan involves close monitoring of the patient’s condition and symptoms. Treatment will be provided as necessary to manage hemolysis and other symptoms. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to ensure ongoing well-being and adjustment of management strategies.

S: The patient feels good and has a noncontributory family history. Five years ago, a small nodule was found in the right lung and a lytic lesion in the fifth lumbar vertebra during a checkup.

O: Initial checkup showed a small nodule in the lower lobe of the right lung and a lytic lesion in the fifth lumbar vertebra. Biopsy of lesions revealed spindle cell neoplasms. A follow-up CT scan showed an increase in size of both lesions. MR imaging confirmed the increased size. Video-assisted thoracic surgery and curettage were performed without significant findings beyond the initial lesions. The lung tumor was well-defined.

A: Suspected multiple metastases from an unknown primary tumor. Pulmonary and vertebral lesions monitored with no additional significant findings after 105 months.

P: Patient is under continued observation and will have regular checkups. Maintain a healthy lifestyle and follow healthcare team recommendations.

S: The patient presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe mid-sternal chest pain radiating to the back. There were no reports of dysphagia lusoria or hoarseness. The patient has a history of a bicuspid aortic valve and has been undergoing yearly cardiac echocardiography.

O: On examination, the patient was hemodynamically stable with no significant deviations in laboratory results. A contrast-enhanced CT scan revealed a contained rupture of a saccular aneurysm at the base of the left subclavian artery, measuring approximately 7 x 8.5 cm and extending to the transverse aortic arch. There was a large diffuse mediastinal hematoma, small left pleural effusion, and bovine aortic arch observed. Cardiac echocardiography showed a bicuspid aortic valve with moderate aortic regurgitation grade 2+, jet width 40% of LV outflow tract, regurgitate fraction 35%, end-systolic dimension 50 mm, end-diastolic dimension 65 mm, end-diastolic volume 150 ml/m2, and end-systolic volume 55 ml/m2. The patient's LV EF was 50%.

A: The patient has a contained rupture of a saccular aneurysm of the left subclavian artery with associated aortic regurgitation and mediastinal hematoma. Additionally, the patient has a history of bicuspid aortic valve with moderate regurgitation impacting cardiac function.

P: The patient underwent urgent surgical intervention, including a right auxiliary artery "chimney graft" and a left common carotid artery-left subclavian artery bypass with Terumo grafts. The left subclavian artery was divided, and a median sternotomy was performed. Postoperatively, the patient needs close follow-up with the medical team to monitor recovery, ensure proper healing, and ongoing management of the bicuspid aortic valve.

S: The patient is a 34-year-old female athlete with four years of FFT experience. She reports having no major issues lately and has maintained a consistent, well-balanced diet during a study. She is aware of the study's protocol and has no concerns or questions about it.

O: No observable findings, vitals, exam findings, or test results were mentioned in the conversation.

A: The patient appears to be in good health with a solid understanding of her training and nutrition. No specific diagnostic impressions or differentials were provided.

P: The patient is advised to continue monitoring her diet and supplementation and follow the protocols outlined by the ethics committee. She should stay in touch with the research team and report any changes in training, nutrition, or health. If unusual symptoms occur, she should contact a healthcare professional. No specific follow-up requirements were mentioned.

S: The patient reports a sudden onset of blurred vision in both eyes that began a day ago. They had ingested three times the recommended dose of a flu medicine containing paracetamol, caffeine, artificial cow-bezoar, and chlorphenamine. The patient has no history of ocular disease or myopia but was diagnosed with hypertension over a year ago and is not currently taking any medication for it.

O: The ocular examination revealed uncorrected vision of 20/400 in both eyes, corrected to 20/100 in the right eye (OD) and 20/60 in the left eye (OS) with refractive corrections of −4.50 OD and −7.00 OS. Intraocular pressure was high, at 54 mmHg OD and 55 mmHg OS. Pupillary reactions were sluggish but present. Slit lamp examination showed mild hyperemia of the bulbar conjunctivas and transparent corneas. Anterior chambers were shallow with round pupils, 3 mm in diameter. Central anterior chamber depth was 1.97 mm OD and 2.05 mm OS. Lens thickness was 4.43 mm OD and 4.40 mm OS. OCT results showed no macular abnormalities, with normal parapapillary nerve fiber layer thickness and a C/D ratio of 0.33 OD and 0.53 OS. Ultrasonography indicated no major findings but noted a highly reflective band separated from the wall in the periphery.

A: The patient is experiencing blurred vision likely due to high intraocular pressure potentially exacerbated by the excessive dose of flu medication. The findings suggest a possible drug-induced acute angle-closure glaucoma or drug reaction.

P: The plan is to monitor the patient's condition closely, adjust medication if necessary, and advise the patient to avoid excessive dosing of flu medication. The patient should follow up regularly for further evaluation and treatment to manage intraocular pressure and prevent further ocular complications.

S: The patient reported increasing weakness and pain in both hips and thighs during the last two months of pregnancy, worsening in the last two weeks, requiring the use of crutches. She recently had an elective caesarean section at 37 weeks and 4 days of gestation due to severe pain. Post-delivery, she experienced an epileptic seizure and a fall, leading to admission in a neurological department where bilateral femoral neck fractures were diagnosed through X-rays and CT. Her medical history includes childhood migraine and epilepsy, with the first seizure at age 15, previously managed with valproate for 11 years without seizures, and treatment stopped two years prior to pregnancy. She denies any past fractures, irregular menstruation, or family history of osteoporosis.

O: Clinical examination revealed massively reduced hip movement on both sides due to severe pain. Serum laboratory examination was normal.

A: Bilateral femoral neck fractures likely due to physiological changes during pregnancy and potential underlying bone density issues, exacerbated by a fall post-seizure. History of epilepsy managed with valproate.

P: Develop a treatment plan for the femoral neck fractures, consider consultation with an orthopedic specialist, and evaluate bone health. Continue monitoring epileptic condition and consider re-evaluation by a neurologist. Plan follow-up appointments for continued assessment and management.

S: The patient is a 32-year-old male who first experienced symptoms at age 23, which included abdominal pain, vomiting, fever, chills, and limb pain. He was diagnosed with Familial Mediterranean Fever (FMF) at age 25, and genetic testing revealed homozygous M680I (G/C) mutations in the MEFV gene. The attacks initially occurred every 10 days and lasted 3-4 days with high severity. He started using colchicine 1 mg twice daily 7 years ago, which reduced the frequency of attacks to once a month. Seven months ago, dapsone 50 mg daily was added, and the patient reports being symptom-free since then. He has not experienced any side effects from the therapy.

O: No observable findings provided.

A: The patient has FMF with homozygous M680I (G/C) MEFV gene mutations. Initially frequent and severe attacks have been effectively managed with colchicine and the addition of dapsone, leading to a current state of being symptom-free.

P: Continue the current medication regimen of colchicine 1 mg twice daily and dapsone 50 mg daily. Schedule regular follow-up appointments for ongoing monitoring and management of FMF. The patient is advised to report any changes in symptoms or new side effects immediately.

S: The patient reported noticing a breast lump a few weeks ago, which has been a source of concern. There is no history of thrombotic or bleeding episodes.

O: The patient has been diagnosed with oestrogen and progesterone receptor positive, HER2 negative, T1cN1bM0 moderately differentiated infiltrating ductal carcinoma. The platelet count is 600 thou/cu mm. A bone marrow biopsy showed increased megakaryocytes. Iron panel and liver function tests were unremarkable, and there is no splenomegaly on ultrasound. Average platelet count during chemotherapy was 480 thou/cu mm, with the lowest being 377 thou/cu mm, remaining between 300 and 350 thou/cu mm at goal.

A: The patient has breast cancer with concurrent elevated platelet count probably related to essential thrombocythemia (ET). The diagnosis is complicated by the anticipated thrombocytopenia during chemotherapy. 

P: The plan includes breast conservation surgery with postponement of aspirin 7 days before surgery and resumption on day 7 postoperatively. Low-molecular weight heparin (LMWH) will be administered postoperatively until the patient is fully ambulatory. The chemotherapy regimen includes 6 cycles of adjuvant docetaxel and cyclophosphamide, during which aspirin 81 mg will be continued. Post-chemotherapy, the patient will be started on letrozole for 5 years, along with radiotherapy. Hydroxyurea will be initiated and titrated to maintain platelet counts between 400-450 thou/cu mm, and zoledronic acid will be used to prevent osteoporosis. The patient's platelet count and overall progress will be closely monitored throughout the treatment.

S: The patient reports experiencing pain, redness, floaters, and decreased vision in their right eye for about two days. They have a history of anterior uveitis, treated with prednisolone acetate eye drops and an intravenous drip of dexamethasone and cephalosporin for seven days. The patient mentions a decrease in visual acuity to light perception in the right eye. They deny any history of systemic diseases, infectious diseases, trauma, surgery, or chronic medication use. The patient has a history of heavy drinking, chronic peptic discomfort, and was recently diagnosed with a peptic ulcer, which emerged two weeks before the eye symptoms. They have experienced a loss of appetite and a weight loss of 15 kg in the past month.

O: The patient's vision is reduced to light perception in the right eye, while the left eye is 6/6. The right eye examination shows mild injection, anterior chamber cells of 2+ with a hypopyon of 1.4 mm, posterior iris synechia, and fibrinous exudates. The fundus of the right eye is obscured by vitreous opacity, whereas the left eye is normal. Intraocular pressure is normal in both eyes. Ultrasound revealed dense vitreous opacities and a hyperechoic mass. Vitals are normal with a blood pressure of 132/80 mmHg, pulse of 76/min, and temperature of 36.7° Celsius. A comprehensive blood panel, liver and renal function tests, and CT scans are unremarkable. Serologic tests for various infections, including HIV, toxoplasma, varicella zoster virus, herpes simplex virus, and treponem, are negative.

A: The clinician suspects continued complications of anterior uveitis, likely linked with vitreous opacity and possibly related to the patient's recent medical history of a peptic ulcer and heavy alcohol use. Infectious causes are unlikely due to negative serology.

P: The patient is advised to continue abstinence from alcohol and attend regular follow-up appointments. Further treatment options will be discussed based on the condition's progression. The patient is instructed to monitor symptoms and reach out if changes occur.

S: The patient is a 25-year-old female with a long-standing history of psychiatric disorder, currently under medical treatment. She was referred to the unit due to abdominal pain, abdominal distension, and failure to pass stool and flatus for one week. The patient reports feeling uncomfortable and bloated for this duration. She also experiences disorganized speech, abnormal motor behavior, and lack of emotional expression as part of her psychiatric disorder.

O: Physical examination revealed the abdomen was distended below the umbilicus with irregular hard multiple masses palpable below the umbilicus, and exaggerated bowel sounds. An abdominal pelvic ultrasound showed abnormal materials in the abdominal cavity. A Barium meal X-ray indicated that the stomach was located in the pelvic brim with stenosis and irregularities in the gastrointestinal tract. During a Laparotomy, various metallic and nonmetallic objects were found in the stomach and proximal small intestine, totaling 780 mg in weight, with the longest item being an 80 mm nail. There was no evidence of perforation or ulceration.

A: The patient has been diagnosed with metalophagia, which is the compulsive consumption of metal objects, likely related to her underlying psychiatric disorder.

P: The patient has recovered well from the surgery. She will be referred back to the psychiatric hospital for further treatment and management of her psychiatric disorder to address the underlying issues and prevent recurrence.

S: The patient, a 71-year-old obese woman, reports progressive left hip pain for about 8 months. The pain is described as mechanical and previously improved with analgesics, but recently the pain has worsened, affecting her walking distance and the effectiveness of painkillers.

O: On examination, the patient's BMI is 35.5. She has nearly normal walking ability with no scars on the left hip or buttock. Abductors have good trophicity, but lateral rotation and abduction are markedly diminished. Radiographs show signs of hip osteoarthritis. During surgery, a well-circumscribed shell 2.5 cm in size was found within the adipose tissue, resembling a purulent collection, which was resected. Cytobacteriological examination showed a greasy appearance with epithelial and lymphocytic cells, but no visible germs. Histological examination revealed a fibrous wall with chronic inflammatory remodeling with lymphocytes and plasma cells, but no necrosis centers.

A: Symptomatic left hip osteoarthritis; chronic inflammatory process in the adipose tissue around the hip.

P: Monitor patient's progress and determine the appropriate timing for the implantation of the prosthesis for hip osteoarthritis. Continue to assess and manage hip pain and function. Follow up based on further developments and laboratory results.

S: The patient reports experiencing intermittent low-grade fever for the past four months, accompanied by night sweats, loss of appetite, and a weight loss of approximately 5 kilograms. Additionally, the patient has observed a decrease in urine output and generalized swelling.

O: On examination, the patient is febrile with an enlarged right axillary lymph node measuring 1cm x 1cm, ascites, and a palpable spleen 8cm below the left costal margin. Fundus examination is normal. Laboratory results reveal pancytopenia with a hemoglobin level of 7.4g/dl, total leucocyte count of 1200/mcl, and platelet count of 20000/mcl. Liver function tests show aspartate transaminase at 209 U/l and alanine transaminase at 117 U/l. Urea and creatinine levels are 78 and 1.7 mg/dl, respectively. CD4 level has decreased from a baseline of 221/μl to 158/μl. Abdominal CT shows multiple enlarged retroperitoneal lymph nodes, with the largest measuring 47 x 22 mm. Peripheral smear indicates normocytic normochromic anemia, folate level is low at 2.2ng/ml, and serum LDH levels are elevated at 834 IU/l. rk39 antibody test is negative. Ascitic fluid analysis shows a protein level of 1.9 g/dl, albumin level of 0.9 g/dl, total leucocyte count of 380/mcl (90% lymphocytes), serum-ascitic albumin gradient of 1.1g/dl, and adenosine deaminase levels of 40 IU/l. Cultures are sterile.

A: The clinical findings suggest a presumptive diagnosis of disseminated tuberculosis, considering the symptoms, lymphadenopathy, ascites, blood test results, and imaging findings.

P: The plan is to initiate an appropriate treatment course for disseminated tuberculosis. Tests such as blood and urine cultures and rk39 antibody were performed; however, due to deranged coagulation parameters, a lymph node biopsy was not possible. Follow-up will be necessary to monitor response to treatment and adjust as needed.

S: The patient reports experiencing blistering and soreness in the mouth for about 8 months, with oral involvement beginning in January 2008. The patient has a history of an itchy rash on the legs, scalp, and chest treated by Dermatology since 2003. The patient was unable to tolerate Azathioprine due to nausea and vomiting. The patient's relevant medical history includes hypertension managed with Nifedipine, and the patient is a non-smoker with low alcohol intake.

O: On examination, small erosions and ulcers were observed on the patient's soft palate and both sides of the buccal mucosae. A past biopsy from a crusted lesion revealed acantholysis of keratinocytes, consistent with Pemphigus Foliaceus. Blood tests, including full blood count, urea and electrolytes, and liver function tests, were normal. Regular blood monitoring was appropriately conducted.

A: The patient is diagnosed with Pemphigus Foliaceus with oral involvement. The patient's cutaneous lesions were well-controlled with Mycophenolate Mofetil (MMF) and Prednisolone. The patient's symptoms have completely resolved with the adjusted treatment plan.

P: The patient was advised to continue the prescribed treatment plan: Mycophenolate Mofetil (MMF) 1 g twice a day. The patient should continue regular check-ups and report any returning symptoms. No oral biopsy was arranged due to the effective response to systemic therapy. Regular monitoring and collaboration with the Oral Medicine/Dermatology clinic will persist.

S: The patient reported experiencing sudden jerky movements in both upper limbs, sitting in strange postures, and having a narrow, shuffling gait. She described a rapid progression of dysphasia, leading to near muteness, social withdrawal, indifference, visual hallucinations, and exaggerated startle responses. No family history of neurodegenerative diseases was noted, although her father and mother passed away from bone and lung cancer, respectively.

O: MRI of the patient's brain showed asymmetrical cortical ribboning with left-sided emphasis and bilateral anterior basal ganglia diffusion restriction. EEG results indicated generalized periodic complexes. Cerebrospinal fluid cell count and routine biochemistry were normal, but specific protein assays were not obtained.

A: The clinical presentation suggests a rapidly progressive neurological disorder with severe motor, cognitive, and emotional disturbances, potentially indicative of a prion disease or other neurodegenerative condition.

P: Further testing was recommended to better understand the condition, with ongoing monitoring and management of symptoms. Due to the patient's passing, no further medical interventions are planned. The doctor expressed condolences to the patient's family and acknowledged the lack of postmortem examination.

S: The patient is a 61-year-old woman with a BRCA1 gene mutation, who reports a medical history including a Cesarean section and a left ovarian cystectomy. She has no history of cancer. She recently underwent a prophylactic total laparoscopic hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. No symptoms or specific complaints were mentioned by the patient.

O: During the prophylactic procedure, a white nodule was found on the fimbriated end of the right fallopian tube, measuring 0.5 x 0.1 x 0.3 cm. The nodule was identified as solid and firm with sections showing small, tightly packed tubules and nests of epithelioid cells in a fibrous background with psammoma bodies. Additional studies indicated negativity for Mucicarmine stain, and IHC studies showed positivity for WT1, calretinin, PAX8, and D2-40, and negativity for p53, estrogen, and progesterone receptors.

A: The clinical impression is that the lesion is not a typical cancerous growth. The findings, particularly the thread-like bridging, support a diagnosis consistent with an adenomatoid tumor.

P: The plan is to continue monitoring the situation with any necessary follow-up tests or treatments. The patient is advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and report any unusual changes in her body.

S: The patient, a 62-year-old man, reports experiencing melena for the past two days. He has a history of alcoholic liver cirrhosis complicated by hepatocellular carcinoma. He has undergone transcatheter arterial embolization and laparoscopic radiofrequency ablation. The patient also has esophageal and gastric varices and has received endoscopic variceal band ligation due to esophageal variceal bleeding. He smokes 20 cigarettes per day and consumes an average of 100 g of alcohol daily for about 40 years.

O: Upon admission, the patient's blood pressure was 116/74 mmHg, pulse rate 80 beats/min, respiratory rate 20 breaths/min, and body temperature 35.9 °C. Hemoglobin level was 8.3 g/dL, decreased from a baseline of 9.2 g/dL. An abdominal CT scan showed cirrhosis, recurrent HCC in S4, S6, and S7, with thrombosis in the right posterior branch of the portal vein. Emergent EGD and colonoscopy did not reveal the hemorrhage source. Anterograde SBE revealed fresh blood and an engorged cystic lesion in the proximal jejunum, diagnosed as ectopic jejunal varices. 

A: The patient is experiencing bleeding due to ectopic jejunal varices secondary to liver cirrhosis and HCC complications, with recent interventions failing to immediately control bleeding. 

P: Initial treatment included injecting 3.5 mL glue mixture into the varix, followed by a second sclerotherapy attempt with 2.0 mL cyanoacrylate, which ceased the bleeding. The plan involves closely monitoring the patient's condition to prevent recurrence and advising the patient to quit smoking and reduce alcohol intake to prevent further complications.

S: The patient presented to the emergency department with sudden onset, intense substernal chest pain that began 30 minutes before arrival. There was no mention of prior medical history or other complaints in the conversation.

O: The patient's ECG showed atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response at a rate of 147 and minimal ST depression in the lateral leads. An initial assessment included point-of-care labs with a basic metabolic panel and troponin test. A chest X-ray showed no gross abnormalities but was non-diagnostic. A bedside cardiac ultrasound was performed, during which the patient experienced ventricular fibrillation.

A: The patient was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and subsequently, life-threatening ventricular fibrillation was observed. Differential consideration included evaluating for right heart strain secondary to pulmonary embolism.

P: The patient received multiple rounds of CPR, epinephrine, 450 mg of amiodarone, and three defibrillation attempts. Double sequential defibrillation successfully converted the ventricular fibrillation. The patient was also given 100 mg of Lidocaine followed by a Lidocaine drip. The patient's condition stabilized, and close monitoring and follow-up care were recommended.

S: The patient reported having experienced a possible tonic-clonic seizure and a reduction of vision in the right eye since 2015. The patient has been living in a rural area in Heilongjiang Province for the last 10 years and mentioned observing white tapeworm segments in feces. No prior medical history was reported.

O: A brain MRI showed multiple parietal cysts at the vesicular stage with edema in the frontal, parietal, and occipital white matter. An eye MRI showed a well-defined ring-enhancing cystic lesion involving the right superior rectus. A chest X-ray revealed multiple nodular calcifications. Anticysticercal IgG antibodies were positive in serum and CSF via ELISA, while CSF exams showed normal WBCs, normal protein level, normal glucose levels, and negative bacterial culture.

A: The patient is diagnosed with a parasitic infection affecting the brain and eyes, suggestive of neurocysticercosis. The symptoms align with the MRI findings and positive anticysticercal IgG antibodies.

P: The patient underwent successful ophthalmic surgery and started treatment with albendazole (20 mg/kg body weight daily) three times a day for 10 days, along with oral antiepileptic drugs and intravenous dexamethasone (5 mg). After experiencing severe epilepsy on the third day, intravenous dexamethasone was increased to 10 mg daily. Antiepileptic therapy continued until the end of albendazole treatment. The patient will receive three additional courses of albendazole with 3-month intervals. Monitoring and adjustment of the treatment plan will continue as needed.

S:  
The patient reports feeling lightheaded for the past two days, along with experiencing abdominal pain and melena. They have a medical history of hypertension, erosive gastritis that required a transfusion, and autoimmune pancreatitis (AIP) diagnosed two weeks ago. The patient was diagnosed with AIP after presenting with abdominal pain, elevated lipase, and hyperglycemia. The patient is currently taking prednisone 20 mg twice a day and has been on diltiazem and tramadol prior to admission. They report no history of drug or alcohol abuse and are not taking nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

O:  
The patient's vital signs on presentation show they are afebrile and not hypoxic, with a blood pressure of 175/39 mm Hg, a pulse of 140, and a respiratory rate of 18. Physical examination reveals normoactive bowel sounds, a soft abdomen with significant epigastric tenderness, and melena on rectal examination. There is no jaundice, splenomegaly, or guarding. Laboratory results include a WBC count of 46,000/mL, hemoglobin of 9.2 mg/dL, platelets of 96,000/mL, creatinine of 1.8 mg/dL, AST of 40 U/L, ALT of 59 U/L, total bilirubin of 0.7 mg/dL, serum glucose of 300 mg/dL, and lipase of 31 U/L.

A:  
The patient is assessed to have symptoms related to autoimmune pancreatitis, gastrointestinal bleeding possibly associated with erosive gastritis, and complications from steroid therapy. The leukocytosis is thought to be due to steroid therapy and stress response to the gastrointestinal bleed. The patient is also experiencing significant hyperglycemia.

P:  
The patient will be admitted to the hospital for further management and monitoring. Continuous monitoring of vital signs and laboratory results will be conducted. A consultation with specialists will be made to determine the best treatment for the patient's AIP and gastrointestinal bleed.

S: The patient reports experiencing back pain and ankle clonus in both ankles. The patient has a history of total nephrectomy for renal cell carcinoma (RCC) 10 years ago.

O: Physical examination results are within normal limits, except for ankle clonus. MRI and CT scans reveal spinal metastases involving the T1-T3 vertebrae, a pathological fracture of T2 causing spinal cord compression, and metastases in the right adrenal gland, sternum, left clavicle, and sacrum. A CT-guided biopsy confirms metastatic renal cell carcinoma (mRCC). Classification includes Enneking grade III, Tomita type 6, and Weinstein-Boriani-Biagini zones 4 to 9, layers A to D. Spine Instability Neoplastic Score is 16, indicating instability.

A: Diagnosed with metastatic renal cell carcinoma (mRCC) with spinal metastases and instability.

P: Treatment includes administering zoledronic acid 4 mg/month. Surgical intervention with Total En Bloc Spondylectomy (TES) and reconstruction using a cryo-treated tumor-bearing bone graft is planned, involving detailed surgical steps including rib resection and nerve root management. Monitoring and follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient is a 32-year-old obese woman, gravida five, para 3104, with a history of preterm contractions and preeclampsia. She was admitted with persistent pelvic pain and a fever of 103.1 F since delivering her baby four days ago via normal spontaneous vaginal delivery at term. Since delivery, she has been experiencing fever and chills. On hospital day three, she developed a productive cough.

O: The patient presented with foul-smelling lochia and laboratory results showing elevated white blood cell count and anemia. A pelvic x-ray revealed diastases of the pubic symphysis measuring 3.75 cm. An MRI scan showed no pelvic abscess or hematoma. She exhibited progressive tachycardia with a fever of 102.5 F, and developed signs of sepsis. Blood cultures grew Streptococcus pyogenes (group A) and Proteus mirabilis. Urine culture showed 80,000 cfu/mL of Proteus mirabilis, susceptible to several antibiotics including ampicillin, but resistant to nitrofurantoin. On day three, she was febrile, tachypneic, tachycardic, hypoxic, and had expiratory wheezes in bilateral upper lung fields. Chest CT showed bilateral patchy opacities.

A: The working diagnosis is sepsis secondary to endometritis, with possible lung infection indicated by bilateral patchy opacities on CT.

P: The patient was started on intravenous ampicillin and clindamycin. Blood cultures revealed the presence of Streptococcus pyogenes and Proteus mirabilis, and an appropriate antibiotic regimen was considered based on susceptibility. Continued monitoring and adjustment of treatment will be carried out as needed, with an emphasis on resting and following the prescribed medication regimen.

S: The patient is a 28-year-old right-handed woman experiencing a severe depressive episode. Her first depressive episode began about 10 years ago, accompanied by panic attacks. The patient has been diagnosed with Bipolar Disorder-II, characterized by alternating phases of depression and occasional elation. Her depressive episodes worsen during autumn and winter. She reports low alcohol consumption socially and sporadic cannabis use during adolescence. The patient has a history of binge eating, beginning with her initial depression diagnosis, which occurs almost daily during depressive phases. She engages in binge eating without compensatory behaviors, leading to physical and psychological distress. Her first formal diagnosis of Binge Eating Disorder occurred during her last depressive episode.

O: The patient is currently on clomipramine (150 mg daily) and pregabalin (225 mg daily). Despite this, she struggles with severe depressive symptoms. Previous medications included valproate, fluoxetine, citalopram, venlafaxine, and bupropion. Assessments using MADRS and HAMD confirm the severity of her depressive symptoms.

A: The patient has a diagnosis of Bipolar Disorder-II and Binge Eating Disorder. The depressive episodes are severe and seem resistant to current medication. There is a notable seasonal pattern to the depressive episodes.

P: The plan is to continue monitoring the patient's progress and consider medication adjustments as necessary. The patient should maintain communication about any changes in condition or concerns about her symptoms.

S: The patient is an 81-year-old male who experienced an accidental fall from a height of 5 meters, resulting in bilateral groin and thigh pain. He has a history of bilateral cementless total hip arthroplasties, with the right side having a 24-year follow-up and the left side a 21-year follow-up. The patient has comorbidities associated with a BMI of 33 kg/m².

O: Clinical examination reveals inability to actively move legs and pain on passive movement. Radiographic studies show bilateral fractures of the femoral shaft, classified as Vancouver type-B2 periprosthetic femoral fractures. The patient has bilateral Robert Mathys (RM®) cementless total hip arthroplasties with acetabular polyethylene wear and instability of the femoral stem with broken screws. Paprosky type II femoral osteolysis is also present.

A: The patient has sustained bilateral femoral shaft fractures with associated complications from previous total hip arthroplasties, including polyethylene wear and femoral stem instability. Diagnosed as Vancouver type-B2 periprosthetic femoral fractures.

P: Fractures were treated with open reduction and fixation using distal femur locking compression plates (LCP®) and a combination of locking and nonlocking screws. Femoral stems were managed by perforation with a 3.2 mm drill. Fracture sites were augmented with cryopreserved morselized cancellous bone allografts, and a structural fibular bone allograft was used on the right side. The patient will undergo a specific rehabilitation program to regain mobility gradually and will be closely monitored with regular follow-up appointments.

S: The patient reports having a foreign body in the left eye for about 8 months following a gunshot injury. Initially, there was a small wound on the left eyelid with normal eye movement, visual field, and no pain. Recently, the patient developed pain in the left eye but has experienced no sinonasal symptoms. An ophthalmologist referred the patient for a minimally invasive procedure to remove the foreign body.

O: Examination reveals no restriction in left orbit movements, normal visual acuity (20/20), and no proptosis or chemosis. A CT scan shows a 6 mm round-shaped metallic foreign body in the medial intraconal space and lateral attachment of the posterior ethmoid sinus.

A: Retained metallic foreign body in the left orbit with recent onset of pain. Consideration of minimally invasive removal of the foreign body using endoscopic transnasal approach due to potential risks associated with retaining the foreign body.

P: Proceed with transnasal endoscopic removal of the foreign body using navigator assistance. Perform uncinectomy and anterior-posterior ethmoidectomy, confirm location with the navigator system, and dissect fibrotic capsule to remove the bullet. Monitor for intraorbital bleeding or damage. Advise the patient to follow up and report any further symptoms or issues.

S: The patient is a 68-year-old diagnosed with Parkinson's disease in 2009 and is currently in Hoehn and Yahr Stage III. The patient reports cognitive problems, specifically with concentration and memory deficits, which began a few years after diagnosis. 

O: No observable findings, vitals, exam findings, or test results were mentioned.

A: The patient has Parkinson's disease with cognitive symptoms, including concentration and memory deficits.

P: The patient is encouraged to continue engaging in cognitive activities, such as playing Bridge, which has subjectively benefited the patient's concentration and memory. The patient is advised to monitor symptoms and consult with the healthcare team if any changes occur. Regular communication with the healthcare team is recommended.

S: The patient reports having a fever that has persisted for 20 days. They are concerned about their health, given the prolonged nature of the fever and the new information provided by the doctor.

O: The patient underwent a CT scan, which indicated signs of a pulmonary infection. Laboratory tests showed cytopenia in peripheral blood, with decreased white blood cells, red blood cells, and neutrophil granulocytes. Hemoglobin level is 74.0 g/L and ferritin is elevated at 3602.5 g/L. Autoimmune antibody tests were normal. NK cell activity was tested and found to be low, at 30% of the low limit of healthy controls, confirmed via two assays measuring IFN-γ secretion and functional activity against K562 cells. Bone marrow aspiration confirmed hemophagocytosis. Epstein-Barr Virus and Cytomegalovirus infections were excluded as causes.

A: The diagnostic impression is Hemophagocytic Lymphohistiocytosis (HLH), assessed according to HLH-2004 guidelines.

P: Treatment for HLH has been initiated. A targeted next-generation sequencing (NGS) panel using an Ion Torrent Personal Genome Machine is being conducted to explore potential genetic causes of HLH. Follow-up is planned to discuss these results and adjust treatment accordingly.

S: The patient, who has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypothyroidism, reports experiencing increasing diplopia and nausea over the past six days, along with an unintentional weight loss of about 10 pounds in the last two weeks.

O: The physical exam revealed bony tenderness localized to the ribs and a right CN VI palsy causing impaired right eye abduction. Hemogram showed a slightly elevated white count of 10,700 k/µL and high absolute neutrophil count at 7.5 k/µL, with normal lymphocyte levels. Blood chemistry indicated elevated serum Ca2+ at 15.8 mg/dL, high ionized Ca2+ at 7.7 mg/dL, and elevated glucose level at 254 mg/dL. Parathyroid hormone was low at <10 pg/mL, with normal parathyroid hormone-related peptide at 1.3. Urine analysis and urine protein electrophoresis were unremarkable. Total protein was 6.8 g/dL, serum globulin was 2.8 g/dL, resulting in a protein gap of 4.0 g/dL. The albumin/gamma globulin ratio was high at 2.4. Serum protein electrophoresis showed a faint monoclonal immunoglobulin. Serum immune-quantification revealed IgG at 1150 mg/dL, IgA at 200 mg/dL, and IgM at 41.

A: The clinical presentation and test findings suggest the need for further investigation to understand the cause of symptoms, particularly looking into the elevated calcium levels and the presence of a monoclonal immunoglobulin.

P: Monitor the patient's condition closely, considering additional testing or specialist consultations as needed to determine the underlying cause. The patient should continue managing type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypothyroidism as prescribed by their primary care physician.

S: The patient reported using a traditional herbal remedy called "lian-serpent," involving T. crispa stem, to detoxify the liver. After the last intake, the patient experienced fever, weakness for a week, and dark urine, prompting an emergency room visit.

O: Upon admission, the patient was diagnosed with acute hepatitis with cholestasis and cytolysis, alongside jaundice. Vitals were normal, and the patient was not overweight. Liver function tests revealed ALT at 1923 U/L, AST at 873 U/L, and γGT at 155 U/L. Abdominal ultrasonography was normal without hepatomegaly or lithiasis. Tests for viral hepatitis (A, B, C), cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus, and varicella zoster virus were negative.

A: The diagnosis is liver damage likely caused by the herbal remedy, indicated by acute hepatitis, with no evidence of viral infection. Condition improved with regression of jaundice and progressive decrease in liver function test abnormalities.

P: The patient is advised to avoid consuming the herbal remedy and to seek medical consultation before trying alternative treatments in the future. Ongoing monitoring of liver function tests is recommended to ensure continued improvement.

S: The patient reported that their left arm was injured on a waterslide at an amusement park when it got caught between the side of the slide and some rocks, resulting in severe pain and a visibly twisted appearance. The injury caused the patient significant pain and deformity in the arm, forearm, and wrist.

O: The physical exam revealed closed injuries, with soft arm and forearm compartments, and the patient was neurovascularly intact. Radiographs identified a left distal third humeral shaft fracture and a left Galeazzi fracture involving a midshaft radius fracture and disruption of the distal radioulnar joint. Treatment included placement in a well-padded long arm posterior plaster splint. Within 24 hours, open reduction and internal fixation of the humeral shaft and radial shaft fractures were performed.

A: Diagnoses include a left distal third humeral shaft fracture and a left Galeazzi fracture. Treatment involved surgical reduction and fixation.

P: The plan includes monitoring the patient's recovery and healing process, providing necessary follow-up care, and advising the patient to keep the affected area clean and avoid movements that may disrupt healing. The patient should reach out with any concerns during recovery.

S: The patient, an 81-year-old woman, has been diagnosed with solid tubular carcinoma. She reported noticing a lump in her breast and experiencing fatigue and weakness. She expressed concerns about the intensity of potential treatments and sought advice on how to manage her condition in the meantime.

O: The patient had tests conducted with parameters: 29 kV voltage, 48 tube current, 41 mm thickness, and AGD of 1.29, using 15 projections to image the carcinoma. These figures assist in determining the size and location of the tumor.

A: The patient is diagnosed with solid tubular carcinoma of the breast. The doctor is considering the stage of cancer, the patient's overall health, and her preferences to determine suitable treatment options, which may include surgery, radiation, or chemotherapy.

P: The doctor recommends maintaining a healthy lifestyle including proper diet, staying active, and adequate rest. A support group or counseling is suggested for emotional support. A follow-up appointment will be scheduled to discuss and finalize treatment options. The patient is encouraged to reach out with any questions or concerns in the interim.

S: The patient reported having right upper abdominal pain along with a palpable lump in the same area. There is no significant past medical or surgical history, and the family and psychosocial history are unremarkable.

O: A physical examination revealed slight tenderness and a semimobile mass in the right upper abdomen. An abdominal contrast-enhanced CT scan showed a 130 × 100 × 90 mm cystic mass in the right upper peritoneal cavity with a thickened wall and enhanced nodules. Gadolinium-enhanced MRI indicated the presence of either bleeding or mucinous fluid within the cyst and a connection with the pancreatic head. During surgery, bloody fluid was aspirated from the cyst, which re-increased shortly after, confirming the hemorrhagic nature of the cyst.

A: The clinical findings led to the diagnosis of a hemorrhagic cyst originating from the pancreatic head. Differential diagnoses considered were MCN, mucinous cystic adenocarcinoma, and hemorrhagic cyst, but the intraoperative findings supported a diagnosis of hemorrhagic cyst.

P: A pancreaticoduodenectomy was planned and a partial pancreatectomy was performed to completely resect the tumor. Post-operatively, the patient had a good recovery and was discharged on day 9. Ongoing monitoring of the patient's condition is advised, and the patient is instructed to report any new symptoms or concerns.

S: The patient first began experiencing sharp pain and claudication in the left lower limb in 2008, making it difficult to walk. Despite treatment, the pain persisted. In 2013, there was an exacerbation of the pain, leading to further investigation. The patient was under surveillance in the private sector and attended follow-ups. The patient reports that the condition has greatly improved, with the pain mostly gone now.

O: Initial investigations included a bone biopsy and curettage with tricortical bone allograft, leading to a presumptive diagnosis of an aneurysmal bone cyst. In 2013, additional imaging studies indicated osteolysis of the left iliac bone. A bone scan was negative for infectious or inflammatory bone disease, but MRI suggested a neoplastic lesion indicative of Ewing’s sarcoma. An incisional biopsy in 2013 indicated an aneurysmal bone cyst. Follow-up biopsy in June 2014 showed necrosis, reabsorption of spongy bone tissue, and other changes. A bone graft was again used two years later for treatment.

A: The initial assessment was an aneurysmal bone cyst. However, given the MRI and histopathology findings, there was a suspicion of a neoplastic process, possibly Ewing’s sarcoma. The condition has shown improvement with treatment, evidenced by symptom relief.

P: Continue regular follow-up appointments for monitoring. The patient should contact their healthcare provider if there are any changes in pain or new symptoms. Regular monitoring will help ensure symptoms remain under control.

S: The patient is a 29-year-old South Asian male with no significant past medical history. He reports experiencing a high-grade fever, malaise, and anorexia for the past 14 days, accompanied by a 10-pound weight loss. His symptoms have not improved despite taking antibiotics and antipyretics. He has no recent medication use, sick contacts, or travel history.

O: The patient is noted to have a resting sinus tachycardia of 110 beats per minute, normotensive blood pressure, and mild pyrexia of 38.8°C. Pulse oximetry is at 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals bilateral conjunctivitis with chemosis, strawberry tongue glossitis, palmar desquamation, and ichthyosis, with no lymphadenopathy or rash. Laboratory tests show leukocytosis, thrombocytosis, and markedly elevated inflammatory markers (erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein), with a normal comprehensive metabolic panel. Infectious disease workup is negative, as is the immunological panel for vasculitis or rheumatological diseases.

A: The diagnosis is an incomplete presentation of Kawasaki disease based on the patient’s symptoms, laboratory findings, and exclusion of other infectious and rheumatological causes.

P: The patient is started on high-dose enteric-coated aspirin to manage symptoms. Close monitoring of the patient’s condition is advised, and he should report any changes or worsening of symptoms immediately.

S: The patient was admitted previously with symptoms of edema in both lower extremities, a feeling of abdominal fullness, and shortness of breath upon exertion. They were diagnosed with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) following a blood test and bone marrow examination. The patient originally presented with giant splenomegaly and hepatomegaly.

O: Initial examination revealed a white blood cell count of 480,000/μL. After starting dasatinib, the patient developed heavy proteinuria (urinary protein-creatinine ratio of 8.93 g/g creatinine) and low serum albumin level (2.3 g/dL). An admission physical examination showed blood pressure of 121/70 mmHg, pulse 56/min, temperature 36.5°C, respiratory rate 16/min, slight splenomegaly, and lower leg edema. Latest blood test results indicate a white blood cell count of 11,500/μL, hemoglobin level of 13.2 g/dL, platelet count of 132,000/μL, serum creatinine level of 0.87 mg/dL (eGFR 78.4 mL/min/1.73m2), serum albumin level of 3.08 g/dL, total cholesterol 287 mg/dL, and LDL cholesterol 166 mg/dL.

A: The patient has a confirmed diagnosis of CML and nephrotic syndrome potentially related to dasatinib treatment. The patient also presented with pancytopenia following initial dasatinib treatment and has ongoing issues with splenomegaly and edema.

P: The patient is advised to return for regular checkups and blood tests to monitor CML, nephrotic syndrome, and overall health. Continuation and adjustment of dasatinib therapy will be determined based on ongoing monitoring and symptom changes. The patient should report any changes in symptoms or new symptoms immediately for prompt evaluation and management.

S: The patient reported symptoms of the right eye bulging (exophthalmos) with severe pain, swelling, redness, and mucopurulent discharge. The patient has a medical history of being HIV and HCV positive for 11 years and has a history of drug and alcohol addiction, including habitual marijuana smoking.

O: Clinical examination revealed severe nonreducible exophthalmos with the eye dislocated medially and inferiorly, eyelid chemosis, decreased vision of 1/10 in the right eye, restricted motility in all gazes due to mechanical proptosis, optic disc swelling, and venous congestion. MRI revealed an intraorbital mass that is inhomogeneously hypointense on T2-weighted images and hypointense on T1-weighted images, located in the lateral orbit cavity, extending to the ethmoid and maxillary sinuses, causing bony destruction and encasing and displacing surrounding structures. Histology from the biopsy showed a monomorphic proliferation of plasmablastic cells suggestive of plasmablastic lymphoma.

A: Differential diagnoses included neoplastic diseases like lymphoma and infections, particularly mycotic origin due to marijuana smoking. Confirmed diagnosis of plasmablastic lymphoma based on histology.

P: The plan included performing a biopsy to confirm the diagnosis, which was completed. However, before further treatment could be initiated for plasmablastic lymphoma, the patient unfortunately died from a heart attack. No further treatment or follow-up could be provided.

S: The patient reports swelling and facial asymmetry on the left side of the face. They were diagnosed with craniofacial monostotic fibrous dysplasia (FD) at 13 years old and underwent surgery. At 18, they noticed recurrence with swelling on the left mid-face region, suggesting growth of the lesion.

O: A clinical extra-oral examination shows significant facial asymmetry. A CT scan reveals a dysplastic dense mass affecting the maxillary and zygomatic bones, with a preoperative cephalometric analysis indicating a 5.5 mm downward canting.

A: The examination and CT results indicate a growth causing facial asymmetry, severe maxillary occlusal canting, gummy smile, and compensatory mandibular occlusal canting with a relatively symmetrical mandibular outline.

P: The plan includes presurgical orthodontic treatment for 14 months, followed by a Le Fort I osteotomy to correct occlusal canting. Additional procedures include removal of dysplastic bone, mandibular sagittal split ramus osteotomy, and a Triaca style mandibular wing osteotomy. The maxilla will be fixed with microplates and miniplates, with slightly weaker fixation on the FD-affected side. Postoperative orthodontic treatment is scheduled to begin 4 weeks after surgery, with monitoring to ensure no skeletal relapse over a 2-year follow-up period.

S: The patient reports feeling fine with no symptoms noted in the mandible or elsewhere in the mouth. The medical and dental history is uneventful. There have been no complaints of paresthesia or issues noted during the extraoral examination.

O: The initial examination showed no redness or tender swelling of the left mandibular mucosa. Panoramic radiography revealed an extensive multilocular radiolucent area with a "soap bubble appearance." CT scan detected a 39 × 19 × 11 mm tumor extending to the roots of teeth #33 - 36. Histopathological findings indicated an odontogenic tumor with spindle-shaped cells in a myxoid fibrous stroma. The diagnosis was confirmed as odontogenic myxoma after conservative surgery.

A: The clinical diagnosis is an odontogenic myxoma based on surgical specimen findings.

P: Conservative surgery was performed, including extraction of the second premolar and total enucleation with curettage of the bone. Follow-up included monthly examinations for the first year, every two months in the second year, and annual follow-up for eight years with panoramic X-rays and CT imaging. The patient is to continue with regular monitoring for ongoing well-being.

S: The patient is a 21-year-old Mexican mestizo woman with a family history of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), as her father also had the condition. She was diagnosed with SLE at age 4 after presenting with a malar rash, fever, anemia, fatigue, and malaise. She has experienced constant disease flares and has been treated with corticosteroids and immunosuppressive agents. At age 6, she had septic monoarthritis in her right knee, requiring surgical drainage and antibiotics. Around the same time, she noticed speech and attention problems, irritability, apathy, and a lack of concentration in school. Seizures began at age 8, characterized by a visceral aura, fixed gaze, altered consciousness, oral automatisms, somnolence, and amnesia in the postictal phase, diagnosed as focal impaired awareness seizures from the left medial temporal lobe, initially controlled with anticonvulsants but treatment-resistant by age 15. At age 19, she was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis and secondary antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) after presenting with generalized fatigue, localized pain, hyperthermia, pruritus, and hyperemia of her right lower extremity. She also has microcytic hypochromic anemia.

O: The patient experienced deep vein thrombosis as confirmed by a Doppler ultrasound, extending from the right popliteal vein through the right femoral vein. Laboratory tests revealed low hemoglobin at 4.83 g/dL, reticulocyte count of 5.6%, MCV of 54.6 fL, and MCH of 15.1 pg. She tested positive for the lupus anticoagulant test.

A: The patient has a history of SLE with constant disease flares, focal impaired awareness seizures, secondary APS, deep vein thrombosis, and microcytic hypochromic anemia. Her seizures are now treatment-resistant, and she requires continuous management for SLE and APS.

P: The patient is advised to continue her current medications, including hydroxychloroquine, prednisone, azathioprine, warfarin, calcium, and vitamin D supplements. Regular follow-up with the healthcare team is crucial for monitoring her condition and adjusting the treatment plan as necessary. She is instructed to report any new symptoms or changes in her condition promptly.

S: The patient, Wayne, reports having a wound on the right foot for two to three weeks that is not healing. He initially developed a blister from wearing a new pair of shoes that were too tight, but he did not feel it due to neuropathy. He has diabetes with a recent HbA1c level slightly over 8. There are no accompanying symptoms such as pain, fever, chills, or drainage. The patient has stopped wearing the problematic shoes.

O: Vital signs: Temperature 98.1°F, heart rate 72 bpm, respirations 16/min, blood pressure 110/65 mmHg. Foot exam: 1x2 inch circular wound on the lateral right foot near the fifth MTP joint, yellow slough, minimal granulation tissue, no erythema, cellulitis, fluid collection, necrosis, or odor. No bony exposure. Vascular exam: Palpable bilateral femoral and popliteal pulses, non-palpable DP and PT pulses, but doppler signals present. X-ray shows no osteomyelitis.

A: Diabetic foot ulcer with neuropathy and potential compromised blood supply. Diabetes control needs improvement.

P: Order an ankle-brachial index (ABI) to assess foot blood supply. Perform debridement of the wound. Prescribe collagenase ointment to be applied daily with a dry sterile dressing. Advise wearing a surgical shoe to offload pressure from the wound area. No additional antibiotics needed. Schedule follow-up in two weeks, with potential referral to a vascular specialist based on ABI results. Recommend diabetic consult to improve glycemic control and possibly lower HbA1c levels.

S: The patient reports a right-sided neck swelling that has been increasing in size over the past three months without associated pain, fever, or difficulty swallowing. There is also a painless scalp swelling present for 20 years, previously unaddressed.

O: Examination revealed a firm, fixed, non-tender mass on the right side of the neck at level II, measuring 3 x 3 cm. A soft, mobile lump was also noted on the scalp, 4 x 4 cm in size. Excisional biopsy of the neck mass suggested hidradenocarcinoma. Immunohistochemical staining was positive for cytokeratin 7, EMA, and p63. Panendoscopy found no pharynx, nasal cavity, or larynx abnormalities. CT of head and neck showed enlarged right-sided lymph nodes and a cystic mass on the scalp. CT scans of chest and abdomen were negative for metastasis. Histopathology confirmed malignant hidradenocarcinoma on the scalp (4.2 x 3.5 x 2.2 cm), with a close deep margin of 0.1 cm.

A: Malignant hidradenocarcinoma with no distant metastasis. Local disease present in the neck and scalp.

P: Proceed with wide local excision of the scalp lesion and right-sided neck dissection. Regular follow-up appointments to monitor for recurrence and manage any new symptoms.

S: The patient reports experiencing swelling below the tongue and pain during meals.

O: Upon examination, a hard swelling was detected on the left submandibular gland duct. An occlusal radiograph confirmed radio-opacity medial to teeth 46 and 47, suggesting the presence of a sialolith, which led to the diagnosis of left submandibular salivary gland duct sialolithiasis. A minor procedure was performed to remove the stone, which was roughly oval and measured 10.4 mm. The duct was sutured at the level of the mucosa on the floor of the mouth.

A: Diagnosis of left submandibular salivary gland duct sialolithiasis confirmed by radiograph, with successful removal of the salivary gland stone.

P: A minor procedure was performed to remove the stone under local anesthesia, with a stay suture placed to prevent the stone from moving posteriorly. Post-procedure follow-up evaluations are to be scheduled to monitor for any postoperative complications. The patient is advised to contact the office in case of discomfort or issues before the follow-up.

S: Angela reports a history of recurrent kidney stones, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes. She experienced kidney stone pain but believes the stone passed three days ago. She no longer has pain or blood in her urine. Her past medical history includes episodes of kidney stones (7-8 occurrences) and treatment with pain medication (Percocet) during a recent ER visit. Angela has been taking Norvasc for hypertension and reports good blood pressure at home despite a reading of 150/90 today. Her diet includes frequent fast food consumption which she finds challenging to control. Angela takes Metformin for diabetes and her last HbA1c was 6.7. She also experiences occasional insomnia and uses meditation apps but prefers not to take sleep medication.

O: Blood pressure reading today is 150/90. Physical exam shows clear lungs, a grade two out of six systolic ejection murmur, and no tenderness in the abdomen or CVA upon palpation. Previously recorded HbA1c is 6.7.

A: Angela appears to have passed her most recent kidney stone, but recurrent stones are a concern. Her hypertension is controlled at home with Norvasc but is slightly elevated today. Her type 2 diabetes is managed with Metformin, although diet remains a concern. Insomnia is likely contributing to overall stress but seems manageable with non-pharmacological strategies.

P: Recommend urinalysis and urine culture to ensure all kidney stones have passed and to check for infections. Referral to urology for recurrent stones. Continue current dose of Norvasc and monitor blood pressure; no refill needed. Consult with nutritionist for dietary control to help manage diabetes and hypertension. Continue 500 mg Metformin daily, advise regular blood sugar monitoring before meals. For insomnia, suggest practicing proper sleep hygiene and using melatonin 10 mg as needed. Follow-up appointment scheduled in three months.

S: The patient reports experiencing shortness of breath for about a month, which worsened and led to hospitalization 57 days ago. They were treated for pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) but continue to experience dyspnea on exertion (DOE) two weeks after completing treatment. The patient has a confirmed HIV-1 infection.

O: Initial blood tests showed a CD4 count of 45/μL (7.3%) and HIV-RNA loads of 56,000 copies/mL. A bronchoscopy identified Pneumocystis jirovecii in the bronchoalveolar lavage fluid, with serum β-D glucan levels over 300 pg/mL. Physical examination revealed "Velcro rales" in the bilateral lower back, with normal oxygen levels at rest (93.5 mmHg) but a rapid decrease to 44.5 mmHg during exertion. Respiratory function tests showed severe restrictive ventilatory impairment, with vital capacity at 36.5% and FEV1 at 107.4%. A CT scan revealed severe fibrotic changes in the bilateral basal parts of the lungs.

A: The patient is diagnosed with HIV-related pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP), residual pulmonary fibrosis with restrictive ventilatory impairment, and persistent dyspnea on exertion likely due to fibrotic changes post-PCP treatment.

P: Continue to monitor the patient's pulmonary condition and adjust treatment as needed. Further evaluation of ongoing dyspnea on exertion and management of restrictive lung impairment will be necessary. Establish a follow-up plan to reassess pulmonary function and consider additional interventions to address the underlying fibrosis and HIV management.

S: The patient reports experiencing left hemiparesis and dysarthria for approximately 5 hours. The patient has a medical history of hypertension.

O: The NIHSS score is 3, indicating a minor stroke. The PCT scan results show a perfusion delay in the right MCA territory with severe stenosis in the superior portion of the right minor branch and moderate stenosis in the right main branch. The average right and left cerebral rSO2 values are 69.01% and 71.28%, respectively.

A: The clinical presentation and diagnostic tests suggest a minor stroke due to significant narrowing of the blood vessels in the brain, specifically in the right MCA territory.

P: The patient will be treated with EVT (Endovascular Therapy) to restore blood flow in the affected area. The patient is advised to continue managing hypertension and follow up with their primary care physician. Monitoring of progress and adjustment of treatment as needed will be undertaken. The patient is instructed to report any new or worsening symptoms.

S: The patient reports a progressively growing mass in the back region with multiple unsuccessful drainage attempts for a suspected abscess. They have a history of non-oncological surgical resection with a pathology report indicating high-grade sarcoma with positive margins. The patient also reports bilateral vision loss for the past month, indicating they can barely see anything now. They experienced disorientation and poor communication in a prior clinical exam but feel slightly better now, though still somewhat disoriented.

O: Clinical examination revealed a hyperpigmented tumor measuring 10 x 8 cm in the back and a scarred postsurgical lesion without inflammatory signs. A biopsy confirmed high-grade sarcoma compatible with myxofibrosarcoma. An ophthalmological examination suggested probable bilateral retinal detachment. An abdominal CT scan showed diffuse density alteration of the subcutaneous tissue likely due to edema, while a chest CT scan with contrast revealed an undefined heterogeneous mass dependent on the posterior thorax wall with muscular infiltration. Inpatient care indicated substantial clinical worsening, progressive deterioration of consciousness, and persistent oral cavity bleeding. Lab tests showed prolongation of certain values.

A: The patient has high-grade sarcoma with significant tumor extension and probable bilateral retinal detachment. Given the tumor's extent and inadequate response to chemotherapy, along with a poor Zubrod performance score, they are not candidates for chemotherapy, surgical, or radiation treatments. Clinical worsening suggests a critical deterioration in their condition.

P: The main focus is on symptom management and ensuring the best possible quality of life. The care plan includes close monitoring of the patient’s condition and providing necessary support.

S: The patient reported the onset of a febrile erythematous rash approximately three weeks prior. About a week before admission, the patient experienced fever, fatigue, vomiting, and non-bloody diarrhea. The patient has no family history of kidney or hematological disorders.

O: On examination, the patient appeared pale with bruises on the abdomen, back, and lower extremities. Laboratory tests revealed hemolytic anemia with marked reticulocytosis, presence of schistocytes, profound thrombocytopenia, elevated uric acid, while serum creatinine was normal. Plasma haptoglobin was undetectable, LDH was elevated, and the direct Coombs test was negative. Anti-streptolysin titers were marginally elevated. D-dimers were increased to 2.49 μg/mL, sC5b-9 was increased to 653 ng/mL. Prothrombin, INR, partial thromboplastin time, fibrinogen, and C3 and C4 were normal. Urinalysis showed microscopic erythrocyturia and mild proteinuria. Despite transfusions, hemoglobin fell to 48 g/L and platelet count dropped to 5 × 10^9/L within 2 days.

A: The patient's clinical presentation and laboratory findings led to a tentative diagnosis of atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome (aHUS).

P: The patient was treated with a single dose of eculizumab and received vaccinations as a precautionary measure. The patient's condition will be closely monitored, and the treatment plan will be adjusted as necessary. Follow-up with the healthcare team is essential to ensure the best possible outcomes.

S: The patient was diagnosed with Takayasu's arteritis (TA) at age 19 and has been on steroid therapy for many years. They have experienced a gradual decline in renal function leading to renovascular hypertension. Symptoms related to this decline include fatigue and vomiting. They began peritoneal dialysis (PD) at age 61 due to inappropriate conditions for hemodialysis, such as severe aortic regurgitation and peripheral arteriosteogenesis. After seven and a half years on PD, with one episode of peritonitis and gradual decline in residual renal function, the patient received a living-related kidney transplant from their husband. The transplant was ABO incompatible with six HLA mismatches and positive donor-specific antibodies (DSA) against HLA-DQ4. Post-transplant, the patient reports feeling better overall but still experiences some fatigue.

O: Gradual decline in renal function with renovascular hypertension as a complication of TA. One episode of peritonitis during more than five years on PD. Increased C-reactive protein (CRP) levels. Post-transplant, severe arterial calcifications noted with a positive DSA against HLA-DQ4 (mean fluorescence intensity of 3683).

A: The patient is experiencing fatigue potentially due to malnutrition, inflammation, and atherosclerosis (MIA) syndrome from inadequate renal replacement therapy, resulting in the accumulation of uremic solutes. Post-transplant recovery appears positive, but fatigue persists, requiring monitoring.

P: Continue monitoring the patient’s progress and adjust treatment as needed. Consider transition strategies from peritoneal dialysis to a combination therapy or hemodialysis if necessary to improve clinical outcomes. Emphasize regular follow-up with the healthcare team and encourage the patient to report any changes in condition or concerns.

S: The patient reported severe right lower abdominal pain and frequent vomiting. There is no history of abdominal surgery or trauma.

O: On physical examination, the patient exhibited deep tenderness at McBurney's point without abdominal distension. A blood test showed slight leukocytosis (9840/μl) with no elevation of C-reactive protein (0.01 mg/dl). An enhanced CT scan revealed a slightly enhanced, thickened appendiceal wall, a slightly dilated ileum, and ascites at the recto-vesical pouch, without signs of intestinal obstruction. Laparoscopic surgery revealed strangulated small bowel obstruction due to trapped ileal loops by a band between the right medial umbilical fold and the ileal mesentery. No ischemic changes were detected in the trapped ileum. The appendix showed slight inflammatory changes.

A: The initial diagnosis was mild acute appendicitis. However, laparoscopic findings confirmed strangulated small bowel obstruction due to an adhesion band, along with slight inflammatory changes in the appendix.

P: The band was resected using laparoscopic coagulation shears, and an appendectomy was performed. The patient will be closely monitored during recovery, with management focusing on pain and symptom control. The patient is advised to communicate any discomfort or concerns.

S: The patient, a 38-year-old woman at 12 weeks of gestational age, gravida 4, para 2, was diagnosed with a missed abortion. An ultrasound indicated a single nonviable fetus with a crown-rump length corresponding to 7 weeks. She initially opted for expectant management but developed mild vaginal bleeding and mild lower abdominal pain after two weeks. She has a history of two Cesarean deliveries, the last one six years ago, and other surgeries including an appendectomy and a partial gastrectomy.

O: Examination revealed stable vital signs and a closed cervical os during the initial per vaginal examination. After treatment with misoprostol, the patient developed severe bleeding with blood clots, and a PV examination showed the os was tip-of-finger. A speculum examination revealed no cervical laceration. Bedside ultrasound showed a bulky uterus with retained products of conception and the cavity filled with blood clots. Laparotomy revealed an intact uterus with a diagnosis of placenta accreta, where the placenta was invading the old Cesarean scar.

A: The diagnostic impression is placenta accreta with retained products of conception following a missed abortion. The severe bleeding post-medication indicates complications associated with the placenta accreta.

P: The patient underwent a successful unilateral ligation of the uterine and ovarian arteries and local resection of the affected uterine wall. The uterine wall defect was repaired. Follow-up care includes regular check-ups to monitor recovery and observation for potential complications related to placenta accreta and uterine scarring. The patient is advised to contact healthcare providers if unusual symptoms occur.

S: The patient reports a history of diabetes, hypertension, and dyslipidemia. The chief complaint is a sudden loss of vision in the left eye since the previous night, accompanied by sharp pain rated as 5 out of 10, which has since resolved. There is no history of trauma, contact lens use, eye surgery, or glaucoma. The patient denies other symptoms such as fever, headache, eye discharge, ear pain, nasal congestion, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, paresthesias, or focal weakness.

O: Examination reveals normal extraocular motility and equal, round, reactive pupils bilaterally. Visual field testing shows decreased vision in the nasal visual field of the left eye with a visual acuity of 20/50, while the right eye has normal visual fields with a visual acuity of 20/20. Intraocular pressure is 19 mmHg in the left eye and 23 mmHg in the right eye. Fundoscopic examination shows a black spot at 5 o'clock in the left eye. Ultrasound of the left eye shows a hyperechoic smooth folded membrane within the vitreous, consistent with a retinal detachment.

A: Retinal detachment in the left eye.

P: Discuss treatment options and follow-up requirements to help preserve vision in the affected eye. Immediate referral to an ophthalmologist or retinal specialist is implied to evaluate further management including possible surgical intervention.

S: The patient reports experiencing vague colicky epigastric pain for approximately two years, with fluctuations in severity. The pain became more severe and constant about four months ago. There is no relationship between the pain and food intake. Initially, anti-acids provided relief, but they are no longer effective. Accompanying symptoms include occasional fever with chills, constipation, malaise, and a weight loss of 10 kg in the last two months. The patient also reports an increased appetite. Medical history includes a cholecystectomy. The patient is a trucker, exposed to potentially unsafe food and water, and is a cigarette smoker.

O: During physical examination, the patient is afebrile, moderately ill, with stable vital signs and normal sclera without icterus. No rash, excoriation, conjunctivitis, lymphadenopathy, gynecomastia, or abdominal distention were observed. Cardiovascular and lung examinations were normal. There was tenderness in the right upper quadrant during abdominal palpation.

A: Differential diagnoses may include gastrointestinal disorders such as peptic ulcer disease, gastritis, or other abdominal pathology, given the history of epigastric pain and tenderness in the right upper quadrant. The history of significant weight loss, constipation, and changes in appetite, along with occasional fever and chills, may suggest an underlying chronic condition needing further evaluation.

P: Further diagnostic tests are needed to determine the cause of the symptoms. The patient should undergo laboratory tests and possibly imaging studies to assess the gastrointestinal tract and related organs. Once the diagnosis is clear, suitable treatment options will be discussed. A follow-up appointment should be scheduled to review test results and plan treatment. Lifestyle modifications and smoking cessation should be recommended to the patient.

S: The patient reports sudden left leg pain and swelling, with a recent fever of 38°C. They have no history of chronic diseases, autoimmune, or auto-inflammatory disorders in the family. The patient had a foot fracture at age 8.

O: Physical examination shows the left leg is swollen and painful with reduced hip range of motion. Bumps on the right tibia are observed, but no arthritis, intestinal inflammation, or skin changes are noted. Blood pressure and urinary output are normal. An ultrasound reveals femoral and pelvic deep vein thrombosis. Investigations indicate high inflammatory markers, severe microcytic anemia, thrombocytosis, hypoalbuminemia, elevated fibrinogen, and D-dimer. Urinalysis shows haematuria and proteinuria; cultures are sterile. X-rays show hyperostosis, sclerosis, and periosteal reaction in the right tibia. An abdominal ultrasound finds a giant pelvic mass and hydronephrosis of the left kidney. Creatinine is 185 μmol/L with urinary protein excretion of 7g/24 hours.

A: The patient presents with deep vein thrombosis, possible acute osteomyelitis (due to the leg findings), and potential bone oncological processes. There is also significant concern for a pelvic mass contributing to hydronephrosis and deteriorating kidney function.

P: The plan includes hospital admission for further treatment and evaluation of thrombosis and inflammation, initial broad-spectrum antibiotics for possible acute osteomyelitis, and monitoring of kidney function. Further investigations will focus on the pelvic mass and its impact on the kidney, while exploring appropriate treatments for the thrombosis, inflammation, and renal issues.

S: The patient is a 65-year-old female non-smoker of Indian origin living in the UK for 42 years. She reports experiencing mild arthralgia in her shoulders, hands, and elbows for about 5 years, a productive cough for the past 6 months, and weight loss. She has not noticed any blood in her cough and denies fever, night sweats, chest pain, or shortness of breath on exertion.

O: Physical examination reveals nodal osteoarthritis in the hands with evidence of Heberden's and Bouchard's nodes, but no active synovitis. The chest, cardiovascular system, and abdominal examination are unremarkable.

A: The patient likely has nodal osteoarthritis, contributing to mild arthralgia, particularly in her hands. The absence of active synovitis suggests no current joint inflammation.

P: The patient is advised to monitor symptoms, maintain a healthy lifestyle, and attend regular check-ups. She should report any new symptoms, ensuring ongoing management of her condition.

S: The patient, Sarah Smith, reports feeling short of breath while sitting and watching TV for the past hour. She also mentions a cough starting yesterday. She recently had a C-section four weeks ago and has been taking Codeine for pain management, which she has not used for a week. The patient is allergic to Ibuprofen but does not specify the reaction.
