She feels her heart racing and experiences soreness in the chest, particularly around the C-section scar. There are no other reported medical issues, and her infant is in good health.

O: The patient's heart rate is slightly elevated, as she counts 30 beats in the duration specified by the doctor, indicating a fast heart rate likely due to stress and pain.

A: The clinician considers the recent C-section and symptoms, entertaining the possibility of a clot (such as a pulmonary embolism) given the risk factors associated with recent surgery and immobility.

P: The doctor advises the patient to go to the hospital promptly for further evaluation due to the risk of clots. Sarah is instructed not to take Codeine for the time being and to prepare accordingly with necessities for her baby. No immediate use of an ambulance is deemed necessary; Sarah will take herself to the hospital.

S: The patient has a painless swelling in the mouth, present for about 2 years. The swelling has been interfering with dental occlusion.

O: The lesion is approximately 1.5 cm, primarily soft on palpation. Surgery was performed with a 2 cm incision inferior and parallel to the Stensen's duct. The lesion was capsulated and composed of adipose tissue with a thin capsule, diagnosed pathologically as an intraoral fibrolipoma. There were no complications during or after the surgery.

A: The patient has an intraoral fibrolipoma, which is a benign tumor. No signs of recurrence after 12 months post-surgery.

P: The lesion was excised surgically, and the tissue was sent for laboratory examination. Post-operative monitoring will continue, with no current concerns about the condition. The patient is advised to reach out if any issues or questions arise.

S: The patient, a 55-year-old entrepreneur, reports having pain in the middle of his left thigh for about 6 days, with a sudden increase in pain and swelling on the day of the visit. He has a significant smoking history of 37 pack years but no other health issues.

O: The patient appears slightly pale, with a heart rate of 120 bpm and blood pressure of 100 x 70 mmHg. Physical examination shows normal findings in the head, neck, thorax, abdomen, and right lower limb, with all pulses present. In the left lower limb, there is ecchymosis and pulsatile swelling in the anteromedial thigh, signs of distal microembolization in the left foot, and absent popliteal and distal pulses. Ultrasonography of the left thigh reveals an aneurysmal dilatation of the SFA measuring 5.8 x 5.3 cm, with thrombi and perivascular accumulations, consistent with a ruptured aneurysm.

A: The clinical impression is a ruptured aneurysm of the superficial femoral artery (SFA) in the left thigh, resulting in compromised blood flow to the distal limb and associated complications.

P: Emergency surgical treatment is recommended to address the ruptured aneurysm. The procedure involves removing the hematoma, addressing the ruptured SFA aneurysm with proximal and distal ligatures, resecting the aneurysm, and performing revascularization using the contralateral great saphenous vein in reverse. Samples will be collected for anatomopathological and microbiological analyses. Pre-operative preparations should be followed as instructed by the medical staff. There are no signs of active infection.

S: The patient reports having sharp, severe abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant for the past two months, initially intermittent but worsening over time. The pain sometimes radiates to the right shoulder and is accompanied by nausea. Pain is not associated with specific movements or meals. Over-the-counter analgesics provide moderate relief. The patient has a history of laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (LRYGB) 9 years ago due to morbid obesity and was diagnosed with obstructive sleep apnea 10 years ago. There are no other significant medical issues noted. The family history includes diabetes mellitus and hypertension. The patient has experienced weight fluctuations, with a current BMI of 23.9 Kg/m².

O: Physical examination revealed the patient is afebrile with normal vital signs. There is moderate tenderness over the epigastrium, central abdomen, and right hypochondrium, along with a positive Murphy’s sign. Complete blood count, urine analysis, and liver and renal function tests were within normal limits.

A: The clinical presentation and positive Murphy's sign suggest the possibility of gallbladder-related issues, such as cholecystitis or biliary colic, considering the patient's surgical history and symptomatology.

P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition. Further diagnostic imaging, such as an abdominal ultrasound, may be warranted to evaluate the gallbladder and surrounding structures. Consider consultation with a gastroenterologist or surgeon for potential further management of the abdominal pain related to the previous surgical history.

S: The patient is following up regarding breast carcinoma and a newly discovered tumor in the right tibia. The patient reports feeling okay overall and has not experienced any symptoms or pain from the tibia tumor.

O: A whole-body CT and bone scintigraphy screen were conducted. A tumor was found in the entire right tibia, confirmed by a plain X-ray and MRI. The intraosseal tumor extended from 4 cm below the knee joint to about 4 cm from the ankle joint. A biopsy confirmed adamantinoma histology. Reconstruction was performed with a custom-made tibia EPR, involving a modular endoprosthesis with knee and ankle joint reconstruction, soft tissue attachment, and musculocutaneous flap coverage.

A: The patient had an adamantinoma in the right tibia. Post-surgical reconstruction was undertaken using a custom-made endoprosthetic replacement system. The patient's condition post-reconstruction is stable with no subjective symptoms reported.

P: The patient should follow up regularly to monitor healing and ensure no complications arise from the surgery. The patient is advised to contact the medical team if any unusual symptoms or concerns occur.

S: The patient has been diagnosed with B-ALL, characterized as Ph+. They expressed concerns about the diagnosis and treatment implications. The patient has achieved complete remission after 29 days of therapy induction. However, minimal residual disease (MRD) was detected through a sensitive procedure. A mutation in the ABL1 domain was identified in follow-up, suggesting acquired resistance to dasatinib.

O: Cytogenetics via FISH test showed 70% positive results for Ph+. MRD was detected using a procedure established by van Dongen et al. Molecular analysis revealed expression of P190BCR-ABL1. Mutational analysis via Sanger sequencing identified a point mutation in the ABL1 domain, c.1319A.G, which was present in 20% of the BCR-ABL1-expressing cells at follow-up but not at initial diagnosis.

A: The patient is in complete remission from Ph+ B-ALL but has detectable MRD, indicating a need for further treatment. The presence of a point mutation suggests acquired resistance to dasatinib.

P: The recommended plan involves a proposal for an allogeneic bone marrow transplant from an HLA-matched sibling. Further analysis of bone marrow samples for mutations associated with TKI resistance is planned. The medical team will continue monitoring and guiding the patient through the process to manage BCR-ABL1 expression reduction before transplant.

S: The patient is a 32-year-old woman, gravida three para one, with a history of cervical incompetence, polycystic ovarian syndrome, antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APLS), and tubal factor infertility. She conceived with a frozen embryo transfer in April 2016. She has a history of two mid-trimester losses and type two diabetes mellitus. During the pregnancy, she was advised to use condoms or refrain from intercourse due to her husband's travel to Haiti during the Zika epidemic. She did not have symptoms of Zika, nor did her husband, and she had not traveled out of the Boston area.

O: The patient had an abdominal cerclage placed pre-pregnancy and received prophylactic low molecular weight heparin for APLS and insulin for diabetes. She was treated with betamethasone for threatened preterm labor. Her blood glucose was euglycemic at delivery. A level II fetal survey at 18 weeks showed normal intracranial anatomy and head circumference. No local transmission of Zika occurred in Massachusetts.

A: The patient's high-risk pregnancy due to multiple morbidities, including APLS, cervical incompetence, and type two diabetes mellitus. History of two mid-trimester losses. There was potential concern for Zika exposure, but no symptoms were reported by either partner.

P: Continue to monitor the patient's health closely post-pregnancy. Encourage the patient to report any new health concerns. No further Zika testing recommended due to lack of symptoms. Follow-up care and guidance for postpartum health.

S: The patient has been experiencing symptoms of shortness of breath and occasional chest pain. They have documented MZ status with an AAT level of 64 mg/dL and have undergone targeted familial genotyping, identifying a single Z allele. The patient's father had ZZ-AATD disease. The patient found a consultation about the health and reproductive risks as an MZ heterozygote to be informative. They were informed about higher health and reproductive risks associated with SZ results from their NGS test. The patient's mother carries an S allele, indicating increased risk for maternal half-siblings.

O: No objective findings or physical examination results were provided. The AAT level is documented as 64 mg/dL.

A: The patient has MZ alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, with consideration of higher risk given the SZ results. Shortness of breath and chest pain may be associated with their AATD status.

P: The plan involves monitoring the patient's condition, advising on symptom vigilance, and discussing the genetic findings with family members, encouraging them to seek medical advice if needed. Consideration of augmentation therapy in the future if symptoms worsen, although atypical for MZ heterozygotes. Follow-up for any changes in symptoms and providing ongoing support as needed.

S: The patient reports experiencing blurred vision for the past 2 weeks. The onset of symptoms coincided with a suicide attempt involving the ingestion of 15 tablets of pregabalin (Lyrica), resulting in unconsciousness and seizures. During this medical event, the patient was treated in an emergency department and intensive care unit. The patient reports blurred vision developing around day 3 of the hospital stay.

O: In the emergency department, the patient's vital signs were recorded as blood pressure 100/60 mmHg, heart rate 165/minute, respiration rate 34/minute, and body temperature 36.8 °C. Initial lab tests showed severe metabolic acidosis with pH 6.79, PaO2 45 mmHg, PaCO2 55 mmHg, HCO3 7.9 mmol/L, and BE -33.6 mmol/L. Post-treatment with intravenous hydration, NaHCO3, and midazolam, the arterial blood gas analysis improved significantly. Ophthalmology findings reported bilateral serous exudative macular detachment, with best corrected visual acuity of 20/40 in the right eye and 20/50 in the left eye. Anterior segment examination and intraocular pressure were normal.

A: The patient is experiencing blurred vision, likely stemming from bilateral serous exudative macular detachment, possibly related to earlier metabolic disturbances or medication overdose.

P: Continue monitoring visual symptoms and conduct further ophthalmologic evaluations to determine appropriate treatment for the macular condition. The patient should report any changes in vision. Follow-up with the ophthalmology department is recommended for further management and treatment planning.

S: The owner reports a 3-year-old intact female red corn snake has a swelling in the middle of her body and has not been eating for the past three weeks. The snake has been healthy previously. The owner feeds her a frozen-thawed adult mouse once a week. Her defecation habits have changed, with stools becoming smaller, drier, and less frequent over the past three to four weeks. Her activity level and behavior remain normal.

O: Physical examination shows the snake is quiet, alert, and responsive, with a good body condition. A soft 6 × 4 cm ventral swelling at the midbody is observed, causing discomfort when manipulated. Ultrasonography reveals a cylindrical structure lateral to the caudal liver near the stomach with a markedly and focally fluid-dilated stomach segment.

A: The diagnostic impression suggests a possible blockage or gastrointestinal tract issue, as indicated by the stomach's fluid dilation.

P: Additional diagnostic tests will be scheduled to determine the exact cause and appropriate treatment for the condition. The owner is advised to monitor the temperature and humidity of the enclosure and report any changes in behavior or condition. Further results will be discussed once available.

S: The patient reports hitting their head in a fall from a height of 4 meters but does not feel too bad currently. The patient has severe dementia and cannot recall any obvious neurological symptoms following the fall.

O: A CT scan of the cervical spine revealed a left nondisplaced impaction OCF with an occipital condyle-C1 interval of 2.5 mm and a 5 mm translation of C1-C2. The fracture pattern was classified as Anderson and Montesano type 1 and Tuli type 1 and considered stable. There was craniocervical misalignment and C1-C2 translation present. A halo device was used temporarily before surgery, and after performing a reduction, a CT scan confirmed complete reduction of the atlantooccipital and atlantoaxial joints. Surgery included internal segmental fixation using an occipital bone plate, bilateral pedicle screws for C2, and an autologous iliac crest bone graft in augmented posterior fusion. The halo vest was removed post-surgery, and the patient’s clinical status has improved.

A: The patient appears to have experienced a stable cervical spine fracture with associated craniocervical and atlantoaxial joint misalignment, successfully treated with reduction and surgical fixation.

P: The patient is being discharged and transferred to a rehabilitation facility for further recovery following surgery and clinical improvement.

S: The patient reports experiencing paroxysmal palpitations, described as the heart suddenly racing and pounding hard. There is a family history of cardiac conditions, notably type-A WPW syndrome in the patient's father, who underwent successful catheter ablation for a left lateral accessory pathway. The patient has undergone surgery for frontonasal dysplasia and shares a genetic mutation in exon 3 of the EFNB1 gene with her sister and father, who have confirmed CFNS.

O: The 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) showed a short PR interval, Delta waves, and widened QRS complexes. Transthoracic echocardiography was normal.

A: The patient has been diagnosed with type-A WPW syndrome.

P: The patient will be referred to the electrophysiology department for an electrophysiological study and transcatheter ablation of the accessory pathway. An appointment with the electrophysiology department will be scheduled to discuss the procedure details and find a suitable date. A referral will be provided to assist with making the necessary arrangements.

S: The patient is a 15-year-old Han Chinese boy presenting with fever, weakness, pallor, edema, dyspnea, and increasing abdominal girth for the past two weeks. He reports feeling weak, tired, and having trouble breathing. He has a history of splenectomy at age 9 due to unexplained splenomegaly and multiple prolonged hospital admissions for fever of unknown origin. His birth history includes a full-term normal delivery with no significant medical history and parents without consanguinity.

O: On examination, the patient appeared unwell with a height of 135 cm and weight of 30 kg, lacking secondary sexual characteristics. He had a fluctuating fever from 37.2 to 39.7 °C, pallor, and inguinal lymphadenopathy. Eyelid edema without cyanosis was present, and the pharynx was normal. There were audible harsh breath sounds and bilateral crackles. Heart rate was 114/min with normal rhythm, no murmurs. Abdominal examination revealed distension, hepatomegaly with the liver palpable 10 cm below the costal margin, and a large scar on the left upper quadrant. Murphy sign was negative, but shifting dullness was positive, and there was marked pitting edema in the lower extremities. Neurological and other systemic examinations were normal.

A: The clinical presentation suggests a possible hematologic or hepatic condition post-splenectomy, with symptoms of hepatomegaly, edema, and respiratory involvement. The differential diagnosis may include hematological disorders, liver pathology, or heart failure, pending further diagnostic workup.

P: Continue analyzing lab tests and imaging to identify the underlying cause. Monitor symptoms and provide supportive care. Encourage follow-up and immediate reporting of any new or worsening symptoms. Further diagnostic tests and specialist referrals may be considered based on ongoing assessments.

S:  
The patient, with a past medical history of coronary artery disease, heart failure, atrial fibrillation, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and type-2 diabetes mellitus, was admitted after a seizure. The patient was found to be hypoglycemic with a blood glucose level of 21 mg/dL at the nursing facility. The patient received 25 g of dextrose 50% (D50), which improved mental status before being transferred to the emergency department. The patient's medication list includes aspirin, atorvastatin, glipizide, losartan, mometasone, spironolactone, torsemide, warfarin, and recently prescribed levofloxacin for pneumonia after a prior hospitalization.

O:  
Upon admission to the ED, the patient was minimally responsive. Laboratory results showed hypokalemia (potassium level 2.9 mmol/L), acute kidney injury (serum creatinine 2.52 mg/dL), and hypoglycemia (blood glucose 34 mg/dL). Liver function tests were normal. The patient received 50 g of D50, raising blood glucose to 134 mg/dL. In the ICU, the patient required additional four boluses of D50 and a continuous D10 infusion to maintain blood glucose levels.

A:  
The patient is experiencing hypoglycemia potentially due to the medication regimen, specifically glipizide, in the context of recent levofloxacin use. Differential diagnoses include medication interaction leading to hypoglycemia and acute kidney injury.

P:  
Monitor blood glucose levels closely in the ICU. Consider adjusting diabetic medications, particularly glipizide, to prevent further hypoglycemic episodes. Maintain D10 infusion as needed to ensure euglycemia. Reassess renal function and electrolyte levels, providing supplementation for hypokalemia. Adjust or review current medications as necessary to avoid further complications. Provide supportive care and regular assessment during ICU stay.

S: The patient reports a discharging wound on the upper abdomen for about a month. This issue began after an emergency exploratory laparotomy six months ago due to abdominal pain. The laparotomy revealed a peptic perforation, which was repaired. Post-surgery, the patient developed a burst abdomen, managed conservatively, with subsequent oral nutrition. Though initially managing well post-surgery, an ulcer with serous discharge emerged in the fourth month after a split thickness skin graft. The discharge output is small, managed with gauze that needs changing one to three times daily.

O: Examination reveals a 12 cm × 5 cm elliptical skin graft on the abdomen with a 1 cm × 1 cm ulcer showing serous oozing and pale granulation. The rest of the graft has pale granulation spots. There's also a scar at a previous drain site and a deficient abdominal wall. Blood work shows hemoglobin at 11.4 gm/dl, WBC count at 11.6 × 10³/mm³, serum protein at 7.9 gm/dl, and albumin at 3.5 gm/dl. Ultrasound indicates a left subphrenic collection of 8 cm × 7 cm.

A: The patient is experiencing a persistent abdominal wound with serous discharge post-exploratory laparotomy and skin graft, potentially linked to a left subphrenic collection or missed pathology from previous surgery.

P: Plan includes consulting with a specialist for further evaluation and management, maintaining wound cleanliness with gauze changes as needed, and close monitoring of blood and ultrasound results. Follow-up for any changes in the patient's condition is advised.

S: The patient reports sudden onset intense right upper quadrant pain that began as colicky sharp stabbing pain and progressed to a constant dull discomfort, exacerbated by coughing or deep breathing. The patient has also experienced a productive cough with yellow sputum for about a week. Past medical history includes undifferentiated immunodeficiency, idiopathic thrombocytopaenia (ITP) with splenectomy, possible previous stroke, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, recurrent lower limb cellulitis, and respiratory tract infections. The patient is on warfarin. 

O: The patient's weight is 152 kg with a BMI of 45. Right upper quadrant tenderness is present on palpation. Blood tests show a platelet count of 232 × 10^9 l−1, mildly elevated white cell count of 13.8 × 10^9 l−1, C-reactive protein of 12.7 mg l−1, normal liver function tests, elevated INR at 3.8, and elevated lactate at 2.7 mmol l−1. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis revealed a well-defined ovoid adrenal lesion and patchy consolidation in the right lower lobe, with no evidence of cholecystitis.

A: The findings are suggestive of a lower respiratory tract infection, possibly pneumonia with pleurisy, rather than cholecystitis. The presence of an indeterminate adrenal lesion was also noted but is not currently symptomatic.

P: Start intravenous antibiotics for lower respiratory tract infection. Monitor the patient's response to antibiotics and evaluate whether further treatment is needed for the adrenal lesion. Continue monitoring INR due to elevated levels and adjust warfarin dosage as necessary to avoid potential bleeding risks.

S: The patient reports experiencing upper abdominal pain, primarily located in the left upper quadrant. The area is tender upon touch. The patient has a past medical history of appendicitis at the age of 20 but no other significant medical history.

O: Physical examination showed left hypochondriac pain and tenderness in the upper abdomen. Laboratory tests revealed elevated inflammatory markers, with a white blood cell count of 13,400/μL and C-reactive protein at 11.58 mg/dL. Elevated biliary enzymes were noted: lactate dehydrogenase at 250 U/L, alkaline phosphatase at 535 U/L, and γ-glutamyltranspeptidase at 76 U/L. Tumor markers are elevated with carcinoembryonic antigen at 9.4 U/mL and cancer antigen 19-9 at 550 U/mL, but pancreatic tumor markers are not elevated. Imaging via CT and MRI showed a markedly dilated main pancreatic duct (55 mm), pancreatic parenchyma atrophy, and gastropancreatic and splenopancreatic fistulas. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy identified four gastropancreatic fistulas on the posterior wall of the gastric body with mucus discharge; cytology of the mucus did not show malignancy.

A: Pre-operative diagnosis of Intraductal Papillary Mucinous Neoplasm (IPMN) of main ductal type penetrating into the stomach and spleen.

P: Surgery has been planned for treatment. No further details on immediate pre-operative or post-operative care provided.

S: The patient reports having a painless mass in the right calf for the last two years, first discovered accidentally. Initially, a doctor identified it as a lipoma, and no treatment was received then. The patient noted the mass has gradually increased in size over the last few months. The patient has a medical history of hypertension, which is controlled with antihypertensive drugs, and surgical history includes a laparoscopic cholecystectomy 10 years ago and a hysterectomy for a large uterine fibroid 5 years ago.

O: No information provided.

A: The doctor considers further examination and testing necessary to determine the nature of the calf mass and to decide the appropriate course of action, given its recent growth in size.

P: The doctor plans to perform further examination and tests to evaluate the mass's cause. The patient is instructed to follow up after tests to discuss results and treatment. The patient is also advised to contact the doctor if there is any pain or discomfort in the meantime.

S:  
The patient has a history of breast cancer diagnosed at age 68, treated with lumpectomy, radiotherapy, and chemotherapy. During a yearly follow-up, a right adnexal mass was identified, but the patient reported no pain or discomfort in the area.

O:  
A physical examination revealed a palpable mass in the right hypogastric area without tenderness. Tumor markers were within normal limits except for mild elevation in serum CEA (5.3 ng/ml) and CA 15-3 (31.4 U/ml). An abdominal ultrasound showed a hypoechoic formation (80.0 x 36.6 mm) below the uterus. An intravaginal ultrasound found a mixed texture mass (8.7 cm) in the right ovary with solid and cystic parts. No free fluid was noted in the Douglas pouch. An abdominal MRI identified a cystic mass (9 cm) in the right iliac fossa, in contact with the right ovary, uterus, and intestines. During an exploratory laparotomy, an appendiceal mass was identified, leading to a formal appendectomy. The frozen section diagnosed cystadenoma, and the pathological examination revealed a low-grade mucinous neoplasm of the appendix. The postoperative course was uneventful.

A:  
The patient has a right adnexal mass diagnosed as a low-grade mucinous neoplasm of the appendix following an appendectomy. Previous breast cancer history is noted, but recent postoperative follow-ups show the patient is asymptomatic with no pathological imaging findings.

P:  
Continue regular check-ups and imaging tests for ongoing monitoring. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns. No additional treatment is required at the moment given the current asymptomatic status and absence of pathological findings.

S: 
The patient, who has a history of HIV diagnosed 5 years ago, presents with constipation and painful defecation for the past 4 weeks. He reports seeing streaks of blood on toilet paper after wiping. His HIV treatment regimen was recently changed to abacavir, lamivudine, and dolutegravir. The patient denies any significant weight loss, with his weight stable at 77.1 kg. He identifies as MSM and reports no unprotected sex in the last 3 months.

O: 
The patient's recent CD4 count is 304 cells/uL, and the HIV viral load is undetectable. Vital signs are within normal limits. The abdominal exam is soft, nontender, and non-distended with normoactive bowel sounds. Rectal exam is normal. Laboratory studies reveal hemoglobin at 14.1 g/dL, leukocyte count at 4.7 K cells/uL, and platelet count at 246 K cells/uL. Alkaline phosphatase was mildly elevated at 142 U/L. Tests for Salmonella, Shigella, Aeromona, Plesiomona, Campylobacter antigen, and Escherichia coli shigatoxins were negative, as were ova and parasites. Rectal swab for gonorrhea and chlamydia PCR was negative. Colonoscopy showed moderate inflammation, congestion, erythema, friability, and shallow ulcerations in the rectum only. Histopathology revealed increased lymphoplasmacytic and neutrophilic infiltrate, acute cryptitis, and focal crypt abscesses in the rectal mucosa.

A:
The findings suggest inflammation in the rectum, potentially attributing to the patient’s symptoms of constipation, painful defecation, and bleeding. The differential includes inflammatory conditions such as proctitis.

P:
The patient has been referred to Gastroenterology for an endoscopic evaluation. A colonoscopy was performed, and the gastroenterologist will discuss treatment options and follow-up care based on the findings of inflammation in the rectum.

S: The patient presented to the emergency department following the intentional ingestion of various objects, including paperclips, screws, batteries, razor blades, and more recently a clock battery, screws, and a colored pencil. The patient reports feeling anxious and having run out of their alprazolam prescription. The patient has a psychiatric history including major depressive disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, posttraumatic stress disorder, borderline personality disorder, and pica. They have more than twenty admissions for ingestion behaviors, often requiring endoscopic retrieval. These ingestion behaviors are sometimes used as coping mechanisms for past trauma, controlling impulses, or escaping difficult situations such as incarceration. The patient experiences symptoms of anxiety like restlessness, feeling tense, and difficulty with sleep but denies symptoms of depression, hallucinations, or paranoid thinking.

O: Abdominal radiograph confirmed the presence of multiple metallic objects in the stomach and small intestine. These were successfully removed endoscopically.

A: The patient demonstrates ingestion behaviors often related to underlying psychiatric conditions, including anxiety and impulse control difficulties. The ingestion is used as a coping mechanism rather than with the intent of self-harm.

P: The patient has been admitted to the adult inpatient psychiatric unit. The treatment plan includes restarting alprazolam at 2 mg three times daily, providing intensive therapy such as Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT) focusing on mindfulness, distress tolerance, emotion regulation, and stress management skills. Continued monitoring and finding effective treatments and coping strategies for anxiety and ingestion behaviors are planned.

S: The parent reported that their six-month-old male infant has had an enlarging head for the past three months. The infant has a significant past medical history of neonatal meningitis on the second day of life.

O: An MRI showed gross asymmetrical hydrocephalus with obstruction at the aqueduct, and no ependymal thickening. CSF cultures were initially sterile. After developing a fever, a blocked external ventricular drain (EVD) was discovered, and a repeat MRI showed dilatation of the left lateral ventricle and pneumocephalus. CSF samples showed infection and presence of Gram-positive budding yeast, with Candida parapsilosis isolated from culture.

A: The findings are indicative of complicated hydrocephalus and infection involving Candida parapsilosis, causing additional intracranial complications such as pneumocephalus and multiloculated abscess.

P: Initial management involved placing an EVD and administering vancomycin and meropenem. After infection was identified, fluconazole was started. Due to persistent infection, the EVD was replaced with an Ommaya reservoir and a ventricular catheter. Treatment continued with intraventricular vancomycin. The infection cleared, with CSF samples sterile after 13 days, and the infant became stable. Continued monitoring and antifungal therapy for three weeks were planned.

S: The patient reports experiencing a nonproductive cough, dyspnea at rest, dysuria, and urinary frequency for about a week. They were previously diagnosed with a urinary tract infection (UTI) and a viral upper respiratory tract infection by their primary care doctor and were on ciprofloxacin treatment without improvement.

O: Vitals show oxygen saturation at 90%, tachycardia, and a low-grade fever. Examination reveals significant bibasilar crackles, a holosystolic apical murmur, 2+ lower extremity edema, and punctuate macular lesions on feet suggestive of vascular emboli. Laboratory studies indicate leukocytosis with neutrophilia (14.7 bil/L and 11.3 bil/L, respectively) and acute kidney injury. The urinalysis shows bacteriuria and leukocytes. The chest X-ray is unremarkable. A transthoracic echocardiogram shows a mobile mass on the posterior leaflet of the mitral valve with an ejection fraction of 40%. Preliminary blood cultures reported gram-positive cocci in pairs and clusters. On day 5, a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) confirmed a 1.4 cm × 2.5 cm vegetation with severe mitral regurgitation and posterior leaflet perforation.

A: The patient presents with symptoms and findings indicative of infective endocarditis with heart failure. The identified pathogen in both blood and urine cultures is AU. The presence of a mobile mass on the mitral valve and severe mitral regurgitation suggests complications related to endocarditis.

P: The treatment plan includes a 6-week course of intravenous gentamicin and penicillin G for infective endocarditis and aggressive diuresis for acute heart failure. The patient was endotracheally intubated on day 8 due to acute decompensation. Continuous monitoring and treatment adjustments will be made as necessary. The patient's family has been informed and is providing support.

S: The patient reports experiencing discomfort and irregular bowel movements. These symptoms led to admission for further examination.

O: A contrast CT examination revealed wall thickness in the sigmoid colon. A colonoscopy was performed, detecting multiple polyps, including a 25 mm pedunculated polyp, which was endoscopically resected. Microscopic examination showed 10% conventional tubular adenocarcinoma cells with certain nuclear characteristics and other dysplastic cell types indicating invasion into the submucosa, classified as pT1b. Various staining tests provided positive and negative results for different tumor components, with significant differences noted in CEA and CD10 staining.

A: The diagnostic impression is a tumor with invasive characteristics, displaying dual components of tubular adenocarcinoma and clear cell features, indicating malignancy with submucosal invasion.

P: The plan includes discussing treatment options, closely monitoring the patient's condition, and recommending regular follow-up appointments to ensure effective management and monitoring of the patient's health status.

S: 
The patient is a 27-year-old female who presented with an abdominal lump persisting for nine months. She reports experiencing abdominal fullness after eating and has noted weight loss during this period. She expressed concern about her condition but felt relieved after learning the lesion was not cancerous.

O: 
The physical examination showed a large, non-tender, soft cystic swelling in the upper abdomen. Radiological investigations, including an ultrasonogram and CECT, revealed a large multiseptated cystic lesion adhered to the pancreas, causing a mass effect with dilation of the main pancreatic duct and portal vein thrombosis with portal cavernoma. FNAC showed straw-colored aspirate with mature lymphocytes without atypical cells. Cyst amylase and CEA levels were within normal range. Surgical exploration found a multiloculated cystic lesion with lymphatic fluid, which was decompressed and excised. Histopathological examination showed dilated lymphatic spaces with lymphatic follicles and fibrocollagenous tissue with chronic inflammation.

A: 
The diagnostic impression is a non-cancerous large multiseptated cystic lesion in the abdomen involving lymphatic structures. No malignancy was detected.

P: 
The patient underwent surgical decompression and excision of the lesion, with postoperative management of lymphatic discharge using an abdominal drain. The patient was discharged with the drain in place, which was later removed after two weeks as the output decreased. Follow-up appointments are necessary for ongoing monitoring of her condition. She is advised to report any changes in symptoms promptly.

S: The patient’s mother reports concerns about her child’s development, specifically that he sat unsupported after twelve months and walked independently at twenty-two months. At 2 years old, he can go upstairs with two-hand support and climb furniture, though his gait is sometimes ataxic. He doesn’t have any words yet but recently started using gestures and can understand one-step commands. He is easily excitable and tries to socialize with other children. The patient has experienced myoclonic seizures between 2 to 3 years of age and is on anti-epileptic medications, which have been somewhat helpful. He prefers pureed foods, has occasional choking episodes, a preference for specific textures, and is fascinated by water. Sleep is disrupted with frequent awakenings, which might be behavioral.

O: An Echocardiogram, abdominal ultrasonography, brain MRI, and genetic testing for Angelman syndrome have all returned normal results. At 2 years, 3 months of age, his measurements are: weight 12.1 kg (15-50th centile), height 87.5 cm (15-50th centile), and head circumference 48 cm (- 1 SD). Physical features include deep-set eyes, down slanting palpebral fissures, and a prominent nasal root and tip.

A: The patient shows developmental delays in motor skills and speech, with a concerning ataxic gait. His understanding of commands, social interaction attempts, and seizure history are significant. Developmental assessments and monitoring are essential due to these observations.

P: Continue anti-epileptic medications and monitor seizure frequency. Engage in speech and physical therapy to address developmental delays. Monitor eating habits to prevent choking, and prioritize consultations with a sleep specialist if sleep disruptions continue. Regular follow-ups with the pediatrician are recommended to ensure ongoing developmental support and interventions.

S: The patient, with a history of osteopenia and a total hip arthroplasty on the left side three months prior, reports falling at home onto a tile floor and landing on the left hip. Since the fall, the patient has experienced leg pain and difficulty walking. The patient also reports tenderness and bruising around the left hip area.

O: Vitals: Blood pressure of 137/92 mmHg (mildly hypertensive), heart rate of 105 beats per minute (tachycardic). Examination revealed tenderness, bruising, slight shortening, and external rotation of the left leg. Radiograph results show medial displacement of the acetabulum and femoral head into the lesser pelvis. Angiography did not reveal any vascular disruption.

A: The patient likely has an injury to the left hip/acetabulum region with potential fracture or dislocation, as suggested by the radiograph findings. The patient is hemodynamically stable.

P: Plan to perform urgent internal pelvic fixation to address the displacement. Surgery to be scheduled as soon as possible. Pre-operative instructions to be followed as provided by the nursing staff. Monitor and manage blood pressure and heart rate as part of pre-surgical care.

S: The patient expresses concern about their growth and health. They commenced rhGH treatment at 6 years old when their height was significantly below average. Over the past 6.5 years of treatment, the patient experienced a noticeable increase in growth velocity, particularly in the initial two years. By age 12.3, they reached the 3rd centile in height but remained prepubertal with bone age a year behind. The patient admits to a period of non-adherence to the treatment, affecting growth velocity and hormone levels. They also have a family history of mild hypercholesterolemia on the paternal side.

O: The patient experienced a marked increase in growth rate with a 14.6 cm and 8.4 cm increase in height during the first two years of treatment. Their height SDS increased by 4.9 after 6.5 years of treatment. IGF-I and IGFBP-3 levels normalized after approximately one year of treatment. The patient's growth velocity and hormone levels decreased during a six-month period due to treatment non-adherence. Cholesterol levels remained stable despite the family history of hypercholesterolemia.

A: The patient is responding well to rhGH treatment with significant improvements in height and normalization of IGF-I and IGFBP-3 levels, although treatment adherence issues have temporarily affected results. The mild hypercholesterolemia is familial and unaffected by treatment.

P: Continue rhGH treatment with emphasis on maintaining adherence to the regimen. Monitor growth, IGF-I, IGFBP-3, and cholesterol levels regularly. Address non-adherence to ensure optimal treatment efficacy. Provide family counseling regarding hypercholesterolemia and its management. Follow up regularly to track progress and adjust the plan as needed.

S: The patient reports chest discomfort after eating for the past eight months. They have a past history of pediatric asthma and were diagnosed with a middle esophageal diverticulum at age 30, which was initially asymptomatic.

O: Upper gastrointestinal contrast exam revealed a 47 mm middle esophageal diverticulum with contrast accumulation. Gastrointestinal endoscopy identified the diverticulum in the right wall, 30 cm from the incisor row, partially covered by adherent white matter unstained with iodine. Narrowband imaging showed type A. An endoscopic biopsy indicated atypical epithelium with no malignant findings. High-resolution manometry confirmed normal lower esophageal sphincter function and esophageal body peristaltic wave.

A: The patient is experiencing chest discomfort likely related to the middle esophageal diverticulum. There is a potential risk for malignancy suggested by atypical epithelium.

P: Proceed with thoracoscopic diverticulectomy to address symptoms and potential malignancy risk. The surgery is to be scheduled at the earliest available date. Further inquiries or concerns should be directed to the medical team prior to surgery.

S: A 13-year-old boy presents with left groin pain and decreased range of motion in the left hip. Six months prior, he sustained an avulsion fracture of the anterior inferior iliac spine (AIIS) during a rugby game. He experiences sharp pain in the left groin when running with a ball. The flexion of the left hip is restricted to 70° with a decrease in internal rotation. Abduction, adduction, extension, and external rotation are similar to the other side. There is no significant tenderness, bruising, or distal neurovascular deficit.

O: MRI post-injury showed a single bony fragment at the AIIS. Radiographs revealed hypertrophic calcification in the region of the avulsion with normal hip joints. CT scan revealed well-corticated heterotopic bone formation, measuring 3.5 cm in diameter. Motion analysis using 3D CT datasets demonstrated an impinging area at 70° of hip flexion.

A: The patient has an impingement due to a prior avulsion fracture of the AIIS with heterotopic bone formation, causing pain and restricted movement, impacting his ability to play rugby.

P: The patient underwent arthroscopic surgery to address the bone formation. Post-operative care involves follow-up with a physiotherapist and surgeon, adhering to rehabilitation exercises, and monitoring progress to return to playing rugby.

S: The patient reported experiencing skin ecchymosis on the trunk and lower limbs for about 10 days. In December 2017, the patient developed intermittent distending pain in the right temporal region, blurred vision, and inarticulate speech. In February 2018, the patient developed severe depression. After chemotherapy, the patient complained of fever, perianal pain, and diarrhea, with worsening symptoms two days later.

O: A routine inspection found a white blood cell count of 47.7×10^9/L, with 83% blasts in bone marrow. The immunophenotype showed abnormal lymphocyte populations, and a PCR test detected NOTCH EXON26 and FBXW7 EXON9 missense mutations, leading to a diagnosis of adult acute T-lymphocytic leukemia. CT and MRI scans were normal, with no blast-like cells found in a bone marrow smear, and a negative cerebrospinal fluid result. During chemotherapy, 12 lumbar punctures and intrathecal injections were performed.

A: The patient was diagnosed with adult acute T-lymphocytic leukemia, and despite negative CT, MRI, and cerebrospinal fluid results, was considered to have CNSL based on symptoms. Depression was noted as a comorbidity during chemotherapy.

P: The patient was started on a hyper-CVAD chemotherapy regimen in September 2017 and received 2 courses of hyper-CVAD-B combined with PEG-ASP chemotherapy for CNSL symptoms. Maintenance chemotherapy with Azathioprine was provided for 2 weeks in February 2018. Citalopram hydrobromide was recommended for depression. The patient underwent multiple lumbar punctures and intrathecal injections for CNSL management. Further attention is necessary for post-chemotherapy symptoms of fever, perianal pain, and diarrhea.

S: The patient reports experiencing mild, dull, aching pain on the left side of the abdomen for the past year and has been losing weight and appetite for the past 6 months. The patient also notes rectal bleeding and changes in bowel habits. There is no family history of malignancy.

O: General examination is within normal limits with no significant lymphadenopathy. Abdominal examination reveals a 7 cm x 6 cm nodular, nontender, firm lump in the epigastric region extending to the left hypochondrium. Rectal examination is normal. Routine lab tests, including complete blood count, liver and renal function tests, are within normal limits. Ultrasonography and CECT show a multicystic lobulated mass in the distal body and tail of the pancreas, with proximal pancreatic duct dilatation, a normal liver, and an irregular mass in the sigmoid colon. Tumor marker tests show elevated carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) at 10.48 ng/ml and normal CA19-9 at 7.19 U/mL.

A: The findings suggest the presence of a multicystic lesion in the pancreas and an irregular mass in the sigmoid colon. The elevated CEA level may indicate neoplastic activity, warranting further investigation and specialist consultation.

P: The patient will be referred to a specialist for further evaluation and management of the pancreatic lesion and the sigmoid colon mass. The patient is advised to monitor symptoms and report any changes. Follow-up plans will be communicated after specialist consultation.

S: The patient reports experiencing gradually worsening weakness in both upper and lower limbs over the past 7-8 years, resulting in difficulty climbing stairs or carrying weights. Additionally, the patient experiences shortness of breath with mild exertion but denies any trouble swallowing or speaking. The patient also mentioned having a recent blood test showing mild hyperCKemia with a CK level of 468 UI/L.

O: The neurological examination revealed lumbar hyperlordosis, abdominal breathing, and a waddling gait. A manual muscle test showed bilateral and symmetric weakness in the deltoid, pectoralis, biceps brachii, triceps brachii, ileo-psoas, and quadriceps, with hypotrophy in the axial musculature and presence of winged scapulae. Blood tests confirmed slightly elevated CK levels with normal serum protein electrophoresis. The functional respiratory test indicated a moderate restrictive ventilatory deficit. Nerve conduction studies were unremarkable, but the EMG showed abundant fibrillation potentials, positive sharp waves, sporadic fasciculations, complex repetitive discharges, and neurogenic MUPs remodeling in various muscles. MRI of the thighs revealed bilateral fibro-adipose degeneration of specific muscles and hypertrophy of the gracilis muscles.

A: The assessment suggests muscle and nerve issues contributing to the patient's symptoms, with a differential diagnosis considering neuromuscular disorders given the EMG findings and MRI results.

P: The plan is to perform a muscle biopsy of the left side to further evaluate the patient's condition for precise diagnosis and to tailor appropriate treatment.

S: The patient reports feeling extremely short of breath with shallow breathing, as if not getting enough air. A history of smoking 30 cigarettes a day for 40 years and consuming a bottle of whisky every 4 days was noted. Past medical treatments include extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy for urinary calculus, endoscopic colon polypectomy for colon polyps, and esophagectomy with gastric reconstruction for esophageal cancer. The patient also has a family history of liver cancer.

O: The patient appears confused and restless. Vital signs show a heart rate of 122 beats/minute, blood pressure of 80/58 mmHg, respiratory rate of 26 breaths/minute, and temperature of 38.7 °C. Arterial blood gases indicate respiratory acidosis with a pH of 7.21, PaCO2 of 117 mmHg, PaO2 of 76 mmHg, and bicarbonate (HCO3−) of 45.9 mmol/L with mask oxygen at 6 L/minute. Intubation revealed aspirated food particles in the trachea, which were removed. A chest X-ray revealed diffuse bilateral pulmonary infiltrates. Laboratory findings include a white blood cell count of 0.9 × 10^9/L, red blood cell count of 4.66 × 10^12/L, hemoglobin of 12.1 g/dL, hematocrit of 41.0%, platelet count of 297 × 10^9/L, aspartate aminotransferase of 17 U/L, alanine aminotransferase of 7 U/L, and total bilirubin of 0.59 mg/dL.

A: The patient is diagnosed with aspiration pneumonia, evidenced by the lung infiltrates and respiratory distress following aspiration of food particles. The lab results, particularly the low white blood cell count, suggest a potential underlying issue to be monitored.

P: The patient has been placed on mechanical ventilation to assist with breathing. Ongoing monitoring of vital signs, blood gases, and laboratory findings will be conducted to manage and adjust treatment as necessary. The patient is advised to report any discomfort or questions to the medical team.

S: The patient is a 19-year-old female with a history of two pregnancies that did not reach 24 weeks and a current intrauterine pregnancy at 32 weeks. She has a history of unspecified psychosis, methamphetamine use disorder, and multiple incarcerations. She reports persistent delusions, paranoia, auditory and visual hallucinations, and persecutory thoughts related to her pregnancy. She experiences agitation and is unsure if previous medication regimens were followed.

O: The patient was brought in by ambulance from a correctional facility with persistent psychotic symptoms. She was initially prescribed quetiapine 300 mg daily and was later increased to 400 mg twice daily due to her symptoms and aggression. Haloperidol was administered as needed for acute agitation. The patient exhibits disorganized and aggressive behaviors, attempts to leave the unit, and has side effects of sialorrhea and mild tremors, attributed to haloperidol.

A: The patient's persistent psychotic symptoms could indicate primary psychosis or drug-induced psychosis. She exhibits poor response to current antipsychotic regimens and experiences side effects from haloperidol.

P: The treatment plan includes reducing haloperidol to 5 mg once daily and initiating diphenhydramine 25 mg daily to manage mild tremors. The patient's progress will be monitored, and medications adjusted as needed. No restraints have been used, and support for ongoing concerns or worsening symptoms is offered. Further adjustments and monitoring are required to optimize the treatment plan.

S: The patient reports a two-day history of nosebleeds and painless gross hematuria that began the day before. Initially, the urine appeared like fruit punch, progressively worsening to resemble ketchup. The patient denies dysuria, frequency, urgency, incomplete bladder emptying, clot formation, flank, or abdominal pain. There is no history of previous hematuria, nephrolithiasis, tobacco smoking, genitourinary malignancies, kidney issues, anticoagulation, or hepatic dysfunction. The patient mentioned using Spice intermittently, with the last usage 24 hours prior to the visit.

O: The patient's laboratory tests showed an INR greater than 11, hemoglobin of 13.3, a white blood cell count of 18.9 × 103/μL, and creatinine of 0.9 mg/dL. Urinalysis indicated >100 RBCs and >100 WBCs. A CT urogram was negative for upper tract pathology, but urine cultures were contaminated. Treatment with fresh-frozen plasma reduced the INR to 2.9 and resolved the gross hematuria by discharge, with an INR of 1.9.

A: The patient's symptoms of hematuria and nosebleeds, combined with the high INR, suggest possible coagulopathy. The resolution of hematuria with plasma treatment indicates a likely relationship to the elevated INR. The negative CT urogram rules out upper tract pathology, pointing towards a bleeding or clotting disorder, possibly influenced by the Spice usage.

P: The patient is advised to follow up for a cystoscopy in three days to further assess the underlying cause of the hematuria and coagulopathy. Ongoing monitoring of coagulation status is recommended. The patient should attend follow-up appointments and reach out if any further symptoms or concerns arise.

S: The patient experienced abdominal pain and vomiting starting in May. They have a history of a right hepatectomy due to trauma in August 2012, followed by a right diaphragmatic hernia and strangulation of the ileus of the small intestine in November 2012, requiring a laparotomy. Recently, they were diagnosed with an intestinal obstruction at a local hospital, where an ileus tube was inserted, leading to a referral for further treatment.

O: Physical examination and laboratory findings, including complete blood count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and biochemical tests, were normal. Chest and abdominal radiographs showed colon gas in the right intrathoracic space. Contrast imaging and CT confirmed the ileus tube in the transverse colon incarcerated in the right intrathoracic space, indicating a diaphragmatic hernia.

A: Diaphragmatic hernia with incarceration of the ileus tube in the right intrathoracic space.

P: The patient will undergo laparoscopic hernia repair. The procedure involves placing four laparoscopic ports for the surgery, with the patient in the left half-lateral decubitus position. Careful separation and repair of the hernia will be performed under laparoscopic view.

S: The patient reports a past diagnosis of infectious cervical tuberculosis at C1 and underwent posterior C1-2 screw-plate fixation surgery. Initially, neck pain improved, but over nine months, swallowing function worsened, leading to progressive dysphagia, severe weight loss (25 kg over 7 months), and referral to the current hospital. The patient has a history of hypertension and mild diabetes mellitus (HbA1c 6.2% NGSP) and has been on antitubercular treatment. Current complaints include neck pain and difficulty swallowing.

O: Height is 165 cm, weight is 52 kg, with a BMI of 19. Neurological examination revealed left dominant proximal arm muscle weakness with atrophy, dysesthesia in distal fingers, and hyperreflexia with bilateral extensor plantar reflex. Oral examination showed left tongue atrophy and left tongue deviation, consistent with unilateral HNP. Slight elevation in CRP levels. Chest X-ray showed no specific abnormality, cervical X-ray indicated O-C2 angle of 17-degree kyphosis. CT showed erosive lesions at the dens and anterior arch of the atlas. MRI revealed a space-occupying lesion in the retropharyngeal space with heterogeneous signals. Previous imaging showed the lesion decreasing in size despite worsening O-C kyphosis.

A: The patient is experiencing severe dysphagia and malnutrition related to the O-C kyphosis and space-occupying lesion in the retropharyngeal space. Additionally, there is left upper limb weakness and progressive neck pain, likely related to the cervical tuberculosis and post-surgical changes. The lesion has shown a decrease in size, indicating partial response to treatment.

P: The plan includes continued monitoring and management of the patient’s condition, maintenance of nasogastric tube feeding for nutritional support, and continuation of antitubercular medications. Follow-up assessments will focus on adjusting treatment for dysphagia and monitoring the cervical spine condition. Further imaging and evaluation may be necessary based on symptom progression.

S: The patient reports experiencing lower back pain for 5 months. There is a history of cervical laminoplasty for ossification of the posterior longitudinal ligament and diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis 19 years ago. The patient has a history of hypertension, diabetes, and previous bladder cancer treated with intravesical mitomycin C and BCG therapy. After the sixth course of BCG therapy, the patient experienced systemic weakness, loss of appetite, inability to walk, and was hospitalized for septic shock, later diagnosed with hypercytokinemia caused by BCG therapy. There are no current motor or sensory disturbances in the legs, but the patient is unable to walk due to back pain.

O: Current temperature is 37.2°C; other vital signs are normal. A physical examination reveals vertebral tenderness at the L2/3 level. Laboratory findings include a normal white blood cell count of 6300 /μL, elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 53 mm/h, and high C-reactive protein level of 2.7 mg/dL. No anemic changes, kidney function, or liver function abnormalities are noted. MRI results suggest L2/3 spondylitis.

A: The patient may have L2/3 spondylitis and is recovering from complications of BCG therapy, namely hypercytokinemia. There is back pain with vertebral tenderness and inflammation markers but without identified infection.

P: The treatment plan will address lower back pain and monitor the patient for potential complications related to their extensive medical history. No specific treatments, medications, referrals, or follow-up instructions were mentioned in the conversation. The patient has not yet received a tuberculin skin test.

S: The patient is a 49-year-old male with no previous medical history. He presents with neck pain due to being accidentally struck by a nail gun on a construction site. He reports pain along the left side of his neck and difficulty swallowing.

O: The patient is neurologically intact with no signs of Horner's syndrome, active bleeding, or hemodynamic instability. The head of the nail is observed behind and above the angle of the mandible, palpably present along the oral mucosa on the left side of the oropharynx. CT angiography reveals the nail is in very close proximity to the left internal carotid artery near the skull base, with preserved proximal and distal blood flow, but significant vessel narrowing at the level of the nail. There is no active contrast extravasation. Further 3D rotational angiography indicates small areas of contrast stagnation and a small dissection flap proximal to the nail.

A: The patient has sustained at least a partial vessel injury to the left internal carotid artery due to the nail's proximity and vessel narrowing, accompanied by contrast stagnation and a dissection flap.

P: The patient was transported to the interventional radiology suite for evaluation and potential endovascular repair. A multidisciplinary team, including trauma surgery, oral and maxillofacial surgery, and neurointervention, will determine the appropriate surgical approach for repair and removal of the nail.

S: The patient reports a throbbing headache for the past 2 days, located in the left frontal area. The headache is moderate in severity but can become severe enough to disturb sleep. The patient has no history of migraines or similar headaches. There are no associated symptoms such as fever, photophobia, changes in behavior or personality, abnormal movements, loss of consciousness, weakness, loss of sensation, vision problems, or difficulty swallowing. There is a family history of stroke at a young age.

O: The patient appears tired, hypoactive, and in mild pain distress, but is hemodynamically stable. Vital signs are: temperature 37 °C, blood pressure 117/68 mm Hg, pulse rate 71 beats per minute, respiratory rate 18 per minute, and oxygen saturation 99% on room air. No neck rigidity or proptosis is observed. The patient is conscious, alert, and oriented with a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 15/15. There is no focal neurological deficit and reflexes are normal.

A: The differential diagnosis remains broad, but no specific cause is identified. The persistent headache with normal examination findings and stable vital signs suggests a non-critical condition, though further investigation is needed.

P: The plan is to consult with specialists and consider further tests to gain a better understanding of the condition. The patient is advised to monitor symptoms and return to the emergency department if they worsen or if any new symptoms develop.

S: The patient is a 40-year-old woman, gravida 2, parity 1, at 23 weeks and 2 days of gestation. She was referred for placenta previa and severe fetal growth restriction (FGR). Her previous delivery was a normal vaginal delivery with manual removal of the placenta. She has no history of taking aspirin or anticoagulants and has been diagnosed with gestational thrombocytopenia.

O: Recent ultrasound showed no fetal anomaly but indicated severe FGR with an estimated fetal body weight of 258 g (-3.7 SD), placenta previa, and an enlarged placenta (8 × 9 × 7 cm). Umbilical artery end-diastolic flow velocity was normal. Blood tests showed hemoglobin at 12.4 g/dL, platelet count at 99,000/μL, APTT at 27 seconds, PT-INR at 0.88, and D-dimer levels at 0.9 µg/L. Pelvic MRI at 24 weeks and 3 days showed internal heterogeneity and enlargement of the placenta, placenta previa, and a fluid-fluid level on the fetal side without blood flow. Ultrasound at 24 weeks and 4 days confirmed a fluid-fluid level on the fetal side of the placenta, measuring 2.8 × 7 cm.

A: The patient has been diagnosed with idiopathic placentomegaly with severe FGR, placenta previa, and gestational thrombocytopenia. There is no evidence of antiphospholipid syndrome, protein S deficiency, or protein C deficiency.

P: The plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and fetal development. The patient is advised to attend all follow-up appointments and report any changes in symptoms. The focus is on ensuring the best possible outcome for the patient and the baby.

S: The patient reports a complaint of several broken teeth and one lost permanent tooth following an accidental fall from a tractor about ten days ago. There are no other medical issues or remarkable medical history to note.

O: The intraoral examination reveals uncomplicated crown fractures on teeth numbers 15, 16, 25, 26, 35, 36, and 45. Tooth number 34 is clinically missing, and tooth number 46 has a complicated crown fracture. A panoramic radiograph confirmed the avulsion of tooth number 34 and showed no other fractures of the maxilla or mandible.

A: The patient has multiple dental injuries resulting from trauma, including uncomplicated crown fractures, one complicated crown fracture on tooth 46, and one avulsed tooth.

P: The treatment plan includes composite restorations for teeth 15, 25, 35, and 45. A root canal treatment (RCT) will be performed on tooth 46, which will also receive a stainless steel crown along with teeth 16, 26, and 36. A functional space maintainer—band and loop with an acrylic pontic—will be used as an interim prosthesis for the missing tooth number 34. The band will assist retention for the composite restoration of tooth 35 until definitive restorative management is completed. Appointments will be scheduled for these treatments, and necessary preparations will be communicated to the patient.

S: The patient reports feeling unwell but is currently unsure of the specific cause. The patient has a history of liver cirrhosis secondary to Hepatitis B, diagnosed in April 2017 after liver decompensation with ascites. The patient was found to have symptomatic iron-deficiency anemia with a hemoglobin level of 5.0 g/dL. The patient is a non-drinker and quit smoking seven years ago.

O: During the initial diagnosis, an upper endoscopy revealed hypertensive gastropathy and esophageal varices (Grade II-III), which were successfully banded. A colonoscopy indicated colonic edema due to portal hypertension. A triphasic CT scan showed irregular nodular contour of the liver, splenic and gastric cardia varices, a splenorenal shunt, and severe ascites. The gallbladder was distended with no biliary obstruction. Subsequent CT and MRCP scans showed a markedly distended gallbladder with a 1 cm gallstone in the proximal cystic duct, common bile duct narrowing, and mild intrahepatic dilation. Loculated ascites and clustering of small bowel loops were also observed.

A: The patient's findings are consistent with advanced liver cirrhosis with complications such as portal hypertension resulting in ascites and varices, gallbladder distension due to a gallstone, and probable related mass effect on the bile duct.

P: Close monitoring and continuation of current medical therapy are advised. The patient should adhere to follow-up appointments and promptly report any changes in symptoms. Further treatment options may be considered based on the patient's condition and progress.

S: The mother reports experiencing pain in her nipple throughout breastfeeding sessions, which recurs with each episode. She noticed a tooth on her baby's lower left gum about two weeks after delivery, followed by an ulcer under the tongue that sometimes bleeds. She is reluctant to continue breastfeeding and has been using formula instead. There is a strong family history of natal teeth, with similar problems in the baby's siblings.

O: The examination of the mother’s breast shows no inflammation, engorgement, or infection, though there is mild eczema around the nipple. The cervical and axillary lymph nodes are not palpable. Examination of the baby’s mouth reveals a neonatal tooth over the left anterior mandibular ridge, measuring 2 mm × 1 mm, with Grade II mobility, and a whitish ulcer on the ventral aspect of the tongue, measuring 1 mm × 1 mm.

A: The clinical diagnosis is a neonatal tooth associated with Riga-Fede disease, causing difficulty in breastfeeding.

P: The recommendation is to refer the baby to the pediatric dental surgery department for extraction of the neonatal tooth under local anesthesia. The wound is expected to heal within 2 days post-extraction, allowing for successful resumption of breastfeeding without complications such as bleeding or infection.

S: The patient is a 72-year-old with a diagnosis of moderately differentiated intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma since October 2015. Initial symptoms included moderate weight loss, pain in the right hypochondrium, loss of appetite, and asthenia. Their Karnofsky scale index was 70% at diagnosis. The patient has undergone four courses of chemotherapy, including Gemcitabine with Capecitabine and Gemcitabine with Cisplatin, with limited effectiveness. 

O: Imaging via MRI showed an increase in tumor size with metastasis to both liver lobes and spread to the bile duct, holedoch, and gallbladder. Serum gamma glutamyltranspeptidase (GGT) levels were significantly elevated, indicating a poor prognosis. The patient's Karnofsky scale index has decreased to 60%.

A: The patient's cholangiocarcinoma is progressing with increased tumor size, metastasis, and elevated serum GGT levels, pointing to a more aggressive disease course.

P: The plan involves advanced molecular analysis to identify the most effective treatment options, particularly considering TKI inhibitors. The tumor gene expression was profiled using RNA extraction and hybridization techniques to aid in treatment decision-making. Further discussions with the patient will occur once the analysis results are obtained.

S: 
The patient reports worsening back pain for a week, tingling, numbness in lower limbs, and difficulty walking. They also experience muscle weakness in lower limbs and decreased sensation on the upper back.

O: 
The physical examination shows moderate muscle weakness in the lower limbs and superficial hypesthesia below the T5 level, indicating a dorsal cord disorder. Laboratory tests and radiography show no abnormalities, but an MRI reveals a dorsally located epidural lesion between Th5-Th8 vertebrae, suggesting an epidural hematoma.

A: 
The clinical impression is a dorsally located epidural lesion likely due to an epidural hematoma. The final pathology confirms a diagnosis of nonfiltrating spinal angiolipoma.

P: 
The plan includes an emergent surgical excision of the lesion via Th5-8 laminectomy. The surgery will address the tumor resection and potential complications, such as intraoperative blood loss. Postoperatively, the patient's sensory loss, numbness, and gait disturbance are expected to improve, and follow-up examinations will monitor recovery and check for recurrence within one year.

S: The patient reports experiencing unusual pain in their left carotid area for the past 24 hours, with the pain radiating to the ear. The patient expresses concern about the seriousness of the condition.

O: The Colour Doppler ultrasound shows an eccentric hypoechoic thickening in the proximal bulbar internal carotid area and partially in the carotid bifurcation with a thin hyperechoic atheromatous fibrous plaque but no significant stenosis. The Contrast-enhanced ultrasound indicates a normal capillary distribution of microbubbles in the hypoechoic thickening, confirming no haematoma, and a well-demonstrated avascular fibrous plaque. The MR imaging reveals hypointense tissue around the proximal internal carotid with intense enhancement on fat-saturated contrast-enhanced T1-weighted images.

A: The patient is diagnosed with Carotidynia or TIPIC syndrome, a treatable condition characterized by inflammation of the carotid artery.

P: The treatment plan includes administering non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs to reduce inflammation and pain. Follow-up with a Doppler ultrasound is scheduled in 14 days to monitor the progress and regression of the condition. The patient is advised to reach out with any further concerns or questions.

S: The patient has been experiencing low mood, suicidal thoughts, and suspicion of others for the past 4 weeks. The patient reports that these symptoms have worsened upon initial treatment with sertraline and olanzapine, leading to slower thought processes and epileptic seizures.

O: The patient had a CSF pressure of 240 cmH2O, a leukocyte count of 10 × 10^6/L, and anti-NMDAR antibodies in CSF and serum at level 1:32. Initial EEG showed epileptic activity with sharp-slow waves in the right anterior frontotemporal region. B-ultrasound and CT of the chest and abdomen were clear of tumors. The patient developed heart and respiratory failure, visual and auditory hallucinations, delusions, aggressive behaviors, muscle stiffness, and slurred speech during treatment.

A: The initial diagnosis was severe depression, but given the presence of anti-NMDAR antibodies, the assessment suggests anti-NMDAR encephalitis. The patient’s psychiatric symptoms and seizures align with this diagnosis.

P: The treatment plan involves intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG), methylprednisolone, and prednisolone for two courses. Levetiracetam and valproic acid are prescribed for epilepsy control. Clonazepam was started for psychiatric symptom improvement, and midazolam sedation was used in ICU. The new medication, quetiapine, is being introduced to manage psychiatric symptoms with ongoing monitoring and adjustment as necessary.

S: The patient has a history of monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) and previous treatment for prostate cancer with external beam radiation therapy. Recently, the patient reported feeling weak and tired, and noticed that the right testicle seems enlarged.

O: Serum biochemistry indicated hypercalcaemia. A CT scan demonstrated a large right-sided scrotal mass with soft tissue extending through the inguinal canal to the inferior vena cava, along with bilateral lung nodules up to 14mm, considered metastatic. An ultrasound showed a heterogeneous mass replacing the right testicle with infiltration of the right epididymis and spermatic cord, demonstrating increased Doppler vascularity. Histology from an ultrasound-guided biopsy revealed diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, germinal centre subtype.

A: The differential diagnosis initially included sarcoma or lymphoma, leading to a diagnosis of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, germinal centre subtype.

P: The patient was referred to haematology for further management and underwent chemotherapy. After 3 cycles, the patient achieved a complete radiological response. Follow-up care includes regular check-ups for monitoring recurrence and addressing any new symptoms or concerns.

S: The patient was admitted to the emergency department with a 12-hour history of abdominal pain, distension, and bilious vomiting. They had no history of similar attacks before.

O: The patient appeared dehydrated and afebrile, with a pulse of 98 per minute and blood pressure of 130/80. The abdomen was distended and tympanic on percussion with tinkling bowel sounds observed. An abdominal X-ray revealed multiple fluid levels without free air, confirming bowel occlusion. A CT scan identified a small bowel obstruction (SBO) with a transitional zone in the right lower abdomen, suggesting an internal hernia.

A: The patient was diagnosed with a small bowel obstruction due to an internal hernia, which was confirmed radiologically and laparoscopically.

P: A laparoscopic approach was recommended and performed using a three trocars technique, revealing an obstructive supravesical hernia involving the terminal ileum. The hernia was repaired without bowel resection as the incarcerated intestine was viable. The internal surface of the sac was cauterized and the hernia's ring was closed using a 2/0 Polydioxanone suture. The patient had a smooth recovery and was discharged on the fourth post-operative day. Two months later, the patient presented with a bulging mass in the right inguinal area and underwent a repair of a direct inguinal hernia.

S: 
The patient is a 52-year-old male who is asymptomatic and a nonsmoker, without any comorbidities, but with class II obesity (BMI of 37.7). The patient has not experienced any symptoms related to the finding on the lung scan.

O: 
High-resolution chest CT scan showed a 1.5 cm mixed ground glass opacity with a larger solid component in the right middle lobe. A follow-up CT scan indicated an increase in size. The patient underwent a right middle lobe lobectomy with systematic mediastinal lymph node dissection. Routine venous thromboembolism prophylaxis (6000 i.u UFH) was administered 12 hours post-operation.

A: 
The patient presented with a lung nodule showing increased size upon follow-up, necessitating surgical intervention. Post-surgical status appears stable as the patient feels much better.

P: 
Monitor recovery and ensure follow-up on necessary appointments. The patient was advised to reach out with any questions or concerns regarding recovery.

S: The patient reported that their vision in the left eye is not as clear as in the right eye. There were no additional symptoms or concerns mentioned by the patient.

O: The patient's visual acuity is 20/20 in the right eye and 20/25 in the left eye. The intraocular pressure is normal in both eyes. A retinal lesion was found in the left eye, measuring 0.6 mm horizontally and 0.5 mm vertically with a dilated feeding retinal arteriole. The lesion has a bi-lobulated "butterfly" appearance and a yellowish, less pigmented superior border. Imaging showed intrinsic hyperreflectivity and blocked signals on various tests. Fluorescein angiography revealed mild ring-shaped fluorescence without leakage. Indocyanine green angiography showed weak cyanescence on the superior boundary.

A: The findings are consistent with congenital simple hamartoma of the retinal pigment epithelium (CSHRPE), a benign condition. 

P: The plan is to continue monitoring the eye during routine evaluations. No additional treatment or testing is needed unless the patient notices changes in their vision or has further concerns.

S: The patient reports experiencing persistent left-side chest pain for 2 months and hemoptysis for 1 month. There is no personal or familial history of major illnesses or malignancies. The patient is a nonsmoker and occasionally consumes alcohol. Recently, the patient has felt weak, experienced vomiting, trouble eating, sleeping difficulties, and constipation.

O: The PET/CT scan revealed two metabolically active soft tissue masses in the left suprahilar region and left lower lobe, with enlarged prevascular and left hilar lymph nodes, a metastatic lesion in the left fourth rib, and moderate left pleural effusion. A biopsy confirmed adenocarcinoma positive for ALK gene rearrangement and negative for epidermal growth factor receptor mutation, with pleural fluid cytology showing metastatic adenocarcinoma. Baseline hemogram, liver, and kidney function tests were normal. After 1 month of treatment, PET/CT showed a partial response with over 30% reduction in primary tumor size and decreased pleural effusion.

A: Advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), staged T4N2M1a, stage IV. Symptoms of weakness, vomiting, trouble eating, sleeping issues, and constipation could be related to treatment with crizotinib and its side effects.

P: The patient was started on palliative radiotherapy, 20 Gy in five fractions over 5 days, and prescribed crizotinib 250 mg twice per day. Weekly liver function tests were recommended to monitor for liver toxicity. The patient is advised to visit the emergency department for evaluation and management of symptoms such as weakness, vomiting, eating difficulties, sleep disturbances, and constipation.

S: The patient reported experiencing a fever of around 38°C, feelings of weakness, lumbar pain, and the appearance of small red spots on the skin, noted by the doctor as petechiae.

O: Blood cultures confirmed septic shock secondary to Neisseria meningitidis infection. The patient showed severe inflammation with a procalcitonin (PCT) level of 121.7 ng/ml, hypotension requiring high doses of norepinephrine (up to 0.75 μg/kg/min), oligoanuria, and severe bleeding from catheter insertion points. Initially treated with meropenem and amikacin, switched to ceftriaxone. Hemofiltration treatment and Cytosorb sessions were initiated, leading to hemodynamic improvement, tapering of norepinephrine and epinephrine, stabilization of lactate values, decrease in PCT to 16.52 ng/ml, and improvement in disseminated intravascular coagulopathy. Skin necrosis areas are demarcating.

A: Septic shock secondary to Neisseria meningitidis infection with severe inflammation and disseminated intravascular coagulopathy.

P: Transfer to ICU for close monitoring and comprehensive care. Empirical antibiotic therapy switched to ceftriaxone. Initiation of norepinephrine and epinephrine infusions for hypotension. Hemofiltration treatment started due to oligoanuria. Cytosorb treatments initiated, resulting in hemodynamic and inflammatory improvement. Plan for extubation in about 10 days. Continued monitoring and adjustments as necessary for recovery.

S: The patient is a 34-year-old primigravida referred to a tertiary care hospital due to suspicion of a chorioangioma or placental teratoma. She was diagnosed with pregnancy-induced hypertension but has no other known comorbidities. The pregnancy was planned without any medical intervention or assistance. There is no family history of congenital anomalies or twin pregnancies.

O: An ultrasonography at the tertiary care hospital showed a single intrauterine fetus at 27 weeks and two days of gestation, with normal growth.
