A multiloculated cystic mass with septations and calcifications, lacking vascularity, was identified. A repeat scan confirmed the findings. At 36 weeks and five days, the patient delivered via C-section: one healthy fetus with good Apgar scores (9/1, 9/5) and a second congenitally malformed fetus. The placenta had two umbilical cords. Histopathological examination noted a placenta with gross malformations in one of the fetuses, including the absence of the head and upper limbs.

A: Differential diagnoses considered included placental teratoma, chorioangioma, hemorrhagic placental degeneration, or degenerating fibroid. 

P: No specific treatment or follow-up plans were mentioned other than the patient being discharged in a stable condition. Further support and information are available as needed.

S: The patient is a 32-year-old multiparous woman at 37 2/7 weeks of gestation, admitted for induction of labor due to abnormal antenatal testing. She has a history of prior cesarean delivery due to arrest of labor at 7 cm dilation. She chose to attempt a Trial of Labor After Cesarean (TOLAC) for this delivery. During induced labor, she experienced moderate vaginal bleeding.

O: Initial cervical exam showed 2 cm dilation and 50% effacement. Labor was induced with oxytocin and amniotomy was performed at 5 cm dilation. The labor progression was from 2 cm to 5 cm in 10 hours and from 5 cm to 6 cm in 3.5 hours. There was minimal fetal heart rate variability and variable decelerations unresponsive to resuscitation, prompting a repeat cesarean delivery. No uterine rupture or significant placental abruption was noted during the surgery. A male infant was delivered weighing 2659 g with Apgar scores of 9 and arterial cord pH of 7.26. Post-delivery, a distended and edematous bladder was observed. A vaginal exam revealed spontaneous detachment and necrosis of the anterior rim of the cervix from 9 to 3 o'clock with the cervix detaching completely during attempted repair. There was no excessive bleeding.

A: Concern for possible uterine rupture or placental abruption; however, none was observed. Cervical necrosis and spontaneous detachment occurred, with no excessive blood loss.

P: The patient is stable post-surgery. Continued close monitoring during recovery is planned. An attempt to repair the cervical detachment was made. Further evaluation and monitoring of the lower uterine segment integrity behind the bladder are advised.

S: The patient is a recent post-operative patient, having undergone phacoemulsification and intraocular lens (IOL) implantation the previous day. The patient reports seeing multiple cords in the eye but denies any pain or discomfort. The patient's medical history includes atrial fibrillation, Raynaud's syndrome, and B-cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia. The patient has been treated with rituximab, chlorambucil, and more recently with ibrutinib for six months prior to cataract extraction. The patient has no history of surgeries or procedures on the fellow eye, nor a history of diabetes, glaucoma, uveitis, or trauma.

O: The patient’s vision is measured at 20/100, and intraocular pressure is 43 mmHg. There are no signs of hypopyon, hyphema, significant corneal edema, or cellular reaction. A dilated fundus examination is unremarkable. During the surgery, the lens showed 2-3+ nuclear sclerosis without pseudoexfoliation or phacodonesis. Preoperative medication included a retrobulbar block of 2% lidocaine and 0.75% Marcaine (bupivacaine). Dexamethasone and cefazolin were applied to the ocular surface postoperatively.

A: Possible fibrinoid syndrome secondary to recent cataract surgery may be causing the visual disturbances described as cords. The elevated intraocular pressure is a notable finding.

P: The patient is advised to start topical prednisolone every 2-3 hours, brimonidine three times per day, timolol-dorzolamide twice daily, and oral acetazolamide to address the visual disturbances and high intraocular pressure. The patient is informed that these measures should result in improvement within two weeks, normalizing vision to 20/30 and intraocular pressure off medications. Follow-up is advised if symptoms worsen or if there are any concerns.

S: The patient reports experiencing numbness and weakness in the right leg, as well as dizziness and nausea. The symptoms initially improved with hormone treatment but worsened later. The patient has a medical history of hypertension, hyperthyroidism, and mammary gland hyperplasia. There is no history of diabetes, heart disease, hepatitis, tuberculosis, or drug allergy.

O: Upon physical examination, the patient showed decreased calculation capacity and instability when pointing at the nose with the right finger and during the tibial experiment. Laboratory findings included leukocyte level of 13.52 × 10^9/L, decreased glucose (2.93 mmol/L), sodium (124 mmol/L), and chlorine (87 mmol/L) levels, and decreased fibroproteinogen (1.62 g/L). CSF examination showed yellow and clear cerebrospinal fluid with 514 cells/μl and 14 leukocytes/μl, high CSF protein (82.54 mg/dl), increased 24-h IgG intrathecal synthesis rate (13.54), and negative IgG oligoclonal band. Cytokine interleukinin-10 level was 641.00 pg/ml, cytomegalovirus IgG of CSF was positive, neuronal antigen spectrum antibody IgG (CSF and blood) and tumor markers (female) were negative.

A: The patient is being assessed for concentric sclerosis with considerations of a demyelinating disease. Possible contributory factors include a positive cytomegalovirus IgG and increased intracranial IgG synthesis. Negative tumor markers and neuronal antigen antibodies help rule out other conditions.

P: Continue monitoring the patient’s condition and provide appropriate treatment based on autoimmune antibody tests and protein electrophoresis results. Manage symptoms and improve quality of life with ongoing evaluation and tailored therapy based on lab findings.

S: The patient reported developing a disseminated vesicular rash on the trunk and extremities, with approximately 40 to 50 lesions, two weeks after receiving a post-partum attenuated varicella vaccine. The lesions crusted and resolved within 10 days without complications. The patient's medical history includes splenomegaly, noted since age 5 as a sequela of infectious mononucleosis, and recurrent mild upper respiratory infections, with no hospitalizations or lymphadenopathy.

O: Tests indicated persistent leucopenia, selective IgA deficiency, and CD4 lymphopenia (111-118 cells/μL). NIH evaluation confirmed splenomegaly with a 17 cm cranio-caudal length and modest mesenteric and retroperitoneal adenopathy. Flow cytometry showed CD4 lymphopenia (189 cells/μL), normal CD8 T cells (383 cells/μL), and increased CD3+TCRαβ+CD4−CD8− double negative T cells (4.3% or 33 cells/μL). CD4 T-cells and DNT showed high cycling (Ki67 12% and 42%) and increased PD-1 expression (42%). B cell numbers were normal (CD19+ at 16.4% or 75 cells/μL). Total IgG levels were elevated at 1,716 mg/dL, while IgM levels were normal at 54 mg/dL.

A: Presumed diagnosis of Idiopathic CD4 lymphopenia (ICL).

P: The patient was referred to the NIH Clinical Center for further evaluation. The plan includes continued monitoring of the patient's condition and appropriate treatment as needed.

S: The patient, a 5-year-old girl, presented to the emergency department after suddenly losing consciousness for a few seconds. This was preceded by abdominal pain, an urge to cry, pallor, cyanosis, loss of muscle tone, and ocular revulsion. Over the past few months, she’s experienced frequent abdominal pain, short episodes of absence, a frequent cough, and reduced exercise tolerance. She has no significant personal or family medical history.

O: Upon physical examination, a systolic regurgitant murmur was noted. Lab tests indicated slight metabolic acidosis, increased Troponin T levels at 65 ng/l, elevated liver transaminases (ASAT at 82 U/l and ALAT at 48 U/l), and NT-Pro-BNP levels at 1,024 ng/l. ECG showed an incomplete right bundle branch block, compatible with right ventricular hypertrophy. Echocardiography revealed slight enlargement of the right ventricle and right atrium, tricuspid regurgitation, elevated systolic right ventricular pressure over 45 mmHg, and pulmonary artery dilatation. Follow-up Echocardiography confirmed the dilatation of the right cardiac cavities and tricuspid regurgitation III. EEG was compatible with partial epileptic seizures, but cerebral MRI showed normal results.

A: The initial diagnosis was a severe seizure equivalent with secondary pulmonary hypertension and myocardial cell damage due to hypoxemia and acidosis.

P: The patient was started on valproic acid to address the seizures. She experienced three crises while monitored, requiring intrarectal diazepam to stop seizures in two instances. Continued close monitoring of her condition and symptoms is advised, with adjustments to her treatment plan as necessary. Regular check-ups are recommended.

S: 
The patient has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, prior stress cardiomyopathy with normal coronaries, and hypertension. The patient was found down by a neighbor and brought to the emergency department, indicating an acute event leading to hospitalization.

O: 
Upon admission, an EKG showed sinus tachycardia with a heart rate of 104 beats per minute, premature atrial complexes, biatrial enlargement, right axis deviation, and prolonged QT interval. A subsequent EKG showed atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular rate and a heart rate of 147 bpm, with prolonged QT. The Troponin I level was 9 ng/ml initially and decreased to 1.5 ng/ml. A transthoracic echocardiogram showed a left ventricular ejection fraction of 55%, a left ventricle apical thrombus measuring 0.95 x 0.7 cm, regional wall motion abnormalities, hypokinetic to akinetic basal myocardial segments, an akinetic apex, and hyperdynamic midventricular segments.

A: 
The patient was assessed with reverse midvariant takotsubo cardiomyopathy, a stress-induced condition with similar symptoms to a heart attack.

P: 
The patient was started on an IV 5 mg metoprolol, an amiodarone bolus of 150 mg, an amiodarone drip, and a heparin drip due to a CHADSVASC score of 4. Post-discharge medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, metoprolol, and apixaban. There is an emphasis on the importance of a follow-up appointment for continued monitoring and management.

S: 
The patient is a 77-year-old male with a past medical history of Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma/Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma (NHL/SLL) diagnosed nearly 10 years ago. He reports abdominal swelling, altered mental status, difficulty urinating, and hematuria. The patient's Idelalisib treatment was discontinued a week prior due to pancytopenia and a mixed response on CT scan imaging.

O: 
Physical examination revealed diffuse bulky lymphadenopathy in the cervical, axillary, and inguinal areas. Laboratory results showed hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase levels. A CT scan of the head was negative for acute events. Abdominal and pelvic CT scans showed significant lymphadenopathy, including a node in the anterior para-aortic region measuring 5 cm × 5 cm × 8 cm. Bone marrow biopsy revealed a CD5 and CD23 positive B-cell population with lambda light chain restriction, consistent with CLL/SLL, and a kappa light chain restricted population of monoclonal plasma cells co-expressed with CD56.

A: 
The patient has active NHL/SLL with ongoing lymphadenopathy and metabolic disturbances contributing to altered mental status. Differential includes toxic and metabolic encephalopathy. There are also urinary complaints requiring urological assessment.

P: 
Consultation with urology is planned for urinary complaints management. A follow-up appointment with the oncologist will be arranged to discuss adjustments in the NHL treatment plan. The patient is advised to monitor his symptoms and report any changes or new symptoms immediately.

S: The patient reported no noticeable symptoms related to the nasal tumor. The patient has a history of renal cancer and underwent surgery for it 5 years ago.

O: A round tumor with a 10 mm diameter was found at the posterior end of the nasal septal mucosa. Imaging analyses, including CT and MRI, indicated a soft tissue mass at the junction of the nasal septum and roof of the nasopharynx. These images suggested a benign tumor. PET scan showed no abnormal uptake of 18F-fludeoxyglucose. Biopsy findings resembled a benign inverted ductal papilloma of the salivary glands, but a definitive diagnosis was not initially made. Hematoxylin-eosin staining of the excised tumor showed a papillary structure lined by columnar epithelium and spindle cells.

A: The tumor excised is most likely a benign inverted ductal papilloma given the imaging and pathological findings.

P: The tumor was successfully excised with a negative margin, indicating complete removal. The patient is advised to attend regular follow-up appointments to monitor recovery and check for any recurrence. The patient is expected to return to normal activities soon.

S: The patient is an 80-year-old male who presented with bilateral posterior uveitis and cystoid macular edema (CME), which began approximately 5 months after starting nivolumab (Opdivo) for metastatic cancer with an unknown primary tumor. Initially, his best corrected visual acuity (BCVA) was 20/70 in the right eye and 20/40 in the left eye. After 6 months of treatment with oral prednisone, topical difluprednate (Durezol), and nepafenac (Nevanac), the CME resolved and vision improved to 20/30 in both eyes. However, 9 months later, foveal thinning and a full-thickness macular hole (FTMH) developed, reducing BCVA to 20/60 in the left eye. Vision further decreased to 20/150 after the macular hole reopened, but spontaneously closed again, improving vision to 20/80 in the left eye.

O: Initial BCVA was 20/70 in the right eye and 20/40 in the left eye. Treatment led to vision improvement to 20/30 in both eyes. A subsequent FTMH reduced BCVA to 20/60 in the left eye. An OCT showed a closed macular hole with residual subretinal fluid. Vision decreased to 20/150 with reopening of the macular hole, then improved to 20/80 after spontaneous closure. Current stable condition with BCVA of 20/70.

A: The patient has experienced fluctuating visual acuity due to bilateral posterior uveitis, CME, and recurrent FTMH, likely related to nivolumab therapy. The spontaneous resolution of the macular hole indicates a complex case requiring careful monitoring.

P: The patient should continue monitoring vision regularly and maintain communication with the ophthalmologist. Immediate consultation is advised if there is any decrease in vision or new symptoms. Continued stability monitoring is essential given the history of variable ocular response.

S: The patient reported experiencing hemoptysis and weakness for the past 30 days. They have had discomfort in their chest and have a history of cardiac surgery for aortic coarctation at the age of 18, which had no post-operative complications. 

O: The patient was found to have severe anemia with a hemoglobin level of 6.9 g/dl and a shock index of 1.4, indicating hemodynamic instability. A chest X-ray showed no significant abnormalities. A digestive endoscopy revealed grade B esophagitis, but no evidence of recent bleeding. Fiber bronchoscopy showed limited traces of blood in the bronchial tract afferent to the left upper lobe with no active bleeding. A contrast-enhanced CT scan revealed aneurysmal dilatation of the descending thoracic aorta communicating with the left upper bronchus, leading to left upper lobe compression and ground-glass opacities.

A: The diagnostic impression included aortobronchial fistula due to the communication between the aortic aneurysm and lung parenchyma. 

P: The patient was referred to the Cardiac Intensive Care Unit, where thoracic endovascular aortic repair (TEVAR) was performed. The aortobronchial fistula was treated successfully with an endovascular stent-graft. A strict follow-up plan will be implemented to monitor recovery and ensure continued health. The patient should attend all scheduled appointments and report any new or concerning symptoms.

S: The patient, an 81-year-old Caucasian male, was diagnosed with melanoma on the right anterior chest wall and later had a recurrence in the right lung. He reported feeling weak and tired. After a second cycle of pembrolizumab, he experienced progressive weakness starting in the legs and spreading to the arms.

O: The patient had a strength of 2/5 in bilateral upper extremities and 0/5 in bilateral lower extremities, with areflexia and no bulbar muscle weakness. MRI revealed multiple metastatic lesions in the brain. A lumbar puncture showed albuminocytologic dissociation with elevated CSF protein (56 g/L), and electromyography indicated motor and sensory neuropathy. CSF cultures, VDRL, and antibodies to ganglioside GM1 were negative. The patient developed acute hypoxic respiratory failure and required mechanical ventilation. A CT scan without contrast revealed a hemorrhage in a metastatic lesion with vasogenic edema.

A: The patient was diagnosed with acute inflammatory demyelinating polyradiculopathy (AIDP) based on clinical and laboratory findings.

P: The treatment included switching to dabrafenib and trametinib, administering a second cycle of pembrolizumab, and providing methylprednisolone and IVIG treatment. After no improvement, plasmapheresis was initiated. Following a seizure, care was withdrawn due to a CT finding of hemorrhage in a metastatic brain lesion, leading to the patient's passing.

S: The patient is a 19-year-old male who presented with a one-day history of left flank pain and dysuria. He also reports mild low back pain attributed to a past car accident. There is a family history of cervical cancer in his grandmother. As a child, he had a small lump on his right forehead, which was X-rayed at the time.

O: Physical examination revealed mild tenderness to palpation on the thoracic and lumbar spine, a slightly more prominent right orbital rim, and a dark skin mark on the right front thigh along the L1-2 distribution. Initial lab tests showed bacteriuria and vitamin D deficiency. Normal results include complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, alkaline phosphatase levels, serum protein electrophoresis, and tumor markers (CEA and PSA). CT scans showed diffuse lumbar and thoracic spinal osseous lesions with osteoblastic and osteolytic features, and a small 4 mm non-specific pulmonary nodule. SPECT indicated ground-glass sclerotic lesions typical for fibrous dysplasia.

A: The primary assessment is fibrous dysplasia, a benign disease process characterized by stable sclerotic lesions. There is no indication of metastatic malignancy or primary tumor.

P: The plan includes ongoing monitoring of the patient's condition and symptom management. Regular follow-up appointments are recommended to ensure no significant changes in his condition.

S: The patient reported a huge mass in the abdomen, weight loss, nausea, and gastric compression. They were initially fearful and refused surgery. Later, they experienced an emergency situation with incarcerated hernias due to intra-abdominal hypertension, leading to the acceptance of liver surgery.

O: CT-Scan and MRI results showed aggressive disease in liver segments 2 to 8 with only a portion of the caudate lobe having visible parenchyma. The physical exam revealed a huge palpable mass involving nearly all abdominal quadrants. Regular controls showed increasing weight loss, low BMI, and severe bilateral lower limb varicose veins and edema due to IVC compression. Post-surgery, a follow-up CT-Scan showed huge hypertrophy of the remanent liver and small-sized remaining cysts.

A: The patient initially presented with progressive liver disease impacting multiple segments with symptoms consistent with advanced liver pathology. Post-operatively, the patient has shown significant improvement, with resolution of digestive symptoms, weight gain, disappearance of the abdominal mass, and lower limb edema.

P: The plan included an open liver resection and several non-anatomic resections with a bilateral sub-costal incision. A re-laparotomy was performed post-operatively for lavage due to hemorrhagic liquid and acute abdominal pain. The patient was discharged without further complications. Continued monitoring and follow-up were planned, with recent imaging showing successful surgical outcomes. The patient is advised to reach out with any concerns or questions.

S: The patient reported experiencing pain, which led to a CT scan that detected a hypervascular mass lesion in the pancreas. They were referred for a 68Ga DOTATATE PET/CT scan to identify potential metastatic disease.

O: The PET/CT scan showed a focus of uptake in the pancreas and moderate tracer uptake in several areas of the spine and right iliac wing. Further examination showed these areas exhibited characteristics of hemangiomas, not bone metastases. The CT images revealed bone demineralization with vertical striation and axial "polka-dot" appearances, indicative of benign hemangiomas.

A: The imaging findings suggest that the areas of tracer uptake in the bones are due to hemangiomas, benign vascular growths, rather than metastatic disease. The hypervascular mass lesion in the pancreas remains to be monitored.

P: The plan includes continued monitoring of the pancreatic mass lesion and the hemangiomas to ensure there are no changes. The patient should follow up with their primary care physician and schedule regular check-ups. They should also report any new or worsening symptoms to their doctor immediately. No immediate treatment or interventions are indicated based on the current imaging findings.

S: The patient is a 63-year-old Japanese man with no prior medical history who presented with right-sided pleuritic chest pain and fever. After initial treatment for bacterial pneumonia with ceftriaxone, the fever of 39°C persisted.

S: The patient reports a swelling on the left side of the neck which has been present for the past few months and causes discomfort.

P: Treatment with liquid nitrogen cryotherapy for actinic keratoses will be applied. The patient should continue their current regimen for psoriasis and monitor for any changes in skin condition. Follow-up should be scheduled as needed, or earlier if the patient experiences changes or new concerns.

S: The patient reports having a painless, firm, and immobile mass on the right side of the scrotum for about a year, which has been slowly increasing in size. The patient expresses concerns about the nature and significance of the masses found during the examination.

O: A CT scan revealed a right inguinal hernia with intraperitoneal fat extending into the scrotal sac and a 14 × 10.5 cm membranous sac, which was excised. The sac contained multiple lobulated masses tracking along the spermatic cord. Microscopic examination showed mature adipose tissue, myxoid areas, adipocytes with variations, arborizing capillaries, lipoblasts, and atypical spindle cells. A PET scan follow-up showed a nonhypermetabolic fatty mass along the distal anterior aspect of the right psoas, indicating a retroperitoneal component.

A: The diagnosis is well-differentiated liposarcoma mixed type, including lipoma-like and sclerosing type, grade 1.

P: The patient will be referred to a specialist to discuss treatment options, which may include surgery, radiation, or chemotherapy. A specific treatment plan will be developed based on further evaluation.

S: The patient reports decreased vision in the right eye and pain around the eye for about a week. There was a subsequent second attack of right optic neuritis with decreased vision after tapering prednisolone.

O: An ophthalmological exam showed the right eye has light perception only, a best-corrected visual acuity of light perception/0.9, a relative afferent pupillary defect of grade 3, diffuse disc swelling, and inferior disc hemorrhage. Neurological exam revealed normal muscle strength, no sensory deficits, and normoactive deep tendon reflexes. MRI showed T2 high signal intensities and diffuse contrast enhancement of right optic nerve and perineural enhancement. CSF analysis showed red blood cell count of 0/μL, white blood cell count of 1/μL, protein level of 27 mg/dL, negative oligoclonal bands, and IgG index of 0.64. Serum AQP4-IgG was negative. Post-treatment, right visual acuity improved but decreased again after a second attack. Retinal nerve fiber layer thickness decreased in the right eye.

A: Right optic neuritis suspected. A confirmed decrease in retinal nerve fiber layer thickness and vision loss is noted, with a second attack indicating recurrence.

P: Initiate treatment with azathioprine 50 mg twice per day between attacks. Patient was previously treated with intravenous methylprednisolone for 5 days, followed by tapering oral prednisolone. Monitor condition regularly and adjust treatment as needed based on clinical and imaging findings.

S: The parent reports their 24-month-old daughter experienced a fever for 10 days, with worsening health over the past 3 days, including symptoms of adynamia, pallor, inappetence, oliguria, and choluria.

O: Upon examination, the child appeared lethargic, discolored (4+/4+), hypoactive, with a radiograph suggesting pneumonia. A complete blood count showed marked anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated hepatic enzymes. Abdominal ultrasonography revealed hepatosplenomegaly. Diagnostic tests confirmed Visceral Leishmaniasis (VL), and serology screening was positive for cytomegalovirus (CMV) IgG and IgM antibodies. Liver function tests showed severe injury: ALT 354 IU/mL, AST elevated, hyperbilirubinemia, hypoalbuminemia, and increased canalicular enzymes.

A: The diagnostic impression is Visceral Leishmaniasis, confirmed by parasitology, indirect fluorescent antibody test, and rK39 rapid test, alongside cytomegalovirus infection. Severe liver injury is present.

P: The plan includes ongoing monitoring of liver function, supportive care to manage symptoms, treatment of CMV infection, and addressing any arising complications. Follow-up appointments are essential to assess progress and recovery.

S: The patient is a 5-week-old boy admitted for jaundice and failure to thrive. He was delivered by Cesarean section at 38 weeks of gestation. His Apgar score was 9/9, birth weight was 2600 g, length 49 cm, and cranial circumference 32.5 cm. He was discharged in satisfactory condition on the 4th day of life. The parent reports he has had hypocholic stools. There is no family history of diabetes, hepatic, or renal disease. He has a healthy 8-year-old brother.

O: Physical examination shows skin and scleral jaundice. Blood tests confirm cholestatic jaundice: total bilirubin 11.95 mg/dL, conjugated bilirubin 6.69 mg/dL, gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase 221 U/L. Routine screening reveals minor pulmonary artery stenosis, a possible thoracic butterfly hemivertebra, and hyperechogenic kidneys with multiple bilateral cortical cysts. Renal function tests show serum creatinine 0.59 mg/dL, eGFR 35 ml/min/1.73m², metabolic acidosis, and tubular proteinuria. The patient experiences polyuria at 7 mL/Kg/h.

A: The patient has cholestatic jaundice, impaired renal function categorized as Chronic Kidney Disease KDIGO stage 3, metabolic acidosis, and tubular proteinuria. Pulmonary artery stenosis and possible thoracic butterfly hemivertebra were noted. Cholestatic disease screening was mostly negative.

P: Continue monitoring renal function and jaundice. Provide fat-soluble vitamins supplementation and feed with cow's milk with highly hydrolyzed proteins enriched with medium chain triglycerides. Monitor growth and development and provide appropriate medical support as needed.

S: The patient is a 22-year-old unmarried South Asian female experiencing issues with her right eye for the past four months. She initially had a headache lasting one day, followed by noticing metamorphopsia in her right eye, where straight lines appear wavy. She has refractive errors with a dioptre sphere of -1.00 in the right eye and -0.50 in the left eye for the past three years. Her sleep is normal. There is no history of ocular trauma, other health issues, comorbid conditions, significant past medical or surgical history, drug use, allergies, addiction, or blood transfusions.

O: The examination revealed best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) of 6/24 in the right eye and visual acuity of 6/18 with BCVA of 6/6 in the left eye. Fundus examination showed 2+ vitreous cells and a slightly elevated area of yellow-white active retinitis of two to three disc diameters over the macula in the right eye. Fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) displayed a hyperfluorescent patch of increasing intensity located 2DD temporal to the optic disc in the right eye. An axial optical coherence tomography (OCT) scan indicated an irregular, thick surface of the retina with a loss of foveal contour and pigment epithelial detachment in the right eye, suggestive of a choroidal neovascular membrane. Optical coherence tomography angiography (OCTA) revealed a patch of abnormally dilated, hyperfluorescent vessels at the outer retina level in the right eye.

A: The findings suggest the presence of a choroidal neovascular membrane in the right eye, with no indications of systemic Toxoplasma infection or other systemic issues.

P: The plan involves monitoring the condition and discussing treatment options for the choroidal neovascular membrane. The patient is advised to attend follow-up appointments to track progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, who has a 10-year history of kidney failure and multiple myeloma, reported having difficulty swallowing and breathing. They denied experiencing symptoms of systemic amyloidosis or any signs of hypo- or hyper-thyroidism.

O: Upon examination, significant neck swelling was noted. Ultrasound revealed an increased thyroid gland volume with measurements of 49 × 38 × 100 mm for the right lobe and 41 × 34 × 51 mm for the left, with mediastinal involvement but no cervical lymphadenopathy. CT and MRI indicated diffuse and multinodular enlargement reaching C2 and the brachio-cephalic trunk. Fine needle aspiration of a 2 cm nodule revealed colloid and histiocytes. The post-operative findings included a diffusely enlarged thyroid with nodular, salmon-colored parenchyma and fibro-sclerotic changes. Negative/weak PAS staining, with Rosso Congo showing apple-green birefringence, indicated amyloid presence.

A: The final diagnosis is "amyloid goiter" based on the morphological and histochemical features observed.

P: The patient underwent a total thyroidectomy with an unremarkable post-operative course and no complications. The removal of the thyroid gland should lead to symptom improvement.

S: Mary Smith, a 28-year-old female, reports having an unusual headache that started yesterday around mid-morning. The headache is located on the left side at the back of her head and described as intense and throbbing, reaching a pain level of 8 out of 10. She has no history of headaches, and no associated symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, blurred vision, fever, or rash. She has been eating and drinking normally and denies any medical conditions, medications, or allergies. Her mother's medical history includes hypertension and migraines. Mary has found it difficult to work due to the headache but has not missed any work. No recent stressors, lifestyle, or dietary changes noted.

O: No observable findings or vitals provided.

A: New-onset acute headache without previous history, possibly tension-type or related to early signs of migraine, given family history. No red flag symptoms currently present.

P: Recommend trying a stronger pain relief, similar to Ibuprofen, and taking Paracetamol. Advise taking medication with food. Encourage rest and adequate hydration. If the headache worsens, or new symptoms such as fever, rash, or vomiting occur, patient should call back. Follow-up if not improved in the next day or two after trying prescribed medication.

S: The patient reports experiencing nausea, vomiting, and a weight loss of 7 kg over the past month. She has a history of Pica disorder since the age of 2 and trichophagia.

O: During the physical examination, the patient appeared pale, but her vital signs were stable. A large, firm, hard mass was found in the epigastric and left upper quadrant areas during the abdominal exam. Blood tests, including a complete blood count, electrolytes, BUN, creatinine, liver function tests, amylase, and lipase were unremarkable. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis revealed a large, multi-layered, heterogeneous, solid mass measuring 30 × 17 × 12 cm in the gastric lumen. The EGD showed a large, hard hairball occupying the entire stomach length.

A: The findings are consistent with a trichobezoar (hairball) in the stomach, causing the observed gastrointestinal symptoms.

P: A surgical intervention was planned and performed with a midline laparotomy and a 7 cm longitudinal gastrotomy to remove the trichobezoar. The gastrostomy site was repaired, and the abdominal incision was closed. Post-operatively, the patient will stay in the hospital for recovery and be closely monitored to ensure proper healing and address any further recommendations as needed.

S: The patient is a 22-year-old female diagnosed with lower extremity CRPS type-I in the left ankle and foot following the IASP Budapest Criteria. She has no history of psychological disorders, seizure disorders, or neurological abnormalities. The patient reports experiencing a tremor in the ipsilateral quadriceps muscles when the left knee is fully extended, but no other involuntary motor movements have been noted.

O: During the physical examination, contracture of the left foot in a plantar-flexed position is observed. A reproducible tremor is noted in the ipsilateral quadriceps muscles. The patient received a diagnostic left lumbar sympathetic block (LSB) followed by five additional LSBs, with local anesthesia and pre-procedural sedation with lorazepam 1.5 mg orally. For the 6th block, DPH 50 mg IV was administered prophylactically. No paresthesia was experienced during needle advancement. Negative aspiration for blood and cerebrospinal fluid was confirmed before injecting Iohexol contrast. Bupivacaine was injected in 1 mL increments after negative aspiration, with monitoring of temperature measurements.

A: The patient has CRPS type-I in the left lower extremity, characterized by a tremor in the ipsilateral quadriceps and plantar-flexed contracture of the foot.

P: The patient is advised to monitor symptoms and report any changes or concerns. A follow-up appointment is recommended to assess progress and determine the necessity for further treatment.

S:  
The patient was admitted with shortness of breath and is still experiencing breathing difficulties. They have a past medical history of hypertension, hypothyroidism, GERD, venous leg ulcers (VLUs), and ambulatory dysfunction. Surgical history includes back surgery, fracture surgery, hysterectomy, and partial thyroidectomy. The patient is aware of a deteriorating ulcer on the right lower extremity.

O:  
The patient exhibited septic shock indicated by hypoxia, tachycardia, hypotension, and non-responsiveness to fluids. They were intubated due to respiratory distress. A large ulcer was found on the distal aspect of the right lower extremity, described as 10 x 16 x 1.5 cm with 20% brown tissue, 40% pink tissue, and 40% tan tissue, covered in fibrotic slough with pitting and woody edema. Malodor was present. Intravenous antibiotics (cefepime, clindamycin, vancomycin) were administered, and a wound care treatment was initiated using ROCT-CC and NPWTi-d with Dakin's solution.

A:  
The patient is experiencing septic shock with associated respiratory distress and a complicated ulcer on the right lower extremity. The condition is compounded by a history of hypertension, hypothyroidism, GERD, VLUs, and ambulatory dysfunction. The ulcer has worsened, and the current medical condition precludes discharge.

P:  
Continue IV antibiotics pending wound culture results. Maintain the ROCT-CC and NPWTi-d treatment with Dakin’s solution on the ulcer. Monitor the patient's stability and response to treatments, with continued care in the medical intensive care unit. Surgical intervention is deferred until the patient is stable. Regular consultation with the WOCN and plastic surgery teams for wound management. Adjust treatment protocols as necessary based on progress and response.

S:  
The patient is an 18-year-old male experiencing seizures for the past 3 months. Seizure episodes begin with blurring of vision, head deviation to the right side, right upper limb tonic posturing, leading to generalized tonic-clonic seizures with loss of consciousness. Postictal symptoms include suboccipital and frontal tension headache. He reports no fever, weight loss, trauma, sensory or motor issues, nor any significant family or surgical history.

O:  
Physical examinations were normal with no signs of neurofibromatosis. A brain MRI showed a right parieto-occipital cortical and subcortical mass lesion (1.5 x 1.5 cm) with specific signal patterns and enhancement after gadolinium, significant vasogenic edema, and mass effect. Surgical findings included a firm, fibrous, yellowish subcortical tumor, resembling meningioma. Post-surgery, the patient had no new neurological deficits.

A:  
The radiological and surgical findings suggest a possible diagnosis of schwannoma with a differential of meningioma. Prior considerations included granulomatous infection or metastasis, but a preoperative diagnosis was inconclusive.

P:  
Recommend a follow-up appointment in 2 months. Prescribe phenytoin 100 mg orally three times a day to manage seizures. Additionally, take Paracetamol 6 as needed for any pain or discomfort.

S: The patient reports worsening vision over the past few years with current vision at 20/400 in both eyes. The patient has a history of bilateral juvenile open-angle glaucoma (JOAG) and high myopia (−8.0D), diagnosed in 2012 at age 16. Previously treated with dorzolamide 2%, latanoprost 0.005%, brimonidine 0.2%/timolol 0.5% fixed combination, and oral acetazolamide 500 mg/day, but intraocular pressure (IOP) was poorly controlled at around 25 mmHg. The patient stopped anti-glaucoma treatment a few months ago.

O: Gonioscopy revealed a normal iridocorneal angle. Pachymetric measurements were 611 μm in the right eye and 614 μm in the left eye. Axial length was 27.56 mm in the right eye and 27.46 mm in the left eye. Fundoscopic examination showed bilateral enlarged disc cupping with sectorial excavation and reduction of the neural rim in the left eye. OCTA revealed RNFL thinning in several areas of both eyes and decreased vascularity of peripapillary capillaries with 43.6% in the right eye and 49.15% in the left eye. Visual field test showed progressive central scotoma in both eyes.

A: The clinical findings indicate bilateral progressive central scotoma with inadequately controlled JOAG and optic nerve damage due to RNFL thinning and reduced vascularity.

P: The doctor plans to perform an electroretinogram (ERG) for further assessment of the patient's eye condition. The patient is advised to resume glaucoma treatment to help control intraocular pressure, with an adjustment in medication as needed. Close monitoring of the patient's condition and timely follow-up appointments are crucial, along with immediate reporting of any changes in vision or symptoms.

S: The patient experienced severe abdominal pain due to a blockage in the intestines, leading to a small bowel resection at a rural hospital. The patient was transferred for further care and was diagnosed with a floating mass involving the descending thoracic aorta. This was identified as idiopathic thoracic aortic thrombosis. Post-surgery, within three weeks, metastatic liver disease was discovered.

O: The patient underwent a procedure to replace the affected part of the DTA with full cardiopulmonary bypass under deep hypothermic circulatory arrest. During the surgery, access was established with inflow cannulation of the left carotid and left femoral artery and outflow cannulation of the left femoral vein. The aorta was filled with gelatinous material, diagnosed as a high-grade myxoid intimal aortic sarcoma. Postoperative recovery was slow but no cerebrovascular accidents were noted. Three weeks post-surgery, diffuse metastatic liver disease was identified.

A: Idiopathic thoracic aortic thrombosis, high-grade myxoid intimal aortic sarcoma, and diffuse metastatic liver disease.

P: Due to the patient's overall health decline and discovery of metastatic liver disease, the recommendation is to transfer the patient to hospice care for supportive care and management. No further adjuvant treatment is feasible.

S: The patient reports experiencing chest pain and shortness of breath. They have a history of dilated ischemic cardiomyopathy and underwent triple coronary artery bypass grafting in 1990. Recently, they had a Non-ST segment elevation myocardial infarction.

O: Coronary angiography revealed complete occlusion of the native coronary circulation at the proximal segments. The baseline GFR was 45 ml/min/1.73 m². Hs-Troponin T was 497 ng/l, and CK-MB was 211 U/l. There were tandem calcified lesions of the saphenous vein graft on the distal right coronary artery and an ostial stenosis of the SVG on the first obtuse marginal branch. The left internal mammary artery on the mid left anterior descending artery was patent.

A: The patient’s native coronary circulation is completely occluded. Tandem calcified lesions and ostial stenosis of the SVG contribute to the symptoms. An attempted PCI was initially suboptimal. Elective PCI with rotational atherectomy and drug-eluting stent placement was performed to improve blood flow.

P: The patient should be closely monitored during recovery and adhere to a proper medication regimen to prevent further complications. Follow-up appointments will be necessary to evaluate the effectiveness of the stent and the patient's recovery progress.

S: The patient is a 42-year-old obese African American male who has presented with new onset right-sided chest pain and a palpable lump on the chest. He has a history of diabetes, hypertension, heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, coronary arterial disease, and atrial fibrillation. Two months after initial evaluation, he reports the chest mass has been growing rapidly with increased pain and new onset chest wall numbness.

O: Initial imaging with ultrasound and CT scan revealed an anterior right chest mass (7.5 × 6.5 × 4.8 cm, 0.6 cm deep to the skin). CT scan showed a 9x9x9cm necrotic mass arising from the pectoralis major. A CT-guided core biopsy identified a high-grade spindle cell neoplasm. Upon follow-up, a CT scan and MRI identified mass enlargement to 21.4 × 17.8 × 13.7 cm (23 cm on MRI) within the right pectoralis major, without vascular or bony invasion or metastatic spread. Restaging CT after chemotherapy and radiation showed a stable tumor at 23 cm.

A: The patient has a high-grade spindle cell neoplasm of the pectoralis major, significant for rapid growth and symptom progression. Multiple comorbidities exist, and neoadjuvant chemotherapy was recommended and completed.

P: Initiate a neoadjuvant chemotherapy regimen with gemcitabine and docetaxel for 2 cycles, followed by radiation therapy (50Gy over 2 months to the tumor bed + 3 cm margins). After completion of therapy, discuss and plan for wide local surgical resection with the Thoracic Surgery clinic. The patient is now considering surgical resection as a definitive therapy, including removal en bloc with resection to the intercostal fascia, involving pectoralis major and minor. Continue multidisciplinary care with Oncology and Thoracic Surgery.

S: The patient reports a cough, rhinorrhea, sore throat, loss of appetite, and anterior cervical pain that started on the left side and moved to the right side. The patient denies family history of autoimmune thyroid diseases and is not taking any medications. No concerns about current medications or other family history provided.

O: The patient is 145 cm tall and weighs 40 kg. Blood pressure is 137/81 mmHg, pulse rate is 116 beats/min, and body temperature is 37.0°C. An electrocardiogram shows sinus tachycardia. Laboratory data reveals normal white cell count (8,290 cells/µL), slightly elevated C-reactive protein (3.94 mg/dL), elevated alkaline phosphatase (460 U/L), elevated thyroid hormones (free triiodothyronine at 20.27 pg/mL, free thyroxine at 6.53 ng/dL, thyroglobulin at 183 ng/mL), and undetectable TSH. Thyroid ultrasonography shows heterogeneous and hypoechoic areas. Subsequent tests show strong anti-TSH receptor antibody and anti-thyroid-stimulating antibody positivity. After treatment, improved thyroid hormone levels, ultrasonography shows hypervascularity, fewer hypoechoic areas, but worsened liver function.

A: The clinical findings suggest subacute thyroiditis. Initial treatment with prednisolone improved symptoms but led to strong antibody positivity and ongoing thyroid hormone elevation. Methimazole treatment improved thyroid hormone levels but caused liver function deterioration.

P: Initiate treatment with prednisolone (20 mg/day) for subacute thyroiditis, then taper dosage. Start combination of prednisolone (10 mg/day) and methimazole (10 mg/day) for four weeks. Discontinue methimazole due to worsened liver function. Continue monitoring thyroid hormone levels and liver function closely. Adjust treatment based on follow-up evaluations. Regular follow-up is advised to ensure patient health improvement.

S: The patient, who has a solitary right kidney, reports experiencing right lower quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, decreased urination, and dysuria. There is no history of kidney stones. 

O: The physical examination revealed right lower quadrant tenderness and right costovertebral angle tenderness. Vital signs showed hypotension with a blood pressure of 77/46, tachycardia at 117 beats per minute, and tachypnea at 22 breaths per minute. The patient was afebrile but had a high leukocyte count of 24,190/μL, creatinine of 3.90 mg/dL, and lactic acid of 7.49 mg/dL. Urinalysis found 30 WBCs and 6 RBCs per HPF, positive leukocyte esterase, and negative nitrites. Urine culture grew Klebsiella pneumoniae. A CT scan showed an atrophic left kidney and a 4 mm stone in the right ureterovesical junction causing mild hydroureteronephrosis, suggestive of pyelonephritis.

A: The patient was assessed with an infection of the solitary right kidney, likely pyelonephritis, with a 4 mm stone causing blockage. There was concern for sepsis due to the patient's SOFA score being >2 and bloodstream infection with Klebsiella.

P: An emergent cystoscopy with right ureteral stent placement was performed to relieve the blockage. The patient was started on piperacillin-tazobactam. Intraoperative findings included purulent discharge from the right ureteral orifice. Postoperative management included vasopressors for persistent hypotension and tailoring antibiotics based on blood cultures. After decompression and continued IV antibiotics, subsequent cultures were negative. A URS-LL and right ureteral stent placement with string were performed, followed by laser lithotripsy to remove the stone. The patient will continue to be monitored for recovery with follow-up care as needed.

S:  
The patient is a 20-year-old female with a history of primary amenorrhoea, indicating she has never had a menstrual period. She has developed all secondary sexual characteristics. She has been referred for further evaluation due to her amenorrhoea.

O:  
Physical examination reveals fully developed secondary sexual characteristics. Abdominal sonography shows normal upper abdominal organs. Pelvic sonography indicates complete non-visualization of the uterus, cervix, and vagina, with ovaries located in the bilateral inguinal canals. A Doppler study shows no significant vascular compromise in the ovaries. Further imaging including CT urography and MRI confirm complete agenesis of the uterus, cervix, and vagina, and bilateral ovarian hernias. There is bilateral ureterocele noted, but kidneys are normal in size, morphology, and location. A genetic karyotyping test shows a 46XX chromosome pattern.

A:  
The patient has been diagnosed with Type I Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome, associated with bilateral ovarian hernias, and bilateral ureteroceles.

P:  
The patient is advised to consult with a specialist to discuss appropriate management and treatment options tailored to her case. Further questions or concerns should be addressed with the specialist to guide her through the available options. Follow-up with the specialist is recommended.

S: The patient is a 15-month-old boy with no significant medical history. Presenting today at the Burn Centre due to a scald burn from hot milk, which occurred after he accidentally pulled a tablecloth causing a mug of just-boiled milk to spill on him. The parent reports that he was struggling with breathing earlier.

O: Upon examination, the patient has mixed deep second-degree burns to the lips, chin, neck, chest, left arm, and left foot, covering 12% of his total body surface area (neck 1%, chest 4%, face 3%, foot 1%, left arm 3%). Initial treatment by Helicopter Emergency Medical Services (HEMS) included intravenous rehydration using the Parkland formula, intravenous analgesics (fentanyl, paracetamol), and supplemental oxygen via non-rebreathing mask at 12 L/min. Breathing assessment revealed progressive stridor and laboured breathing. Oxygen saturation dropped to 80% despite maximal supplemental oxygen administration. Blistering noted on the lower lip with no intra-oral redness or swelling. Circulation is intact.

A: The patient exhibits mixed deep second-degree burns and respiratory distress characterized by persistent stridor and low oxygen saturation despite maximal oxygen supplementation. No intra-oral edema suggests the airway is not compromised by swelling, but severe respiratory distress indicates possible underlying complications due to burn inhalation injury or other factors.

P: The plan is to closely monitor the patient’s respiratory status and provide necessary interventions to ensure airway patency and adequate oxygenation. Further assessment and treatment options will be discussed as needed based on the patient’s progress. The clinical team will continue to manage pain and fluid resuscitation according to burn management protocols.

S: The patient is a 72-year-old man presenting with dysphagia, or trouble swallowing, which led to his hospital admission.

O: During hospitalization, a gastroscopy revealed a large submucous eminence lesion 18-24 cm from the incisors. CT examination showed a 1.8 cm × 5.2 cm × 2.9 cm soft tissue mass in the upper esophageal wall. Endoscopic ultrasonography indicated the lesion was hypoechoic, originating from the muscularis propria with clear boundaries. 

A: The pathological diagnosis of the tumor was leiomyoma.

P: The patient underwent endoscopic submucosal excavation (ESE) as he opted for it over invasive surgical resection. The procedure involved a full-thickness resection with the use of a LeCamp™ endoloop for suturing and closure of the perforation. Postoperative recovery was uneventful, monitored for 2 months with no esophageal stricture observed. The patient will continue to receive follow-up care.

S: The patient reports recurrent chest pain and transient syncope beginning nine months ago, described as burning pain on the right side of the chest and back, accompanied by sweating, fatigue, and dizziness. The patient also has a history of recurrent periorbital nodules and a submaxillary mass over the past 12 years, with multiple surgeries and biopsies revealing inflammatory pseudotumor, dacryoadenitis, and reactive lymph node hyperplasia. There is an improvement in symptoms with steroid treatment, though detailed treatment records are unavailable. The patient denies any history of hypertension, diabetes, hepatitis, tuberculosis, smoking, or drug use. Today, the patient experienced another episode of chest pain, sweating, and transient syncope.

O: The patient was initially found with hypotension (blood pressure of 85/50 mmHg) and a drop in hemoglobin level from 93 g/L to 50 g/L. A thoracic ultrasound showed right-sided pleural effusion with septa and a chest CT revealed right-sided encapsulated pleural effusion. Today, the physical examination showed blood pressure of 110/61 mmHg, a normal electrocardiogram, decreased hemoglobin level from 121 g/L to 71 g/L, anemia, scars, and yellowish nodules on the skin.

A: The differential diagnosis for the patient's symptoms includes recurrent pleural effusion of unclear etiology, inflammatory pseudotumor, anemia of unknown origin, and recurrent syncope possibly related to underlying hematologic or autonomic dysfunction.

P: Plan includes additional diagnostic tests to determine the underlying cause of chest pain, syncope, and anemia. Supportive treatment to manage symptoms will be continued, and fluid resuscitation may be required. The patient will be carefully monitored, and findings from further testing will guide specific treatment interventions. Follow-up to track symptom progression and response to treatment will be necessary.

S: The patient presented with sudden onset of diffuse abdominal pain that started in the morning and worsened throughout the day. The pain is described as a constant pressure. The patient has a history of recurrent episodes of gonococcal urethritis but no other major ailments.

O: The patient is hemodynamically stable. Lab results show leukocytosis at 11,200 and a positive urinalysis. A CT scan revealed mild telescoping of loops of the small bowel and mesenteric fat in the left mid abdomen, with no bowel obstruction or definitive masses. A diagnostic laparoscopy identified intussusception of the mid jejunum. Pathology showed marked congestion and focal reactive lymphoid hyperplasia in the lamina propria of the invaginated bowel.

A: The diagnostic impression is intussusception of the mid jejunum, accompanied by inflammation and congestion, confirmed by pathology and exploratory laparoscopy findings.

P: The patient underwent open exploration, segmental resection, and primary anastomosis of the jejunum. The patient will be discharged on postoperative day 2, provided follow-up remains unremarkable. The patient is instructed to follow postoperative care instructions and report any unusual symptoms or concerns.

S: The patient reports feeling worried about their prehepatic portal hypertension caused by portal vein thrombosis. They have experienced two episodes of acute pancreatitis with severe abdominal pain and sickness, the onset of which was at 9.7 years old. The patient denies any recent injuries or other health problems and is not aware of any family history of pancreatitis.

O: An abdominal ultrasound has shown chronic pancreatitis, a heterogeneous pancreas, and a dilated pancreatic duct. There are no identified risk factors of pancreatitis such as injury, anatomical anomalies, toxic-metabolic disorders, or biliary disease. Genetic testing revealed a heterozygous c.568G>A (p.Glu190Lys) variant in the PRSS1 gene. No other pathogenic variants in susceptibility genes were found.

A: The patient has portal vein thrombosis-induced prehepatic portal hypertension and chronic pancreatitis with episodes of acute pancreatitis. The genetic finding of the PRSS1 p.Glu190Lys variant may contribute to the patient's condition.

P: The plan includes scheduling regular check-ups to monitor the pancreas and hypertension. Lifestyle recommendations include avoiding alcohol and maintaining a low-fat diet. The patient is advised to report any new or worsening symptoms immediately. The uncertain significance of the genetic variant will be noted, and monitoring will continue.

S:  
The patient was diagnosed with IgG lambda multiple myeloma (MM) in November 2007 and initially received lenalidomide and dexamethasone as front-line treatment. The patient experienced a relapse and subsequently underwent multiple lines of chemotherapy. The patient has been previously treated with pomalidomide.

O:  
RNA analysis of the patient's CD138+ cells revealed activation of the HDAC pathway. Prior to current treatment, IgG levels were elevated at 2,910 mg/dL and free lambda light chains at 141 mg/dL. After starting the treatment, IgG levels decreased to 785 mg/dL and free lambda light chains to 19.16 mg/dL.

A:  
The patient's multiple myeloma appears to be responding to the current treatment regimen, evidenced by reduced IgG and lambda light chain levels. The activation of the HDAC pathway and the effectiveness of vorinostat as an HDAC inhibitor were identified through RNA analysis and drug repurposing.

P:  
Continue with venetoclax 400 mg PO once daily, panobinostat 20 mg on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday, 2 weeks on with 1 week off, and pomalidomide 2 mg Monday to Friday, 3 weeks on with 1 week off. Monitor the patient's progress and IgG/lambda levels. The patient should report any side effects or issues experienced during treatment.

S: The patient, Sharon, reports right shoulder pain that began three weeks ago after falling while painting on a ladder. She experienced initial numbness and tingling, but not currently. Pain level is described as a 6/10 without medication and 4/10 with ibuprofen. The pain persists all the time with intermittent intensity and increases with movements such as lifting the arm overhead. This is the first occurrence of such pain.

O: The physical exam reveals limited active and passive range of motion in the right shoulder with tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. Vitals are normal. Right shoulder X-ray shows no fracture or bony abnormalities. Neurovascular exam indicates brisk capillary refill and equal bilateral sensation in the arms.

A: The clinical impression is rotator cuff tendinopathy in the right shoulder due to tendon injury.

P: Plan includes ordering an MRI of the right shoulder, referral to physical therapy for six to eight weeks, and the continuation of NSAIDs or Tylenol if tolerated. A follow-up appointment is scheduled in two weeks to evaluate progress and consider further treatment options such as a steroid injection if necessary.

S: 
The patient reports generalized body weakness and anorexia. They have a history of hypertension and chronic kidney disease.

O: 
The patient is found to have severe hyponatremia with a sodium level of 116 mmol/L, hypokalemia with a potassium level of 2.8 mmol/L, hypomagnesemia with a magnesium level of 1.2 mg/dL, and elevated ionized calcium at 1.82 mmol/L. The serum PTH level is significantly elevated at 3071.90 pg/mL, and the serum vitamin D level is within the normal range at 35.52 ng/mL. Parathyroid scintigraphy shows a large focus of increased tracer activity in the inferior pole of the right lobe, suggesting a parathyroid adenoma. Additionally, a fainter focus of tracer uptake is noted in a soft tissue mass on the lateral aspect of the 7th right rib.

A: 
The findings suggest primary hyperparathyroidism likely due to a parathyroid adenoma. There is also an incidental finding of a soft tissue mass near the 7th right rib that requires further investigation.

P: 
The case will be discussed with a multidisciplinary team to determine the best course of action, which may include surgery to remove the parathyroid adenoma. The patient's electrolyte levels will be carefully monitored, and further investigation of the thoracic soft tissue mass will be undertaken. The patient will be kept informed and involved in the decision-making process.

S: The patient reports a 2-year history of sporadic abdominal pain, which became sharp and frequent, primarily in the left lower abdomen, during the past week. The patient denies any nausea, vomiting, or abdominal trauma. The patient has a congenital anomaly of the kidneys and uterus and does not menstruate. The patient had a previous appendectomy.

O: During the physical examination, the patient was afebrile. A mass measuring approximately 4 × 5 cm was palpated in the left lower quadrant, without rebound tenderness or muscle rigidity. Laboratory results showed a white blood cell count of 7.13 × 10^9/L, neutrophilic granulocytes at 76.8%, hemoglobin at 120 g/L, and a platelet count of 322 × 10^9/L. CT and radiography indicated an intestinal stromal tumor and pelvic kidneys with possible extraintestinal involvement. Abdominal laparotomy revealed a normal intestinal tract, but a mass in the sigmoid flexure was found, exophytic and measuring 6.0 × 5.0 × 3.0 cm. It was excised, and pathologic examination identified it as a solitary fibrous tumor (SFT). A colon anastomosis was performed, and the patient fully recovered in 7 days post-operatively. The final diagnosis was an ectopic ovary with corpora lutea bleeding.

A: The patient was diagnosed with an intestinal stromal tumor, which was later confirmed as a solitary fibrous tumor upon pathologic examination. The final diagnosis was an ectopic ovary with corpora lutea bleeding.

P: The plan included excision of the tumor and a portion of the colon, followed by a colon anastomosis. The patient recovered well with no post-operative complications and was advised to undertake regular follow-up visits. At the 11-month follow-up, the patient was doing well and is instructed to report any new symptoms or issues. Regular check-ups are recommended to monitor recovery.

S: The patient reported experiencing right-sided lumbago for about a month. There was a concern regarding the lower echo mass found in the lower pole of the right kidney, identified through B mode ultrasonography.

O: The ultrasonography showed a 5.4 × 4.8 cm irregularly shaped tumor with no clear boundary and uneven internal echo. A CT scan revealed a round tumor measuring 5.2 × 4.9 cm with a clear boundary and uneven density. After performing a laparoscopic radical nephrectomy, the tumor exhibited pigmentation and had a clear boundary. Immunohistochemistry tests were positive for HMB45, Melan-A, S100, Ki67, and TFE3.

A: The tumor was diagnosed as a translocation of XP11.2 tumor associated with pigment differentiation, characterized by low malignant biological behavior.

P: The tumor was successfully removed, and due to its low malignant nature, aggressive treatment was not necessary. The patient has been monitored for 3 months post-operation with no recurrence of the tumor and no additional treatment required. Regular follow-ups will continue to monitor the patient's health.

S: The patient is a chef who suffered an injury a year ago involving a meat chopper, resulting in the amputation of the middle, ring, and little fingers on the left hand. The middle and ring fingers were amputated at the level of the proximal phalanx, and the little finger at the middle phalanx. The patient experiences phantom pain with a VAS score of 4/10 and a Quick-DASH score of 81.82/100.00, with no changes in pain or function since the injury. The patient has been referred for hand reconstruction using bilateral second toe transfer to the middle and ring fingers.

O: Radiographic images confirmed the initial clinical findings of the hand injury. A preoperative VAS score of 4/10 and Quick-DASH score of 81.82/100.00 were noted. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography of the foot showed that bilateral second toe transfer (STT) is suitable for reconstruction.

A: The patient has consistent phantom pain and functional impairment following the traumatic amputation of three fingers. Reconstructive surgery is planned to restore function to the middle and ring fingers using bilateral second toe transfer.

P: The plan involves reconstructive surgery where the patient's bilateral second toes will be transferred to the middle and ring fingers. Initial steps include surgical incisions and identification of key structures in both the hand and foot, followed by the disarticulation and transfer of the second toes, with vascular and nerve connections. Postoperative recovery will include physical therapy to regain function and manage pain, with ongoing monitoring and adjustments as needed.

S: The patient, a 19-year-old Japanese woman, reports a history of dull pain following a root canal treatment on tooth #47 in 2005 which persisted even after the extraction of tooth #48 in August 2010. In August 2015, she experienced purulent discharge from the pocket of tooth #47. After the extraction of tooth #47 and associated treatment in 2015, her pain resolved. In March 2016, she noticed expansion of the right posterior mandibular bone, which remains a concern despite feeling okay overall. She denies any recent discomfort or other symptoms.

O: The patient has a low body mass index of 17.0 but is in good nutritional health. Blood test and chest X-ray are normal. There is no lymphadenopathy or nerve paralysis. Clinical exam reveals slight bulging of the right inferior mandibular border. The socket of tooth #47 is epithelialized, and tooth #46 is vital with a pocket depth of 3 mm. Panoramic radiography shows new bone formation where teeth #48 and #47 were and a radiolucent area around the distal root of tooth #46. CT scan indicates continuous absorption from the alveolar bone of tooth #46 to the lingual cortical bone at tooth #47, along with six granulated hard tissues. MRI shows low intensity in the right lower molar region on an enhanced T1-weighted image.

A: There are ongoing changes in the bone structure around the extraction site, which may indicate underlying pathology requiring monitoring. 

P: Monitor the changes in bone structure closely. The patient is advised to report any changes in symptoms immediately. Further treatment to be determined based on monitoring results and any emerging symptoms.

S: The patient presented with a 2-day history of right-sided lower abdominal pain. The pain initially began in the central abdomen and then moved to the right side, worsening with movement. The patient reported experiencing nausea and loss of appetite but denied vomiting, diarrhea, or rectal bleeding. Bowel movements were normal, and there were no urinary or gynecological symptoms. The patient has a history of sarcoidosis and frequent respiratory tract infections but no similar previous abdominal issues.

O: The patient appeared generally unwell but was afebrile. Vital signs included a pulse rate of 76 beats per minute, blood pressure of 110/70 mmHg, and a respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute. Abdominal examination showed marked tenderness in the right iliac fossa (RIF) with rebound tenderness and localized guarding, with the rest of the abdomen soft and nontender and normal bowel sounds. Blood tests revealed a WCC of 7.1 and a CRP of 16.6; renal and liver function tests were normal. Urinalysis was normal and the pregnancy test was negative. A CT scan showed epiploic appendagitis of the caecum with mild pericaecal fat stranding, a normal appendix, and no collection or free air.

A: The initial presumptive diagnosis was acute appendicitis. However, CT findings confirmed the condition as epiploic appendagitis of the caecum.

P: The patient was managed conservatively with analgesia and antibiotics for 2 days, after which there was a complete recovery. The patient was discharged from surgical care following a follow-up visit where they reported no recurrence of symptoms.

S: The patient was born at 38 weeks via natural childbirth, weighing 2.1 kg, with neonatal respiratory distress syndrome and typical features of Pierre Robin Sequence (PRS) including micrognathia, glossoptosis, and cleft palate. The patient also has triphalangeal thumbs and was diagnosed with a congenital perimembranous ventricular defect without hemodynamic effects. A neurodevelopmental delay was observed, with milestones such as head control at 4-5 months, sitting at 11 months, standing unassisted at 13 months, and walking precariously at 20 months. Verbal language development was also poor. The patient was hospitalized in infancy for congenital abnormalities and was diagnosed with inherited hyporegenerative anemia requiring regular blood transfusions. The patient currently receives four units of packed red blood cells each month and has been diagnosed with Diamond-Blackfan anemia (DBA) due to a chromosomal deletion involving RPS26. Facial dysmorphisms include PRS features, a prominent nose bridge, low-set ears, external auditory meatus abnormalities, ocular asymmetry with buphthalmos, intermittent exotropia, severe myopia, and tooth decay.

O: Clinical examination at age 21 revealed a peculiar face, skeletal abnormalities, complex malformation syndrome, and mental deficiency. Dysmorphic facial features noted include prominent nose bridge, low-set ears, bilateral external auditory meatus abnormalities, ocular asymmetry with buphthalmos, intermittent exotropia with left eye dominance, severe myopia, tooth decay, and cavities.

A: The patient presents with Diamond-Blackfan anemia (DBA) and associated congenital anomalies, including features of Pierre Robin Sequence, developmental delays, and dysmorphic facial characteristics. The patient has hyporegenerative anemia managed with regular blood transfusions and complex ocular and dental issues.

P: Continue to monitor the patient’s condition and manage associated congenital abnormalities. Maintain regular follow-up appointments to assess changes in symptoms and manage anemia with ongoing packed red blood cell transfusions. Monitor ocular health and dental care due to severe myopia and tooth decay. Genetic counseling may be recommended, and patient should be informed to report any new symptoms or concerns promptly.

S: The patient reports having undergone curative surgery for endometrial cancer in 2010, including a hysterosalpingooophorectomy and greater omentum resection due to endometrial glandular squamous carcinoma with invasion of the uterine myometrium. Post-surgery, the patient received adjuvant therapy: pelvic radiation (40 Gy), vaginal stump radiation (20 Gy), and three courses of chemotherapy (cyclophosphamide, adriamycin, and 5-fluorouracil). No signs of relapse were noted for seven years. In May 2018, the patient began experiencing a dull pain in the right hypochondrium.

O: In July 2018, a liver lesion was detected through an abdominal ultrasound. A contrast-enhanced MDCT revealed a large, well-circumscribed tumor in the SVIII of the liver. PET-CT showed a large hypermetabolic lesion of the right hemidiaphragm measuring 11.4 × 13.5 × 10.7 cm, likely invading the right liver lobe. Imaging showed a fatty tissue layer separating the diaphragmatic tumor from the liver, confirmed with volume rendering. A surgical approach was undertaken, starting with video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery and converted to open right lateral thoracotomy due to the tumor's size.

A: The patient presents with a diaphragmatic tumor invading the right liver lobe. Differential diagnosis includes primary diaphragmatic tumor with secondary involvement of the liver. The lesion's solitary nature, size, and contact with the liver suggest surgical intervention as the treatment of choice.

P: A comprehensive surgical plan was executed, initiating with video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery and transitioning to open thoracotomy for complete resection. Continued monitoring of the patient’s progress and coordination with the multidisciplinary team is recommended. Further follow-up appointments and imaging studies may be required to assess the postoperative recovery and detect any potential recurrence. Patient is advised to report any new or worsening symptoms promptly.

S: The patient reports chronic inflammation around teeth #24, #25, and #34. They have undergone endodontic treatments on tooth #16. Tooth #12 is causing significant pain, and the patient believes it is hopeless. The patient's main concern is the discomfort and ongoing issues with these teeth.

O: No observable findings, vitals, exam findings, or test results were mentioned in the conversation.

A: The clinician suspects advanced bone loss in regions #12, #24-26, and #35-37. Tooth #12 has both palatal and buccal bone loss. The overall assessment suggests that multiple teeth may require extraction and implant placement due to chronic inflammation and pain.

P: The patient is recommended to consider strategic extraction and implant placement for the affected teeth. A single-staged approach for implant fixed restoration is suggested. Bone augmentation, including sinus floor elevation in the second quadrant, is planned. Specific sites will be treated with a 7-mm bone ring following extraction. The mandible will be supported with a cylindrical bone block. Preparation includes a discussion with the dentist for consent and specific procedural instructions. The patient is advised to follow up with their dentist for further preparation details.

S: The patient is a 73-year-old male with significant asbestos exposure and a recent history of recurrent diverticulitis. He reports persistent left lower quadrant pain despite several courses of antibiotic therapy. He also had a previous CT scan showing fluid near the sigmoid colon, suggesting nonspecific colitis, but the pain did not resolve.

O: The repeat CT scan showed possible nodularity of the mesentery, and the PET scan demonstrated multiple hypermetabolic mesenteric lesions, favoring carcinomatosis. A colonoscopy revealed severe diverticulosis with no obvious luminal lesions, and tumor marker serology was negative. Exploratory laparoscopy found extensive peritoneal carcinomatosis involving all mesenteric surfaces, the right diaphragm, and encasement of the left colon. The final pathology showed malignant epithelial mesothelioma with peritoneal seeding.

A: Extensive peritoneal carcinomatosis with malignant epithelial mesothelioma and previous recurrent diverticulitis.

P: The patient was referred to oncology, and hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy (HIPEC) and cytoreductive surgery (CRS) were recommended as treatment. Symptomatic relief was provided by sigmoid colon resection with a diverting colostomy.

S: The patient presented with a lack of defecation and was diagnosed with stage IIIb rectal cancer, specifically cT4bN2M0, after a colonoscopy revealed a circumferential tumor in the lower rectum, 45 mm from the anal verge. The patient was informed of the serious condition and expressed concern.

O: A colonoscopy showed circumferential luminal narrowing in the lower rectum and smooth, edematous stenosis. The patient underwent five courses of neoadjuvant therapy (XELOX plus bevacizumab), resulting in a complete clinical response (cPR). A SEMS was placed as a bridge to surgery. Six weeks later, a laparoscopic low anterior resection with diverting ileostomy was performed; the operation lasted 308 minutes with minimal blood loss. The pathological diagnosis post-surgery showed moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma stage IIA with a positive chemotherapeutic effect noted as grade 2. The postoperative course was uneventful, and the patient was discharged 20 days later.

A: The patient showed a complete clinical response to neoadjuvant therapy, followed by a successful surgical intervention. Histopathological examination revealed the tumor response to treatment and no evidence of recurrence at 17 months post-treatment.

P: The treatment plan included starting XELOX as adjuvant chemotherapy 5 weeks after surgery to reduce recurrence risk. Continuous monitoring of the patient’s progress and adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary were recommended. The patient was advised to report any changes or concerns in their condition.

S: The 20-day-old infant was admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit due to poor oral intake. The parent reported the baby has been lethargic and sucking poorly, consuming only about 10 to 20 mL of formula per feeding over the last two days. The infant has had regular wet diapers (10 to 14 per day) without vomiting or diarrhea. There were no abnormal findings during the prenatal or immediate postnatal periods. The infant is the first child of healthy nonconsanguineous Korean parents, with an unremarkable family history.

O: The infant was born at 38+2 weeks of gestation, weighing 3380 g, via cesarean section. At admission, the infant's weight was 3100 g, with a length of 53 cm and head circumference of 36 cm. Vital signs: heart rate of 150 beats/min, blood pressure at 78/50 mmHg, respiratory rate of 48 breaths/min, and body temperature of 36.5 °C. Observed clinical findings included dry lips, prolonged capillary refill time (5–6 seconds), both thumbs in palms, frontal bossing, prominent upper lip, high arched palate, sparse frontal scalp hair, and bilateral 5th finger clinodactyly. Capillary blood gas analysis indicated severe metabolic acidosis: pH of 7.16, pCO2 at 28.3 mmHg, pO2 at 42 mmHg, HCO3− at 17.3 mmol/L, and base excess at -17.3 mmol/L. Serum tests showed sodium at 113.3 mEq/L and potassium at 8.79 mEq/L.

A: The clinical presentation and lab findings suggest severe dehydration and electrolyte imbalance, evidenced by poor oral intake, dry lips, prolonged capillary refill, and significant metabolic acidosis. The high serum potassium and low serum sodium levels are indicative of potential underlying endocrine or renal pathology.

P: Initiated treatment with 20 mL/kg normal saline intravenously over 1 hour to address dehydration. Continuous monitoring of the infant's condition and electrolyte levels is planned, with further interventions depending on the infant’s response and additional laboratory findings.

S: The patient reports worsening left upper quadrant abdominal pain radiating to the left shoulder. Symptoms began the day after an outpatient colonoscopy.

O: CT scan shows a grade III splenic injury without obvious active extravasation. The initial hemoglobin level was 9 grams per deciliter, decreasing to 7.4 grams per deciliter over 24 hours. Angiography revealed a subcapsular blush, leading to the recommendation for a splenic artery embolization.

A: Grade III splenic injury with subcapsular blush post-colonoscopy. Decreasing hemoglobin levels indicated a need for intervention.

P: Admit to intensive care for monitoring and treatment. Plan for splenic artery embolization using interlocking coils. Patient will be monitored post-procedure, with stabilization of hemoglobin levels. Discharge is planned for the following day if stable.

S: The patient is a car electrician who presented to the emergency room after falling on their right shoulder from a hoverboard accident. They have no routine medications or allergies. The patient expressed a need to regain hand function for work. Initially, the patient was advised surgery due to the fracture pattern and their expectations for recovery. Two weeks post-operation, the patient reported feeling good and showed improvement. However, five weeks later, the patient heard a breaking sound when lifting a grocery bag and felt the shoulder fall.

O: Initial X-ray showed a displaced comminuted right middle third clavicle fracture with clavicle shortening. The operation involved using a right-sided Acumed Locking Clavicle Plate.
