Postoperative imaging showed the fracture fixated by the plate. Another X-ray after the incident of picking up a grocery bag showed breakage of the fixation clavicle plate with displacement of the fracture.

A: The patient initially had a displaced comminuted right clavicle fracture. Post-operation, the fracture appeared stabilized until the plate breakage occurred five weeks later, resulting in a displaced fracture again.

P: The plan is to perform a second surgery to remove the existing plate and screws, and implant a new, longer fixation plate along with a cancellous bone graft to refill the fracture site. After the surgery, the broken plate will be sent for inspection. The patient will need to continue physical therapy with specific restrictions and avoid lifting heavy weights.

S: The patient, with a history of asthma, experienced severe respiratory distress and was admitted to the hospital by ambulance. Initially treated in the ICU for status asthmaticus, the patient required heavy sedation and paralysis. The patient recalls receiving treatment with low molecular weight heparin for a detected bilateral segmental pulmonary embolism and a tracheostomy due to respiratory weakness. After a PEG tube placement, the patient became acutely hypotensive and suffered an asystolic cardiac arrest, requiring CPR and ICU readmission.

O: The patient was initially managed in the ICU with sedation and paralysis for status asthmaticus. CTA showed bilateral segmental pulmonary embolism; TTE indicated mild RV dilatation and normal RV function. Post-PEG tube placement, the patient experienced acute hypotension with systolic pressures of 70-80 mmHg, requiring a saline bolus and CPR. Arterial blood gas showed a pH of 7.05 and pCO2 of 77 mmHg. Treatments included norepinephrine, vasopressin, phenylephrine, dobutamine, and inhaled nitric oxide. Follow-up TTE revealed severe RV function decrease. Alteplase treatment was provided, totaling 250 mg over 36 hours. Subsequent pulmonary angiography showed normal pulmonary artery pressures with no clot, and TTE indicated mild decreased RV function.

A: The patient experienced critical complications from massive PE following status asthmaticus. There was significant cardiorespiratory compromise, likely due to PE-related RV strain, necessitating aggressive thrombolytic therapy.

P: The patient’s condition is closely monitored, with improvements noted. The care plan includes regular follow-up and adherence to medical recommendations. The team successfully managed to wean inotropes and inhaled nitric oxide. Continuous monitoring and supportive care remain crucial as the patient recovers from recent events.

S:  
The patient reports experiencing extreme weakness and fatigue constantly. They have a history of B-cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (B-ALL) and previously diagnosed renal clear cell carcinoma, which was surgically removed. The patient underwent six courses of chemotherapy according to the BFM schedule for B-ALL and achieved morphologic complete remission with MRD negativity initially.

O:  
Peripheral blood count indicated severe anemia with hemoglobin at 7.3 g/dL, reduced white blood cell count at 2400/μL, and severe neutropenia with neutrophils at 600/μL. Platelet count was normal at 168,000/μL. Diagnostic tests revealed B-ALL with normal karyotype, negative for BCR-ABL rearrangement, and immature B-cell origin. A CT scan showed a 7.0 cm lesion on the right kidney diagnosable as clear cell carcinoma. Post-treatment, a PET-CT showed multiple lesions, including a large pancreatic lesion. Pancreatic biopsy identified CD19+ and CD22+ lymphoid cells, indicative of B-ALL.

A:  
The patient has a recurrence of B-ALL with blast cells documented in peripheral blood smear and new lesions confirmed to be B-ALL localizations via biopsy. The patient also has a history of surgically removed renal clear cell carcinoma.

P:  
The treatment plan involves administering Inotuzumab ozogamicin (IO) on a weekly basis as a targeted approach for relapsed B-ALL, due to the blast cells' CD22 positivity.

S: The patient has been experiencing severe headaches and fatigue, which led to the referral for a renal angiogram. They have uncontrolled hypertension despite receiving antihypertensive medications for 8 months. There is no history of smoking, alcohol use, diabetes, or family history of diabetes or atherosclerosis. The patient’s blood pressure has remained high at 175/110 mmHg.

O: The patient’s physical examination, including general, cardiovascular, respiratory, and abdominal assessments, were unremarkable. Neurological examination showed normal alertness, attention, orientation, speech, and motor functions. Laboratory investigations indicated normal complete blood count, cholesterol, lipid profile, and renal function, with serum creatinine at 119 μmol/L. A Renal Doppler ultrasound showed renal artery stenosis with a renal resistive index of 0.58. Initial imaging revealed left renal artery stenosis, with blockage percentages of 70% and 75% in the two branches of the left renal artery, unchanged after the first balloon angioplasty. After a second ballooning and stenting procedure, revascularization was achieved.

A: Uncontrolled hypertension likely secondary to renal artery stenosis.

P: The patient is advised to continue with current antihypertensive medications and attend follow-up appointments for ongoing monitoring and treatment adjustments.

S: The patient is a 74-year-old man with squamous cell carcinoma of the mouth floor, scheduled for tumor-wide excision, mandibulotomy, tracheostomy, and free flap reconstruction. He has a medical history of hypertension and underwent cystolitholapaxy for bilateral ureteral stones. He is currently taking losartan and hydrochlorothiazide and reports no drug allergies. The patient has experienced a mild productive cough recently.

O: Pre-operative chest radiograph was normal. Echocardiogram indicated normal left ventricular function. Pre-operative vital signs: heart rate 74 bpm, blood pressure 168/85 mmHg, respiration rate 18/min, oxygen saturation 94% on room air. Airway secretions were observed during tracheal intubation. Anesthesia was induced with remifentanil, lidocaine, propofol, and succinylcholine. Mechanical ventilation settings were adjusted as detailed.

A: The patient has squamous cell carcinoma of the mouth floor with a recent mild productive cough. His hypertension is managed with losartan and hydrochlorothiazide. Normal cardiac function noted; current cough and airway secretion potentially related to ongoing respiratory condition.

P: Proceed with the scheduled surgical procedures with planned anesthesia and monitoring. Post-operative care will include careful observation and follow-up instructions to ensure recovery. Continue current antihypertensive medications post-surgery unless contraindicated by surgical outcomes or changes in clinical status.

S: The patient was detected with microscopic hematuria and proteinuria during a school urinary screening at 10 years old. There was no presence of edema or hypertension. The patient developed nephrotic syndrome, and lab tests showed hypocomplementemia with a serum albumin level of 2.5 g/dL and urinary protein excretion of 3.4 g/day. The patient had normal blood pressure and renal function. The patient was negative for systemic lupus erythematosus, thrombotic microangiopathy, malignancies, Anti-DNA antibody, hepatitis B, hepatitis C, and cryoglobulins.

O: Initial renal biopsy at 11 years old showed 30 glomeruli with an increase in mesangial cells and matrix, a lobular pattern, thick glomerular capillary walls with double contours, and subendothelial and mesangial deposits observed on Masson trichrome stain. The immune-enzyme method revealed lumpy C3 deposits, with weak staining of IgA, IgG, and IgM. No tubulointerstitial change was detected. The urinary protein excretion decreased to 2+ by dipstick after treatment, with improvement in hypoalbuminemia and hypercholesterolemia. At 14 years old, microscopic hematuria, proteinuria, and hypocomplementemia persisted, and a follow-up biopsy with 18 glomeruli was performed.

A: The patient was diagnosed with MPGN type I. Persistent microscopic hematuria, proteinuria, and hypocomplementemia continue despite treatment.

P: Continue monitoring the patient’s condition with regular check-ups. Adjust treatment as needed, and ensure the patient reports any new symptoms. Prednisolone and dipyridamole improved hypoalbuminemia and hypercholesterolemia, but persistent renal issues require ongoing surveillance.

S: The patient experienced a first episode of a generalized tonic-clonic seizure and reports weakness on the left side. There is a history of a benign breast lesion.

O: Examination revealed mild left pyramidal hemiparesis with upper motor neuron signs. MRI showed a 16-mm right parafalcine, extra-axial lesion with homogenous contrast enhancement and surrounding vasogenic edema. CT scan revealed pretracheal and precarinal lymphadenopathy, without a primary lesion elsewhere. Post-surgical recovery was without neurological deficits. Histological examination showed neoplastic cells with moderately pleomorphic nuclei, low mitotic rate, and a prominent peripheral lymphoid cuff. Immunohistochemically, the tumor cells were positive for desmin, ALK1, vimentin, and EMA.

A: Differential diagnosis includes atypical meningioma and inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor (IMT). The lesion had characteristics of a meningioma.

P: The lesion was surgically excised with a small component of residual tumor left deliberately. The case was referred for international consultation, and future monitoring and follow-up care were planned.

S: The patient was referred to the Department of Gynecology due to experiencing abdominal pain for the past 2 weeks. She reports no other symptoms besides the pain.

O: Tests revealed a large mass extending from the right side of the uterine body to the adnexal region. Ultrasonography indicated the mass was solid and hypoechoic. Serum levels of carcinoembryonic antigen, carbohydrate antigen 19-9, and carbohydrate antigen 125 were normal. CT and MRI findings showed a large solid mass with cystic areas and varying signal intensities. A right adnexectomy was performed, removing a mass measuring 12 × 9 × 7 cm. Microscopy revealed cystic spaces with mucinous fluid, ovarian stromal fibrous tissues, vascular spaces, and mucus-producing tumor cells with moderate atypia.

A: Preoperative diagnosis suggested an endometrioma with a related malignant tumor, possibly clear cell carcinoma or endometrioid carcinoma. Microscopy confirmed malignancy due to the presence of atypical tumor cells.

P: Further treatment options need to be discussed, and the patient's condition should be closely monitored to ensure the best possible outcome.

S: The patient reported a painless mass on the head, located under the midline parietal-occipital scalp, present for about a year.

O: The radiograph indicated erosion of the skull bone beneath the mass. MRI showed a large parasagittal tumor with homogenous contrast enhancement, suggestive of hypervascular meningioma. Angiography revealed dense stains with distorted vessels in the mass location. Post-surgery, the excised tumor was dark-reddish and rubbery, invading through the skull but easily separable from the dura. Histopathology identified it as a plasmacytic type plasmacytoma with positive lambda stain. Systemic evaluations showed no evidence of residual tumor, other skeletal involvement, or tumor cells in the bone marrow biopsy. The patient displayed no signs of anemia, hypercalcemia, or renal impairment.

A: The patient presented with a plasmacytic type plasmacytoma with confirmed complete resection and no systemic involvement.

P: The plan included total surgical resection of the tumor with cranioplasty using bone cement. No radiotherapy was required due to successful complete removal and absence of systemic spread or recurrence. The patient will continue under close monitoring, with follow-ups showing no signs of recurrence or progression after one year. No additional treatment is currently needed.

S: The patient is a 75-year-old female with a history of smoking (30 pack-year). She reports feeling fatigued, having a cough, and experiencing weight loss. She is concerned about the seriousness of her condition.

O: The chest CT demonstrated an 8.6 cm lesion in the right upper lobe with mediastinal invasion, extensive cervical and mediastinal adenopathy, and a malignant pericardial effusion. A biopsy confirmed squamous cell carcinoma, TTF-1/NAPSIN negative, staged as stage IV cT3N3M1b. The patient developed hypercalcemia as a paraneoplastic complication. Histopathology showed no PD-L1 expression prior to immunotherapy. After treatment, imaging showed no active disease initially, followed by focal progression with new lymph nodes, confirmed as poorly-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma.

A: The patient is diagnosed with stage IV squamous cell carcinoma of the lung with hypercalcemia as a paraneoplastic complication. There has been a transient partial response to initial treatments, followed by recurrence and oligo-progressive disease. Current management has shown durable control after cryoablation.

P: The patient underwent multiple treatments: palliative PT-DC chemotherapy, palliative radiotherapy, salvage chemotherapy, combination immunotherapy, surgical excision of cervical lymph nodes, and cryoablation of the aortocaval lymph node. Follow-up imaging showed complete control. The plan includes continued monitoring, follow-up appointments, and adapting treatment as needed based on symptom changes and imaging results.

S: The patient reports a burning sensation on the right side of the tongue persisting for about a month. They have a 30-year history of chewing approximately 10 betel nuts per day. The patient’s father had a history of oral cancer.

O: During an intraoral examination, a tender, firm, 2 × 2.5 cm ulcero-proliferative growth was noted at the right lateral border of the tongue, with normal tongue movements observed. A single 1 × 1 cm tender, firm, ovoid lymph node was found in the right submandibular region. A CECT was performed, followed by a biopsy which confirmed infiltrating squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) on the right lateral border of the tongue. The cancer is classified as stage III - T2 N1 M0.

A: The diagnosis is infiltrating squamous cell carcinoma of the tongue at stage III, indicating cancer spread to one nearby lymph node without distant metastasis.

P: The plan involves discussing treatment options and initiating treatment as soon as possible. Follow-up and support throughout the treatment process were assured. Further specifics of the treatment plan were not provided.

S: The patient reports having a fever and a rash that started on their forearms 4 days ago, which has spread to the lower extremities, shoulder, and back. Additionally, they have a dry cough and mild itching on the chest.

O: Examination reveals a WBC count of 16.7 × 10³/µL and an AEC of 1600 cells/µL. A biopsy of lesions on the posterior right arm shows dermal edema, subepidermal vesicle with fibrin, and irregular brown pigmentation in the epidermis. Coccidioidal serology test results include weakly reactive ID-IgM and ID-IgG, with a CF antibody titer of less than 1:2. A chest X-ray shows bilateral infiltrates, particularly worse on the left lower lobe.

A: The patient is assessed to have a maculopapular rash with respiratory involvement, likely due to some underlying infection or inflammatory process. 

P: The plan includes recommending the patient get plenty of rest, stay hydrated, and take over-the-counter fever reducers and antihistamines to manage the fever and itching sensations. The patient is advised to return for further evaluation if symptoms worsen or do not improve after 2 weeks.

S: The patient reports experiencing a popping sensation followed by heat and pressure at the base of the skull, starting at age five. These sensations occur when suddenly rotating the head and are accompanied by numbness in the back of the tongue and difficulty speaking for about 15 seconds. The frequency was higher during periods of competitive fencing and military training, currently reduced. The patient reports a normal birth history with no instrumental delivery and denies any significant past medical, surgical, or developmental issues.

O: A physical and neurologic examination, including a cranial nerve exam, was conducted, showing completely normal results. An MRI of the cervical spine revealed slight dysplastic enlargement of the anterior arch of the C1 vertebrae, mild degenerative changes at the atlantoaxial junction, and a spinal canal caliber at the lower end of normal limits, without abnormal bone spurring or abnormalities of the hypoglossal canal.

A: The popping sensation and associated symptoms do not appear to be caused by the observed MRI findings. The clinical impression is that the symptoms may not relate to significant underlying pathology at this time.

P: The plan is to monitor the patient’s condition. The patient is advised to return for a follow-up if there are any changes or worsening of symptoms. No immediate intervention is required based on the current findings.

S: The patient, a 33-year-old male with no comorbidities, was admitted to the hospital on June 28th with a fever of 39.5°C, paresthesia in the feet, difficulty walking and speaking, and a fall from his own height. He was admitted to the ICU due to dyspnea, pneumonia, and persistent muscular pain. On June 30th, he experienced acute respiratory insufficiency type II, leading to sedation and orotracheal intubation.

O: Initial laboratory tests showed hemoglobin at 14.0 g/dL and creatinine at 0.72 mg/dL with other normal levels. A serology test was positive for Zika virus (IgG antibodies). Cerebrospinal fluid analysis revealed increased protein levels (191mg/dL) with a normal cell count, indicative of Guillain-Barré syndrome. Blood cultures and serological tests for bacterial and viral infections (toxoplasmosis, herpes, varicella, and HIV) were negative. The patient developed septic shock during the ICU stay.

A: The patient has a diagnosis of Guillain-Barré syndrome potentially triggered by a Zika virus infection. The development of acute respiratory insufficiency type II required mechanical ventilation. The condition was complicated by septic shock of undetermined focus.

P: The treatment plan included administering 0.4g/kg intravenous immunoglobulin for 5 days, which did not improve the condition. The patient was treated for septic shock with vasoactive amines and intravenous antimicrobial agents (Meropenem combined with Fluconazole) for 10 days. Mechanical ventilation was managed using a pressure controlled mode (PCV) and an 840TM ventilator from Covidien-Nellcor and Puritan Bennett. The patient will continue to be monitored with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient reports feeling generally alright but expresses nervousness about upcoming prostate surgery. There is no mention of symptoms related to the incidental finding of the abdominal aortic aneurysm, which was discovered during a CT angiogram. The patient has a history of uncontrolled hypertension contributing to the aneurysm and dissection.

O: An incidental finding from a CT angiogram revealed a 3.2cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm with dissection extending distally involving both common iliac arteries. An endovascular procedure using the Endologix AFX2 bifurcated AAA endograft system was performed without complications. At a 12-month follow-up, the stent-graft was patent with no evidence of endoleak.

A: The patient has an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm with associated dissection, primarily due to uncontrolled hypertension. The condition was successfully treated with endovascular stenting, and follow-up shows no complications such as endoleak.

P: The focus should be on managing hypertension to prevent further complications. Regular follow-up appointments are necessary to monitor the stent and aneurysm. The patient should maintain a healthy lifestyle and prepare for prostate surgery. If any concerns or questions arise, the patient is encouraged to reach out to the healthcare provider.

S: The patient reports experiencing central vision loss in the right eye for about two weeks. There is no previous medical history or family history of eye problems. The patient returns the next day with central vision loss in the left eye as well.

O: Initial examination shows a best-corrected visual acuity of 1.2 OU with no refractive error. Slit-lamp examination reveals no abnormalities in both eyes. A Funduscopic examination identifies a wedge-shaped dark reddish lesion at the macula in the right eye. Infrared imaging using a Scanning laser ophthalmoscope (SLO) detects a corresponding dark area. Enhanced Depth Imaging Optical Coherence Tomography (EDI-OCT) shows loss or disruption of the interdigitation zone (IZ) at the macula in the right eye. Upon follow-up, a similar lesion and IZ disruption are found in the left eye. Fluorescein angiography displays hypofluorescence at the lesions, and indocyanine green angiography reveals initial geographic hypofluorescence corresponding to the AMN lesion in both eyes, with obscured findings in the late phase. Fundus autofluorescence (FAF) shows faint hypo-autofluorescence at the lesion sites. Humphrey threshold 10–2 perimetry indicates decreased central sensitivity corresponding to the lesion.

A: Acute Macular Neuroretinopathy (AMN) diagnosed in both eyes based on clinical findings.

P: The patient's condition is being actively monitored without specific treatment. The patient is advised to return if any changes in vision are noticed. Upon three-month follow-up, improvement in lesions and macular structure recovery is noted, and continued monitoring is recommended.

S: The patient reports experiencing bloating and stomach pain over the past few months. They have no personal or family history of illness and do not smoke, consume alcohol, or take any medications.

O: On examination, the patient was afebrile, neurological examination was normal, blood pressure was 126/84 mmHg, pulse was regular at 75-80 beats/minute, and temperature was 36.8 °C. Laboratory tests showed elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, C-reactive protein, and lactate dehydrogenase levels, indicating inflammation and tissue necrosis. A CT scan revealed a large mass (23.7 cm × 16.5 cm × 11.5 cm) originating from the right adrenal gland, compressing the right hepatic lobe and inferior vena cava. A fine-needle core biopsy diagnosed adrenal cortical carcinoma (ACC). Metastatic work-up showed no metastases. Postoperative pathology confirmed ACC.

A: The patient has been diagnosed with adrenal cortical carcinoma (ACC). The mass has been completely removed with no metastasis and an uneventful postoperative recovery.

P: No further adjuvant treatment is necessary at this time. The patient will be monitored for progress and advised to contact the clinic if any concerns arise in the future.

S: George reports numbness and tingling in his left wrist and hand, with pain that has been ongoing for several months. He experiences these symptoms mostly at night, waking up with his hand asleep and needing to shake it out. He often notices numbness in all fingers, particularly the thumb and pointer finger, sometimes extending to the fifth finger. George works in landscaping, performing repetitive tasks such as raking and digging. He denies any issues with his right hand and consumes a few beers on weekends. No history of rheumatoid arthritis has been reported. He experiences weakness and occasional difficulty feeling objects, leading to dropping items.

O: On physical examination, George exhibits reduced grip strength in the left hand. He experiences a "jolt" or "zing" in his fingertips when Tinel's test is performed on both wrists, suggesting bilateral positive Tinel's sign.

A: The diagnostic impression is bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome, likely due to repetitive motions associated with his landscaping work. This is supported by the history and positive Tinel's sign in both wrists.

P: The plan includes ordering an electromyography (EMG) study to assess electrical impulses in his fingers. Recommended treatments are activity modification to reduce repetitive movements, wearing a wrist splint, and taking 600 mg of ibuprofen every six hours. George should delegate heavier tasks to others at work. A follow-up appointment is scheduled in two weeks to evaluate the need for further intervention or possible surgical consideration.

S: The patient's parent reports that their 6-month-old daughter is not growing well and has been experiencing vomiting and diarrhea. The parent is concerned about potential underlying health issues.

O: The daughter exhibits anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia. Her serum vitamin B12 level is normal, but her serum homocysteine level is elevated at 53 µmol/L. Bone marrow aspiration shows megaloblastic changes and vacuolization. An immunological evaluation reveals hypogammaglobulinemia, though lymphocyte subsets are normal. Genetic testing identifies a c.1106+1516_1222+1231del mutation, a 5304-bp deletion causing a frameshift and premature stop codon.

A: The clinical assessment indicates a genetic deficiency likely affecting the immune system and hematological health. Suspected diagnosis includes issues related to a metabolic or genetic condition, potentially due to the identified mutation.

P: The treatment plan involves administering intramuscular vitamin B12 and oral folic acid to address hematological issues. Long-term follow-up and monitoring are necessary, with additional support for speech development due to detected speech deficits at 2-year follow-up.

S: The 76-year-old patient presents with progressive shortness of breath worsening over the past two weeks. He has a history of well-controlled hypertension and coronary artery disease. Despite treatment with three antihypertensive medications, the patient remains significantly hypertensive.

O: On presentation, vital signs showed blood pressure at 238/146 mm Hg, heart rate of 75 beats per minute, and oxygen saturation at 80%. Examination revealed pulsus paradoxus, distant heart sounds, marked jugular venous distension, diminished breath sounds at the bases, and mild bilateral lower extremity pitting edema. EKG showed low voltage, chest radiograph indicated an enlarged cardiac silhouette and bilateral pleural effusions. Echocardiogram demonstrated a moderate to large pericardial effusion with tamponade physiology. After pericardiocentesis, a follow-up echocardiogram showed resolution of the effusion, and there was a significant improvement in right-sided pressures. Further fluid analysis was exudative and negative for malignant cells.

A: Cardiac tamponade secondary to a moderate to large pericardial effusion, causing significant shortness of breath and hypertension. The fluid is exudative, etiology pending further investigation, but malignancy has been ruled out.

P: Initiated labetalol drip to manage hypertension. Pericardiocentesis performed, removing 1200 cc of fluid, improving cardiac output and pressures. A follow-up echocardiogram showed resolution of effusion. Further workup included fluid cytology, culture, LDH, ANA, serum complement, ESR, CRP, anti-dsDNA, and anti-Smith antibody tests to determine the underlying cause. Continue monitoring and appropriate treatment based on test results.

S: The patient reports past medical history of nonischemic cardiomyopathy and has undergone two heart transplants, one in 1994 and another in 2002. The patient also underwent kidney transplantation in 2004 due to ESRD. The patient has a history of ehrlichiosis, cryptococcal pneumonia, and histoplasmosis requiring chronic antifungal treatment. In 2013, the patient experienced syncope, was diagnosed with a subarachnoid hemorrhage, and subsequently underwent dual chamber pacemaker placement due to sinus node dysfunction and bradycardia. The patient reports issues with pacemaker lead stability and further intervention involving the removal and replacement of an atrial lead. The patient was admitted with cryptogenic encephalopathy related to subclinical cirrhosis, experiencing confusion, disorientation, and memory issues.

O: The patient had a pacemaker implanted with evidence of unstable lead, undersensing on atrial channel attributed to decreased P wave amplitude. Atrial lead replacement was performed with a Medtronic 3830 lead successfully implanted. Subsequent admission for cryptogenic encephalopathy, thought to be related in part to subclinical cirrhosis.

A: The patient has a complex medical history including cardiomyopathy with heart transplants, sinus node dysfunction requiring pacemaker management, attenuated renal function requiring transplantation, and infectious disease history. The recent encephalopathy is assessed to be potentially linked to underlying cirrhosis.

P: Treatment plan includes continued monitoring of cardiac function with pacemaker follow-up, evaluation and management of renal function, monitoring for potential complications related to past infections, and ongoing assessment for hepatic function due to subclinical cirrhosis. The patient is advised to keep all healthcare appointments and report any new symptoms promptly.

S: The patient reports a history of short bowel syndrome following a choledochoduodenostomy 38 years ago and extensive small intestine excision 32 years ago. The patient has been on home parenteral nutrition for over 30 years. Recently, the patient has experienced liver dysfunction. The patient smoked 10 cigarettes a day for 45 years and sometimes drinks alcohol. There is a noted abdominal scar with no tenderness, but the patient has felt a palpable mass in the abdomen. 

O: The patient’s height is 156 cm and weighs 44.3 kg, with a BMI of 18.3 kg/m². Laboratory results show elevated aspartate aminotransferase (AST) at 55 IU/L, alanine aminotransferase (ALT) at 57 IU/L, lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) at 317 IU/L, γGTP at 445 IU/L, and alkaline phosphatase (ALP) at 1067 IU/L. Tumor markers are slightly elevated with CEA at 11 ng/ml and CA19-9 at 37 U/ml. Liver infection panels and hepatitis B and C tests are negative. Abdominal ultrasonography reveals a papillary mass of 40 × 30 mm in the left hepatic duct and a dilated distal left intrahepatic bile duct. Enhanced CT shows a mass in the left hepatic duct and a 12 mm lymph node in the hepatic hilar region. FDG-PET shows abnormal uptake in the left bile duct (SUV max = 4.6) and in the hepatic hilar lymph node (SUV max = 12).

A: The patient may have a concerning issue involving the liver and bile duct, possibly a neoplastic process given the findings of the mass and elevated tumor markers. There may also be lymph node involvement.

P: Further evaluation is necessary to determine the cause of the mass and liver dysfunction, including possible biopsy of the hepatic and lymph node masses. Follow-up appointments are essential for monitoring and determining appropriate treatment options. The patient should be advised to reduce or cease smoking and alcohol consumption.

S: The patient is a 12-year-old girl with an unerupted permanent right maxillary central incisor. Her mother reports issues with her smile, leading to low self-esteem and bullying at school. The patient has no history of medical illness or trauma to her teeth or jaws.

O: No information provided.

A: Unerupted permanent right maxillary central incisor contributing to esthetic concerns and low self-esteem.

P: Schedule a follow-up appointment with a dental specialist to determine the most appropriate treatment options to improve the patient's smile and address her self-esteem issues. Reassure the patient and her family of continued support and assistance.

S: The patient is a 54-year-old male with a history of stage 1 squamous cell carcinoma. He underwent a partial right upper alveolectomy and obturator reconstruction approximately 3 years ago. Two years post-surgery, he experienced a local recurrence and underwent a definitive upper alveolectomy with a hard palate resection from the midline to the right posterior molar, including bone removal. He did not receive radiation or adjuvant therapy after the second surgery.

O: No information provided.

A: Status post definitive upper alveolectomy for recurrent stage 1 squamous cell carcinoma with no adjuvant therapy. Considering reconstructive options.

P: Discuss reconstructive options, such as an osteocutaneous radial forearm or fibula flap, with the surgeon. Plan to explore the pros and cons of each reconstructive option during the upcoming appointment. Follow up with the doctor if there are any questions or concerns after the surgeon's consultation.

S: The patient reports experiencing occasional pulling pain in the left side, along with nausea and a low-grade fever, since May.

O: Examination revealed a cyst in the patient's spleen, measuring 7.5 x 7.5 x 5 cm on CT scan. The spleen measured 20 x 10 cm, with the lower pole palpable in the mesogastrium, dense and painless upon palpation. Blood and urine tests were normal except for elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate at 29 mm/h. Platelet count was normal at 315 thousand/μl. Negative results for Kasoni and ELISA tests for Human Cystic echinococcosis. CT and US findings included a spleen cyst with clear smooth contours and uniform content.

A: Diagnosis of a splenic cyst (NSC) established. Differential ruled out Human Cystic echinococcosis.

P: The patient will be admitted for surgery in the Department of Surgery on June 13. Plan includes percutaneous puncture and microwave ablation (MWA) of the splenic cyst under ultrasound and X-ray fluoroscopy, using intravenous anesthesia with Propofol 150 mg and Phentanylum 0.2 mg. An MWA catheter from MedWaves Incorporated, AveCure®, will be used.

S: The patient is a 62-year-old man with a history of sigmoid colon cancer. He underwent a sigmoidectomy and was diagnosed with adenocarcinoma, type 2, por1>tub2, at pStage IV with liver metastases in segments S3, S4, S6, and S8. The metastases were initially unresectable due to invasion of the umbilical portion. He completed eight cycles of chemotherapy with FOLFOX and panitumumab, experiencing tough but manageable side effects. Subsequent CT imaging showed a 44% decrease in liver tumor size, indicating a partial response. After adverse effects from panitumumab, he had further cycles with FOLFOX only, resulting in stable disease and slight tumor reduction. The tumors became resectable 15 months post-sigmoidectomy. He underwent left hepatic trisectionectomy, partial posterior segmentectomy, and partial right hepatic vein resection. No postoperative complications were reported.

O: Vital signs and exam findings were not provided. Abdominal CT after initial chemotherapy cycles showed a 44% decrease in liver tumor size. Following additional chemotherapy, a 10% decrease in tumor size was observed. Surgery for liver metastases involved a 630-minute procedure with an intraoperative hemorrhage volume of 3540 mL. Gross examination of the hepatic lesions showed multinodular growth with varying edematous and sclerotic areas.

A: The patient was diagnosed with pStage IV adenocarcinoma of the sigmoid colon with liver metastases. Initial presentation included unresectable liver metastases, but following chemotherapy, the metastatic tumors were deemed resectable. The patient's condition progressed to stable disease after additional chemotherapy cycles.

P: The patient should continue monitoring his condition with regular follow-ups. It is important to be vigilant for any changes or concerns related to his postoperative recovery and ongoing cancer management. No new treatments, tests, or referrals were discussed during the conversation.

S: The patient reports swelling around the upper left second molar with exposed bone in the left buccal region. There is a history of excisional biopsies twice before, with a previous diagnosis of osteoma. The patient does not report pain and lacks any special medical or family history. Bone exposure recurred a year after natural recovery, with swelling increasing over time.

O: The maxillary bone exposure is noted without pain. A CT scan shows a diffuse radiopaque lesion from the first molar to the second molar, with a diffuse bone mass and radiolucent areas extending into the pterygopalatine fossa. Biopsy results indicate features of necrotic bone without atypia. MRI reveals heterogeneous contrast-enhanced masses; histopathology shows dense atypical spindle cell proliferation and focal cartilage formation with mild atypia. Immunohistochemical staining results show expression of β-catenin, α-SMA, RUNX-2, SATB2, and SOX9 in atypical spindle cells.

A: The differential includes a lesion with atypical spindle cell proliferation and cartilage formation, previously diagnosed as osteoma but now showing characteristics that could indicate a different pathological process.

P: The plan involves discussing treatment options, considering previous surgeries and current lesion status. The patient will be informed of potential next steps to make an informed decision regarding their care.

S: The patient reports experiencing bulging in the right eye (exophthalmia) and excessive tearing (epiphora) for the past 8 months. There are no known family history of endocrine problems, although her mother had breast cancer, and her father has high blood pressure and type 2 diabetes. The patient has had a regular menstrual cycle since age 12 and a complication-free pregnancy.

O: No information provided.

A: The patient's symptoms are indicative of exophthalmia and epiphora, potentially requiring endocrinology evaluation for further diagnosis.

P: The patient will be admitted to the Endocrinology Department for a thorough examination and tests to determine the cause of exophthalmia and epiphora. The results will inform the development of a treatment plan. The patient is advised to bring personal belongings and any medications currently being taken.

S: The patient is a 23-year-old male from Cameroon, presenting with acute-onset, right-sided scrotal pain and swelling. He reports no prior sexual activity and denies symptoms such as penile discharge, hematuria, fevers, night sweats, weight loss, or cough. Initial treatment with ceftriaxone and doxycycline improved his symptoms temporarily, but they recurred after 6 weeks. A course of ciprofloxacin alleviated the pain, but swelling persisted. Five months later, he experienced another recurrence, with prominent right-sided scrotal swelling and tenderness.

O: Initial urinalysis showed pyuria; NAAT was negative for Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis. Repeat ultrasound showed persistent epididymitis. Physical exam showed right-sided scrotal swelling and tenderness. Ultrasound indicated right-sided epididymitis, possible necrosis, complex hydrocele, and concern for scrotal abscess. CT of chest, abdomen, and pelvis revealed complex scrotal fluid collection, enlarged heterogeneous prostate, enlarged juxtaesophageal lymph node, and right lung apical nodular scarring. Post-orchiectomy findings included an enlarged epididymis with caseating necrosis, miliary deposits, scrotal abscess, and diffuse necrotizing granulomas; acid-fast bacilli were present in the testicular parenchyma.

A: The findings suggest possible tuberculosis as a differential, with concerns about malignancy leading to orchiectomy. The presence of acid-fast bacilli and necrotizing granulomas point towards a granulomatous infection, likely tuberculosis.

P: Follow-up appointments are scheduled to monitor recovery and control infection. The patient is advised to manage pain or discomfort actively, follow all prescribed treatment plans, and report any changes in symptoms. Monitoring and supportive care will continue throughout the healing process.

S:  
The patient reports severe headaches, visual loss, primary amenorrhoea, and galactorrhoea. These symptoms led to concerns requiring further investigation.

O:  
MRI results identified an apoplectic suprasellar tumour with significantly high prolactin levels of 10,919 miU/L. Post-treatment follow-up indicates no improvement in vision after a week of cabergoline treatment. After surgical intervention, the patient reports improvement in vision and resolution of galactorrhoea. Six years post-surgery, there has been no recurrence, prolactin levels are normal, and histology confirms pituitary apoplexy with prolactin expression in a diffuse pattern and a low Ki67 proliferation index.

A:  
The diagnostic impression is pituitary apoplexy with tumor-related hyperprolactinemia leading to the patient's symptoms. The differential includes pathologies that can cause similar endocrine and visual disturbances, but findings support the assessment.

P:  
The initial plan involved medical management with cabergoline, followed by endoscopic trans-sphenoidal surgery when treatment did not resolve vision issues. Post-surgery, the plan includes monitoring progress and regular follow-ups to check for recurrence and ensure health maintenance. Continued observation is advised due to the successful surgical outcome and favorable histological findings.

S: The patient reports experiencing fatigue for the past 2 months and has unintentionally lost about 60 pounds. They also describe a new band-like pain wrapping around the chest.

O: The patient's hemoglobin level is 5 g/dL. Laboratory tests indicate AIHA, C3 positivity, elevated IgG, elevated LDH, low haptoglobin, elevated reticulocyte count, elevated RDW-CV, positive direct Coombs test, thrombocytopenia, and proteinuria. A CT scan showed a compression fracture of the L1 vertebral body. A bone marrow biopsy demonstrated plasma cell myeloma in over 80% of marrow elements, absent iron deposits, and normal myeloid, erythroid, and megakaryocytic elements. Flow cytometry showed monoclonal plasma cells with cytoplasmic kappa light chain restriction and specific markers. Serum protein electrophoresis confirmed monoclonal gammopathy with IgG-K. Quantitative IgG was 7468, with very low IgA and IgM, a markedly elevated Kappa free light chain of 1879, and elevated β-2-microglobulin of 6.99. Cytogenetics were normal.

A: The patient presents with symptoms and laboratory findings indicative of Evans syndrome (ES) and plasma cell myeloma. The anemia and other hematologic abnormalities are associated with these conditions.

P: The patient was started on high-dose methylprednisolone 500 mg intravenously for 2 days followed by an oral prednisone taper. Multiple blood transfusions have been administered to stabilize the hemoglobin level. The patient will continue to be monitored, and the treatment plan will be adjusted as needed based on their progress and response to current therapies.

S: The patient reports laryngeal burns sustained during a house fire, leading to a severe breathy voice and cough. They have experienced difficulties with breathing and notice significant changes in their voice. The patient is also seeking counseling for post-traumatic stress related to the incident.

O: Observations include laryngeal edema and restricted laryngeal movement during phonation. The patient's vocal fold vibrations are impaired, with a non-vibrating portion noted. High-speed video and kymography confirmed increased stiffness of the vocal fold mucosa and absence of mucosal waves. Acoustic analysis results are abnormal, with cepstral peak prominence (CPP), low-to-high frequency spectral ratio (L/H spectral ratio), and mean CPP F0 outside normal range. Auditory perceptual assessment using the GRBAS scale confirms significant dysphonia.

A: The patient is experiencing significant voice changes and dysphonia due to laryngeal burns, characterized by increased stiffness of vocal fold mucosa and impaired vocal fold vibrations.

P: The treatment plan will focus on addressing the laryngeal damage and improving voice quality. Resources for counseling will be provided to help the patient cope with post-traumatic stress from the house fire.

S: The patient, a book binder, experienced an injury to the dominant hand when it got caught in a binding machine two weeks ago. Since the accident, the patient reports sensory disturbance, numbness, and severe neuropathic pain in the index finger. The pain is described as constant and rated at 10 out of 10 on a visual analog scale, occurring both at rest and with movement. Additionally, the patient reports hypoesthesia in the thumb, index, middle, and little fingers.

O: Examination reveals a wound scar near the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint on the ulnar side of the index finger, with redness beyond the wound indicating a loss of protective sensation. Tinel's sign is present, suggesting nerve involvement. No fractures are noted on radiological examination. There is significant restriction in the range of motion of the index finger due to neuropathic pain: MP joint: 0°/70°, PIP joint: 0°/40°, DIP joint: 0°/60°; resulting in a total active range of motion (TAM) of 63%.

A: The assessment indicates nerve involvement in the injured hand, specifically affecting the sensory nerves of the thumb, index, and middle fingers. The patient's symptoms are consistent with neuropathic pain and sensory disturbance post-injury.

P: A sensory nerve conduction study (NCS) will be performed using the antegrade recording method to derive sensory nerve action potentials (SNAPs) from the thumb, index, and middle fingers. This will help in determining nerve conduction issues. Based on the NCS results, a treatment approach will be developed to manage the neuropathic pain and aid recovery. Monitoring and symptom management will continue to support the patient's recovery.

S: The patient is a 14-year-old male who reports obesity and a recent injury to his left knee after jumping from three stairs. He landed on his left lower limb with the knee in full extension and external rotation. He experiences significant pain, a limited range of motion, and cannot bear weight on the injured knee.

O: The physical examination showed the left knee to be swollen and bruised, with tenderness over the tibial tuberosity and lateral joint line. The patient was unable to actively move the knee joint, and passive range of motion was painful. No signs of compartment syndrome, neurological, or vascular injury were noted. X-ray radiographs revealed a Watson-Jones type IIIB avulsion fracture of the tibial tuberosity apophysis. The CT scan showed a step of the articular surface greater than 2 mm extending to the posterior-lateral epiphyseal part of the proximal tibia (lateral tibial plateau).

A: The patient has a Watson-Jones type IIIB avulsion fracture of the tibial tuberosity with articular involvement extending to the lateral tibial plateau.

P: The plan includes admission to the hospital for operative management under general anesthesia. The procedure involves reducing the fracture without arthrotomy through an anterolateral approach. A tourniquet will be used to prevent excessive bleeding. Post-operative instructions for follow-up care and rehabilitation will be provided to aid recovery.

S: The patient reports having had a forehead reduction surgery about a year ago and is now concerned about a postsurgical linear hairless scar near the hairline. The scar is described as a long, straight line approximately 20 cm long and 1 cm wide.

O: No information provided.

A: Postsurgical linear hairless scar following forehead reduction surgery. Potential candidate for hair transplantation to address cosmetic concerns related to the scar.

P: Discussed hair transplantation as a treatment option to camouflage the scar. Explained the procedure involves harvesting around 700 follicular units (FUs) from the occipital area and transplanting them at a density of 35 FUs per square centimeter into the scarred area. The operation would take about 2.5 hours in a single session, with an expected graft survival rate of approximately 80% and significant improvement in scar appearance based on the Patient and Observer Scar Assessment Scale (POSAS). Recommended scheduling a consultation with a hair transplant specialist for further assessment and planning.

S: The patient came for a routine check-up and reported persistent untreated conjunctivitis in the right eye. He has a history of hypertension treated with amlodipine and furosemide, and primary open-angle glaucoma managed with Timolol 0.5%. He previously underwent ectropion surgery on the right lower lid, bilateral cataract surgery with IOL implantation, and a YAG-laser capsulotomy. Recently, he experienced worsened vision to just hand movement, developed a corneal paracentral ulcer with localized edema, and reported a positive Tyndall effect.

O: Clinical examination showed the patient's BCDVA in the right eye was 0.7 logMAR (20/100), with intraocular pressure of 20 mmHg in the right eye and 15 mmHg in the left. Slit-lamp examination indicated conjunctival hyperemia and brownish non-granulomatous endothelial precipitates. Corneal fluorescein staining was negative, and the posterior segment had no pathological findings. Corneal scraping confirmed Aspergillus niger infection.

A: Initial suspicion of viral conjunctivitis. After further deterioration and worsening corneal condition, the diagnosis was updated to fungal keratitis due to Aspergillus niger.

P: Initially prescribed Ganciclovir gel 1.5 mg/g, 3 times a day. Following the worsening condition and fungal culture confirmation, the treatment was modified to topical voriconazole 2 mg/ml (1%) 4 times a day and moxifloxacin 0.3% 6 times a day. The patient was advised to monitor his condition closely and follow up with the treatment plan.

S: The patient, a 12-year-old female, reports experiencing fever for 5 days, melena, haematemesis, and haematuria with passage of blood clots. She has not experienced abdominal pain or other warning signs of dengue prior to admission.

O: The patient appears ill but adequately hydrated with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 15/15. Vital signs show a blood pressure of 125/75 mmHg, pulse rate of 90 beats per minute, and capillary refilling time of less than 2 seconds. Examination findings reveal clear lungs and a soft, non-tender abdomen. Both NS1 and IgM tests are positive for dengue. The dengue PCR reveals a serotype of DEN 2. An abdominal ultrasound shows no evidence of plasma leakage. Liver enzymes are mildly elevated with AST at 87 u/L and ALT at 56 u/L. The clotting profile is normal, but the complete blood count shows a hemoglobin level of 7 g/dL and a platelet count of 17 × 10^9/μL. 

A: The patient is diagnosed with primary dengue fever with bleeding manifestations.

P: The patient received a transfusion of 1 pint of blood and 4 units of platelets. Her symptoms resolved within the next few days post-transfusion. Follow-up includes continued monitoring of blood counts and liver enzymes. Recommendations include resting, staying hydrated, and adhering to prescribed medications. Instructions were given to contact the clinician if any new symptoms or concerns arise.

S: The patient reports experiencing symptoms of angina pectoris for the past 9 months. The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia.

O: The electrocardiogram revealed ST-segment depression in anteroseptal leads and pathological Q waves in inferior wall leads. Echocardiography showed a normal left ventricle cavity size with good systolic function and no regional wall motion abnormalities, with a left ventricular ejection fraction of 57%. Coronary angiography revealed a severe stenosis in the proximal left anterior descending artery (LAD) and a chronic total occlusion (CTO) in the proximal right coronary artery (RCA). The complexity of the CTO was assessed using the J-CTO score (3) and the PROGRESS CTO score (2).

A: The patient has severe stenosis in the LAD, which was treated with a 3.5 mm × 18 mm biodegradable polymer drug-eluting stent. The RCA revascularization was challenging and initially unsuccessful with wire escalation strategies due to complex collateral connections.

P: The plan involves exploring alternative treatment options for RCA revascularization, including considering a retrograde approach. The patient is advised to continue taking medications and maintain a heart-healthy lifestyle. The doctor will discuss the case with colleagues to develop a tailored plan and closely monitor the patient's condition.

S: The patient is a former marathon runner who has been experiencing difficulty in breathing during exercise since their 60s. The patient reports no past illnesses until now. They were unaware of previously noted electrocardiogram abnormalities.

O: A recent treadmill test electrocardiogram revealed a complete left bundle branch block. Echocardiography showed an enlarged RCA (10 mm) and a vessel with blood flow into the pulmonary artery, with a left ventricular ejection fraction of 60% and mild mitral regurgitation. Coronary CT indicated the LCA arising from the dorsal side of the PA, with markedly dilated and tortuous coronary arteries. Cardiac catheterization showed contrast medium flowing from the RCA into the PA via the LCA, with pulmonary/systemic blood flow ratio of 1.4 and pulmonary artery pressure (systolic/diastolic/mean) at 39/19/28 mmHg. Adenosine-loading myocardial scintigraphy revealed ischemia in the left anterior descending branch.

A: The findings suggest a coronary artery anomaly with dilated and tortuous coronary arteries, contributing to ischemia and difficulty in breathing during exercise.

P: Surgical intervention was performed with a median sternotomy and cardiopulmonary bypass. The PA was incised longitudinally, and a 6-mm Gelsoft™ Plus was anastomosed end-to-end at the ostium of the LCA. Post-surgery, the patient will be closely monitored with regular follow-up to ensure recovery. Further instructions will be provided as needed.

S: The patient reports experiencing shortness of breath and a fever over 38 °C for two weeks. They have been diagnosed with left pneumonia and have a performance status score of 2 on the ECOG scale, with a Hugh-Jones classification of IV, indicating significant breathlessness. 

O: Observable findings include rhonchi in the anterior chest and an increased inflammatory response in laboratory studies. Tumor markers are within normal limits. A chest X-ray and CT imaging show an infiltrative shadow in the lower left lung field and a solid tumor in the left main bronchus with possible esophageal and aortic involvement. Bronchoscopy revealed almost complete occlusion of the left main bronchus by the tumor; cartilage rings were invaded. Rigid bronchoscopy improved cardiopulmonary function (PS 2 to 0, H-J IV to I). FDG-PET scan shows abnormal enhancement in the tumor with a maximum standard uptake value.

A: Tracheobronchial adenoid cystic carcinoma causing obstructive pneumonia.

P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition and develop a tailored treatment plan based on the PET scan results and clinical progress. Continue follow-up for further management of the tracheobronchial adenoid cystic carcinoma.

S: The patient reports feeling extremely tired, experiencing muscle aches, nausea, and a skin rash for about a month. Additionally, the patient notes blurry vision in the left eye for the past 5 days without double vision, pain with eye movements, flashing lights, floaters, or changes in color vision. They deny any recent sick contacts or travel history and have no past ocular or medical history. They have been taking non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs for muscle aches.

O: The patient has a malar rash and raised papules on the elbows and knees, worsening with sunlight exposure. Blood pressure is 115/70 mmHg. Visual acuity is 20/20 in the right eye and 20/100 in the left eye. Intraocular pressure is normal, with full and conjugate extraocular movements. The conjunctiva, cornea, and anterior chamber appear normal. There is bilateral retinal vascular engorgement, inner retinal whitening consistent with cotton wool spots, and superficial hemorrhages, mainly around the macula and optic nerve. OCT shows central macular edema in both eyes, more severe in the left, with serous subretinal fluid.

A: Possible autoimmune or inflammatory condition affecting the eyes and skin, with retinal changes suggestive of a condition like lupus or dermatomyositis.

P: Further tests and consultations are needed to confirm the diagnosis and determine the appropriate treatment plan. The patient is advised to monitor and manage symptoms, with follow-up as necessary.

S: The patient reports experiencing musical hallucinations (MH) that began suddenly six months ago during a stressful period. These MH occur daily, primarily in the afternoons, and consist of familiar Neapolitan, English, and French songs. The patient denies any associated emotional attachment or memories. The MH do not interfere with sleep or daily activities and weaken when listening to the radio or watching TV. There is no history of neurological illnesses, neurodegenerative disorders, psychopathological conditions, or auditory hallucinations. The patient has been diagnosed with hearing impairment and presbyacusis and uses bilateral mobile acoustic prostheses.

O: The patient has 5 years of education and is a housewife. Neurological evaluation indicates the occurrence of daily MH mainly in the afternoons. The patient has been using recommended bilateral mobile acoustic prostheses.

A: The differential diagnosis includes investigating the epileptic nature of the musical hallucinations.

P: Proceed with MRI-PET exam to investigate the epileptic nature of the MH. Obtain written informed consent for the use of data for publication in an anonymous form. Continue the use of bilateral mobile acoustic prostheses.

S: The patient reported multiple episodes of vomiting three days prior to the consultation. They also experienced reduced urine output and shortness of breath over the past couple of days. The patient confessed to a suicide attempt due to poor academic performance, having ingested 900 mg of amlodipine (90 tablets of 10 mg each).

O: During examination, the patient was conscious, oriented, and afebrile with a blood pressure of 70/50 mm Hg and a pulse rate of 108/min. Oxygen saturation was 85% on room air, and the patient was tachypnoeic. Observable findings included engorged neck veins, bilateral pedal edema, bilateral pleural effusion, and ascites. Blood investigations revealed acute kidney injury with serum creatinine of 1.8, Type I respiratory failure from arterial blood gas analysis, sinus tachycardia on ECG, and confirmed bilateral pleural effusion on chest roentgenogram. A diagnostic pleural tap showed a transudative picture. Blood and urine cultures were sterile, and the serum pro-calcitonin level was normal.

A: The patient was diagnosed with acute kidney injury and Type I respiratory failure, secondary to an overdose of amlodipine. The presentation was consistent with shock unresponsive to fluid resuscitation and inotropic support. 

P: The patient was resuscitated with IV fluid bolus, oxygen inhalation, and dual inotropes (noradrenaline and dopamine). After shock remained unresponsive, inotropes were escalated, and empirical antibiotics were added. Targeted management for the overdose included IV calcium gluconate infusion, IV bolus of 50% dextrose followed by regular insulin, and IV dextrose to counteract the effects of amlodipine. The patient showed improvement with these interventions, leading to the tapering and stopping of inotropes and restoration of adequate urine output. The patient is to be discharged in three days with stable vitals and instructed to follow up in the psychiatry outpatient department to address underlying issues related to the suicide attempt.

S: The patient reports a history of Tetralogy of Fallot repair with a Dacron Patch over a large ventricular septal defect. They have experienced fever and weight loss for the past 2 months and left-sided abdominal pain for the past week. The patient was previously treated for right-sided pneumonia and suspected infective endocarditis with ceftriaxone and gentamicin but had persistent fevers of 40°C.

O: On examination, the patient had grade IV clubbing without cyanosis, a loud pansystolic murmur at the left sternal edge, and tenderness on palpation of the left upper abdomen. Initial investigations showed a high white blood cell count, elevated C-reactive protein, left mid and right lower lung zone infiltrates on chest X-ray, and an ill-defined splenic lesion on abdominal ultrasound. Blood cultures were negative. Echocardiogram revealed vegetation on the VSD patch, dehiscence, a large VSD, and moderate right ventricular outflow obstruction. CT abdomen with contrast showed multiple liver, splenic, and lung abscesses, an infarcted left kidney, and a thrombus at the bifurcation of the aorta. Post-surgery echocardiogram showed no residual VSD or vegetation, mild left ventricular dysfunction, and moderately reduced right ventricular function.

A: The patient has septic embolic phenomena likely secondary to infective endocarditis with complications involving vegetations on the VSD patch and obstruction. There are multiple organ abscesses and an infarcted left kidney with thrombus formation.

P: The patient underwent redo-sternotomy for removal of vegetations and repair of the Tetralogy of Fallot. Monitoring and adjusting treatment based on test results will be ongoing. The patient's recovery will be closely observed with regular follow-ups to watch for new or worsening symptoms.

S: The patient has been experiencing bilateral headaches for over 10 years, with a noted increase in progression in the past year. He denies any additional symptoms such as fever, nausea, vomiting, altered consciousness, sensory or movement disorders, visual disturbances, facial palsy, aphasia, incontinence, or convulsions.

O: Upon admission, the patient's vital signs and neurologic examination were normal. Laboratory examinations were unremarkable. MRI revealed a dilated posterior horn of the right lateral ventricle containing a well-delineated oval mass measuring 1.3 × 1.2 × 1.0 cm. The mass was hypointense on T1-weight images with hyperintense spots and hyperintense on T2-weight and FLAIR images, with no enhancement on contrast.

A: The MRI findings suggest the presence of an abnormal brain mass, likely contributing to the patient's progressive headaches.

P: The patient underwent a stereotactic neuronavigator-guided ventriculoscopic procedure to address the mass. Follow-up is recommended to monitor recovery and detect any complications. The patient is advised to report any new or worsening symptoms immediately. Regular follow-up appointments are needed to ensure appropriate recovery.

S: The patient reports coughing up blood and mentions a history of spending childhood in northern Iran, raising sheep. After hospitalization, the patient developed respiratory distress and hypoxia.

O: Initial chest CT scan revealed a right lower lobe cyst, measuring 9 by 11 cm. A repeat CT scan showed air within the pulmonary cyst with a floating wavy membrane at the air-fluid level, indicative of the sign of the camalote. During urgent lobectomy, clear cystic fluid was suctioned, and a large ruptured cyst in the right lower lobe was found. Histopathology showed echinococcal scolices. Preoperative ecchinococcal ELISA IgG antibody assay was initially negative, but postoperative results were positive with a value of 7.15 IV.

A: Diagnosis of pulmonary echinococcosis (hydatid disease) based on the presence of echinococcal scolices and positive antibody assay postoperatively.

P: Prescribe a 4-week course of albendazole. Instruct the patient to take the medication as directed and encourage them to contact the clinic if they have any concerns or questions.

S: The patient reports a sudden onset of fever, shivers, and believes they might have an infection. They have a history of left-sided ductal breast cancer with lymph node involvement treated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy, partial mastectomy, axillary lymph node dissection, and radiation therapy in 1999. In 2001, they had right-sided localized ductal breast cancer treated with partial mastectomy. They developed lymphoedema in the left arm secondary to lymph node dissection, treated with compression stockings. They are on an ACE inhibitor and a beta-blocker for hypertension and have a known systolic murmur with normal echocardiographs in 2011 and 2017. The patient has experienced six episodes of erysipelas in the left upper arm, presenting with sudden spiking fever and spreading erythema in the same location. Previous blood cultures showed S. mitis group bacteria, with specific MIC values and sensitivity to clindamycin. Currently, the left upper arm is swollen, painful, and has sharply demarcated erythema measuring about 7 × 15 cm in the lymphoedematous area. No local portal of bacterial entry has been identified.

O: No objective findings such as vitals or test results provided in the conversation.

A: The clinician suspects the patient may be experiencing another episode of erysipelas based on the history and current presentation.

P: The plan includes performing tests and starting appropriate treatment for the suspected erysipelas. The patient is advised to follow up after the tests to discuss the next steps in the treatment plan.

S: The patient reports experiencing low back pain and worsening left lower extremity pain, described as neurogenic claudication, which started after a fall from standing height around five months ago. The left leg pain began about a month following the initial back pain. The patient denies any recent fever or difficulty passing urine. There is a history of mild hypertension but no history of malignancy or use of anticoagulant drugs.

O: The patient's platelet count and prothrombin time are within normal ranges. Examination revealed full power and symmetrical reflexes in both lower extremities, with a patchy reduction in sensation in the left lower limb. A left L5 nerve root block was administered but was effective for only three days. A lumbar MRI without gadolinium, performed four months after symptom onset, showed a posterior mass at L4/5 with specific signal characteristics on T1- and T2-weighted images. A second MRI with gadolinium showed an isointense mass and a slightly extended hyperintense area on T2-weighted imaging, with no significant enhancement. Symptoms remained unchanged between the two MRIs.

A: The clinical assessment suggests a possible spinal tumor at L4/5. Despite the findings, there was no significant change in symptoms between imaging studies, and there is an absence of enhancement on MRI with gadolinium.

P: The plan is to continue monitoring the patient's symptoms and consider additional imaging or treatment options if necessary. Current efforts will focus on managing the patient's pain and ensuring comfort. The patient is advised to report any changes in their condition.

S: The patient is a 21-year-old African American man with a psychiatric history of schizophrenia, initially diagnosed at age 19. He has a history of frequent hospitalizations due to nonadherence with his home medications. The patient was transferred from the psychiatry unit to the medical floor to rule out sepsis after developing fever and tachycardia. He reports no pain, vomiting, diarrhea, loss of consciousness, or seizures.

O: Initial labs and urine toxicology were within normal limits. Admission vitals included a temperature of 102.4 degrees Fahrenheit, BP of 115/81 mmHg, HR of 114 beats per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. The physical examination was significant for mild dehydration. No skin rash, jugular venous distension, basal crepitation, or pedal edema were present. Cardiac auscultation revealed a tachycardic heart rate but was otherwise normal. Apex beat was located in the 5th intercostal space, midclavicular line; heart sounds S1 and S2 were normal with no rubs, murmurs, or gallop rhythm. Peripheral extremities were warm with a normal capillary refill.

A: The patient is being evaluated to rule out sepsis. The history of nonadherence with medication and recent change to clozapine could be contributing factors to his current condition.

P: Continue monitoring the patient’s condition and adjust treatment as necessary. Emphasize the importance of medication adherence to prevent further complications and hospitalizations. No specific new treatments or medications were discussed in the conversation.

S: The patient reports feeling feverish, experiencing a rapid heartbeat, and having nausea and vomiting for the past three days. The patient was brought in from an assisted living facility and has a past medical history of profound intellectual disability, schizophrenia, posttraumatic stress disorder, Parkinson's disease, gastroesophageal reflux disease, and a seizure disorder.

O: On admission, the patient had a temperature of 102.5°F, pulse of 123 bpm, respiratory rate of 40 breaths per minute, O2 saturation of 96% on room air, and blood pressure of 154/84 mmHg. Physical examination showed moderate distress, diaphoresis, agitation, tachycardia, and tachypnea. Chest X-ray showed no acute cardiopulmonary disease, and ECG indicated sinus tachycardia with possible right atrium enlargement and ventricle hypertrophy. Lab results revealed segmented neutrophil at 92.8% and absolute neutrophil count of 9.19 k/cmm, decreased hemoglobin and hematocrit at 12.8 and 38.0%, and an initial lactic acid level of 1.96 mmol/L increasing to 2.63 mmol/L. Metabolic panel showed sodium at 149, chloride at 114, BUN at 37 mg/dL, AST at 136, and ALT at 43. Urinalysis had trace blood and urine ketones of 40 mg/dL. Urine culture was negative after 48 hours, and blood cultures were negative after five days. Influenza screen and viral PCR were negative.

A: The patient was diagnosed with sepsis of unknown origin.

P: The patient was started on antibiotic therapy with vancomycin, levofloxacin, and piperacillin/tazobactam and received fluid resuscitation. The patient’s progress will be monitored closely, with treatment adjustments as needed. The patient’s home medications include paliperidone 3mg daily and haloperidol 2mg daily. Follow-up arrangements have been made.

S: The patient reports a family history of seizures, high blood lactate levels, and easy fatigability. The patient developed generalized epilepsy at age 14, which has been controlled with valproic acid. At age 16, the patient experienced tachypnoea and tachycardia, along with increased serum glucose and lactate levels. The patient also has diabetes, ketoacidosis, and persistent high lactate levels and tachycardia despite treatment. The patient recently experienced limb weakness, external ophthalmoplegia, respiratory acidosis, and respiratory failure type II, requiring intubation and a tracheotomy.

O: Neurological examination showed external ophthalmoplegia, mild limb weakness, and pyramidal signs, but no myoclonus or cognitive abnormalities. Laboratory tests revealed elevated plasma lactate (9.4 mmol/L), pyruvate (0.35 mmol/L), and glucose (12.5 mmol/L) levels. Urine tests for glucose and ketones showed positive results (3+ and 2+, respectively). Arterial blood gas analysis indicated low pH (7.23). The patient’s HbA1c was 14.60%. Fasting plasma insulin and post-prandial insulin values were 112.54, 298.03, and 73.

A: The patient has a diagnosis of diabetes, ketoacidosis, and generalized epilepsy. Persistent high lactate levels and tachycardia have been noted, along with respiratory and neurological complications.

P: The plan includes monitoring the patient's condition and developing a treatment plan for diabetes, ketoacidosis, and generalized epilepsy, along with managing high lactate levels and tachycardia. Guidance will be provided on treatment adherence, and regular follow-up appointments are recommended.

S: The patient reports experiencing severe long-term restless legs syndrome (RLS). They previously used pramipexole and pregabalin but discontinued due to side effects. The patient still experiences severe phases of restlessness and sleepless nights occasionally, but notes general improvement in sleep after recent treatment adjustments.

O: Initial baseline polysomnography (PSG) results indicated low sleep efficiency at 67%, frequent arousals at 22 per hour, short wakefulness phases with restlessness, periodic leg movements at 6 per hour, and light obstructive sleep apnea with an apnea-hypopnea index of 7.5 per hour and oral desaturation index of 8 per hour. Follow-up PSG after 2.5 months showed improved sleep efficiency at 90% and a PLMS index reduced to 1 per hour.

A: The patient has severe long-term RLS with previous intolerance to pramipexole and pregabalin. Improvements in sleep metrics and symptoms were observed with current treatment, including the addition of BP 50% tablets.

P: Continue the current treatment regimen that includes rotigotine patches and L-DOPA for acute phases, with magnesium as needed, and BP 50% tablets four per day (0-0-2-2). Schedule another follow-up and PSG if severe restlessness and sleepless nights persist.

S: The patient reports having blurry vision in the left eye for the past 8 months and was previously diagnosed with uveitis. They have received both local and systemic corticosteroid treatment, but the inflammation persisted. The patient also experiences non-ocular symptoms, including oral ulcers and shoulder arthralgia, but no skin or genital lesions. There is no family history of autoimmune diseases, and a previous colonoscopy showed no abnormalities.

O: The examination reveals fine keratic precipitates and an anterior chamber cell grade of 2+ in the left eye. The right eye shows a vitreous cell grade of 1+, and the left has a grade of 2+. Fluorescein angiography (FA) shows leakage and hyperfluorescence in the left eye. The best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) is 1.2 in both eyes, and intraocular pressures (IOPs) are 16 mmHg in the right eye and 22 mmHg in the left eye. Tests including Interferon-gamma release assay, tuberculin tests, rapid plasma regain assay, and Treponema pallidum antibody hemaglutination test were negative. Angiotensin-converting enzyme, antinuclear antibody, matrix metalloproteinase-3, and anti-citrullinated protein antibody levels are normal. The patient tested negative for HLA-B51.

A: Incomplete type of Behçet's disease is suspected based on symptoms and exclusion of other conditions, as per the Japanese diagnostic criteria.

P: Continue treatment with 0.1% dexamethasone eye drops four times a day, tropicamide/phenylephrine eye drops once a day, and 5 mg of prednisolone orally per day. The patient is referred to a pediatrician for further investigation. Regular monitoring and communication with the clinic are advised.

S: The patient is a 14-year-old boy from Fars province, Iran, experiencing failure to thrive, fatigue, muscular dystrophy, generalized muscular atrophy, kyphoscoliosis, and flexion contracture of the knees and elbows. His motor symptoms began at age four, with frequent falls worsening over time. He has a family history of consanguinity but no genetic disorders. The patient had two prior admissions to the pediatric ICU for pneumonia and respiratory distress and now uses a BiPAP machine for nasal speech and sleep apnea. He started walking at 11 months with no motor milestone delays and was diagnosed with scoliosis at age 12, now requiring bracing.

O: The patient is cachectic with generalized muscular atrophy. Physical exam shows decreased muscle power in shoulder-girdle muscles, foot extensors, and limb muscles (4/5 MRC scale), pes cavus, and contractures of knees and elbows. Spine rigidity with a chin-sternum distance of 15 cm is noted. Transthoracic echocardiography indicates mild pulmonary hypertension and tricuspid regurgitation. Pulmonary function tests show FEV1 at 35% and FVC at 32% of predicted values. Serum calcium is 8.2 mg/dL, phosphorus 3.1 mg/dL, CPK is 340 U/L, and LDH is 1200 U/L. Needle EMG reveals myopathic changes in deltoid, biceps, tibialis anterior, and rectus femoris muscles.

A: The patient presents with clinical signs and test results suggestive of a form of muscular dystrophy, with associated respiratory involvement. The presence of high CPK and LDH, along with myopathic changes observed on EMG, supports this assessment. 

P: The plan includes continued use of the BiPAP machine to assist with respiratory issues. Ongoing monitoring and development of a comprehensive treatment plan focusing on muscle and respiratory issues will be pursued. Regular follow-up appointments are necessary for further evaluation and management of the patient's condition.

S: The patient initially presented with severe redness and discharge in the left eye. A follow-up visit revealed the symptoms had alleviated after treatment. However, the patient later reported blurred vision in the left eye, which was addressed in subsequent visits.

O: Initial examination revealed redness and discharge in the left eye. Immunochromatography test was positive for adenovirus. Follow-up showed the visual acuity in the left eye was 10/20, with mutton-fat keratic precipitates (KPs) and multiple stellate keratitis. No cells or flare were found in the anterior chamber. After further treatment, the patient’s eye improved, with visual acuity recovering to 20/20 and resolution of KPs and stellate keratitis.

A: Initial diagnosis was adenoviral conjunctivitis. Subsequent developments included blurred vision related to mutton-fat KPs and stellate keratitis.

P: The patient was initially prescribed levofloxacin and fluorometholone instillation four times daily, which alleviated the initial symptoms. Following the recurrence of symptoms, levofloxacin and betamethasone were prescribed to be used four times daily. The patient was advised to return for follow-up, which showed resolution of symptoms and recovery in visual acuity. The doctor instructed to return if further issues arise.

S: The patient, a 57-year-old construction worker, experienced a mechanical fall where he tripped and hit his head on a flower pot, resulting in a loss of consciousness for about 10 minutes. Upon regaining consciousness, he reported confusion, right-sided weakness, double vision, and difficulty speaking. He has no history of seizure-like activity.

O: On initial examination, the patient was alert and oriented but exhibited dysarthria, ataxia, nystagmus, right-sided weakness, hyperreflexia, and a positive Hoffman's sign bilaterally, with an up-going plantar response on the left. Systolic blood pressure in the emergency room was elevated, ranging from 202 to 220 mmHg. A CT scan showed no acute intracranial findings; however, an MRI revealed non-enhancing T2/FLAIR hyperintensities in the brainstem, cerebellar peduncles, and periventricular white matter. The cervical spine MRI indicated degenerative changes at the C5-6 level. A lumbar puncture showed elevated proteins (80 mg/dl), normal white blood cell count (4/mcL), red blood cell count (17/mcL), and glucose level of 63 mg/dl, with an opening pressure of 13 cm.
