A: The clinical findings and imaging suggest potential damage or inflammation in the brainstem, cerebellum, and periventricular white matter. Elevated blood pressure and findings from the lumbar puncture also inform the assessment.

P: The patient was transferred to the neuro-intensive care unit (NICU) for further management of high blood pressure, initiated on carvedilol 12.5 mg three times daily and labetalol as needed, with a target systolic blood pressure of 140 to 180 mmHg. Monitoring and ongoing evaluation will continue, with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary.

S: 
Joe reports his right knee feels swollen and painful after a skiing accident. He describes a fall where his skis dug into the snow, causing him to do a partial cartwheel and feel a pop in his knee. The accident occurred on Saturday. He is experiencing pain, especially with movement, but can walk a little. He has been taking Advil, icing, and occasionally applying heat for relief. This is his first knee injury. Joe also mentions his right shoulder feels bruised and tender, as he landed on it during the fall.

O: 
Vitals: Temperature 97.9°F, Heart Rate 64 bpm, Respirations 16/min, Blood Pressure 110/74 mmHg, O2 Saturation 98%. On physical exam, there is edema and ecchymosis on the right knee, with pain on palpation and mild pain during flexion and extension. The range of motion is nearly full but tight. Right knee x-ray shows no fractures or bony abnormalities. Right shoulder shows bruising and tenderness upon raising the arm.

A: 
Right knee contusion. Possible right shoulder injury due to pain and tenderness upon raising the arm.

P: 
For the right knee: Rest, apply ice 2-3 times a day for 20 minutes, and take NSAIDs like ibuprofen every 6-8 hours as needed. If not improved, consider physical therapy. For the right shoulder: Order an x-ray to rule out any additional injury. Follow-up after x-ray results and continue monitoring symptoms.

S: The patient is a 25-year-old non-smoker woman with a diagnosis of CVID experiencing respiratory issues, feeling that her condition is progressing. She has a history of LIP progression, granulomatous lung disease with lymphocytic infiltration, and previously experienced subileus due to splenic extension. She reports ineffective treatments with adjusted IVIG and high-dose glucocorticoids and continues to feel short of breath.

O: The patient has a spleen size extended to the iliac crest measuring 27 cm, LPD with hyperviscosity, paraproteinemia, high β2M and IgM levels, reduced FVC of 60%, and low diffusion capacity for carbon monoxide at 49%. Cultures (BAL, blood, urine, bone marrow, sputum) were negative for bacteria, mycobacteria, actinobacteria, and fungi. BAL fluid showed increased cell count, predominantly neutrophils and lymphocytes, without significant NKT cell predominance.

A: The patient has CVID with LIP and granulomatous lung disease. Persistent respiratory issues suggest progression despite current treatments. Continued high IgM-paraproteinemia and risk of opportunistic infections indicate management challenges.

P: Continue monitoring the patient’s condition closely, adjust treatment plans as needed, and maintain current prescribed treatments. Ensure regular follow-up appointments, and the patient should report any changes in symptoms or concerns. Consider ongoing assessment for possible alternative therapies and management strategies.

S: The patient reports a history of atopic dermatitis since age 2, with worsening over the past 4 years. Current medications include 250mg cyclosporine, 5mg desloratadine in the morning, and 25mg hydroxyzine in the evening, alongside moisturizing lotion and clobetasol propionate cream twice daily. The patient also manages hypothyroidism with 50mg levothyroxine sodium daily, metabolic syndrome with 500mg metformin hydrochloride daily, and depression and insomnia with 25mg agomelatine and 5mg buspirone daily. The patient mentions a past hospitalization for an infection related to skin lesions in late 2015 and subsequent outpatient treatments. Recently, there has been a 12kg weight loss, menstrual changes, and telogen effluvium after switching to mycophenolate mofetil, 1g every 12 hours, tapering off cyclosporine.

O: On examination, the patient has extensive eczema covering 90% of skin tissue, intense pruritus, and dry skin. The SCORAD index for atopic dermatitis is 45, indicating severe disease.

A: The patient's atopic dermatitis is severe and poorly controlled, affecting the quality of life despite treatment adjustments. Current symptoms and side effects suggest medication intolerance or inefficacy. Additional diagnoses include allergic rhinitis, hypothyroidism, metabolic syndrome, depression, and insomnia.

P: The plan includes exploring alternative treatment options with a multidisciplinary team to find a more effective management strategy for atopic dermatitis and improve the patient's quality of life. Close monitoring of symptoms will be essential. A new treatment plan will be developed and communicated to the patient.

S: The patient, an 8-month-old girl, was born at full term by natural delivery. The mother reports developmental issues, including a slow pupillary light reflex, hyporeflexia, and hypotonia in all limbs.

O: The patient's cerebral MRI revealed widened ventricles, cisterns, and sulci, indicative of delayed myelination. The EEG results were normal. Urinary organic acid analysis showed increased excretion of GHB. A compound heterozygous mutation (c.1344-2delA/c.1529C > T) was identified, inherited separately from each parent.

A: The patient presents with signs consistent with developmental delay. The genetic mutations and MRI findings suggest a specific but unspecified genetic condition affecting development.

P: Monitor the child's development and provide interventions as needed. Regular follow-ups and adherence to any recommended interventions are advised. There is no current cure for the specific genetic mutation identified.

S: The patient is a 40-year-old white man with severe addiction to nicotine and caffeine, experiencing positive psychotic symptoms including auditory and visual hallucinations. He has no family history of medical conditions. Previously, he was unresponsive to haloperidol and promazine, which were initially prescribed. On clozapine therapy, he developed tachycardia on the sixth day.

O: Patient was admitted to psychiatry in December 2017. During treatment with clozapine, propranolol was prescribed for cardioprotection. Vital signs before ECT showed blood pressure at 110/70 mm Hg, heart rate at 92/min, axillary temperature at 36.0°C, and ECG showed a normal sinus rhythm. After ECT, the patient experienced gastric pain, appeared pale and tachypnoic, and had no palpable radial pulse. Troponin T level was 1956.

A: The patient has persistent psychosis unresponsive to initial antipsychotic treatments. Clozapine was initiated, but led to tachycardia. No improvement in psychosis post-clozapine. ECT was pursued after rigorous evaluation, but post-ECT complications included significant gastric pain and elevated troponin T indicating potential cardiac stress or injury.

P: Discontinue diazepam, continue monitoring post-ECT complications closely. Evaluate and manage cardiac condition given elevated troponin T and lack of palpable radial pulse post-ECT. Adjust psychiatric medication regimen as necessary based on patient response and side effects. Provide continuous supportive care and reassessment of psychosis management plan.

S: The patient reports persistent aching pain in the abdomen and lower extremities lasting for 20 days, along with severe hair loss over the past 10 days. The patient denies any significant past health issues or medication usage and is unaware of any accidental poisoning.

O: Physical examination reveals diffuse alopecia of the scalp and evidence of liver function damage with ALT at 154.8 u/l and AST at 49.2 u/l. Tests for urine mercury, hair arsenic, and blood lead levels are normal. Elevated thallium levels were found in urine (4677.0 μg/l) and blood (312.1 μg/l), confirming thallium poisoning. Thallium levels decreased after treatment.

A: The patient is diagnosed with thallium poisoning, confirmed by elevated thallium concentrations in urine and blood. The neurological manifestations and liver function are improving with treatment.

P: The patient is receiving ten cycles of hemoperfusion and hemodialysis, each lasting 5 to 6 hours daily. Additionally, they are being treated with Prussian blue 2.64 g every 6 hours, forced diuresis, 20 mmol potassium chloride twice daily, and intravenous B complex. Pain is expected to decrease slowly, with hair regrowth anticipated during a 6-month follow-up. The cause of poisoning is unknown, despite an investigation.

S: The patient presented with a headache, fatigue, and decreased stamina. They have a medical history of diabetes, hypertension, and a prior stroke. The patient has no history of rheumatic disease or underlying bleeding or clotting disorders. They expressed concern upon learning about the mass in the ascending aorta but opted for medical therapy over surgical intervention.

O: Initial tests revealed a mass in the ascending aorta consistent with an aortic mural thrombus, measuring 1.6 × 1.0 × 1.9 cm with some mobility. Hypercoagulability testing, including antiphospholipid antibody, beta 2 glycoprotein, factor V Leiden, lupus anticoagulant, and prothrombin gene mutation, returned negative results. The patient was observed inpatient for 48 hours, during which symptoms resolved.

A: Aortic mural thrombus was identified with no underlying hypercoagulability or known pathology contributing to its formation. Based on clinical findings and patient preference, a medical therapy path with anticoagulation was chosen.

P: Start anticoagulation therapy with apixaban due to its immediate therapeutic effect. The plan includes repeat radiographical surveillance and close clinical monitoring for symptom recurrence, increase in thrombus size, embolic phenomena, aortic valvular involvement, or coronary arterial compromise. The patient was followed for 15 months with serial CTA showing resolution of the thrombus. Following the latest visit and absence of symptoms, the patient was taken off anticoagulation.

S: The patient reported experiencing sudden and intense acute chest pain radiating to the back, described as a tearing sensation. The history includes undergoing investigation for an acute myocardial infarction, which revealed an acute type A aortic dissection.

O: Postoperative findings indicate the patient was intubated and ventilated on day 2, with urine output dropping below 20ml/hour and creatinine levels increased to 280 micromol/L, suggesting possible kidney issues. Abnormal blood gas levels were noted: pH 7.28, PO2 8.3 kpa, PCO2 5.1, HCO3 22 mEq/L, and Lactate 3.2 mmol. A chest X-ray post-dialysis catheter insertion showed the catheter tip abnormally positioned toward the hilum of the left lung at the T6 level, near the carina at T4/5, instead of the expected T2/3 level crossing the midline.

A: The patient was diagnosed with an acute type A aortic dissection requiring surgery. There is a possible complication concerning the dialysis catheter position, with a need for confirmation due to atypical placement.

P: The plan includes urgent surgical repair of the type A aortic dissection. Continuous veno-venous hemodialysis was initiated via a catheter placed under ultrasound guidance, though its use is pending further imaging to confirm correct catheter positioning. The patient will be closely monitored, and additional imaging will be performed to ensure correct catheter placement. Regular updates will be provided regarding the patient’s stability and any further interventions required.

S: The patient has a history of recurrent keratosis on the lower lip over the course of 3 years and was diagnosed with oral lichen planus (OLP) 2 years ago, which was treated with corticosteroids without complete relief. The patient reports no other skin or oral mucosal diseases, no history of smoking, alcohol consumption, or hospitalization, and has natural dentition. The patient's occupation involves selling crabs at a fish market and often handling and tasting crabs.

O: A hyperkeratotic white plaque lesion was observed on the patient's lower middle lip, which altered to the lateral side. A superficial excisional biopsy showed an initial stage of SCC (squamous cell carcinoma), suspected to result from chronic irritation. Additional imaging (CT, MRI, PET-CT) showed no metastasis or significant hypermetabolic lesions.

A: The differential diagnosis includes malignancy transformation of oral lichen planus into SCC due to chronic irritation.

P: The plan is to perform a wide V-shaped wedge resection with excision involving the superficial lip mucosa and underlying orbicularis oris muscles with a 5.0-mm safety margin. Direct closure with layered sutures will follow after confirming negative margins in a frozen biopsy. The patient has been informed and will sign a consent form for the surgery, followed by close monitoring during recovery.

S: The patient reports experiencing a fever for 20 days, along with fatigue, weakness, joint pains, vomiting, diarrhea, chills, abdominal pain, and dark urine. The patient was previously diagnosed with anemia and treated with ferrous bisglycinate without improvement. They were admitted to a rural hospital with a diagnosis of pancytopenia and received 2 units of packed red blood cells. There is a suspicion of a lymphoproliferative disorder. The patient's past medical history includes posttraumatic osteomyelitis in the right humerus and septic arthritis in the right elbow.

O: The patient's vital signs are tachycardia (heart rate 131 bpm), tachypnea (breathing rate 45 per minute), and low oxygen saturation (91%). Physical examination findings include jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly (liver 6 cm below costal margin, spleen 2 cm below), fine crackles in the right lung, and a soft systolic heart murmur at the left sternal border and third intercostal space. Laboratory tests show thrombocytopenia, lymphopenia, hemoglobin 11.5 g/dL, WBCs 4600/µL, neutrophils 3404/µL, lymphocytes 1058/µL, platelets 59000/µL, elevated C-reactive protein 21.57 mg/dL, ALT 349 U/L, AST 135 U/L, total bilirubin 6.67 mg/dL, direct bilirubin 5.3 mg/dL, LDH 1376 IU/L, albumin 2.1 g/dL, hypertriglyceridemia 787 mg/dL, and hyperferritinemia >2000 ng/mL. Tests for HIV, dengue, malaria, Hepatitis B and C, CMV, EBV, and Mycoplasma were negative.

A: The differential diagnosis includes a lymphoproliferative disorder, given the pancytopenia, liver abnormalities, and suspicion raised from the transfer orders. Other underlying conditions are also being considered due to the complex presentation of symptoms and test results.

P: Further testing and consultation with specialists are necessary to determine the diagnosis and appropriate treatment plan. Continuous monitoring of symptoms and vital signs will be carried out. No specific treatment plan has been established yet.

S: The patient is a 26-year-old Hispanic male who presented to the emergency department with sudden numbness and weakness in his left arm, which resolved within one hour. Shortly after, he developed a moderate, pressure-like pain in the left upper abdominal quadrant, and experienced repeated vomiting episodes. He has a history of smoking 2-3 cigarettes per day, daily consumption of hard liquor, and use of illicit drugs, including cocaine and marijuana.

O: Initial evaluations included a CT of the head with and without contrast, a CTA of the cervical carotids and intracranial vessels, and an MRI of the brain without contrast, all of which were negative for any acute intracerebral hemorrhage or infarct. A CTA of the renal arteries indicated a left renal infarct with a filling defect. A transthoracic echocardiogram revealed mild to moderate dilation of the left ventricle (ejection fraction of 55%-60%) and mild dilation of the right ventricle. Two oval, mobile, pedunculated hyperechoic masses were identified: a 2.4 x 1.5 cm mass in the left ventricle and a 2.3 x 1.1 cm mass in the right ventricle. Coagulation studies detected the presence of lupus anticoagulant (LA).

A: The patient's symptoms and imaging results suggest cardiac thrombi with a resultant left renal infarct. The underlying presence of lupus anticoagulant indicates possible antiphospholipid syndrome as a contributing factor.

P: The plan is to initiate treatment with appropriate anticoagulants to manage the patient’s symptoms and prevent further thrombotic events. Follow-up appointments are essential to monitor progress and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: 
The patient is a 47-year-old male with no known comorbidities, experiencing bilateral anterior uveitis. He reports generalized weakness and fatigue, making it difficult to walk without assistance. The patient did not experience chest pain, dyspnea, altered bowel habits, syncopal episodes, headaches, dizziness, or substance abuse.

O:
On examination, the patient had bilateral periorbital puffiness, appeared lethargic but alert and well-oriented, with a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 15/15. Vitals were: heart rate 80 bpm, blood pressure 70/50 mm Hg, respiratory rate 20/min, temperature 98.6°F. Neurological exam showed 4/5 power in all muscles, intact pain, touch, proprioception, and no cerebellar signs or impaired reflexes. Ophthalmological exam revealed normal visual acuity and normal pupillary reflexes. Initial workup ruled out septic shock; elevated TLC with neutrophilia likely due to prednisone use.

A:
The patient initially suspected of septic shock was ruled out as cultures were normal. Generalized weakness and hypotension could be related to prednisone use and its effects on leukocyte count.

P:
Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely. Continue current treatment of intravenous fluids, norepinephrine, hydrocortisone (100 mg every eight hours), and tazobactam/piperacillin (4.5 g every eight hours). Adjust treatment plan as needed based on patient's response and any new symptoms. Follow-up regularly and report any new or worsening symptoms.

S: The patient reports being slightly obese and a current smoker with over 50 pack-years, and drinks alcohol moderately. He was admitted to the hospital with sudden onset hemoptysis and headache. Previously diagnosed with hypertension with a blood pressure of 240/110 mmHg. No history of disease or medication.

O: Initial CT scans showed no brain findings and alveolar hemorrhage in the chest. Echocardiogram revealed mild to moderate mitral valve regurgitation and prolapse. Admission vitals: temperature 37.6°C, heart rate 98 bpm, respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute, blood pressure 177/89 mmHg. Arterial blood gas showed mild hypoxemia: pH 7.47, pCO2 34 mmHg, pO2 68 mmHg, HCO3 18 mmol/L, O2 saturation 93%. Blood tests normal except elevated uric acid levels. Chest CT revealed alveolar hemorrhage and consolidation in the right middle lobe. Abdominal CT showed slightly enlarged liver and bilateral adrenal lesions possibly adenomas. Pulmonary function tests indicated obstructive lung disease. Bronchoscopy identified blood clots in the right middle lobe. HIV and TST tests were negative.

A: The patient presents with obstructive lung disease, alveolar hemorrhage likely associated with smoking history, and hypertension with previous severe blood pressure readings. Elevated uric acid and potential adrenal adenomas noted. Mild mitral valve regurgitation and prolapse also present.

P: Continue empiric broad-spectrum antibiotic treatment with piperacillin-tazobactam and oxygen supplementation. Monitor progress and follow up regularly. Encourage the patient to quit smoking and reduce alcohol consumption for overall health improvement. No further immediate brain imaging as per patient’s refusal.

S: The patient is a 65-year-old man with advanced renal cell carcinoma and has undergone 1 cycle of combination Ipilimumab/Nivolumab therapy. He reports chest pain and dyspnea. He also mentions increased fatigue and experiencing irregular heartbeats.

O: No information provided.

A: The clinician is concerned about potential myocarditis related to the patient's immunotherapy. This condition might be causing the chest pain, dyspnea, fatigue, and irregular heartbeats. Myocarditis is associated with elevated cardiac enzymes, left ventricular dysfunction, and myocardial inflammation.

P: The plan includes an initial evaluation to investigate the patient's cardiac symptoms. This involves assessing for hypervolemia and pulmonary edema, conducting an ECG to check for ST-segment changes, measuring cardiac markers, and evaluating ejection fraction with a transthoracic echocardiogram. A cardiac MRI will be performed to detect any myocardial inflammation. Based on the findings, if myocarditis is confirmed, the patient's Ipilimumab/Nivolumab therapy will be discontinued, and he may be transferred to the Cardiac Care Unit for continuous telemetry monitoring under cardiology care.

S: The patient reported feeling extremely tired and lethargic over a couple of weeks, along with severe backache, leg, and rib pain unrelieved by opioids. These symptoms led them to the emergency department in June 2015.

O: Upon initial examination, the patient exhibited leukocytosis with a white cell count of 67 × 10^9 cells/l and 34% lymphoblasts per flow cytometry. Hemoglobin levels were 12.3 g/dl, and platelet count was 49 × 10^9/l. A bone marrow aspirate and biopsy confirmed Philadelphia chromosome-positive (Ph+) precursor B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). During subsequent treatment, the patient achieved complete molecular remission with negative BCR-ABL1 p190 transcripts via RT-PCR, but experienced complications such as constipation, febrile neutropenia, and pneumonia.

A: The patient was diagnosed with Ph+ precursor B-cell ALL. Treatment led to complete molecular remission, though complications such as constipation, febrile neutropenia, and pneumonia were noted during therapy.

P: The patient was initially enrolled in the UKALL14 protocol, receiving multi-drug induction regimens followed by consolidation treatment with myeloablative conditioning and stem cell transplant. Continuous monitoring and regular follow-ups are recommended to maintain stability and address any future complications promptly.

S: The patient, a pediatric male, developed hypertension following a right heminephrectomy for neuroblastoma. After surgery, he had severe renal artery stenosis and right kidney atrophy, leading to refractory hypertension treated with Transcatheter Arterial Embolization. He needed a transfusion due to anemia, after which he experienced anxiety, breathlessness, spitting frothy sputum, and suffered a cardiac arrest. Intubation and CPR were administered, followed by cortisone treatment for suspected TRALI. He is currently in the ICU with respiratory support.

O: Post-transfusion, the patient became anxious, breathless, and produced frothy sputum, leading to cardiac arrest. Intubation and 20 minutes of CPR were performed, restoring circulation. He was treated with cortisone. On presentation, vitals showed a heart rate of 160 bpm and blood pressure of 150/111 mmHg, with flesh-colored aqueous sputum from the endotracheal tube. Invasive ventilation parameters included tidal volume of 30ml, PI of 15cmH2O, and PEEP of 10 cmH2O in PCV mode. Arterial blood gas analysis showed a pH of 6.7, PO2 of 56mmHg, PCO2 of 28mmHg, lactate of 16 mmol/l, BE of -30, with FiO2 at 100%. No urine output noted in the first hour.

A: The patient likely experienced Transfusion-Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI) following a packed red blood cell transfusion which led to severe respiratory distress and cardiac arrest. Hypertension is secondary to renal artery stenosis and right kidney atrophy post-heminephrectomy.

P: Continue intensive care and respiratory support in the ICU. Monitor hemodynamic status and adjust ventilation settings as needed. Follow up on critical care ultrasound findings and adjust treatment accordingly. Monitor renal function closely, considering anuria post-incident. Further diagnostics and interdisciplinary team consultations may be necessary to address complex multi-system involvement.

S: Patient 2 has a history of seizures related to a left frontal hemorrhage from head trauma that occurred 2 months prior. The patient reported becoming unresponsive and having a 60-second episode of focal to bilateral tonic-clonic seizure. After initial treatment, they felt better, experienced no seizures for 4 days, but then had a 30-second focal clonic seizure involving the right face and hand with impaired awareness, leading to inattentiveness and somnolence. They experienced continuous right face and hand jerking, which was uncomfortable and scary. Later, they felt more alert, and the jerking stopped when lacosamide was added. However, on day 9, focal aware clonic seizures resembling the initial epilepsia partialis continua returned, occurring frequently, around 1 per hour, causing frustration.

O: Initial treatment included lorazepam 4-mg IV, levetiracetam 1500-mg IV loading dose, then 500-mg IV q12h. EEG on day 2 showed left frontal interictal sharp waves, and the patient became less somnolent. On day 5, the EEG showed 0.5 to 1/s lateralized periodic discharges locked to jerks, consistent with epilepsia partialis continua. Brain MRI revealed acute left temporoparietal infarction in addition to old traumatic brain lesions. Lacosamide 100-mg IV q12h reduced myoclonic jerks and improved alertness, but seizures returned on day 9, leading to an increase to 150-mg IV q12h.

A: Recurrent focal clonic seizures with features of epilepsia partialis continua, possibly related to acute left temporoparietal infarction and old traumatic brain lesions.

P: Continue monitoring seizure frequency and adjust medications as needed. Increase lacosamide to 150-mg IV q12h to try to control frequent focal seizures. Follow up on any changes in symptoms or new concerns.

S: The patient is an 84-year-old woman with a history of hypertension. She reports experiencing epigastric pain, nausea, and dizziness for the past 3 hours.

O: The patient underwent a 12-lead electrocardiogram which revealed a junctional rhythm at a rate of 40, 2 mm inferior ST-elevations, and lateral ST depressions. Initial high-sensitivity troponin-I level was 0.01 ng/mL. There was ostial total occlusion of the right coronary artery (RCA). Angiographic evaluation showed a smooth RCA with no coronary artery disease and abrupt termination of the distal PL2 branch. A computed tomography angiogram identified an aortic root thrombus measuring 21 × 16 mm extending into the right coronary sinus and near complete obliteration of the left atrial appendage with another large thrombus. Subsequent troponin-I levels peaked at 74 ng/mL. Transthoracic echocardiogram indicated inferobasal septal hypokinesis and an ejection fraction of 45%. MRI of the brain revealed multiple embolic cerebral infarcts and complete occlusion of the left internal carotid artery. Serial ECGs showed paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and resolution of ST-segment elevation.

A: The patient is diagnosed with acute myocardial infarction with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, aortic root thrombus, embolic cerebral infarcts, and hypokinetic heart function with an ejection fraction of 45%.

P: The patient is treated with aspirin, clopidogrel, intravenous heparin, and warfarin therapy after bridging. She will be discharged in good condition on hospital day 5 and scheduled for a follow-up appointment 6 months post-discharge.

S: The patient is a seven-month-old boy with a four-month history of fever and recurrent infections. Symptoms include intermittent bleeding from the nose, mouth, and anus, severe pallor, bruising, and failure to thrive with height and weight below the 3rd percentile. The patient's parents are first cousins.

O: Physical examination reveals severe pallor, bruising, and bilateral anterior and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, which is firm and tender. The liver is palpable at 9 cm, soft and non-tender; the spleen is also palpable, firm, and 3 cm in longitudinal axis. Previous tests show bicytopenia, leukocytosis, growth of Burkholderia cepacia and Staphylococcus aureus in blood cultures, and high inflammatory markers. Further investigations confirmed anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukocytosis, cellular marrow on bone marrow aspiration and trephine biopsy. Immunodeficiency workup indicated normal immunoglobulin levels and normal CD18 expression.

A: There is a strong suspicion of primary immunodeficiency due to persistent leukocytosis and recurrent infections.

P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition and develop a treatment plan tailored to the suspected primary immunodeficiency. Ongoing evaluation and adjustments of management will be necessary as more information becomes available.

S: The patient is a 24-year-old female diagnosed with Bruck syndrome, confirmed by genetic testing. She reports no family history of osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) or arthrogryposis multiplex congenita (AMC), and no parental consanguinity, dentinogenesis imperfecta, blue sclera, or hearing loss. Her birth weight was 2.5 kg. She has micrognathia and joint contractures from birth, affecting her upper and lower limbs with a limited range of motion in shoulders and hips. She experiences -30 degrees of extension in the knees, scoliosis with a thoracic curve of 51 degrees and a lumbar curve of 27 degrees, and spondylolisthesis at L5 with lumbar hyperlordosis. At 12 years, she developed scoliosis, and at 13 years she underwent posterior spine fusion from C7 to T10. She has had fractures in the right olecranon and right proximal humeral shaft, treated by casting and intramedullary flexible nails. At 23, she developed left ulnar nerve compression (cubital tunnel syndrome), treated with operative decompression and subcutaneous transposition. She also had bilateral clubfoot treated by casting and operative realignment on the right foot at age 2, and a right femur fracture at age 9, treated by intramedullary flexible nails.

O: The patient uses bilateral ankle-foot orthotics for mobility. She received pamidronate therapy intravenously in cycles for five years. Her last DEXA scan was normal for her age.

A: The patient presents with Bruck syndrome, confirmed by genetic testing. Clinical issues include joint contractures, scoliosis, spondylolisthesis, bilateral clubfoot, multiple fractures, and left ulnar nerve compression.

P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition and regular consultations with the healthcare team. Emphasize reaching out if new symptoms or concerns arise.

S:  
The patient reports experiencing decreasing central vision in both eyes over the past five years and mild night blindness. There is no significant medical history or family history of retinal disease.

O:  
The patient's best-corrected visual acuity is 20/60 in the right eye and 20/200 in the left eye. Examination reveals mild nuclear sclerotic cataracts and large areas of macular atrophy centered on the fovea with reticular pseudodrusen, peripapillary atrophy, and scattered areas of peripheral pavingstone degeneration. There is no intraocular inflammation. A recent electroretinogram (ERG) is within normal limits. Fundus autofluorescence (FAF) shows well-defined areas of atrophy sparing the central fovea in the right eye. Spectral domain OCT (SDOCT) reveals outer retinal and choriocapillaris atrophy with reticular pseudodrusen. OCTA indicates a marked absence of choriocapillaris flow and mildly attenuated retinal vasculature, which are not readily apparent on fluorescein angiography. Genetic testing for A3243G and C1QTNF5 mutations is negative.

A:  
The patient presents with symptoms and exam findings indicative of macular and chorioretinal atrophy with vascular changes. The cause remains unclear as genetic testing was negative.

P:  
The plan includes regular follow-up appointments for monitoring and potential adjustment of the treatment plan. Further investigation into possible causes and treatment options will be explored. The patient is advised to report any changes in vision or other symptoms.

S: The patient reports experiencing mild, intermittent epigastric pain associated with nausea and vomiting. The pain is exacerbated by food intake and improves with fasting. The patient's medical history is unremarkable.

O: Physical examination findings were unremarkable, with no palpable abdominal mass. A PET-CT scan revealed a mass located in the GEJ extending to the cardia with heterogeneous thickening, with no evidence of lymphadenopathy or metastasis. Endoscopic Ultrasound showed a T1 mass, and a pathology report from the endoscopic biopsy indicated a low-grade intestinal type adenocarcinoma staged as T1 GEJ Carcinoma (T1N0M0).

A: T1 GEJ Carcinoma (T1N0M0), low-grade intestinal type adenocarcinoma.

P: On May 22, 2016, the patient underwent an endoscopic submucosal dissection. The procedure was successful with satisfactory negative margins confirmed by intra-operative frozen section pathology. No other lesions or complications were found. The patient will continue to be monitored closely for any recurrence or metastasis, with follow-up every 18 months, as no recurrence or metastasis has been detected.

S: The patient is a 3-year-old boy with an 11-month history of hemoptysis and mild wet cough. He has experienced 7 months of intermittent low fever and right thoracic collapse, along with 5 months of right-sided chest pain. Despite initial antibiotic treatment, he continued to expectorate bloody sputum and experience chest pain.

O: A chest X-ray showed right-sided pulmonary consolidation and pleuritis. Chest imaging revealed pleural thickening. A contrast-enhanced CT revealed diffuse high-density opacities, patchy shadowing, calcifications, and cavitations in the lower lobe of the right lung, along with mixed-density irregular soft tissue in the right inferior mediastinum and calcification in the thickened pleura. Thoracoscopy identified a mass in the thoracic cavity with severely adherent, thickened, fibrotic pleura and consolidated, necrotic right lower lobe.

A: Differential diagnoses were mediastinal teratoma or multifocal myofibroblastoma. Histopathologic analysis of the pleura showed fibrous tissue without granuloma. Given the findings and continued symptoms, a surgical intervention was pursued.

P: The treatment plan included excision of the tumor and necrotic tissues, and repair of any air leaks. Continued monitoring for recovery and provision of follow-up care were recommended. The family was advised to contact the healthcare team if new symptoms appeared.

S: The patient is a 16-month-old boy who presented with growth retardation and hypotonia. He was born 5 weeks prematurely via cesarean section, with a birth weight of 2.0 kg and no history of asphyxia. He frequently experienced coughing, snoring, or a stuffy nose after birth. During the first 3 months, his development was relatively normal, but his independent activities were less than his peers. He showed crying weakness, limb weakness, hypotonia, and diurnal symptom fluctuation. He was suspected of having cerebral palsy. At 5 months, he exhibited poor grip strength and could not hold his neck stable. However, he was able to recognize his family and understand speech. There were no abnormal eye movements, convulsions, hidrosis, or ptyalism.

O: There were no peripheral nerve abnormalities in electromyography (EMG). Brain MRI showed bilateral widened frontotemporal extracerebral space, consistent with premature children, and myasthenia gravis was ruled out after examination and testing. No relevant genetic pathogenic mutations were detected for spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) in genetic testing.

A: The patient was initially suspected of myasthenia gravis, which was ruled out. Spinal muscular atrophy was suspected due to myasthenia and dyskinesia, but testing did not confirm it. The current consideration is a congenital hereditary metabolic disease.

P: The plan is to continue monitoring the patient's condition closely and provide appropriate treatment to manage his symptoms. Regular follow-ups are advised to ensure his well-being and address any emerging symptoms or concerns.

S: A 54-year-old male patient reports a history of severe psychotic disorder and drug-resistant epilepsy since age 6, congenital bilateral nerve palsy, type II diabetes mellitus, and dyslipidemia. He does not smoke or drink alcohol and has no known allergies. His medical regimen includes Levetiracetam, Oxcarbazepine, Clobazam, Ebastine, Pregabalin, Risperidone, Metformin, Ezetimibe, Eicosapentaenoic acid, and Omeprazole. Communication and cooperation challenges were noted.

O: The patient has an American Society of Anesthesiologist Physical Status of grade 3. Preoperative screening and clinical examination showed no pathological findings. ECG was normal, and chest X-ray did not reveal any issues. Preoperative airway evaluation revealed a Mallampati classification grade III, thyromental distance (TMD) <6cm, median teeth distance <3cm, and moderate cervical spine mobility.

A: Considering the difficult intubation anticipated due to airway evaluation findings and the patient's poor physical status, dexmedetomidine sedation is deemed more suitable than general anesthesia for the upcoming cataract surgery.

P: The plan is to use a sedation technique with dexmedetomidine. Prior to sedation, standard monitoring will be established, and an intravenous line will be set up. The patient will be prehydrated with 300 ml of Ringer's Lactate and given a single bolus of 50 mcg of Fentanyl as an adjuvant analgesic. Dexmedetomidine will be administered at a loading dose of 1 mcg/kg for 10 minutes, followed by a maintenance dose of 0.4 mcg/kg.

S: The patient reported symptoms of severe confusion, receptive aphasia, headaches, and dizziness. They admitted to not being compliant with their Xarelto medication, which was prescribed for atrial fibrillation.

O: MRI showed hyperintensity in the posterior medial left thalamus, bilateral hippocampi, and the left precentral gyrus on T2 FLAIR imaging with no contrast enhancement. CT scan revealed mild microvascular disease but no acute intracranial process or stenosis. Vital signs were BP 103/65 mmHg, HR 64 bpm, RR 18, and temperature 36.9°C. EEG indicated no seizures. CSF cultures were negative for HSV and VZV with normal differentiated cell count. CBC showed elevated lymphocyte levels of 3.89E9 cells and low creatinine levels of 0.73 mg/dL. MRI performed 2 weeks post-admission showed stable and asymmetric non-enhancing T2 FLAIR hyperintensity in the left thalamus and increased size of enhancing intra-axial lesion in the left precentral gyrus. Biopsy post-resection determined glioblastoma.

A: Initial differential included potential infection or inflammation. Final assessment after biopsy identified a neoplastic process, specifically glioblastoma.

P: The patient was started on IV acyclovir during hospital admission. A future treatment plan for glioblastoma and further discussions on treatment options were recommended. The patient will require ongoing communication with the healthcare team to adjust the management plan and support.

S: The patient is a 4-year-old Saudi boy who was born at term after an uneventful pregnancy, with a birth weight and length at the 30th centile. He has undergone cardiac surgery for correction of an atrial septal defect and repair of hemi-anomalous pulmonary venous drainage, as well as an orchiopexy for an undescended left testis. The family history is unremarkable.

O: The patient exhibits the following features consistent with RSTS Type 1: intellectual disability, highly-arched eyebrows, down-slanted palpebral fissures, broad nasal bridge, low-set posteriorly-rotated ears, thin upper lip, pouting of the lower lip, highly-arched palate, mild micrognathia, broad flat angulated thumbs, broad big toes, and overlapping post-axial toes. Additional noted features include a midline notch of the upper lip, bifid tip of the tongue, midline groove of the lower lip, plump fingers, broad and flat fingertips, and brachydactyly. Genomic DNA testing via NGS and Sanger Sequencing confirmed RSTS Type 1. A full systemic examination and radiological investigations revealed no other defects.

A: The patient has been diagnosed with Rubinstein-Taybi Syndrome (RSTS) Type 1, which has been confirmed through genetic testing. Differential diagnosis considered included Cornelia de Lang syndrome and Floating-Harbor syndrome, but these were ruled out by genetic tests.

P: The plan includes surgical correction of the patient's angulated thumbs. Post-operative follow-up requirements and any additional necessary guidance will be discussed after surgery.

S: The patient reports a severe burning sensation on the right chest wall and back for the past week, rated 8 out of 10 in intensity, worsened by deep breathing and walking. Additionally, he experiences sharp, moderate pain in the right upper abdomen and flu-like symptoms including fatigue, low-grade fever, night sweats, and generalized bony pains. The patient was prescribed acetaminophen and pregabalin by a general practitioner, which provided no relief. Medical history includes mild hypertension, hypothyroidism, a past episode of chickenpox at age 40, acute pericarditis, and pleuritis 10 years ago. The patient is retired, with past exposure to animals in rural Italy, owning three dogs, and a family history of thoracic surgery for a pulmonary hydatid cyst.

O: Blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg, heart rate is 90 beats per minute, and respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute. Heart and lung findings are within normal limits. Tenderness is present upon palpation of the right upper abdominal quadrant, but Murphy's and Blumberg's signs are negative. Allodynia and hyperesthesia are observed on the right chest wall. Blood test results show a White Blood Cell count of 9960/mm3 with an eosinophil count of 360/mm3 (3.6%).

A: Potential differential diagnoses include infection or allergic reaction as indicated by the eosinophil count. The symptoms and medical history may suggest a possible hydatid cyst or radiculopathy.

P: The patient is referred to the Division of General Surgery and Liver Transplantation, POIT Department at San Camillo Hospital – “Lazzaro Spallanzani” National Institute for Infectious Diseases (INMI) in Rome for further evaluation and management. Follow-up instructions include updating the doctor on progress and reaching out with any questions or concerns.

S: The patient reports a worsening right-sided headache, nausea, vomiting, cold-induced epistaxis, and blurring of vision from the right eye for several weeks. Additionally, the patient has experienced right facial numbness, a 25-pound weight loss, and increasing right tongue swelling over the past two months. 

O: The physical examination revealed a disconjugate gaze to the right and palsy of right cranial nerves VII and XII. Laboratory studies indicated 10% circulating blasts without evidence of coagulopathy or tumor lysis syndrome. Peripheral blood smear showed myeloblasts and promonocytes with granulated cytoplasm, irregular nuclei, and prominent vacuoles. CT imaging showed a large focus of edema in the right temporal lobe with hyperdense dural thickening in the right medial petrous apex and a 6 mm midline shift. MRI displayed an abnormal T1-intense signal in the dural surface of the right medial petrous region, paraclinoid region, sphenoid bone, and cavernous sinus extending to the foramen ovale and the right infratemporal fossa. An endoscopic biopsy revealed an MPO-positive blast population positive for CD34, CD117, HLA-DR, CD33, CD11b, and partial CD13, consistent with myeloid sarcoma. PET-CT showed intense FDG avidity in the right side.

A: The diagnostic impression is myeloid sarcoma, a rare malignant tumor, based on biopsy and imaging findings.

P: The treatment plan will be discussed and determined by a team of specialists to find the best course of action for the patient's condition.

S: The patient is a 32-year-old male with a history of HIV infection and a recent diagnosis of pulmonary tuberculosis. He reports experiencing headaches and fevers for the past 2 weeks and confusion since yesterday. He has been on antiretroviral therapy (zidovudine, lamivudine, efavirenz) and co-trimoxazole prophylaxis for about 5 years but admits to poor adherence. He completed 2 months of induction therapy for tuberculosis and is currently 3 months into continuation therapy. 

O: The patient's temperature is 38.6°C, blood pressure 112/71 mmHg, pulse 94 beats/minute, respiratory rate 48 breaths/minute, and oxygen saturation 98%. Physical examination reveals he is wasted, dehydrated, and experiencing rigors. Neurologically, his Glasgow Coma Scale score is 14/15 with nuchal rigidity and a positive Kernig's sign; cranial nerves are intact and limbs exhibit normal tone and power. A cryptococcal antigen assay is negative, and liver and renal function tests are normal. CSF analysis shows elevated opening pressure of 33 cm CSF, white cell count of 590/µl, and protein level of 419 mg.

A: The clinical findings and laboratory results suggest possible HIV-associated meningitis, potentially bacterial in origin, given the elevated CSF opening pressure and cell count. 

P: The patient is to be enrolled in a study on HIV/AIDS-related meningitis diagnostics and outcomes. Empiric therapy with ceftriaxone 2 g twice daily has been initiated for possible bacterial meningitis. Regular follow-up and adherence to medications are emphasized. Continued monitoring of the patient's condition and adjustment of treatment as necessary will be undertaken.

S: The patient reported having a mass on the right upper back, which initially arose as a radiation-induced injury following a prolonged heart catheterization procedure. The injury progressed from a burn to a chronic nonhealing ulcer, evolving into a malodorous, painful, outward-growing mass. The patient has a history of coronary artery disease and hyperlipidemia, with prior interventions including two stents and multiple heart catheterizations performed around seven years ago.

O: Examination revealed a fungating mass approximately 5 × 9 cm with central purulent necrosis and peripheral induration. Initial biopsies showed undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma without additional nodularity or adenopathy. Staging indicated localized disease with no metastasis by MRI and CT. Subsequent radical excision involved a 20 × 9 cm elliptical area, with reconstruction using a human dermal matrix. Histological analysis revealed a highly cellular spindle cell neoplasm, focal necrosis (less than 50% of sampled tissue), and 17 mitotic figures per 10 high-power fields.

A: The patient is diagnosed with undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma with localized disease, following the progression of a radiation-induced injury to a malignant state.

P: The patient underwent a radical surgical excision with reconstruction using a human dermal matrix. Close monitoring of the surgical site will continue, with directives to report any changes. Further treatment options will be discussed as necessary during follow-up consultations.

S: 
The patient reports developing an itchy rash covering the whole body nine days ago, which did not improve despite oral and topical medicines prescribed by a dermatologist. The patient also feels generally unwell, has lost their appetite, and was found to have liver function disorder through blood tests. The patient experiences a dull headache and blurry vision upon rising, worsened itching, conjunctival congestion, and jaundice. Past medical history includes a total hysterectomy for a uterine fibroid at age 35.

O: 
On admission, the patient's height is 162 cm, weight is 46.5 kg, temperature is 36.6 °C, blood pressure is 126/82 mmHg, pulse is 77 bpm, and SpO2 is 96% on room air. Examinations show conjunctival congestion, jaundice, erythemas, itching sensations on face and extremities, partially fused wheals, and small papules. There is no dryness in the mouth, pedal edema, purpura, superficial lymph nodes, or nocturnal sweating. Blood test results include AST 165 U/L, ALT 291 U/L, ALP 840 U/L, γ-GTP 373 U/L, and creatinine 3.08 mg. Abdominal imaging reveals thickening of the gallbladder wall.

A: 
The patient presents with symptoms of systemic rash, jaundice, and abnormal liver function tests, indicating potential liver dysfunction. The observed erythematous rash, elevated liver enzymes, conjunctival congestion, and gallbladder wall thickening suggest a differential diagnosis that may include liver pathology or systemic disease affecting the liver and skin.

P: 
The plan includes continued monitoring of the patient's condition with adjustments to care as necessary, considering the specified symptoms and test results. Further evaluation by the gastroenterological department may be warranted. Immediate relief of symptoms such as pruritus may be addressed through supportive care, and treatment may focus on managing liver dysfunction. Future follow-up and any additional testing should be considered based on the patient’s response to treatment and progression of symptoms.

S: The patient reported having issues with her right arm, including lymphedema and ecchymosis following a right-sided mastectomy and axillary lymph node excision in 2007 due to invasive adenocarcinoma. Despite a microsurgical lymphovenous derivation in 2009, these issues persisted. In 2017, she experienced a painful nodular and purpuric transformation of the skin on her right arm, with increasing pain.

O: A biopsy revealed cutaneous epitheloid angiosarcoma in the right arm. MRI findings included a diffusely thickened cutis and subcutis with extensive lymphedema and muscle edema, an amorphous mass extending from the ventral cutis to the biceps muscle with spicular infiltration reaching the neurovascular bundle, an intermediate signal on T1-weighted images, and a heterogeneous high signal on TIR images with heterogeneous contrast enhancement. The follow-up CT examination indicated progressive disease with new subcutaneous and intramuscular metastases in the right hemithorax, and an additional MRI showed diffuse skeletal metastasis.

A: The patient is diagnosed with cutaneous epitheloid angiosarcoma with local infiltration and metastasis to the right hemithorax and skeletal system. The condition is considered serious, indicating advanced disease progression.

P: The planned management includes amputation of the affected arm to control the angiosarcoma. Ongoing monitoring of the condition is recommended, with discussions of potential treatment options. The patient is advised to stay in contact with the healthcare team and report any new symptoms.

S: The patient had been experiencing general malaise and thoraco-abdominal pain for about a week before his death. He lived alone and reported violent chest and abdominal pains with vomiting before alerting emergency services. He had a history of alcoholism, arterial hypertension, and an ischemic stroke 5 years ago.

O: Upon autopsy, external examination revealed coffee-colored material in the perioral region, on the hands, and on clothes. No traumatic lesions were observed. Internal examination showed the heart weighing 305g with slight myocardial sclerosis and patent, elastic coronary arteries. There were 300 cm^3 of coffee-colored material in the left pleural cavity and 350 cm^3 in the right cavity. Hemorrhagic infiltration was noted in the esophageal wall with a 3 cm vertical transmural tear in the distal esophagus. The jejunal loops contained digested blood and semisolid material. His liver weighed 2385g with marked steatosis. Histopathological examination revealed granulocytic inflammatory infiltrate in the esophageal mucosa and submucosa and hemosiderin accumulations.

A: The findings suggest esophageal rupture (likely Boerhaave syndrome) with associated pleural effusions, hemorrhage, and liver steatosis, possibly related to alcohol abuse and hypertension as underlying factors.

P: No information provided.

S: The patient reported a history of prolonged jaundice since infancy with an initial bilirubin level of 400 μmol/L. They were diagnosed with GS soon after delivery due to the presence of the A(TA)7TAA allele in homozygous form. Childhood included periodic jaundice managed with phenobarbital, decreasing bilirubin levels to 100–200 μmol/L. Post-puberty, the patient experienced severe jaundice with bilirubin levels increasing to 300–350 μmol/L but had no other complaints. All developmental milestones were normal. The patient had no history of kernicterus symptoms.

O: The patient's bilirubin levels have fluctuated from 100 to 400 μmol/L depending on treatment and life stage. Hepatological tests, including hepatitis markers and metabolic screens, came back negative or normal. Abdominal ultrasound, MRI, and liver biopsy revealed no pathological findings. Indirect bilirubin elevation, reduced glutathione, and low urine glucuronide levels were noted. The patient responded well to phenobarbital.

A: The differential diagnosis includes CNS-II, given the isolated indirect bilirubin elevation, negative test results for other liver or metabolic conditions, and positive response to phenobarbital.

P: Further investigations are required to confirm CNS-II. The patient is advised to follow up with their hepatologist for additional diagnostic steps and ongoing management of their condition.

S: The patient reports a severe degloving injury on the right leg, from the knee down to the back of the foot, resulting from being run down by a car. Concerns include pain, injury severity, and recovery progress.

O: At the time of injury, the wound area was 1200 cm², severely contaminated, with circumferential multi-plane injury, fibula exposure, and partial muscle rupture. Vitals were blood pressure 109/61 mmHg, heart rate 84 beats/min, HGB 98 g/L, HCT 30.4%, albumin 25.8 g/L, total protein 52 g/L, and PT 12.2 seconds. Ten days post-injury, slow granulation growth and some residual necrotic tissue were observed. Sixteen days post-injury, granulation tissue covered the area except the medial malleolus, without infection or active bleeding. Post-operation, 96% of the skin graft was viable; a small area of the ankle failed to take. After 1 year, significant improvement in skin texture was noted.

A: The patient is recovering from a severe degloving injury with good progress in healing and skin graft viability. Monitoring continues to ensure complete healing and recovery.

P: Continue monitoring the healing process and maintain follow-up appointments to assess long-term recovery and address any potential complications.

S: The patient was referred to the emergency department by their family doctor due to experiencing dyspnoea with inspiratory stridor and wheezing for the past 3 months. They have been treated for asthma for 2 weeks with no improvement. The patient reports no fever, weight loss, or night sweats.

O: Upon examination, the patient had a heart rate of 96/min, respiratory rate of 19/min, and oxygen saturation of 89% on room air. Chest auscultation was normal, but a non-tender mass was detected on the right side of the neck. CT scans revealed a large thyroid mass causing tracheal stenosis and multiple cystic lesions in the lungs. Blood arterial gases showed mild hypoxemia with a PaO2 of 82 mmHg. Laboratory tests showed normal renal, liver, thyroid function, and blood cell counts. Immunological tests were negative, and VEGF-D levels were low at 347 pg/mL. ECG and pulmonary function tests were normal.

A: The patient presents with a large thyroid mass causing tracheal stenosis and multiple cystic lung lesions, likely contributing to their respiratory symptoms. The findings suggest the primary source of the patient's issues is the thyroid mass affecting the trachea.

P: Surgical intervention is recommended, including the removal of the thyroid mass with subtotal thyroidectomy, resection of a 3.5 cm segment of the trachea, and multiple adenectomies to alleviate symptoms and prevent further complications. The patient will follow up on surgery and further treatment.

S: The patient reported experiencing significant pain following treatment for nephrolithiasis. They also described a complete loss of vision in the right eye, followed by tunnel vision during the first two chemotherapy cycles with FOLFIRINOX. These visual changes resolved within two and five days, respectively. The patient did not report any visual changes in the left eye.

O: The abdominal CT scan showed a calculus in the right ureteropelvic junction and an ill-defined mass in the head of the pancreas compressing the common bile duct. Biopsy via EUS-guided FNA confirmed pancreatic adenocarcinoma, stage IB (T2N0M0). During the Whipple procedure, liver cirrhosis was discovered, leading to the abortion of the surgery. Visual changes were investigated with an ophthalmologic examination, which revealed no retinal or optic nerve damage.

A: Diagnosed with stage IB pancreatic adenocarcinoma. Presence of liver cirrhosis was identified, complicating surgical options. Visual disturbances appeared to be linked to the oxaliplatin component of the FOLFIRINOX regimen.

P: The initial plan for a Whipple procedure was aborted due to liver cirrhosis. The treatment plan includes systemic chemotherapy with FOLFIRINOX, which was switched to gemcitabine plus nab-paclitaxel following adverse visual side effects. The patient should continue the current chemotherapy regimen, and visual symptoms are being monitored, with no further abnormalities reported.

S: The patient was referred to endocrinology for hypercalcemia discovered during routine blood tests after a gastric bypass operation a year ago. The patient reports no history of kidney stones, fractures, osteoporosis, hyperthyroidism, Addison's disease, malignancy, sarcoidosis, or other granulomatous diseases. The patient has lost contact with their mother and sister, making it difficult to investigate a family history of hypercalcemia. The patient inconsistently takes calcium, vitamin D3, iron, cobalamine, and multivitamins and has not used diuretics or other medications. They have experienced symptoms of depression and anxiety and have been prescribed an antidepressant. The patient also reports episodes of dizziness, tremor, sweating, and fatigue related to hypoglycemia, which have improved with dietary changes.

O: Blood tests showed Ca-ion levels between 1.42 and 1.47 mmol/l, PTH levels between 6.3 and 8.9 pmol/l, and 25-hydroxy vitamin D levels between 43 and 58 nmol/l. Alkaline phosphatase and thyroid function are normal. DXA results show T-scores of -0.6 at the lumbar spine and -0.2 at the total hip.

A: Mild hypercalcemia with high normal to slightly elevated PTH levels suggest the possibility of primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT). The need to rule out Familial Hypocalciuric Hypercalcemia (FHH) is noted.

P: Additional tests will be scheduled to confirm the diagnosis and determine the best course of action. The patient is advised to continue following the dietitian's instructions and take prescribed medications. A possible referral to a surgeon will be considered upon further diagnostic confirmation.

S: The patient reports recent discomfort in the area of the previous operation from a video-assisted thoracic surgery for a thymic cyst resection 10 years ago. The patient has no other medical issues, is not taking any medications, and reports no history of tobacco or alcohol use. There is no significant family history of cancer or other illnesses, and the patient works as a clerical worker with no known exposure to cancer-causing agents.

O: A physical examination and laboratory tests, including tumor markers, showed normal results. A contrast-enhanced CT scan revealed a solid nodule with a multilocular lesion at the previous operation site in the left thorax, measuring 30 x 30 x 15 mm. An MRI indicated the solid component of the lesion is iso-intense on both T1WI and T2WI, while the cystic component is iso-intense on T1WI and highly intense on T2WI, with no evidence of invasion to surrounding organs. A trans-sternal radical thymectomy was performed, finding the tumor located at the left inferior pole of the thymus with serous fluid in the cystic component. The pathological examination reported the tumor size as 3.7 × 2.5 × 1.0 cm, composed of small nodules and abundant lymphoid stroma, without dissemination or adhesion.

A: The presence of a solid nodule at the site of the previous thymic cyst resection suggests a potential malignancy such as thymoma or thymic carcinoma. The pathology indicates characteristics consistent with a thymic mass, prompting surgical removal and further monitoring.

P: The plan includes conducting follow-up care to monitor the patient’s condition after the trans-sternal radical thymectomy. No dissemination or adhesion was observed, but continued surveillance is advised to monitor for any recurrence or complications. The patient is instructed to contact the healthcare provider with any questions or concerns.

S: The patient, referred by the Endocrinology and Metabolism division, reports a history of stillbirth at 21 weeks of gestation a year ago, high creatine phosphokinase levels, muscle weakness, and exertional dyspnea since then. She is currently pregnant, with worsening exertional dyspnea at 8 weeks of gestation. She was diagnosed with a glucose metabolism disorder in the first trimester and is on insulin therapy.

O: Higher muscle enzyme levels than previously recorded (CK 3875 U/L, aldolase 29.5 U/L, myoglobin 440 ng/mL), myalgia, muscle weakness, arthritis, and positive anti-Jo1 antibodies (32-fold higher than normal). Electromyogram shows myogenic change and inflammatory reaction. No skin lesions. Decreased ambulatory SpO2 to 84% at room atmosphere. Elevated interstitial lung disease markers (KL-6: 1572.0 U/mL; SPD: 195.5 ng/mL). Chest radiograph, chest-computed tomography, and respiratory function test indicate ground-glass opacity and partial honeycomb lung with restrictive respiratory involvement.

A: Diagnosed with polymyositis according to Bohan's criteria and interstitial lung disease.

P: The treatment plan involves managing polymyositis and interstitial lung disease, including potential medications and monitoring of lung function. The pregnancy will be closely monitored in collaboration with the obstetrician to ensure the best outcome for the patient and the baby.

S: The patient reports discovering a painless, mobile lump in the right axilla approximately 6 months ago. Over the last 2 months, the patient has experienced increasing numbness in the right ring and little fingers, affecting daily activities. No other masses have been noted elsewhere on the body.

O: On physical examination, the right axilla shows a 5 × 5 cm ill-defined mobile mass with a smooth surface and no skin changes. There are no other adjacent masses or palpable regional lymph nodes. A neurovascular exam reveals a mild decrease in superficial touch sensation in the right little and ring fingers. Ultrasound and mammogram were negative for breast cancer. Biopsy confirmed monophasic synovial sarcoma. MRI of the axilla indicated a well-defined oval-shaped heterogeneous soft tissue mass measuring 3 × 3.3 cm axially and 4 × 4 cm craniocaudally near the axillary artery. CT angiogram showed mild compression at the axillary/brachial arteries transition, with peripheral vessels patent. CT of chest, abdomen, pelvis, and bone scan showed no metastasis.

A: Diagnosis of monophasic synovial sarcoma in the right axilla, with mild sensory changes in the right hand due to the mass. No evidence of metastasis.

P: Plan for mass excision surgery, exploring the axillary artery and surrounding structures to remove the mass while preserving blood vessels and nerves. Schedule the surgery as soon as possible, with patient monitoring for any symptom changes or additional concerns.

S: The patient reported diffuse abdominal pain and vomiting. There is no history of abdominal surgery.

O: On admission, the physical examination revealed abdominal distension, muscle rigidity, and absent peristalsis. Groins were checked for swelling, which appeared normal. A nasogastric tube decompression showed small bowel content. A plain abdominal x-ray demonstrated multiple dilated loops of small intestines. A CT scan showed a herniation of the ileum between the internal and external obturator muscles. During surgery, a serosal laceration was observed, and an ICG fluorescence angiography indicated irreversible ischemia of the bowel.

A: Small bowel obstruction due to obturator hernia with signs of incarceration and irreversible ischemia.

P: Emergency diagnostic laparoscopy was performed to address the herniation. The ileum segment was reduced, and the hernia was managed by laparoscopic resection and closure of the redundant peritoneum using an endoloop. The ischemic ileum segment was resected, and a side-to-side stapled anastomosis was performed. Postoperative management included fast tract rehabilitation, physical therapy, and mobilization. The patient was discharged on postoperative day seven after a successful recovery.

S: The patient reported experiencing symptoms such as high blood pressure, a rounder face, a fatty bump on the back of the neck, muscle weakness, and facial hair growth. They also mentioned recent feelings of weakness and weight gain.

O: The doctor confirmed a diagnosis of ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome through hormonal analysis and detected a pituitary adenoma via MRI. The patient underwent transsphenoidal surgery in May 2007, which revealed a microadenoma, and post-surgery, blood pressure, PC, and ACTH levels returned to normal. Recent thyroid function evaluation showed low FT4 levels, a TSH of 1.3 mIU/L, and positive TPO antibodies (212 IU/mL), with ultrasound imaging revealing a diffuse dyshomogeneous pattern in the thyroid gland, suggesting Hashimoto thyroiditis.

A: The patient was diagnosed with ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome and post-surgery hypothyroidism due to Hashimoto thyroiditis.

P: The patient was started on levothyroxine 50 mcg once a day to improve thyroid function and alleviate symptoms. Continued monitoring and adjustment of treatment will be conducted as needed.

S: The patient is a 57-year-old man with a history of diabetes and hypertension. He has a family history of ischemic heart disease. He reports experiencing chest burning after meals and occasional chest heaviness at rest, which is not related to exertion. He also has a dry cough for the past four to five days.

O: The patient's blood pressure is 138/84 mmHg, heart rate is 76 beats per minute, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Cardiac auscultation reveals S1 and S2 with no added heart sounds. Chest examination reveals normal vesicular breathing, and the rest of the systemic examination is within normal limits. An ECG shows normal sinus rhythm with left bundle branch block (LBBB). Blood work, including a complete blood count, creatinine, electrolytes, and troponin I, are within normal ranges and negative for any issues. During a myocardial perfusion scan, a cough led to an ECG conversion from LBBB to a narrow complex, and back to LBBB after another cough. Stress SPECT imaging was completed following specific pharmacologic protocols.

A: The patient’s symptoms and family history raise concerns for ischemic heart disease. The presence of LBBB and changes with coughing may warrant further investigation. The normal blood tests and ECG findings will be complemented by the results of the myocardial perfusion scan for further assessment.

P: The plan includes reviewing the results of the myocardial perfusion scan to assess for ischemia. The patient received IV dipyradimole and Tc-99m tetrofosmin for the stress SPECT imaging and IV aminophylline for myocardial perfusion. Follow-up instructions will be provided after reviewing the scan results in the next appointment.

S: The patient, a 28-year-old woman, has a regular 28-day menstrual cycle and was diagnosed with poorly differentiated invasive ductal high-grade carcinoma of the left breast in 2010. Postoperative pathology classified her cancer as pT2 pN0 M0 G3 stage IIA. She underwent testing that revealed no cancer-related genetic mutations in genes such as BRCA1 and BRCA2. Due to the gonadotoxic nature of her planned chemotherapy and radiotherapy, she was informed about the associated risk of fertility issues and opted for ovarian tissue cryopreservation.

O: The patient's FSH level is 5.1 U/L. The sentinel node biopsy was negative. During laparoscopy, ovarian tissue was harvested for cryopreservation. Targeted gene sequencing showed no pathogenic variants in several key genes. The ovarian cortical tissue was cryopreserved after being prepared in HEPES-buffered IVF culture media with human serum albumin.

A: The patient has stage IIA breast cancer with a high risk of infertility due to chemotherapy and radiotherapy. Current preservation of fertility was achieved through ovarian tissue cryopreservation. The negative sentinel node biopsy is a favorable prognostic indicator.

P: The patient should continue with regular follow-up appointments to monitor health and fertility status. The oncology team will guide her on the next steps based on her ongoing treatment and recovery process. Continue discussing any concerns during follow-ups and manage any treatment side effects as they arise.

S: The patient reports a medical history of cough, including visits to another hospital 5 and 9 years ago. Previous investigations revealed a 20 mm nodule in the left lung, suspected to be a bronchial cyst. Recently, an abnormal radiographic shadow prompted the patient to seek further examination. 

O: A recent chest CT scan showed a 35 mm multicystic mass in the left lung between the S1+2 and S6 segments. Bronchoscopy revealed three bronchi branching from the left main bronchus, but no histological diagnosis was obtained. A 3D CT indicated unusual displacement of a bronchus to the dorsal side of the left main pulmonary artery.

A: The preoperative diagnosis suggests a likely benign bronchial cyst; however, the possibility of malignancy cannot be ruled out due to the growth of the mass. 

P: Surgical resection is planned to achieve a more accurate diagnosis. Should the mass be malignant, further surgery for mediastinal lymph node dissection will be necessary. Postoperative follow-up is essential to discuss the results and determine the next steps.

S: The patient is a 40-year-old obese African American female who was found in cardiac arrest at home. She has no history of drug abuse or recent physical trauma but has been ingesting Epsom salt for weight loss.

O: Upon presentation, the patient was hypotensive, intubated, and nonresponsive with minimally reactive pupils. Initial blood work showed hypermagnesemia (9.7 mg/dL), lactic acidosis, mild elevation of liver enzymes, and a negative urinary drug screen. ECG revealed normal sinus rhythm with a prolonged QT, a first-degree AV block, PR interval of 220 ms, QRS interval of 120 ms, and nonspecific intraventricular block. Brain CT scan showed no acute intracranial process. Serum creatinine was normal (0.9 mg/dL), with normal urinary output (1350-1600 mL).

A: Differential diagnosis includes acute coronary syndrome, stroke, and toxic ingestion of magnesium sulfate, with findings consistent with hypermagnesemia.

P: Continue supportive therapy and close monitoring of the patient's condition. Regular assessment of vital signs, blood work, and overall progress will be conducted without the need for dialysis at this time.

S: The patient reports experiencing a rapid heartbeat as the primary symptom. He also mentions concerns about his serum calcitonin levels and experiences symptoms of hyperthyroidism and dysphagia.

O: The initial laboratory evaluation indicates mild hyperthyroidism. A thyroid ultrasound reveals a multinodular goiter. A thyroid scintiscan identifies a toxic multinodular goiter with a 2 cm hyperfunctioning left nodule. Fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB) of a 15 mm non-hyperfunctioning nodule in the right lobe shows benign features (Thy 2). Serum calcitonin levels are borderline increased at 13.2 pg/ml. The final histology after total thyroidectomy reveals struma with C-cell hyperplasia (CCH) and medullary multifocal microcarcinoma, with the largest microcarcinoma in the left lobe measuring 6 mm.

A: Toxic multinodular goiter with hyperthyroidism and dysphagia, confirmed by scintiscan and ultrasound. The patient also has struma with CCH and medullary multifocal microcarcinoma post-thyroidectomy.

P: Recommend total thyroidectomy to alleviate symptoms and treat the toxic multinodular goiter. Post-surgery, regular monitoring and management of potential complications related to struma with CCH and medullary multifocal microcarcinoma. Continue to monitor serum calcitonin levels and overall health.

S: The patient is a 14-month-old boy brought in for a pediatric visit due to fever and fatigue. The child has oculocutaneous albinism and sickle cell disease. He was born at term with a birth weight of 3000 g and had neonatal jaundice that resolved on its own. He experiences episodes of fever about twice a month but has not been diagnosed with a vaso-occlusive crisis or dactylitis. The patient has received all vaccinations according to the recommended schedule in the DRC. He has never been hospitalized, and his febrile episodes have been treated at health centers. The family history includes three siblings with oculocutaneous albinism; some siblings have the sickle cell trait.

O: On examination, the patient was wide awake with good contact and interaction. Noted findings include generalized pallor, subicteric conjunctivae, bluish gray translucent irises appearing red with nystagmus, consistent with albinism.

A: The child presents with fever and fatigue, which are notable in the context of his known sickle cell disease and albinism. His symptoms and health history suggest that febrile episodes may be due to infections like malaria or typhoid fever given the treatment history at health centers.

P: Continue monitoring the fever and fatigue, with a focus on managing sickle cell disease. Ensure the patient follows the recommended vaccination schedule. Seek immediate treatment for febrile episodes, such as malaria or typhoid fever. Encourage parents to contact healthcare providers if symptoms worsen or for any concerns.

S: 
The patient is a 42-year-old who is 34 weeks pregnant and was admitted due to premature rupture of membranes. Her past medical history is negative. She underwent a caesarean section after being admitted. Post-surgery, she experienced increased blood pressure, a generalized tonic-clonic seizure, mild right hemiparesis, and eventually developed severe right hemiparesis.

O:
On admission, the patient's arterial blood pressure was 110/70 mmHg, and her temperature was normal. A complete blood cell count showed leukocytosis with 12,430 cells/mmc and severe microcytic hypochromic anemia (Hb 6.9 mg/dL, Hct 25.2%, MCV 70.8 fL, MCHC 27.4 g/dL). Post-transfusion, Hb increased to 9.3 mg/dL. Blood pressure rose to 165/90 mmHg after transfusion. Following a seizure, neurological examination revealed a lethargic status and mild right hemiparesis. Brain MRI showed multiple hyperintense signal areas in T2, DWI, and Flair sequences, involving frontal lobes and the right thalamus. Blood pressure before the seizure was 170/90 mmHg.

A:
The patient presents with chronic anemia due to uterine myomas, increased blood pressure post-transfusion, a generalized tonic-clonic seizure with subsequent lethargy, and progressive right hemiparesis. MRI findings suggest possible neurological involvement that requires further investigation.

P:
The patient received a blood transfusion, post-operative hydration, low molecular weight heparin, antibiotics, NSAIDs, ranitidine, calcium gluconate, cabergoline, and methylergometrine. The seizure was treated with intravenous diazepam. The patient was referred to the Neurology Department for further evaluation and treatment. Recommendations include close blood pressure monitoring and adherence to Neurology Department's follow-up instructions.

S: The patient reports experiencing shortness of breath and coughing up blood for the past three days, along with heart palpitations, fever, and significant weight loss over the last two months.

O: The patient is malnourished and anemic. Vitals recorded were blood pressure at 130/80 mm Hg, pulse at 103 beats per minute, and oxygen saturation at 84%. Physical examination revealed markedly reduced air entry in the right upper zone and bilateral basal coarse crepitations, as well as a 2-3/6 systolic ejection murmur. A chest X-ray showed a boot-shaped heart, cavitation, and fibrosis in the right upper lobe, with a collapsed right upper lobe. Echocardiography revealed an enlarged and hypertrophied right ventricle, a right-to-left shunt across a large ventricular septal defect, mild overriding of the aorta, pulmonary stenosis, and a right pulmonary artery measuring 8 mm. Sputum examination for acid-fast bacilli was positive in two out of three samples, and the GeneXpert MTB/RIF test was positive.

A: The diagnostic impression includes tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) and multi-drug-resistant pulmonary tuberculosis.

P: The patient has been started on anti-tuberculous therapy (ATT) with second-line agents, including injectable amikacin and oral medications such as levofloxacin, cycloserine, ethionamide, and pyrazinamide. The treatment duration is 12 months, with amikacin to be stopped after eight months. Dosages are adjusted according to the patient's weight. The plan involves close monitoring of the patient's progress and making necessary adjustments to the treatment. The patient is advised to report any concerns and strictly adhere to the medication schedule.

S: Patient has a history of hypertension and chronic back pain. The patient reports experiencing new symptoms of chest pain and shortness of breath, leading to this evaluation.

O: Examination and test results reveal a 7.2 cm aneurysm in the ascending aorta with a Stanford classification type A dissection. An 18-gauge peripheral intravenous (IV) line is in the right antecubital (AC) fossa. 

A: Diagnosis of a Stanford type A aortic dissection with a large aneurysm requiring emergent repair.

P: Plan includes emergent surgical repair via axillary cannulation using the right subclavian artery with side graft anastomosis. Prior to anesthesia, medication infusions will be switched to an IV in the left forearm and various monitoring lines will be placed. A complex setup involving central and arterial lines is detailed for intraoperative management, with attention to pressure monitoring and adjustments during cardiopulmonary bypass.

S: The patient is a 7-year-old boy who has been having seizures for the past 3 years. His parent reports that he has been experiencing two types of seizures, with a baseline frequency of approximately 9.41 times per day. The parent mentioned that he is currently taking sodium valproate, clonazepam, and topiramate.
