A: The child is diagnosed with microcephaly and presents with symptoms that may be associated with a genetic condition, notably the identified de novo nonsense variant. The MRI findings and facial features suggest potential syndromic associations.

P: The doctor recommends monitoring the child’s development closely and coordinating care with a neurologist and genetic counselor. Genetic counseling is advised to further understand the implications of the genetic variant. Follow-up with the recommended specialists is essential to tailor ongoing care and management.

S: The patient reported that her dog has been experiencing issues with her left eye for about 7 months, including mucopurulent and hemorrhagic discharge. The problem began suddenly after a walk in the park. Additional symptoms include redness and swelling around the left eye. The right eye appears normal.

O: No observable findings, vitals, or test results were reported in the conversation.

A: The doctor suspects unilateral dacryocystitis, which is an inflammation of the tear sac. The diagnosis is based on the symptoms of discharge, redness, and swelling in the left eye.

P: The doctor plans to perform an ultrasound to examine the dog's nasolacrimal system to look for foreign bodies or abnormalities in the lacrimal sac. If a foreign body is identified, the next step would be to anesthetize the dog and remove the object. The ultrasound is to be scheduled for later this week. The patient was advised to call the reception desk to make an appointment.

S: The patient is a 9-year-old female with a 1-year history of pain in the low back and left lower limb leading to a diagnosis of osteosarcoma of the left tibia and a solitary metastasis in the L3 vertebrae. She underwent a below knee amputation and spinal surgeries. In December 2016, recurrent osteosarcoma was confirmed. The patient reports doing okay with second line chemotherapy (ifosfamide and etoposide).

O: The patient is able to ambulate with a below knee prosthesis and shows no neurological deficits. Imaging tests show only a single metastatic site at L3. Physical examination suggests previous implants are stable.

A: Recurrent osteosarcoma at the L3 level with confirmed metastatic site. The patient's previous surgeries and treatments have maintained a degree of mobility and stability, but ongoing treatment is necessary.

P: Continue with planned complex en bloc resection of L2, L3, and L4, removal of deep spinal implants, and anterior and posterior spinal fusion as decided by the patient’s family. Consider risks of nerve root sacrifice at L2 and L3. Provide thorough explanation and support to the family regarding postoperative expectations and possible complications.

S: The patient has been feeling very tired for the past 3 days and had a fever lasting 2 days. They've noticed behavioral changes, becoming abnormally talkative, and developed a limp for a day. The patient also reports black spots on both palms and soles, with the left second finger and left fifth toe turning black. 

O: Vital signs: temperature 39.8 °C, heart rate 130 beats/min, blood pressure 100/71 mmHg, respiratory rate 18 breaths/min, oxygen saturation 98% on room air. Exam findings include orientation with garrulous behavior, petechial hemorrhages on the uvula and posterior pharynx, no cardiac murmurs, blackened left second finger and left fifth toe, petechiae on right palm, and the dorsum of the left foot is erythematous, warm, and swollen. Initial lab results indicate disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), elevated white blood cell count, and elevated C-reactive protein. Blood cultures grew Streptococcus pyogenes. Echocardiography revealed vegetation on the mitral valve and mitral regurgitation (MR).

A: The patient is likely experiencing streptococcal pharyngitis and a skin and soft tissue infection leading to bacteremia and DIC, suspected to be caused by Group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes). There is also new onset mitral regurgitation due to mitral valve vegetation, likely due to an infection.

P: Start IV clindamycin and switch to ampicillin based on susceptibility testing. Continue close monitoring of the patient’s condition, especially the cardiac status, due to the development of mitral valve vegetation. Discuss further treatment options for mitral regurgitation. Maintain follow-up examinations and consider potential surgical intervention if necessary.

S: The patient has a history of a long-standing swelling on the left lower leg, initially confirmed as dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP) via biopsy. The patient underwent a wide local excision with clear margins and no distant metastases, so no adjuvant therapy was administered at that time. Two years later, a recurrence led to another excision followed by a second recurrence involving the knee joint, which necessitated a transfemoral amputation. After two years, the disease recurred again at the left lower limb stump. A metastatic workup returned negative results. The patient experienced progression of lesions on the limb stump and posterior torso, which led to referral for further management. The patient reports some pain but an overall feeling of improvement with the prosthetic limb.

O: The physical examination revealed a 15 x 12 cm mobile mass on the left lower limb stump, and two palpable, firm, and fixed lesions on the posterior torso, with the largest measuring 9 x 7 cm. Immunohistochemistry showed positivity for CD34, focally positive for actin, and negative for desmin and S100 protein. A chest X-ray and abdominal ultrasound showed no evidence of metastasis.

A: Recurrence of dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans with progression after the initial and subsequent excisions. The condition has led to multiple lesions in the posterior torso and a significant mass on the left lower limb stump, with no evidence of distant metastases.

P: The patient initially started on imatinib mesylate at 400 mg twice daily, but the treatment stopped after progression of lesions. Palliative radiotherapy was administered to the left lower limb stump for pain relief and to allow the use of a prosthetic limb. Continued monitoring of symptoms and progression is advised, with the recommendation to report any new symptoms. Reassessment of the treatment plan will be conducted as necessary.

S: The patient was diagnosed with bifocal invasive ductal breast cancer in 2006 and underwent mastectomy, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy. She was in remission and took tamoxifen for five years. Recently, she developed severe dorsal pain.

O: The MR study revealed signs of diffuse medullary metastatic disease in the spine, particularly in the dorsal segment, affecting the T2-T3 level and molding the posterior medulla. Leptomeningeal metastatic spread with small nodular foci were observed on the spinal cord and dorsal roots. Bone deposits were found in the right pedicle of T4 and vertebral body of T7. No signs of brain or intramedullary metastatic disease or CSF blockage were noted. The disease showed homogenous gadolinium uptake.

A: The patient is experiencing metastatic spread to the spine and leptomeningeal areas, with associated dorsal pain likely due to these findings.

P: The plan includes delivering a 30Gy radiotherapy treatment to reduce the metastatic sleeve volume at the thoracic level, aiming for partial symptom relief and reduction in analgesic medication dosage. The patient will also be referred to a pain management unit and prescribed anastrozole (an aromatase inhibitor) for hormonotherapy. Follow-up will include monitoring progress and treatment adjustments as needed.

S: Matthew, a 67-year-old male, reports injuring his right shoulder about four days ago while playing tackle football. He landed awkwardly on his shoulder and has since experienced persistent pain in the posterior area of the shoulder, around the acromioclavicular joint. He denies any numbness or tingling in his fingers, weakness in the arm, or neck injury. He has difficulty with shoulder movements, especially lifting the shoulder to touch the ear. Over-the-counter Tylenol has not alleviated the pain. He reports a slight headache but no fever or chills and no prior injuries to this shoulder. Medical history includes an appendectomy three to four years ago.

O: Vital signs: Blood pressure 122/76, heart rate 82 bpm, oxygen saturation 95% on room air. Physical exam shows pain on palpation of the posterior shoulder at the acromioclavicular joint, with decreased abduction and adduction to about 90 degrees, and pain with supination and pronation of the right arm. No trauma or bruising observed on the head or right shoulder. X-ray results indicate an acute acromioclavicular joint fracture.

A: Acute acromioclavicular joint fracture of the right shoulder.

P: Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once daily for pain management. Place the right arm in a sling. Order a CT scan of the right shoulder for further evaluation of the joint. Refer to physical therapy to strengthen the shoulder and reduce the likelihood of future surgery. Advise against returning to tackle football until the fracture is healed and suggest considering less intensive activities like flag football.

S: The patient is a 3-month-old female diagnosed antenatally with tetralogy of Fallot. She was born at term via vaginal delivery to non-consanguineous Afro-Caribbean parents with a birth weight of 2.45 kg and APGAR scores of 9. In the third trimester, she was noted to have intrauterine growth restriction. Recently, she presented with central cyanosis, significant inconsolable agitation, and had oxygen saturations between 48-66%. The parent reports multiple cyanotic spells daily, with the longest lasting more than 30 minutes.

O: Physical exam initially revealed no murmurs, and her baseline oxygen saturation was 95% on room air with a grade 4/6 ejection systolic murmur. Echocardiography confirmed tetralogy of Fallot morphology. During her second hospital stay, the baseline oxygen saturation dropped from 85% to 70%, with saturations as low as 40% during cyanotic spells. Genetic analysis showed a normal karyotype with no 22q11 deletion.

A: The patient is experiencing recurrent cyanotic spells with a confirmed diagnosis of tetralogy of Fallot. The increase in frequency and duration of cyanotic episodes indicates a worsening condition despite medical management.

P: Continue with close monitoring of her condition. Medical management has included posture adjustment, morphine, fluid boluses, and increased beta blockade up to 2 mg/kg/dose. Further treatments need to be considered due to lack of improvement. Ensure regular follow-up appointments and immediate reporting of any sudden changes in her condition.

S: The patient reports a 4-month history of abdominal pain and weight loss, with pain also noted in the left inguinal area. There is a history of retroperitoneal operation, potentially related to current symptoms.

O: Initial examinations showed normal parameters. An abdominal CT scan revealed retroperitoneal enlarged lymph nodes. A biopsy indicated nonspecific adenitis. A subsequent CT scan showed a large left retroperitoneal fluid collection, causing slight left hydronephrosis and more lymph node enlargement. Percutaneous drainage extracted 1100 mL of milky liquid with high protein and triglyceride levels, consistent with chyle. Lymphangiography showed contrast leakage at the level of the fourth lumbar spine.

A: The diagnostic impression is an injury to the cisterna chyli possibly due to a past retroperitoneal operation, leading to chylous fluid accumulation and lymphatic leakage.

P: Initial conservative management included a low-fat diet, medium-chain triglycerides, and octreotide; however, due to persistent high output from the drainage, surgical management is planned. Lymphangiography findings will guide the surgical approach. The patient will continue to be monitored closely.

S: Patient A reports severe symptoms affecting their ability to speak, move, or care for themselves over the past two months, with a gradual onset of positive psychotic symptoms such as bizarre delusions and auditory hallucinations over 14 months, followed by negative symptoms and catatonia. The patient denies any prior mental health issues and has not experienced echolalia, echopraxia, negativism, waxy flexibility, mitmachen, or ambitendency. The patient has been unable to manage basic self-care, including toileting, leading to incontinence. Prior to seeking medical care, the family attempted spiritual treatment through faith healers, which was ineffective.

O: No observable findings, vitals, or test results provided.

A: Diagnosed with catatonic schizophrenia as per ICD-10 criteria, based on reported symptoms and functional decline.

P: Initiate treatment with aripiprazole (15 mg daily) and lorazepam (1 mg thrice daily). Monitor patient progress closely, with expectations of visible improvement by the third day of treatment. Conduct assessments using the Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS) and the Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale (BPRS) to evaluate treatment response. Advise regular follow-up appointments to adjust treatment as necessary and address any concerns.

S: The patient is a 12-year-old boy experiencing bleeding per rectum and mild abdominal pain for the past 3 days following a blunt abdominal trauma while playing football. There is no relevant past medical, surgical, family, or psychosocial history. 

O: Physical examination reveals slight abdominal tenderness with present bowel sounds. Initial vital signs on admission include a heart rate of 86 bpm and blood pressure of 100/70 mmHg. Hemoglobin level is 9.6 gm/dl. A FAST examination shows mild intraperitoneal fluid in the pelvis. A CT scan reveals mild pelvic hemoperitoneum without definite solid or hollow visceral injury. During hospitalization, the patient exhibits a continuous drop in hemoglobin levels with ongoing rectal bleeding, fever with a temperature of 37.8 °C, tachycardia with a heart rate of 140 bpm, and hypotension with blood pressure at 70/40 mmHg. On the third day, hemoglobin falls to 6.1 gm/dl despite transfusion of 2 units of packed red blood cells.

A: The clinical presentation suggests post-traumatic internal bleeding likely contributing to anemia, tachycardia, hypotension, and fever. The progressive drop in hemoglobin and rectal bleeding indicates a need for surgical intervention due to potential ongoing hemorrhage.

P: The plan involves resuscitation and stabilization with intravenous crystalloid fluids and additional transfusion of 2 units of packed red blood cells. Urgent exploration is planned, starting with an on-table colonoscopy under general anesthesia, followed by a laparotomy to identify and manage the source of bleeding. Monitoring intake and output and maintaining the patient nil per mouth continues to be part of the management strategy.

S: The patient is a 45-year-old English teacher reporting right knee pain for about a year, worsening eight months ago. There is no recollection of any trauma that might have caused the pain. Previous treatments included intermittent non-steroid anti-inflammatory drugs, injections (unspecified), and physical therapy. The patient describes severe anterior knee pain, especially when climbing stairs or squatting, and has noticed a cystic mass in the posterior aspect of the right knee joint, which has been increasing in size.

O: The physical examination revealed mild swelling and effusion in the right knee, with painful crepitation and moderate tenderness during motion. A large, non-tender cystic mass was found in the posterior aspect of the right knee. The infrapatellar region is larger and firm, with a painful full knee range of motion. Radiographic examination showed a large ossicle beneath the patellar tendon in the infrapatellar fat pad of the right knee, and a similar-sized ossicle partially fused to the hypertrophied tibial tuberosity in the left knee. MRI of the right knee revealed a well-circumscribed ossicle, several smaller ossicles, inflammatory changes in various structures, and reactive bone marrow edema at the anterior tibial condyle.

A: The clinical findings suggest a possible diagnosis related to ossicles beneath the patellar tendon and associated inflammatory changes, likely contributing to the reported symptoms.

P: The treatment plan includes discussing potential medication, additional therapy, or surgical options if necessary. Regular follow-up is essential to monitor progress and symptoms, with adjustments to the treatment plan as needed.

S: The patient reports experiencing mild muscle and bone pain in both lower limbs since childhood, which does not interfere with daily life. There is no history of rickets, fractures, or dental problems, but the patient had developmental dysplasia of the hip during infancy. The patient denies any medication use, supplements, smoking, alcohol abuse, or drug use. No known allergies are reported. Family history includes a mother with breast cancer and a sister with Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

O: The initial examination recorded a body temperature of 37.0 °C, blood pressure of 115/80 mmHg, pulse of 101 beats/min, height of 150.3 cm, and weight of 44 kg, resulting in a BMI of 19.6 kg/m². Examination revealed spontaneous pain in the right femur and left crus but no tenderness or pain with percussion. No signs of anemia or jaundice were observed, the thyroid was not palpable, and chest and abdominal examinations were normal. Neurological exams, including muscle strength, deep tendon reflexes, and esthesia, were normal except for spontaneous pain in bilateral legs. A complete blood count showed normal results with a hematocrit of 41.4% and hemoglobin of 13.8.

A: The patient presents with low serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels, mild muscle and bone pain in lower limbs, and a history of developmental dysplasia of the hip. The cause of low serum ALP levels is currently under evaluation.

P: Continued monitoring of the patient's condition is recommended to determine the cause of low serum ALP levels. The patient is advised to follow up as needed and report any changes in symptoms.

S: The patient reports a history of 16 nonmelanoma skin cancers, actinic keratoses, seborrheic dermatitis, stasis dermatitis, and tinea pedis. They also have sleep apnea treated with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) using two liters of oxygen each night. Other medical history includes hypothyroidism, congestive heart failure, coronary atherosclerosis, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, sick sinus syndrome, and chronic kidney disease. They are currently taking amlodipine, carvedilol, febuxostat, ferrous sulfate, finasteride, folic acid, furosemide, levoxyl, pravastatin, tamsulosin, and warfarin with no changes reported.

O: The examination revealed keratotic plaques on the scalp, face, and arms. There is elongation of the lateral aspect of the cuticle on the great toes, with curling of the cuticles on the lateral and medial views.

A: The patient presents with actinic keratoses, which will be treated with cryotherapy. The elongation and curling of the cuticles on the great toes are likely due to inadequate hygiene, possibly related to difficulty reaching the toes.

P: Treatment of actinic keratoses with liquid nitrogen cryotherapy. Recommend a pedicure to address the cuticle elongation and curling, involving soaking and trimming of the cuticles. The patient is advised to continue their current medications and sleep apnea treatment. Schedule the pedicure at the patient’s convenience. The patient is advised to reach out with any questions or concerns.

S: The patient reports feeling weak with generalized abdominal pain, nausea, and intractable vomiting for a week. They also report multiple episodes of loose, non-bloody bowel movements. The patient denies fevers, chills, hematochezia, melena, voiding difficulty, dysuria, hematuria, or flank pain. They have no past medical history and are not aware of any family history of gastrointestinal or renal disease. The patient mentions not having seen a doctor in the past 18 years.

O: The patient appears diaphoretic and in moderate distress. Vital signs show temperature at 36.8°C, heart rate of 69 bpm, respiratory rate of 16 br/min, blood pressure at 147/102 mmHg, and oxygen saturation at 100% on room air. Abdominal exam reveals a soft, diffusely tender abdomen with no distension, guarding, or rigidity and normoactive bowel sounds. Both costovertebral angle tenderness and Murphy sign are negative. Laboratory tests show a white blood cell count of 6100 K/mcl, hemoglobin 5.9 g/dL, hematocrit 18%, platelet count 240,000 K/mcl, sodium 130 mmol/L, potassium 4.7 mmol/L, chloride 95 mmol/L, CO2 24 mmol/L, BUN >150 mg/dL, creatinine 26.9 mg/dL, anion gap 21, glucose 87 mg/dL, and serum calcium 6.5 mg/dL. Liver function studies and lipase are within normal limits. FOBT is negative. The anemia workup shows normal iron levels, low TIBC, high ferritin, normal B12, and low reticulocyte count. Arterial blood gas results: pH 7.35, pCO2 32 mmHg.

A: The clinical presentation and laboratory findings suggest a possible underlying renal issue or anemia-related condition, but further diagnostic testing is required to confirm the exact cause of symptoms.

P: Plan includes scheduling an appointment with a specialist and conducting additional tests. The patient is advised to monitor symptoms and seek immediate care if they worsen or new symptoms develop. Follow-up appointment scheduling will be coordinated.

S: The patient reports a history of generalized tonic-clonic seizures for about five years. They had a seizure episode in Honduras three years ago but have been seizure-free since. The patient recently immigrated from Honduras, has no US medical insurance, and has a history of nonadherence to antiepilepsy medications. They have not been on routine medications as an outpatient and have not received known treatment for neurocysticercosis (NCC).

O: A CT scan of the brain showed no remarkable findings. The patient was loaded with a single dose of IV levetiracetam 1000 mg and started on oral levetiracetam 500 mg twice a day. Physical exam and review of systems were noncontributory, and the patient was afebrile. Labs showed mild leucocytosis (WBC 11.02) and elevated creatinine kinase (CK) of 1.6, with a normal liver panel. An MRI revealed a 5 mm ring-enhancing lesion in the posterior right frontal lobe with surrounding vasogenic edema, suggestive of an infective neurocysticercosis lesion. CT and EEG were normal. A positive serological antibody test for cysticercosis IgG confirmed the diagnosis.

A: The patient is diagnosed with parenchymal neurocysticercosis, likely causing the seizures.

P: The plan is to start the patient on appropriate treatment to manage the infection and control the seizures. The patient is advised to adhere to medications and follow up with their healthcare provider as needed.

S:  
The patient reports experiencing a dry cough for approximately three weeks. The patient has no significant past medical history, and there are no previous similar issues reported.

O:  
Initial chest imaging revealed a mass in the anterior mediastinum. A repeated chest X-ray at KFSH showed a right-sided para-pericardial mass in the anterior mediastinum with a significant decrease in the size of the right middle lobe opacity. No other focal opacities, pleural effusion, or pneumothorax were identified, and the cardiac silhouette was unremarkable. CT scan confirmed a cystic mass. Surgical findings revealed significant adhesion of the right lung to the anterior chest wall, a thick cyst in the anterior segment of the right upper lobe, and cheese-like material within the mass. The postoperative specimen weighed 64.4 g and measured 14.5 x 6.0 x 3.0 cm with a mass measuring 6.0 x 5.0 x 2.5 cm containing soft yellow material. The patient’s recovery was described as uneventful.

A:  
Cystic mass in the anterior segment of the right upper lobe, consistent with findings of significant adhesion to the chest wall and cheese-like material.

P:  
The patient underwent surgical resection via a right thoracoscopic approach, including wedge resection of the cyst. Postoperatively, a chest tube was inserted, and the wound was closed in layers. The patient was to be monitored during recovery with follow-up as needed.

S: The patient reports experiencing progressive weakness and arthralgia in the proximal parts of the upper limbs for the past 3 months, accompanied by intermittent fever and weight loss. The patient also notes having a skin rash for approximately 6 months. No treatment has been received prior to this consultation.

O: At admission, the patient's temperature was 37.4°C. Physical examination revealed significant hepatomegaly and mucocutaneous lichenoid papules (Gottron papules) on the hands. The jugular venous pressure was raised; however, heart sounds were normal, and the chest was clear to auscultation. Vitals included blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg, heart rate of 82 bpm, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation at 98%. Blood tests indicated elevated alanine transaminase (78 IU/l), high creatine phosphokinase (736 UI/l), positive Rose-Waaler test, positive anti-Jo1 antibody, and elevated NT-proBNP (3150 ng/l). Electromyography showed small, short, polyphasic action potentials with early recruitment, suggesting membrane irritability. A right quadriceps femoris biopsy demonstrated B cells inflammatory infiltration. Muscular MRI showed generalized muscular edema, atrophy, and adipose infiltration.

A: The clinical findings, combined with elevated laboratory markers, biopsy results, and MRI findings, lead to a diagnosis of Dermatomyositis (DM) according to Bohan and Peter’s criteria.

P: Initiate treatment with corticosteroids at 1 mg/kg/day of oral prednisolone and methotrexate (15 mg) to manage symptoms and slow disease progression.

S: The patient reports swelling and pain in the right anterior mandible for about three weeks. They have a medical history of non-muscle invasive urothelial carcinoma (UC), hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient attempted self-medication with amoxicillin and cephalexin, which were ineffective.

O: An earlier radiograph showed a radiolucent lesion in the mandible, which was concerning for a tumor. An incisional biopsy was performed, and pathologic evaluation confirmed metastatic urothelial carcinoma with positive GATA-3 immunostain. The patient was previously diagnosed with noninvasive high-grade papillary UC 4.5 years ago with multiple foci and classified as high-risk. Post-treatment with TURBT and intravesical BCG/interferon, there was no evidence of recurrence until the current mandibular findings.

A: The current mandibular lesion is assessed as metastatic urothelial carcinoma. History includes non-muscle invasive high-grade papillary UC.

P: The treatment plan involves discussing the case with the medical team to develop a strategy for addressing the metastatic UC. The patient will be informed and guided through the process, with details to be communicated after further team discussions.

S: The 18-month-old patient presented with snoring, mouth breathing during sleep, sleep apnea, weak aspiration, and nasal leakage when drinking fluids. She was admitted to Shanghai Children's Hospital for these symptoms.

O: The patient's physical examination showed a wide fissure splitting from the palate vertical anterior cleft to 1/3 of the hard palate, bilateral tonsils hypertrophy without exudation, and an unclear-bordered uplift in her left palate. A soft movable mass was present in the right soft palate trailing edge. CT scan revealed a pharyngeal cavity mass measuring approximately 27 mm × 21 mm × 26 mm. No abnormalities were noted in the nasopharyngeal bone or soft tissue.

A: The patient was diagnosed with an incomplete cleft palate and soft palate vascularized space-occupying lesions, likely a fibrous hemangioma.

P: The patient underwent palatal lump resection and cleft palate repair under general anesthesia with endoscopic guidance. Postoperative treatment included ablation of residual tumor tissue with a plasma radiofrequency knife, hemostasis, cleft palate repair, symptomatic treatment for infection, and nasal feeding. Follow-up is required to monitor recovery and manage her condition.

S: The patient reports having a headache, nausea, and vomiting for the past day. The headache is described as persistent and blunt, located in the right temporal region. The patient has a history of hypertension for three years, which has been well-controlled with antihypertensive drugs. There is no relevant psychosocial or familial hereditary history.

O: Neurological examination appears normal. Routine blood tests, including serum C-reactive protein, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, thyroid and sex hormone levels, were normal. Serum anti-MPO and P-ANCA were weakly positive, while other autoantibody tests were negative. Serum tumor markers were negative. Lumbar puncture showed elevated intracranial pressure at 240 mmH2O; CSF analysis was normal with negative tests for pathogens. Brain MRI showed multifocal white matter hyperintensity lesions with associated mass effect, slightly hypointense on T1 and did not enhance with contrast. SWI showed multiple cerebral microbleeds. MRS was normal, and both magnetic resonance angiography and venogram appeared normal.

A: The findings suggest a possible vascular issue in the brain leading to increased intracranial pressure and white matter hyperintensity lesions. The presence of cerebral microbleeds supports this assessment.

P: Monitor the patient’s condition closely. Consider further tests or treatment options if necessary, based on the progression of symptoms and clinical findings. No specific treatments or medications were recommended at this time.

S: The patient was diagnosed with an astrocytoma a few weeks ago after presenting with new onset seizures. She was initially treated with levetiracetam, but experienced breakthrough seizures despite therapeutic serum levels, leading to the addition of Lamotrigine. Since starting Lamotrigine, the patient has experienced a rash, right upper quadrant abdominal pain, and fever for four days, without nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or joint pains. She is allergic to nuts and pollen, with no significant family history. She is a stay-at-home mother of one child and has not traveled out of the city in the last 18 months.

O: The patient is in mild distress due to abdominal pain and has a fever with a temperature of 38°C. Pulse is 110 per minute, respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute, blood pressure is 124/77 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals a reticulated macular erythematous rash on the upper extremities and trunk, right upper quadrant abdominal tenderness, and no localized swelling, lymphadenopathy, or icterus. Cardiac and lung exams are within normal limits. Lab data shows an eosinophil count of 4 x 10^5/ml, elevated white cell count, ALT of 1231 units/L, AST of 1026 units/L, and alkaline phosphatase of 362 units/L. An ultrasound and magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography confirmed the diagnosis.

A: The patient is experiencing symptoms consistent with DRESS syndrome after starting Lamotrigine, with no improvement noted 48 hours after discontinuation. Diagnosis was confirmed through imaging.

P: The plan involves discussing the test results with the patient, formulating a treatment plan to manage symptoms, and addressing the underlying issue. Monitoring the condition closely and scheduling follow-up are critical steps forward.

S: The patient presented a 4-month-old female Simmental calf with polymelia, particularly an accessory limb attached to the left upper scapula, separating into two rudimentary lower limbs. The calf was alert and in good body condition. The owner noted a slightly increased respiratory frequency at 34 breaths per minute, likely due to excitement. No other significant symptoms or issues were reported.

O: On clinical examination, the calf was in a good state of physiologic development with no abnormalities in haematology and blood chemistry. There was a scoliotic and lordotic curvature in the thoracic part of her spine. Initial radiographs showed overlapping of anatomical structures, leading to the decision to perform a CT scan. The calf was prepped for the CT with IM xylazine hydrochloride and IV butorphanol tartrate, and anesthesia was induced with IV ketamine hydrochloride and maintained with isoflurane. Monitoring included pulse oximetry, capnography, ECG, and blood pressure. CT revealed polymelia originating from the thoracic spine with a single rudimentary limb.

A: The calf has polymelia originating from the thoracic spine, associated with spinal scoliosis and lordosis. The limb formation is rudimentary. There are no systemic issues as per haematology and blood chemistry.

P: Further discussions on treatment options and possible surgical interventions are needed. No specific treatment or follow-up plans have been provided.

S: The patient is a 7-year-old boy with congenital bilateral sensorineural deafness and a history of a failed right cochlear implant. He is scheduled for ABI (Auditory Brainstem Implant) insertion and reports no discomfort during a pre-operative MRI where his airway was secured with a size 5.5 mm internal-diameter uncuffed ETT.

O: During the MRI, the patient's airway was secured using a size 5.5 mm internal-diameter uncuffed ETT without discomfort. For the surgery, intraoperative neurophysiology monitoring is planned. Details of electrode placements and anesthetic management include the following: lead placement for CN IX, X, XI, XII, with specific electrode details for CN X (laryngeal electrode), CN IX (pin electrode on ipsilateral soft palate), and CN XII (anterior tongue electrodes). Anesthesia involves Total Intravenous Anesthesia (TIVA) with propofol (target plasma concentration 3.5–5.0 mcg/ml) and remifentanil (0.08–0.3 mcg/kg/min).

A: The patient is a candidate for Auditory Brainstem Implant insertion due to congenital bilateral sensorineural deafness and previous failure of a right cochlear implant. The procedure preparation includes intraoperative neurophysiology monitoring and carefully planned anesthesia management.

P: The plan is to proceed with the ABI insertion using intraoperative neurophysiology monitoring to ensure nerve function during the surgery. Anesthesia will be managed with TIVA, including propofol and remifentanil, to ensure the patient remains comfortable and pain-free. Post-operatively, the patient will be closely monitored, and follow-up care will be provided as necessary. The medical team will be available for any questions or concerns from the patient or family.

S: The patient has a history of unilateral breast cancer and has undergone a previous abdominoplasty, making her unsuitable for bilateral DIEP flaps. She had a surgical-site infection at the left breast postoperatively, which was treated with antibiotics, local debridement, and wound care. She underwent a second-stage procedure with bilateral fat grafting and nipple reconstruction six months after the initial autologous breast reconstruction.

O: No information provided.

A: The patient is undergoing treatment for unilateral breast cancer with autologous breast reconstruction using bilateral fleur-de-PAP flaps. The past infection was successfully managed, and secondary procedures were conducted to enhance the reconstruction outcome.

P: Continue monitoring health and follow up with the medical team to ensure the best possible outcome. Further questions or concerns should be addressed as needed.

S: The patient reports experiencing pelvic pain with a 5-day history of left lower quadrant abdominal pain, described as atypical. There is no nausea, vomiting, dysuria, or diarrhea. She reports that her pelvic pain has been relieved since taking antibiotics. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks prior to this visit. The patient has a history of PCOS and has undergone ovulation induction and intrauterine insemination, with subsequent IVF using Marvelon. She is gravida 4, para 1, abort 3.

O: Examination revealed palpable, cystic, solid masses on both sides in the lower quadrant. Laboratory tests indicated a white blood cell count of 22.9 × 10^9/L, a granulocyte rate of 80.6%, and a normal β-hCG level. The patient had a transient fever of 37.9 °C. Imaging studies, including ultrasound and CT, showed both ovaries enlarged (≥10 cm) with multiple follicles. Serum hormone levels were normal except for slightly elevated dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA, 497.5 μg/dL) and 24-h urinary-free cortisol (UFC, 165.24 μg). Adrenal ultrasound, TSH/FT4, T4, and hypothalamic-pituitary MRI showed no abnormalities. Tumor marker CA125 was elevated at 365.7 U/mL.

A: The findings suggest potential hormonal imbalance and the possibility of a malignant tumor, given the elevated CA125 and history of PCOS with enlarged ovaries.

P: The patient is advised to monitor symptoms and report any changes. A follow-up appointment will be scheduled to discuss further test results and determine the best course of action. The need for close monitoring and additional testing is emphasized to explore the cause of the ovarian enlargement and pain.

S: The patient is a 55-year-old male who presented with critical left lower limb ischemia and a great toe ulceration. He experienced severe pain and numbness in his left leg. A week post-discharge, he developed sudden pain and numbness in the right foot along with short distance calf claudication, but denied symptoms of critical limb ischemia at that time. Later, he developed intense rest pain with no relief from positional changes. He reports feeling sore post-surgery but notes improvement.

O: Initial findings showed a TASC A lesion in the left superficial femoral artery with patent runoff vessels. After angioplasty, a confirmatory angiogram showed satisfactory results. Post-procedure physical examination revealed an unremarkable access site with palpable femoral and popliteal pulses, absent pedal pulses, and a metallic artifact indicating VCD embolisation in the distal popliteal artery. Surgical exploration found a thrombus and a closure device occluding the TPT bifurcation, leading to selective embolectomy.

A: Initial critical left lower limb ischemia due to a TASC A lesion, resolved by angioplasty. Post-procedure complications included right foot ischemia due to VCD embolisation leading to arterial occlusion, diagnosed after imaging and unsuccessful endovascular retrieval efforts. Subsequent surgical intervention resolved the mechanical obstruction.

P: The plan includes continuing dual anti-platelet therapy and statins. Regular follow-up appointments are recommended to monitor recovery and ensure healing is progressing well. Further observation and possibly additional interventions may be needed based on the patient's ongoing symptoms and progress.

S: The patient's mother reports that her six-year-old son has been experiencing hypotonia since birth. She expresses concern about his condition. At the age of six, he has developed kyphosis. There is no history of seizures, and his cognitive function is normal.

O: The patient's CK and aldolase levels are 6304 and 44 U/l, respectively, indicating possible muscle disorder. A muscle biopsy and IHC tests performed at five months old showed dystrophic changes. An MRI study of the brain conducted at six months old was normal.

A: The clinical and biochemical findings suggest a potential diagnosis of merosin deficiency. The presence of hypotonia, elevated CK and aldolase levels, dystrophic changes on muscle biopsy, and kyphosis support this assessment.

P: A genetic test for the LAMA2 gene is recommended to confirm the diagnosis of merosin deficiency. The patient's condition should be monitored for symptoms, particularly the kyphosis as he grows. Follow-up will be based on genetic test results to determine appropriate treatment and management options. The family is advised to contact the healthcare provider with any concerns.

S: The patient, originally from Sierra Leone, reported symptoms over the past three months, including personality changes, excessive sleepiness, a shuffling gait, and significant fatigue. The patient also experienced a generalized tonic-clonic seizure and became unresponsive, leading to intubation and admission to the intensive therapy unit (ITU).

O: The examination revealed right side lateral gaze palsy, rigidity, and bradykinesia. The patient developed fevers and progressive somnolence. CSF analysis showed a white cell count of 250 (100% mononuclear), a protein level of 0.57 g/l, and a normal CSF/serum glucose ratio. Tests for herpes virus and syphilis serology were negative. Elevated levels of voltage gated potassium channel-complex and moderate levels of N-methyl-D-aspartate antibodies were present in the blood. MRI showed bilateral supratentorial deep white matter high signal intensity extending to cerebellum and brain stem, involvement of the mesial temporal lobe structures, and prominent ventricles. Trypomastigotes of T. brucei were found in bone marrow and peripheral blood. CSF and serum tested positive for T.b. gambiense IFAT.

A: The initial treatment with intravenous acyclovir and ceftriaxone showed no effect. The presence of trypanosomes in blood and CSF indicated Stage 2 West African trypanosomiasis. The patient had high levels of voltage gated potassium channel-complex antibodies suggesting an autoimmune component.

P: Initiated nifurtimox and eflornithine combination therapy per WHO guidelines for Stage 2 West African trypanosomiasis. The patient was extubated after four days and transferred to the ward. Despite becoming drowsy on day 9, CSF tests showed no trypanosomes, so treatment adjustments were made based on high antibody levels. Continued monitoring and regular follow-up are advised to adjust the treatment plan as required.

S: The patient reports progressive visual loss in both eyes for the past week, along with headaches, nausea, and vomiting over the last two months. The patient denies experiencing prolonged fever, chronic cough, weight loss, or loss of appetite. Family history includes the patient’s father having pulmonary tuberculosis two years ago, who completed anti-tuberculosis therapy.

O: The patient's best corrected visual acuity is 3/60 in the right eye and 4/60 in the left eye. Optic nerve function tests show impairment in light brightness, contrast sensitivity, and color vision, with the right eye more affected. There is a relative afferent pupillary defect in the right eye. Confrontation test reveals generalized haziness with dense central scotoma. Anterior segment and intraocular pressure are normal. Fundoscopy shows bilateral papilledema, swollen and elevated optic discs, peripapillary flame-shaped hemorrhages, and macular exudates. The patient is alert and oriented, vital signs stable, afebrile, and no signs of meningism. Respiratory exam shows crepitation in the right lung. Baseline blood tests mostly unremarkable except for increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate (79 mm/h) and C-reactive protein (23 mg/l). HIV test negative, Mantoux test positive with 16 mm induration. Sputum exam shows acid-fast bacilli. Chest radiograph reveals cavitations in the right lower zone. CT confirms tuberculosis.

A: The diagnostic impression is a tuberculosis infection, likely affecting both the lungs and the eyes (ocular tuberculosis). The presence of acid-fast bacilli in sputum and radiological evidence supports this.

P: Start appropriate tuberculosis treatment regimen immediately. Schedule regular follow-up appointments for monitoring progress and adjusting treatment as necessary. Patient instructed to report any changes in symptoms.

S: The patient is here for an assessment in preparation for orthognathic surgery. The patient reports having a 1.5 cm tongue lesion since birth, which has not changed since childhood.

O: Physical examination reveals a 1.5 cm smooth, regular, and soft exophytic midline tongue lesion. MRI shows a 1.5 cm mass on the dorsal aspect of the tongue in the midline, partly fatty, with mild contrast enhancement. The lesion does not involve the intrinsic tongue muscles, and the overlying mucosa is intact. The sublingual space and salivary glands are normal. Histological examination identifies the lesion as a leiomyomatous hamartoma with fibrovascular connective tissue and other components, showing no atypia or necrosis.

A: Benign leiomyomatous hamartoma of the tongue, with no concern for malignancy. 

P: Surgical removal of the mass was performed, followed by histological examination confirming the benign nature of the lesion. Recommended monitoring during future check-ups. The lesion should not interfere with orthognathic surgery plans.

S: The patient reports having ankylosing spondylitis for the past 10 years and has recently been experiencing significant fatigue. The patient has not experienced fever, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, confusion, or headaches. The patient has been on certolizumab pegol for 6 months, reporting no symptoms when a decrease in hemoglobin level was observed. There is no history of recent travel, illicit drug use, or consumption of quinine-containing drugs or untreated water.

O: Initial complete blood count showed hemoglobin of 14.4 g/dL, hematocrit at 52%, leucocyte count of 8900/mm3, and platelet count of 415000/mm3. Recent results show a hemoglobin of 5.3 g/dL, hematocrit at 16.1%, mean corpuscular volume of 90 fL, leucocyte count of 4460/mm3, and platelet count of 28000/mm3. Coagulation profile is normal with a negative D-dimer. Biochemical analysis reveals elevated lactate dehydrogenase (5680 U/L), total bilirubin (2.2 mg/dL), direct bilirubin (0.32 mg/dL), and reduced haptoglobulin (28 mg/dL). Renal functions are normal with no proteinuria. Peripheral blood smear shows schistocytes in about 20% of erythrocytes per field.

A: The findings are indicative of thrombotic microangiopathy.

P: The plan is to start plasma exchange and administer 1 mg/kg/day of methylprednisolone. Samples for ADAMTS13 evaluation will be collected prior to plasmapheresis. Certolizumab treatment will be temporarily stopped. The patient's progress will be closely monitored with the expectation of a rapid and significant improvement.

S: The patient, a 2.5-year-old male, has been noted to be underweight with a BMI of 17.7 and has had complete hearing loss since birth. He also presents with aphasia, alertness but unassessable orientation, developmental delays in milestones like neck holding, crawling, sitting, and walking. Past medical history includes episodes of bilious vomiting, failure to thrive, and severe constipation at six months, leading to a diagnosis of Hirschsprung's disease confirmed by rectal biopsy, followed by an end-colostomy. Family history reveals WS in the father and paternal aunt, but without Hirschsprung's disease or hearing deficits.

O: Vitals include a heart rate of 85 bpm, blood pressure of 110/85 mmHg, and a respiratory rate of 18/min. The patient is afebrile. Physical examination reveals blue homochromatic irises with normal visual response, coarse hair texture, pallor of nails, slightly broad high nasal root, and segmental depigmentation on the forehead and left forearm. A white hair patch (poliosis) was noted in the frontal distribution since birth. An auditory brainstem response test showed bilateral sensorineural hearing loss.

A: The patient presents with features suggestive of Waardenburg syndrome (WS), including hearing loss, poliosis, and certain facial features, combined with a history of Hirschsprung's disease. The bilateral sensorineural hearing loss and developmental delays are consistent with this assessment.

P: Continue monitoring the patient's developmental progress and hearing. Evaluate potential interventions for sensorineural hearing loss, possibly including hearing aids or cochlear implants, aligning with WS management. Regular follow-up for developmental assessment and any gastrointestinal issues related to Hirschsprung’s disease and colostomy is recommended. Consider genetic counseling for the family.

S: The patient is a 52-year-old smoker with a history of intermittent hematuria and clotting for the past two weeks. There are no additional symptoms reported. The patient has a past surgical history of bilateral cryptorchidism treated at the age of 5. The patient has a significant smoking history of 30 pack-years.

O: Physical examination showed no localized tenderness or palpable mass in the lumbar region, and the prostate was painless without suspect lesions. Laboratory results indicated a hemoglobin level of 13 g/dl, normal platelet levels, homeostasis, and renal function. Urine analysis revealed sterile red blood cells. Prostate-specific antigen level was 1.09 ng/ml. Ultrasound showed an enlarged hypoechoic mass on the upper pole of the right kidney, a dilated ureter, and a suspicious hypovascularized intraluminal papillary tumor in the right lumbar ureter. The CT scan demonstrated right ureteral duplicity with a destroyed upper pole and a 20 mm endoluminal tumor. MRI showed no parenchymal lesions, with drainage ending in the prostatic right lobe. Cystoscopy under anesthesia indicated normal meatuses.

A: Findings are suggestive of a suspicious tumor in the upper pole of the right kidney and a hypovascularized intraluminal papillary tumor in the right lumbar ureter. The diagnosis involves right ureteral duplicity and potential malignancy or ureteral obstruction.

P: The plan involves discussing treatment options to address the tumor in the right lumbar ureter and continuous monitoring of kidney function. Further evaluation and possible surgical intervention may be needed. Follow-up consultations are necessary to determine the most appropriate course of treatment.

S: The patient was hospitalized on 16th December 2011 with symptoms of dyspnea and small-volume hemoptysis that started 2 weeks prior. The patient reports trouble breathing, coughing up a little blood, and feeling weak but has not experienced weight loss. The patient has a history of smoking with a 20 pack-year history and continued smoking. No exposure to toxic chemicals was reported. The patient has a history of pre-eclampsia during two pregnancies but no prior pulmonary disease or family history of renal, cardiac, or pulmonary diseases.

O: Upon admission, patient showed apyrexia, hypertension with a blood pressure of 184/105 mmHg, a pulse rate of 96 beats/minute, and skin pallor. A chest X-ray revealed bilateral infiltrates and a thoracic CT scan showed diffuse and bilateral ground-glass opacification. Laboratory findings indicated normocytic normochromic anemia with a hemoglobin level of 7 g/dL, normal platelet and leucocyte counts, but a significant increase in creatinine level to 614 μmol/L, indicating acute renal failure. Bronchoscopy revealed hematic traces with negative bacterial cultures. Serologic tests for auto-antibodies and ELISA for anti-GBM antibodies were negative, with normal hemolytic complement fractions. Renal biopsy showed fibrinoid necrosis in 34.5% of glomeruli, glomerulosclerosis in 30%, cellular crescents in 28%, and linear IgG deposition on immunofluorescence.

A: The clinical presentation and findings are consistent with Goodpasture Syndrome, an autoimmune disease affecting the kidneys and lungs.

P: The patient received three daily boluses of methylprednisolone followed by 1 mg/kg/day of prednisone. Treatment included daily plasmapheresis. The condition will be monitored closely, and appropriate treatment will continue to be provided.

S: The patient reports experiencing chronic heel pain for the past two and a half years, which they suspect may be due to the prominence at the bottom end of a previously inserted Fixion® nail. They had undergone treatment for a multifragmentary Pilon fracture with a primary retrograde expandable Fixion® nail and could walk without significant pain 22 weeks post-treatment. Initially, they did not consent to the nail removal but now request it.

O: The patient previously had a Fixion® nail due to a multifragmentary Pilon fracture. During the removal procedure, the nail fractured at the junction of the valve and fins; only the end cup and valve were successfully removed.

A: The patient has chronic heel pain, possibly related to the retained nail fragment. Currently, the patient is asymptomatic following the partial removal of the nail.

P: Advise the patient to keep the nail remnant unless it becomes symptomatic. Continue with regular follow-up visits to monitor the condition and ensure stability.

S: The patient reported no symptoms of abdominal pain or discomfort. They have a history of acute appendicitis treated with antimicrobial therapy 2 months ago, followed by the presence of an asymptomatic, enlarged, and thickened appendix. The patient is diagnosed with Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1) and expressed feeling nervous about the upcoming surgery but has no other co-morbidities.

O: Physical examination revealed multiple neurofibromas and café-au-lait spots. Laboratory analysis showed normal levels of hemoglobin, white blood cell count, platelets, serum total protein, serum albumin, total bilirubin, aspartate aminotransferase, alanine aminotransferase, lactic acid dehydrogenase, and C-reactive protein, along with normal tumor markers (carcinoembryonic antigen and carbohydrate antigen 19-9). Contrast-enhanced CT showed an enlarged and diffusely thickened appendix. Colonoscopy showed thickened appendiceal mucosa projecting to the cecum, with a benign appendiceal mucosa sample pathologically.

A: The patient is preoperatively diagnosed with treated acute appendicitis with potential chronic appendiceal inflammation or an appendiceal neoplasm, yet the findings suggest a benign nature.

P: The plan is to proceed with a laparoscopic cecectomy to remove the affected appendix. Post-surgery, the resected specimen will be examined to gain further insights into the condition. The patient will be monitored during the surgical and post-operative phases to ensure appropriate care. Further treatment options will be discussed post-operatively as needed.

S: The patient is a 40-year-old African-American male with neurosarcoidosis involving the hypothalamus and pituitary. He presented with altered mental status and reports feeling lethargic, with the ability to respond to verbal stimuli.

O: Upon arrival, the patient was hypothermic with a temperature of 32°C, hypernatremic with a sodium level of 176 mEq/L, and exhibited sinus bradycardia at 41 bpm, first-degree AV block with a PR interval of 280 ms, premature atrial contractions, prolonged QRS at 160 ms, and a QTc of 584 ms on ECG. Osborn waves were noted in the precordial lateral leads. The physical exam was otherwise unremarkable.

A: Altered mental status in the context of neurosarcoidosis, likely exacerbated by hypernatremia and hypothermia.

P: The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit and treated with intravenous fluids, intranasal desmopressin, and external warming blankets. This led to an improvement in serum sodium levels, mental status, and resolution of ECG abnormalities. Continued treatment includes corticosteroids, testosterone, levothyroxine, and desmopressin. The plan is to discharge the patient ten days after presentation with follow-up for further evaluation and management.

S: The patient is a 76-year-old man with no prior pathological history, admitted due to a 5-day history of fever, abdominal distension, and a palpable mass in the hypogastrium. The patient also reported feeling weak and experiencing tachycardia.

O: The patient presented with hemodynamic instability, blood pressure of 90/50, and tachycardia. Initial resuscitation included 2000 ml of physiological solution and antibiotic therapy with Metronidazole and Ceftriaxone. Examination revealed an indurated, mobile hypogastric mass without peritoneal irritation. Blood tests showed leukocytosis with immature cells, increased CRP, and normal lactate levels. Abdominal CT showed a large supra-bladder pelvic mass of 12 cm with central necrosis and intra-portal hepatic gas. Blood and abscess culture grew Streptococcus anginosus and mixed anaerobic flora; biopsy was negative for malignant cells. Thoracoabdominal CT showed respiratory distress, abdominopelvic free fluid, and a drained intra-tumoral abscess. Surgical intervention revealed a 15x15 cm tumor in the jejunum, 20 cm from the duodenojejunal angle. Post-operative recovery was successful after intestinal resection and anastomosis.

A: Large pelvic abscess formation due to jejunal tumor, positive for Streptococcus anginosus and mixed anaerobic flora, associated with intestinal perforation. Mesenchymal proliferation in tumor without mucosal infiltration.

P: Continued resuscitation and intensive care management with noradrenaline, followed by surgical intervention for tumor resection and anastomosis. The patient's recovery was monitored, leading to discharge after 13 days. Further follow-up is implied but not explicitly stated in the conversation.

S: The patient, a 16-year-old, reports having headaches since the age of 10. The patient's mother also experiences headaches and has significant brain calcification. There is a family history of calcification associated with headaches, with the patient's younger sister having mental retardation, but no detailed clinical information is provided about her condition.

O: The patient's neurological examination findings were normal. CT images show spotty calcification in the bilateral globus pallidus and caudate nuclei, as well as mild calcification in the thalamus, subcortical white matter, and dentate nuclei. DNA analysis shows that the patient shares a genetic variant with their mother and third brother, who also has brain calcification.

A: The recurrent headaches are possibly linked to cerebral calcification, which is a familial condition affecting the patient, mother, and third brother.

P: The plan is to continue monitoring the patient's condition and symptoms closely with regular checkups. The patient is advised to contact the doctor if there are any changes or worsening in the headaches.

S: The patient reports a history of two cervical surgeries with titanium plates and screws placed at C4-C5 and C5-C6. Since 2005, the patient has experienced fatigue, chills, headaches, nausea, asymmetric arthralgia, and a malar rash after sun exposure, as well as a fluctuating trunk rash. From 2005 to 2007, the symptoms were untreated with a fluctuating course. In 2007, the patient had fatigue, rash, arthralgia, and developed edema in the hands and feet, without improvement from prescribed prednisone and methotrexate. Subsequent symptoms included dysphagia, halitosis, and purulent "sputum" production, with no abnormalities found by an ENT specialist.

O: Physical examination showed arthritis in the left shoulder and left ankle, livedo reticularis, and an erythematous rash on the thorax, with no infection detected. Laboratory studies indicated thrombocytosis (485,000 cells/mm³), elevated CRP (75 mg/dl), elevated ESR (40 mm/h), negative autoantibodies, and normal complement levels. A SPECT suggested spondylitis in the cervical spine (C4-C6) and identified an inflammatory process in the nasopharynx, an increase in the prevertebral space of >2 cm, and free air in this area. An esophagogram was performed.

A: The clinician suspects spondylitis in the cervical spine and an inflammatory process in the nasopharynx, along with a possible connection to the reported systemic symptoms. There is ongoing thrombocytosis and elevated inflammatory markers, with a need to further evaluate and manage these chronic symptoms.

P: The plan includes discussing further treatment options with the patient, closely monitoring the condition, and emphasizing the importance of regular follow-ups with the rheumatologist and other specialists for effective symptom management. Further evaluation and potential adjustment in treatment may be necessary based on ongoing symptoms and test results.

S: The patient reports having left lower quadrant abdominal pain for the past 3 days, rated at 6 out of 10 in intensity, radiating to the left lower back. The patient also experienced a high-grade fever of 103°F, nausea, and some vomiting. The patient denies any urinary issues or history of urinary tract infections or renal stones. Medical history includes well-controlled type II diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Current medications are canagliflozin 100 mg daily, lisinopril 20 mg daily, and atorvastatin 80 mg daily. The patient has been taking canagliflozin for 14 months. Ten days after the initial treatment, the patient reports intermittent low-grade fevers around 100°F.

O: Vitals: Blood pressure 172/86 mmHg, heart rate 94 beats per minute, temperature 102°F. BMI: 46.61 kg/m2. Physical exam: tenderness in the left lower quadrant and left flank. Urinalysis: pyuria, bacteriuria, and nitrites. Hemoglobin A1C: 7.5% (59 mmol/mol). CT scan: 4-5 mm obstructive left distal ureteral stone with mild hydroureteronephrosis. Cystoscopy with retrograde pyelography: left 6-French × 24 cm double-J ureteral stent placed. Intraoperative urine cultures: no growth.

A: The patient is diagnosed with obstructing nephrolithiasis complicated by pyelonephritis.

P: Initial in-hospital treatment with intravenous ceftriaxone 1 gram every 24 hours. Placement of a ureteral stent to alleviate obstruction. Discharge medications include cefdinir 300 mg twice a day for 14 days and tamsulosin 0.4 mg daily for 30 days. Follow-up with urology in 2 weeks. Patient advised to monitor symptoms and report any changes. Re-evaluation planned due to reported low-grade fevers 10 days later.

S: The patient is a 31-year-old woman experiencing recurrent itchy eruptions on her mid- to lower back, lateral chest wall, and the nape of her neck. These eruptions occur during fasting in Ramadan or when traveling to North America. After resolution, the eruptions leave a net-like pigmentation. She reports no other medical issues.

O: No information provided.

A: The clinician notes that the eruptions may be linked to fasting and travel, but no specific diagnosis is mentioned.

P: The patient is advised to keep her skin moisturized, avoid irritants, and minimize stress to manage symptoms. Adjusting fasting practices and travel plans is suggested to prevent future occurrences. She is also advised to monitor the affected areas for any changes and to schedule a follow-up if symptoms worsen or new ones develop.

S: 
The patient, Ms. C., was diagnosed with uveal melanoma in 2014 and treated with proton beam radiation therapy. She had a confirmed diagnosis of liver metastases from a November 2015 MRI. Her past medical history includes angiomyolipoma of the kidney, uterine leiomyoma, obstructive sleep apnea, enthesopathy in the hip, Achilles tendinitis, arthritis, and she's undergone a bone graft. She is taking estradiol-norethindrone and trazodone and is allergic to gabapentin. She has no family history of inflammatory bowel disease or GI malignancies. After liver metastases, she was treated with pembrolizumab and SIRT but developed pulmonary metastases, leading to the discontinuation of pembrolizumab. She started on ipilimumab as a second-line therapy. She has new onset paroxysmal atrial fibrillation for which she is on metoprolol and apixiban. Post-ipilimumab, she developed epigastric pain, gastric reflux symptoms unresponsive to proton pump inhibitors, and mild diarrhea with 3-4 loose stools daily.

O: 
Endoscopic examination revealed normal-appearing esophageal, gastric, and duodenal mucosa without ulceration or significant mucosal injury. Gastric biopsies displayed lymphocytic inflammation surrounding pigmented cells scattered throughout the gastric mucosa.

A: 
The patient has metastatic uveal melanoma with liver and pulmonary metastases. Current clinical issues include managing immune-related adverse effects from ipilimumab, indicated by gastrointestinal symptoms and inflammation found on gastric biopsy, as well as atrial fibrillation.

P: 
Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely with further treatment adjustments as necessary. Address gastrointestinal symptoms and manage adverse effects with appropriate interventions. Maintain current medications for atrial fibrillation. Consider additional immunotherapy strategies or supportive care as dictated by ongoing assessments.

S: The patient is a 69-year-old with a history of Felty syndrome at age 64, which included rheumatoid arthritis, neutropenia, and splenomegaly. The patient had a splenectomy at age 67 and developed transfusion-dependent anemia at age 68. Initially diagnosed with anemia of chronic disease, the management included multiple rheumatoid arthritis medications. Later, the patient was diagnosed with myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) after another bone marrow examination. Treatments for MDS included erythropoietin, lenalidomide, and azacitidine; however, the patient is currently transfusion-dependent again.

O: Recent bone marrow core biopsy and aspiration showed hypercellular marrow with trilineage dysplasia, moderate reticulin fibrosis, and 2% blasts. Flow cytometry indicated changes consistent with MDS, such as cytoplasmic hypogranularity, absence of hematogones, and aberrant myeloid blasts with specific expression patterns. Cytogenetic studies revealed a normal diploid karyotype.

A: The patient has a history of myelodysplastic syndrome with current transfusion dependency and evidence from recent tests supporting MDS diagnosis. Despite previous interventions, there is an absence of response to treatments, leading to current evaluation for further management.

P: The case will be discussed with a team of specialists to determine the best course of action for managing the patient's anemia and MDS. The patient will be kept informed, and necessary support will be provided. Further treatment options are under consideration.

S: The patient is a 76-year-old Asian man with a 55-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, experiencing right intermittent claudication for 3 years. He has a history of diabetic retinopathy and has been on insulin therapy for the past 3 years.

O: On examination, there is a right femoral bruit and diminished right popliteal pulse, suggesting a right femoral lesion. The right ABI is 1.28, while the left ABI is elevated to 1.55 due to incompressible infrapopliteal arteries. Angiography revealed a severe stenotic lesion at the origin of the right superficial femoral artery and severe calcification in the infrapopliteal arteries at the right ankle and bilaterally. Five years later, the patient's right ABI decreased to 0.83 with a right ankle upstroke time of 240 milliseconds.

A: The patient likely has peripheral artery disease (PAD) in the right extremity, with falsely normalized right ABI due to incompressible arteries. Severe stenosis at the right superficial femoral artery origin was confirmed, with extensive calcification in infrapopliteal arteries.

P: Revascularization is not indicated. The patient was enrolled in a supervised exercise training program for 6 months, with instructions to continue walking 2 hours daily thereafter. Further follow-up and lifestyle adjustments are advised to manage PAD and diabetes.

S: The patient presented to the emergency department with nausea, vomiting, and bloody diarrhea for five days. They reported visiting their primary care doctor on the third day of illness and were treated for viral gastroenteritis, which led to some improvement in nausea and diarrhea. However, they continue to experience poor oral intake and increased weakness. The patient recalls consuming meatloaf from a local store three days before symptoms started.

O: The patient's vital signs are stable. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes. Laboratory tests show hemoglobin at 12 g/dl, reduced from 15.4 two months ago. Platelet count is 47 x 10³/mL, reduced from 161. Sodium is 119 mmol/L, potassium 4.4 mmol/L, creatinine 6.7 mg/dl (baseline was 1.0 mg/dl), and blood urea nitrogen is 99 mg/dL. Urinalysis indicates a urinary tract infection. Peripheral blood smear shows mildly increased schistocytes, normochromic normocytic erythrocytes, and marked thrombocytopenia. Hemolytic workup revealed elevated reticulocyte count (3.08%), lactic acid dehydrogenase (480 IU/L), normal bilirubin levels, haptoglobin (163 mg/dL), and elevated free hemoglobin (115 mg/dL).

A: The findings suggest a urinary tract infection caused by Enterococcus faecalis with accompanying new-onset thrombocytopenia, anemia, and acute kidney injury. There is concern for thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA), with further evaluation for possible atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome. Normal ADAMTS13 activity at 92%, and normal C3 complement, C4 complement, and complement CH50 levels were noted.

P: The plan includes starting treatment with ampicillin for the urinary tract infection. The patient's condition will be monitored closely with continued assessment and appropriate treatment for TMA. The patient is advised to follow up with their primary care physician and inform them of the recent hospital visit and results.

S: The patient is a 27-year-old female with no past medical or surgical history. She reports experiencing fever for a few days and feeling disoriented, with noted low blood pressure. She mentions having a facial rash for the last year, which did not improve with steroid treatment. There is no history of recent travel or contact with sick individuals.

O: During the physical examination, signs consistent with dermatomyositis, including a heliotrope rash on the face, were noted. Lab results show anemia with hemoglobin at 8.5 g/dl, hematocrit at 0.28, and red blood cells at 3.30x10¹²/L. Platelet count is low at 40,000/ul. LDH is elevated at 814 IU/L, total bilirubin at 2.2 mg/dl, and renal parameters are high with BUN at 42 mg/dL and creatinine at 3.5 mg/dL. Coagulation tests show PT at 16 seconds and aPTT at 38 seconds. ANA and anti-Jo tests are positive. Spinal tap, urinalysis, and blood cultures are negative for infections.

A: The patient is diagnosed with thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), evidenced by fever, altered consciousness, renal impairment, anemia, and thrombocytopenia. Dermatomyositis is confirmed as an underlying autoimmune condition.

P: The patient is being treated with plasmapheresis to improve her condition. Continuous monitoring and adjustments to treatment will be made as necessary.

S: The patient reported a sudden and intense onset of severe back pain, necessitating a visit to the emergency department. The patient has medical histories of asthma and atrial fibrillation and is a smoker but does not consume alcohol. The patient has a corgi dog that has bitten and scratched them a few times. The patient is not currently taking any medications.

O: Upon admission, the patient had a body temperature of 37.5 °C, blood pressure of 127/48 mmHg, heart rate of 84 beats per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95% without accelerated respiration. Physical examination showed no spinal knocking pain, neurological abnormalities, or specific findings. Laboratory tests revealed a white blood cell count of 13,360 cells/mm3, platelet count of 17.0 × 10^4/μL, serum creatinine level of 0.66 mg/dL, and C-reactive protein level of 18.5 mg/dL. Blood cultures detected Gram-negative bacilli, later identified as P. multocida.

A: The provisional diagnosis is a spinal epidural abscess or vertebral osteomyelitis/discitis, likely related to P. multocida infection.

P: The patient is being treated with intravenous meropenem 1 g every 8 hours. The plan is to monitor the patient's response to the treatment and overall condition. The patient is advised to avoid further dog bites or scratches. The patient should report any worsening of symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient was admitted in November 2012 during pregnancy with high blood pressure and small red spots on the skin, identified as petechiae. She was diagnosed with an acute pregnancy-onset TTP episode. Her laboratory results showed low platelet count, anemia, hemolytic anemia, increased lactate dehydrogenase levels, and the need for pregnancy termination due to severe intrauterine growth restriction. She had a history of a missed abortion and was unaware of any family history related to TTP or blood clotting disorders. 

O: The patient had a platelet count of 5 x 10^9 platelets/L, hemoglobin level at 7.0 g/dL, and increased lactate dehydrogenase levels at 454 U/L. Schistocytes were observed in 7-10 out of every 1,000 red blood cells, and the direct Coombs test was negative. An MRI showed old ischemic lesions in both cerebral hemispheres, likely from an ischemic event 7 months earlier. The patient developed Escherichia coli-induced sepsis following plasma exchange treatment.

A: Acute pregnancy-onset Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP) episode with severe intrauterine growth restriction and subsequent need for pregnancy termination. Complications included low platelet count, anemia, and Escherichia coli-induced sepsis.

P: The patient underwent plasma exchange and was treated with corticosteroids, normalizing platelet count after 6 days. Plasma exchange was stopped due to infection, and the patient remains in remission. Continued monitoring through regular follow-ups is recommended, and patient is encouraged to contact healthcare providers if new symptoms arise. Two remission samples were collected in 2013 and 2014 for ADAMTS13 characterization.

S: The patient was referred for acute liver failure of unknown origin, initially presenting with extreme fatigue and indolent jaundice. There are no pre-existing medical conditions and no exposure to drugs, promiscuity, or autoimmune disorders.

O: During the physical examination, the patient exhibited distinct jaundice and hepatic encephalopathy grade I. Laboratory tests showed massively elevated transaminases; ALT was 4645 U/l, AST was 4956 U/l, alkaline phosphatase was 216 U/l, and γ-GT was 91 U/l. Liver synthesis parameters indicated impairment, with a total bilirubin of 14.8 mg/dl, INR of 2.39, and factor V activity less than 35%. The patient’s liver function was severely impaired, as indicated by a LiMAx test result of 147 μg/h/kg. Subsequent deterioration of these parameters fulfilled the criteria for non-acetaminophen-induced acute liver failure.

A: The patient is diagnosed with cryptogenic acute liver failure, with potential non-acetaminophen-induced acute liver failure, as infectious, autoimmune, and metabolic causes were ruled out.

P: The treatment plan includes supportive care with vitamin K, ursodeoxycholic acid, and lactulose. The patient's condition will be monitored closely, and the treatment plan will be adjusted as necessary.

S: The patient is a 56-year-old woman experiencing multiple neck lumps for 4 months, along with vague abdominal pain, loss of appetite, and lower back pain. The patient reports no significant medical, family, or psychosocial history.

O: Clinical examination shows multiple enlarged cervical lymph nodes (firm to hard), a 2x2 cm firm lump on the lower pole of the left thyroid lobe, and enlarged right inguinal lymph nodes. The uterine cervix feels hard and unhealthy, and spinal tenderness is noted. Neurological examination of the lower limbs is normal. Blood tests, liver profile, and renal tests are within normal limits. An ultrasound reveals multiple nodules in the thyroid with increased vascularity and enlarged cervical lymph nodes with obliterated fatty hila. CT scan shows a mass in the uterine cervix, multiple enlarged lymph nodes, low-density nodules in the thyroid gland, and a mixed density mass lesion in the lower pole of the left thyroid lobe. An anterior wedge fracture of the L2 vertebra is noted. Biopsies indicate moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the uterine cervix and metastatic deposits in the cervical lymph nodes.

A: The clinical findings and test results suggest cervical carcinoma with local extension into the endometrium and metastasis to the lymph nodes, thyroid, and possibly bone (L2 vertebra). 

P: The patient will need a comprehensive treatment plan that may include surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, or a combination of these options. Detailed discussions will be held with the patient to decide on the best course of action.

S: The patient, a 61-year-old male with a history of alcohol abuse and presumed cirrhosis, reports feeling very weak and experiencing right-sided facial droop. 

O: The patient presented with very low blood pressure and decreased body temperature. Ascites were noted, and a diagnostic paracentesis showed 9,787 nucleated cells per microliter with abundant bacteria. A point-of-care ultrasound indicated pneumoperitoneum. A portable abdominal radiograph was suspicious for free air. Surgery revealed a ruptured gastric ulcer and ischemia in the distal ileum and cecum, with no frank necrosis.

A: The patient is likely experiencing complications of cirrhosis, including infection and pneumoperitoneum, indicative of a perforated gastric ulcer and intestinal ischemia.

P: The patient was intubated and started on continuous norepinephrine infusion for hemodynamic support. Intravenous vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam were administered to address the infection. Surgery was performed to manage the ruptured gastric ulcer and ischemia. Continued medical care and monitoring are planned, with follow-up care to be discussed prior to discharge.

S: The patient reports a painless swelling on the right side of the neck below the jaw for the past two weeks. They deny any fever and have underlying conditions of hypertension and diabetes, for which they are receiving regular treatment.

O: Physical examination reveals right submandibular swelling of 6 x 5 cm, non-tender, mobile, and firm, with normal overlying skin. Intraoral examination shows pus at the Wharton's duct orifice. No sialolith is palpated initially. Preoperative tests including complete blood count, serum urea and electrolytes, serum uric acid, electrocardiography, and chest radiographs are normal. CT scan indicates opacity in the right submandibular gland and duct. Intraoperative findings include an indurated gland, a firm bulge along the duct with smaller stones, and a 25 mm largest stone. Histopathology shows severe acute-on-chronic sialadenitis with multiple calculi.

A: Right submandibular sialolithiasis with severe acute-on-chronic sialadenitis.

P: The patient underwent an excision of the right submandibular gland under general anesthesia. Postoperative recovery has been uneventful. Further monitoring and discussion of additional treatment options as necessary.

S:  
The patient reports that her husband noticed skin color changes on her back a few weeks ago. She has a history of generalized pain and has been using an electrical heating pad for about 12 months to alleviate this pain. The patient has been bedridden due to intractable pain. The heating pad is often used for at least six consecutive hours, but she reports no burning or discomfort from its use.

O:
