Upon physical examination, reticulated, ill-defined, reddish-brown patches were observed on the patient's back. These lesions appear to be due to chronic heat exposure from the heating pad. At the follow-up visit 18 months later, a physical examination showed that the skin lesions had resolved.

A:  
The clinical impression is that the skin lesions were caused by prolonged use of the heating pad, resulting in 'erythema ab igne' due to chronic heat exposure. 

P:  
The patient was advised to discontinue the use of the heating pad and avoid any heat sources on her back. A follow-up visit was scheduled to monitor the progress of her skin condition, which subsequently resolved. The patient is advised to reach out if further assistance with pain management is needed.

S: The patient reports experiencing muscle weakness for the past two months. They have a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, stroke, and a remote exposure to statins.

O: The physical examination revealed 2/5 strength on the left side and 4/5 on the right side. Initial CK level was extremely high at 28,885 U/L. MRI showed extensive proximal muscle edema. Biopsy of the vastus medialis showed necrotizing features without inflammation. HMG CoA antibodies were strongly positive. One month later, CK levels dropped to 5,546 U/L. Three months later, CK levels were 3,178 U/L. After eight months, CK level was 117 U/L, and LDH was 251 U/L. One year after starting tacrolimus and MMF, the physical exam was normal with full strength throughout.

A: The clinician suspects necrotizing myositis based on the high CK levels, MRI findings, biopsy results, and positive HMG CoA antibodies.

P: The patient was treated with IV methylprednisolone followed by PDN 60 mg/day. IVIG was given for 5 days, and MMF 1 g/day was started. Due to continuing weakness, rituximab was added, and the regimen was adjusted to MMF (3 g/day) and prednisone (60 mg/day), with two doses of IVIG as bridge therapy. Later, TAC 4 mg/day was added, which was increased to 6 mg/day, alongside a taper in PDN dose. Monitoring and follow-up appointments are recommended for ongoing management.

S: The patient reports having intermittent abdominal pain and diarrhea for 3 months, describing the diarrhea as mucoid-runny, occurring 3-4 times a day, with visceral pain around the belly button that usually subsides after diarrhea. The patient has a history of a gastrointestinal hemorrhage due to a peptic ulcer about 10 years ago. The patient denies any surgeries or drug use.

O: Physical examination shows fever at 36 °C, pulse at 82/min, and blood pressure at 130/80 mmHg. Abdominal distention, increased bowel sounds, and ileocecal tenderness with deep palpation were noted. Laboratory findings include a white blood cell count of 14,000/uL, C-reactive protein at 185 mg/L, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate at 60 mm/h. Celiac markers tested negative. Stool microscopy showed many leukocytes, with no specific microorganisms in the stool culture. Gastroscopy and colonoscopy revealed purulent fluid evacuation, ulcerated and granular appearances on the caecum base, and biopsy indicated colitis. Abdominal ultrasonography showed inflammation of intestinal loops, omental inflammatory thickening, and a 7x5x4 cm fluid collection in the pericaecal area. CT scan revealed a hyperdense area of 12x16 mm, compatible with plastron appendicitis.

A: Diagnostic impressions include plastron appendicitis and colitis, explaining the abdominal pain, diarrhea, and associated symptoms.

P: Continue hydration, and administration of empiric antibiotics cefixime 1x100 mg and metronidazole 3x500 mg. Monitor progress and adjust the treatment plan based on the patient's response. The reduction in C-reactive protein and symptom improvement will continue to be monitored.

S: The patient is a 46-year-old woman previously treated for anaplastic oligoastrocytoma with radiation and currently on temozolomide. She reports experiencing a cough and palpitations recently.

O: Vitals on admission: blood pressure 115/83 mm Hg, heart rate 117 beats/min, body temperature 36.5°C, SpO2 96% on 2 L/min oxygen cannula. ECG reveals sinus tachycardia and SIQIII TIII with negative T in V1–3. Ultrasound cardiogram shows a distended right ventricle, D-shape (+), moderate tricuspid valve regurgitation, and moderate to severe pulmonary hypertension (pressure gradient 59 mm Hg). Chest X-ray indicates distended pulmonary arteries and interstitial lung infiltrate. CT scan shows no thrombus in major pulmonary arteries but reveals nodular opacities with tree-in-bud pattern. Abdominal CT displays slightly distended gastric wall and lymphadenopathies. Blood tests show decreased platelets (71 × 10^3/μL), increased D-dimer (20.08 μg/mL), fibrinogen (100 mg/dL), no signs of infection—white blood count 7450/μL, CRP 0.24 mg/dL, and βd-glucan <2.4 pg/mL.

A: The clinician suspects temozolomide-induced interstitial pneumonia complicated with disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) and right heart failure.

P: The patient will be admitted for further treatment. She will undergo steroid pulse therapy with methylprednisolone 1 g/d for the interstitial pneumonia. Recombinant thrombomodulin and continuous heparin infusion will be administered to address the hypercoagulable state. Monitoring and treatment adjustment will be ongoing throughout hospitalization.

S: The patient, who was brought in with a coma and shock, has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus but has never been to a hospital or taken any medications for it. There was no prior examination for complications related to diabetes.

O: Upon admission, vital signs included a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 3/15, blood pressure of 80/40 mm Hg, pulse rate of 130 bpm, and temperature of 37.3°C. Laboratory analyses revealed neutropenia with a neutrophil count of 640/µL, elevated C-reactive protein level of 12.73 mg/dL, blood glucose level of 237 mg/dL, and hemoglobin A1c level of 12.1%. Blood and urine cultures identified Escherichia coli, and a CT scan showed diffuse gas collection in the urinary bladder wall indicative of infection.

A: The patient was diagnosed with uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus and an Escherichia coli infection with gas-forming bacteria. The infection led to circulatory failure.

P: Initiated treatment with meropenem hydrate (a broad-spectrum antibiotic) and vasopressor therapy. The patient was also placed on a respirator and catheterized for management. Despite treatment efforts, the patient succumbed to circulatory failure caused by the infection.

S: The patient has a history of tobacco smoking and was diagnosed with non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), stage T1bN3M0 stage IIIB, a year ago. They were thought to be in remission after undergoing radiation and immunotherapy with pembrolizumab. Recently, the patient experienced progressively worsening abdominal pain and constipation.

O: A colonoscopy revealed a large rectosigmoid mass resulting in near total rectal occlusion. Laboratory findings showed an elevated carcinoembryonic antigen of 4.2 ng/dL. CT scan indicated a severe colonic stool burden, a soft tissue left upper lobe lung mass, and a single large mass in the rectosigmoid colon. During surgery, bowel-to-bowel and bowel-to-anterior abdominal wall adhesions were observed, and the rectal mass appeared to invade the small bowel. A colostomy, ileocecectomy, and anastomosis, as well as a resection of the rectosigmoid mass, were performed. Postoperative biopsies confirmed positivity for high-grade NSCLC and favored metastatic poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of lung origin. Hematoxylin and eosin staining showed extensive necrosis and focal mucosal involvement in the rectosigmoid mass, with negativity for regional lymph node carcinoma.

A: The diagnostic impression is of metastatic poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma originating from the lung, involving the rectosigmoid region.

P: The plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and discussion of further treatment options based on upcoming immunohistochemical testing results (CK7, TTF-1, Napsin-A, and EpCAM). Follow-up with the oncologist is advised, along with continued reporting of any new or worsening symptoms.

S: The patient's 5-year-old male Jack Russell Terrier is showing sudden weakness and reluctance to move, which is unusual given his normally active nature. The dog is primarily an indoor pet, up-to-date on vaccinations, and does not have a history of traveling abroad. However, he goes on forest hikes in Belgium where ticks are occasionally found on him.

O: The dog's hematology examination and biochemistry profile were unremarkable. Serology for toxoplasmosis was negative, but Lyme serology was positive with a titer of 1:1024.

A: The dog has been diagnosed with Lyme disease, caused by the bacteria transmitted through tick bites.

P: The recommended treatment is a course of doxycycline at 5 mg/kg, given orally twice a day for 30 days. Improvement is expected within three days, with symptoms like weakness, muscular and articular pain, and fever subsiding. The patient is advised to monitor the symptoms and contact the clinic if there are concerns or if symptoms do not improve.

S: The patient has been experiencing symptoms for the past 5 days, including frequent vomiting, moderate to severe headache, and giddiness. There was a development of right-sided body weakness and altered sensorium in the last 24 hours before presenting to the emergency department. The patient also had one episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizures before the onset of weakness. There is no history of major illness, drug treatments, or addictions.

O: The patient is afebrile with a pulse of 86/minute and blood pressure of 126/74 mmHg. Neurological examination shows the patient is drowsy and poorly responsive to verbal commands. There is hypertonia and grade III power in the right upper and lower limbs. Deep tendon reflexes are mildly exaggerated, and Babinski sign is positive on the right side. Other systemic examinations, including chest, abdomen, and cardiovascular, are unremarkable. Blood tests reveal macrocytic anemia with hemoglobin of 11.4 g/dl and MCV of 110 fl, macrocytes, macro-ovalocytes, and hypersegmented neutrophils in the peripheral blood film. Serum cobalamin is low at 68 pg/ml, folate levels are normal, and anti-intrinsic factor antibodies are negative. Stomach biopsy shows no gastric atrophy. CSF examination is normal. The immunologic profile is negative, and thrombophilic workup shows normal prothrombin time, activated partial thromboplastin time, protein C, protein S, and antithrombin III levels.

A: The clinical presentation and test results suggest neurological issues potentially related to low cobalamin levels with a possible connection to the episode of seizures and right-sided weakness.

P: Further investigations are recommended to determine the exact cause of symptoms and plan an appropriate treatment strategy. Ongoing monitoring of the patient's condition is advised, and any changes in symptoms should be reported immediately.

S: The patient reported noticing a firm palpable mass close to the supernumerary nipple on the right side within the past few months. No other symptoms were reported.

O: The objective findings included a small mass associated with the supernumerary nipple on the right side. The mammogram and ultrasound showed normal breast tissue, but a hypoechoic, well-defined area was identified measuring about 10 mm. Clinical examination revealed inversion of the supernumerary nipple and a palpable firm mass. A biopsy described elongated epithelial islands with a dense fibrous stroma and indicated the possibility of SyT, categorized as a B3-lesion. Post-resection, the tumor macroscopically measured 7 x 5 x 5 mm and microscopically 13 mm in diameter, composed of solid trabecular and glandular formations, cuboidal cells, and foreign body giant cells.

A: The assessment suggests a B3-lesion with uncertain malignant potential based on the biopsy and pathology report. The differential diagnosis included SyT (Syringomatous tumor).

P: The patient underwent resection of the mass with a 5 mm rim of normal tissue, following a Multidisciplinary Team Conference decision. For follow-up, the patient is advised to have regular check-ups to monitor the condition closely.

S: The patient is a 54-year-old Caucasian male, lead singer of a local rock band, with no prior psychiatric history or hospitalizations. He has used cocaine for about 20 years, mainly before performances. After a cocaine binge, he developed a severe headache and lower extremity numbness. He has since experienced depressive and anxiety symptoms, significant crying spells, sleeping difficulties, and ruminative worries about his health. He denies feeling depressed or having suicidal thoughts but experiences uncontrollable crying spells and a flat affect. 

O: The patient had an MRI showing two small foci of increased signal intensity in the subcortical white matter of the left frontal lobe and bilateral foci of infarct in the right side of the pons, consistent with an embolic phenomenon. He was diagnosed with an adjustment disorder after a stroke. He is objectively tearful with a flat affect.

A: The differential includes depression and anxiety possibly stemming from adjustment disorder post-stroke, with prominent crying spells and ruminative worries despite denial of subjective depression.

P: The plan includes developing a comprehensive treatment plan in coordination with the primary care physician to address depression and anxiety, monitoring progress, and making necessary adjustments to the treatment. Continued support and follow-up with mental health services are advised.

S: The patient reports experiencing daily vertigo worsened by sudden head movements, accompanied by nausea and vomiting, and difficulties with balance in confined spaces. The patient has no significant medical history except for having meningitis at 2 years old. There is no family history of vertigo, epilepsy, hearing loss, or familial cancer syndromes. The patient initially denied headaches. Three years later, the patient reports a persistent balance disorder with decreased lateral visual field vision for fast-approaching objects, such as tennis balls.

O: Initial examination revealed perceptive high tone loss in the right ear. An MRI focused on the cerebellum and cerebellopontine angle was normal. Follow-up neurological examination revealed new bilateral horizontal nystagmus on lateral gaze, subnormal tandem gait for age, difficulty standing with closed eyes, and a positive Dix-Hallpike test on the right side. Audiometric evaluation showed persistent perceptive high tone loss in the right ear. A subsequent MRI showed no pathology.

A: Initial diagnosis was probable benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). Persistent symptoms suggest potential ongoing BPPV.

P: Home exercises were recommended to alleviate symptoms. A follow-up MRI with thin slices and contrast showed no pathology. The patient is advised to continue home exercises and monitor symptoms, reporting any changes.

S: The patient reported feeling unwell after returning from a trip to Lagos, Nigeria. Symptoms began approximately six days after returning and included nausea, diarrhea, fevers, and sweats occurring multiple times a day. The patient also experienced two episodes of syncope the day before visiting the emergency room. There were no symptoms of headache, neck stiffness, sore throat, or respiratory issues. The patient used mosquito repellent with DEET, slept indoors, and consumed only bottled water but did not use a mosquito net. They recall taking a medication for malaria prevention though the name is not remembered. The patient had vaccinations for typhoid, yellow fever, hepatitis A, TDaP, influenza, and meningococcal diseases within the past year. There is no significant past medical history, and the patient is not currently on any medications.

O: Vital signs at presentation included a temperature of 100.8°F, pulse of 117 beats per minute and regular, blood pressure of 127/78, respirations at 18 per minute unlabored, and an O2 saturation of 98% on room air. Tests were conducted, but specific results were not provided in the conversation.

A: Differential diagnoses considered may include malaria or other travel-related infections given recent travel history, symptoms, and lack of specific malaria prophylaxis information.

P: The patient received a prescription for medications based on test results and was advised to follow set follow-up requirements. Specific tests, medications, and follow-up details were not provided in the conversation.

S: The patient reported swelling in the suprapubic area and difficulty passing urine for the past four months. Additionally, the patient experienced constipation for the last two months. There is no history of fever, vomiting, hematuria, or bleeding per rectum.

O: During the physical examination, the patient's pulse rate was 86/min and blood pressure was 110/76 mmHg. A smooth, firm, slightly tender, nonmobile lump was found in the suprapubic region, 5 cm above the pubic symphysis. A digital rectal examination revealed a smooth spherical mass outside the rectal wall, with a normal rectal mucosa. Blood test results were mostly within normal limits, with haemoglobin at 12.4 g/dl, total leucocyte count at 8900/mm3, and normal liver function tests. Urine examination showed pus cells (5-6/hpf) but a sterile culture. Ultrasound indicated a cystic mass in the pelvis, suggesting a hydatid cyst with bilateral hydroureteronephrosis. CT scan showed a capsulated mass compressing the urinary bladder and rectosigmoid, consistent with a hydatid cyst, along with moderate hydronephrosis on the right and mild on the left, and dilated ureters.

A: Likely diagnosis of a hydatid cyst in the pelvis causing compression symptoms and hydronephrosis.

P: Referral to a specialist for further management of the hydatid cyst and hydronephrosis. Monitor symptoms closely and report any changes or worsening.

S: The patient initially reported constipation. Following neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy, the patient experienced an inability to defecate for several days, indicating concern about bowel obstruction.

O: A colonoscopy revealed a circumferential tumor in the lower rectum, 60 mm from the anal verge, identified as a moderately differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma. CT results showed a 6.3-cm bulky rectal tumor and enlarged regional lymph nodes without distant metastasis. The cancer was staged cT3N1M0 stage IIIa. After neoadjuvant therapy, there was a clinical partial response with a noted obstruction in the lower rectum where fibrous tissue growth caused smooth stenosis. A self-expanding metallic stent was placed. Post-surgery, the operation lasted 265 minutes with minimal blood loss.

A: The patient is diagnosed with cT3N1M0 stage IIIa rectal cancer. After neoadjuvant therapy, the tumor showed partial response but resulted in obstruction due to fibrous tissue. Successful stent placement relieved symptoms, and surgical intervention was performed to remove the tumor.

P: The patient underwent neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy (45 Gy pelvic radiation with chemotherapy using irinotecan and S-1), followed by the placement of a self-expanding metallic stent to relieve bowel obstruction. Laparoscopic low anterior resection with diverting ileostomy was performed to remove the tumor. The patient is advised to continue regular follow-ups to monitor recovery and manage further treatment if necessary. The patient can be discharged three days post-stent placement and will be monitored further after surgery.

S: The patient reports a year-long history of progressive dysphagia, with recent onset of dysphonia and dyspnea. He also mentions pain in the right lower limb. 

O: Clinical examination revealed a large, firm, and tender mass in the oropharynx measuring 80 x 55 mm with no fluctuation and non-palpable cervical lymph nodes. A rescue tracheotomy was performed. MRI showed a voluminous process in the posterior tongue (75 x 55 x 39 mm), infiltrating the uvula and tonsils, but no cervical lymph nodes were associated. A biopsy revealed tumoral proliferation with plasmacytic differentiation, positive for CD138 and monoclonal Lambda chains expression. Whole-body MRI detected a lesional process in the right femur (61 x 47 x 47 mm) with cortical destruction, but no spinal abnormalities. Lab tests showed a normocytic anemia of 7.5 g/dl, elevated sedimentation rate, normal calcemia and renal function, no monoclonal peak in serum electrophoresis, lambda chains presence, and slightly elevated Beta2 microglobulin.

A: The diagnostic assessment indicates a complex condition involving tumor presence in the tongue and right femur, with suspected plasmacytic differentiation and potential systemic involvement.

P: The plan involves developing a comprehensive treatment plan that may include surgery, radiation, and/or chemotherapy. Close monitoring and collaboration with a team of specialists will be essential, with regular updates provided to the patient and family.

S: The 3-day-old male Boxer puppy is very active and continuously suckling but has not gained any weight. The owner observed nasal discharge after the puppy suckles.

O: The puppy is in good general condition and lively. Examination revealed a midline defect in the hard palate and a caudally divergent defect in the soft palate, diagnosed as a cleft palate. The cleft palate is moderately wide but without asymmetrical facial growth. LAHSAL classification is "- - H S H - -". No other congenital diseases were detected, and there are no signs of pneumonia. The puppy has a good appetite and suckled milk replacer immediately.

A: Cleft palate (- - H S H - -) with potential feeding difficulties and associated nasal discharge and occasional sneezing due to the cleft.

P: The puppy will be raised at the Clinic for Obstetrics, Gynecology and Andrology of Large and Small Animals with Ambulatory Service of the Justus-Liebig University in Germany. The plan includes monitoring the puppy's progress, ensuring he gains weight, and keeping the owner updated on his health and development.

S: The patient reported pain, redness, and hyperemia in the right eye following exposure to cigarette ash. Initial symptoms did not improve significantly after two weeks of outpatient treatment, leading to hospitalization. Post-surgery, the patient experienced persistent pain related to infection complications.

O: Initial testing included a corneal scraping with negative results on Gram staining, KOH preparation, and cultures. The examination revealed a grayish-white ulcer in the central bitamporal cornea, inflammatory infiltrates with feathered margins, hypopyon, and stromal opacity. Post-surgery, there was exudation in the anterior chamber. Mycelial growth was observed on PDA post-enucleation, and ITS rRNA gene sequencing identified P. insidiosum.

A: The diagnostic impression was a fungal infection in the right eye leading to complications unresponsive to initial treatments, confirmed to be P. insidiosum by gene sequencing analysis.

P: The treatment plan involved initial antifungal and antibacterial therapy, followed by penetrating keratoplasty. Due to persistent issues, an intracameral fluconazole injection was administered, and eventually, enucleation was performed to mitigate infection and relieve pain. Follow-up care recommendations were provided for continued management.

S: The patient reports feeling weak and disoriented following a drowning incident at sea, which led to their admission to the emergency department.

O: Upon arrival, the patient was hemodynamically unstable with a blood pressure of 100/55 mmHg, a heart rate of 135 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute. The patient was afebrile with a temperature of 36.7°C. Initial lab investigations revealed a hematocrit of 23% and hemoglobin of 7.3 g/dL. The patient underwent fluid resuscitation and received 2 units of blood transfusion, yet continued to be unstable with Hct dropping to 19% and Hgb to 6.4 g/dL. An abdominal ultrasound showed free intra-abdominal fluid, while a chest X-ray was negative.

A: The patient experienced intra-abdominal bleeding likely from vessels originating from the lesser curvature of the stomach, confirmed and treated during an exploratory laparotomy.

P: The patient was stabilized with an exploratory laparotomy where the bleeding vessels were ligated. The recovery was uneventful, and the patient was discharged on the 12th postoperative day with full recovery and no limitations reported eight years post-procedure. Follow-up care includes monitoring symptoms and reaching out for any future concerns.

S: The patient reports experiencing lethargy, extreme exhaustion, and fainting, following mild flu-like symptoms, low-grade fever, and multiple episodes of nonbilious vomiting for the past 3 days. The patient denies any recent medication changes or contact with toxic substances. The patient has high-functioning autism and a history of taking methylphenidate and sertraline. There is no history of suicide attempts or ideation.

O: On arrival, vital signs were temperature 98.2°F, blood pressure 140/71 mm Hg, heart rate 136 beats per minute, respiratory rate 38/min, and oxygen saturation 96% on ambient air. Physical examination revealed a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 10/15, suggestive of mental state impairment. Dehydration signs were noted, including dry mucous membranes and cold skin with decreased turgor. The patient's breathing was deep and labored, but chest was clear to auscultation. Gastrointestinal and cardiovascular examinations were unremarkable.

A: The patient’s symptoms and examination findings are indicative of dehydration, possibly secondary to vomiting and decreased intake related to recent flu-like illness.

P: Recommended treatments include monitoring vitals closely, ensuring hydration and rest. There was emphasis on the importance of staying hydrated. Further observation and support will be provided as needed. The patient was advised to communicate any worsening of symptoms.

S: The patient is a 38-year-old nulliparous woman who presented with right lower abdominal pain. She reports significant pain in the lower right side of her abdomen. 

O: Biochemistry tests show no significant changes. The pregnancy test was negative, C-reactive protein was normal, and there were no signs of infection. An abdominal ultrasound revealed a non-echogenic cyst in the right flank. A CT scan confirmed a right lower abdominal cystic formation with a diameter of approximately 38 by 33 millimeters and a density of 24 Hounsfield units. The cyst is closely approximated with the colon ascendens and the psoas muscle, with discrete infiltration of the perilesional fat tissue. Gynecological examination showed a normal cervix, a mobile uterus with normal adnexa, a vaginal ultrasound showed an intrauterine device in the uterine cavity, a normal left ovary, but the right adnex could not be visualized. Laparoscopy found a normal appendix, a deep-seated cecum, a unicornuate uterus, and a normal left fallopian tube and ovary. The right fallopian tube and ovary were located infrahepatically, positioned upon the psoas muscle and crossed by the right ureter. A firm spherical formation over the course of the left round ligament was noted, likely a rudimentary part of the unicornuate uterus.

A: The possible diagnoses considered include enteric duplication cyst, mesenterial cyst, peritoneal inclusion cyst, and appendiceal mucocele. The abnormal position of the right adnexa, along with the cyst, may be contributing to the abdominal pain.

P: The patient was hospitalized for further observation and underwent an explorative laparoscopy. Potential treatment options will be discussed with the patient to address the cyst and the abnormal positioning of the right adnexa. Further management plans will be based on ongoing evaluation and consultation.

S: The patient reports feeling down, having trouble sleeping, a lack of energy, and experiencing stress after a colleague's hurtful comments. They have anxiety, depressed mood, anger, loss of drive, anhedonia, and insomnia. The patient has a family history of depression, is a smoker, and has hypertension and neurodermatitis, for which they take diclofenac 75 mg daily. They experienced persistent left-thoracic chest pain about 2 hours prior, unrelated to breathing, along with hyperventilation and symmetric leg tingling and heaviness, which subsided 30 minutes before visiting the doctor. No past episodes of dyspnea or disturbances of consciousness were reported.

O: Physical examination and initial ECG were unremarkable. Troponin T level was significantly elevated at 243 ng/ml. The patient was transferred to cardiology, where ECG showed sinus rhythm, heart rate of 84/min, normal cardiac axis, and normal transition between R and S waves with no repolarization disorders. Emergency cardiac catheterization showed severely reduced left ventricular function with typical apical ballooning. Coronary heart disease was ruled out. Elevated NT-pro-BNP level at 307.0 pg/ml.

A: The patient may have major depressive disorder and is diagnosed with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, a temporary heart condition often triggered by stress, with reduced left ventricular function.

P: The patient's condition will be closely monitored, with potential adjustments to medications as needed. It's crucial for the patient to follow up with the healthcare team and report any new or worsening symptoms. Stress management and addressing mental health concerns are recommended to help prevent future episodes.

S: 
The patient reports hematemesis occurring for the past 7 days, preceded by three episodes of non-bloody emesis. Over the past year, the patient has experienced recurrent epigastric pain, daily post-prandial vomiting one to two times shortly after eating, and significant weight loss. The patient’s medical history includes a laparoscopic cholecystectomy five years ago, an ischemic brain stroke two years ago, and paraplegia due to a lumbar herniated disc approximately a year ago. There is no family history of gastrointestinal disorders.

O: 
The physical examination findings include the patient being cachectic and extremely weak with a blood pressure of 90/40 mmHg, heart rate of 110 beats/min, respiratory rate of 22/min, and an oral temperature of 36.8°C. The examination revealed no icterus in the sclera, lymphadenopathy, abdominal tenderness, or palpable mass. An esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) showed a linear clean base ulcer in the lower third of the esophagus (Mallory Weiss syndrome) and a submucosal lesion in the duodenum. An endoscopic ultrasonography showed an anechoic lesion measuring 45x55 mm, likely located near the right kidney. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis revealed multiple cortical cysts in both kidneys, with one cyst measuring 45x55 mm pressing on the duodenum.

A: 
The diagnostic impression is Mallory Weiss syndrome, likely from repeated vomiting. Additionally, the presence of multiple cortical kidney cysts, with one pressing against the duodenum, has been identified.

P: 
The plan includes conservative treatment with close monitoring of the patient’s condition. Initial treatment involved the administration of crystalloid fluids and intravenous pantoprazole. Adjustments to the treatment plan will be made as necessary based on ongoing evaluations.

S: The patient reports intractable pruritus, scaling, dry skin, and generalized eczematous lesions resistant to typical atopic dermatitis therapy. The patient has experienced itchy skin with red patches for a considerable time. Born at 37 weeks of gestation, the patient had desquamative skin lesions shortly after birth, which resolved after seven months, followed by pruritic, erythematous lesions. The patient has allergies to eggs and cow's milk but reports no family history of skin disorders. The patient’s scalp hair is dry and short, with sparse eyebrows and eyelashes.

O: The patient was found to have dry skin with erythematous scaly patches on the abdomen, face, and extremities. Height and weight are normal. Biochemical tests, serum folate, iron, vitamin B12, and zinc levels are normal. Urinary amino acid analysis, immunoglobulins, complements, and lymphocyte subset counts are normal. Antibody tests were negative, as were thyroid hormone levels and thyroid autoantibodies. Serum IgE levels were elevated at 530 IU/ml, and serum eosinophilia was present.

A: The patient's condition is not typical of atopic dermatitis and may be indicative of a more complex condition, such as erythroderma or Ichthyosis linearis circumflexa, combined with elevated IgE levels and atopic reactions.

P: The plan is to explore other treatment options and consult with a specialist to better understand the condition and determine the most appropriate course of action. The patient should continue to avoid allergens like eggs and cow's milk and maintain the current skincare routine. Further steps will be discussed in subsequent consultations.

S: The patient reports experiencing left-sided mastodynia and has a history of excisional biopsy for a fibroadenoma in the left breast.

O: An MRI showed no findings to explain the patient's complaints but revealed a 7 mm enhancing stellate lesion in the right breast at 9 o'clock, with a homogeneously low signal on T1-weighted images and rapid early enhancement with plateau kinetics on dynamic contrast imaging. No diffusion restriction was noted. Mammography identified a focal asymmetric density with spiculated margins in the superolateral quadrant of the right breast, without associated microcalcifications. A second-look ultrasound displayed a 4 mm oval hypoechoic mass with partially obscured borders. The biopsy histologically showed an infiltrative stromal process suggesting a desmoid tumor, but no nuclear atypia or mitosis was observed.

A: Discrepancy between suspicious morphological findings and dynamic characteristics resulted in a further evaluation that revealed a BI-RADS 4b lesion, suspected to be a desmoid tumor confirmed by biopsy as fibromatosis.

P: Recommended wide excision to remove the tumor, which confirmed the diagnosis of fibromatosis. Further questions or concerns from the patient are encouraged for discussion.

S: The patient is a 26-year-old primigravida woman who was admitted due to labor complications during the second stage, with a suspected intrauterine infection. She underwent an emergency caesarean section due to these complications and experienced severe postpartum hemorrhage. The patient reported severe dyspnea after receiving a blood transfusion. She also found the caesarean section experience to be traumatic and sought psychological help.

O: The patient experienced a blood loss of 2 liters and was treated with sulprostone, intravenous fluids, and a blood transfusion. Chest X-rays showed congestion, and echocardiography indicated severe left ventricular dysfunction with an ejection fraction of 15% and moderate basal septal wall motility. There was no ischaemia or coagulopathy. Follow-up echocardiography showed normalization of left ventricular function.

A: The initial suspicion of peripartum cardiomyopathy (PPCM) was reconsidered, concluding that the patient likely suffered from takotsubo cardiomyopathy due to the nature of the delivery and rapid recovery of cardiac function. The absence of ischaemia and specific echocardiography findings supported this diagnosis.

P: The patient was treated with conventional heart failure medications and quickly extubated following therapy initiation. She underwent cardiac follow-ups and her left ventricular function remains normal. Future pregnancies were deemed safe, and she has since had several uncomplicated pregnancies with no cardiac issues. Psychological counseling was also part of her management to address trauma.

S: The patient reports a slow-growing, ulcerated skin mass on the front, inner part of the left lower leg for about 2 years. The mass is tender, moves slightly, measures approximately 5 by 6 centimeters, and is associated with skin surface ulceration, purulent drainage, and a foul odor. The patient has no significant past medical history and had previously consulted traditional healers with no improvement.

O: Blood test results indicate normal white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet levels. A biopsy of the lesion showed infiltration by intermediate to large-sized immature cells with irregular nuclei in the dermis and subcutis, sparing the epidermis. Initial immunostains showed positivity for CD45, terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (mostly), and PAX5 (weak, small subset), and negativity for CD3, CD20, myeloperoxidase, and lysozyme. Additional studies revealed positivity for CD2, CD33, CD4 (weak), CD56, CD123, and TCL1.

A: The diagnostic impression suggests an abnormal cell proliferation in the skin lesion. The immunophenotype is inconclusive, requiring further analysis to determine the precise nature of the lesion.

P: The plan is to closely monitor the lesion and discuss further to determine the best course of treatment, including any additional tests or therapies recommended by the healthcare team. Follow-up appointments will be necessary to evaluate the progress and make further decisions.

S: The patient is a 4-year-old girl born at 33 weeks with esophageal atresia (EA) and a distal tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF). She underwent early surgery to repair the EA and has since experienced complications, including anastomotic stricture and an additional fistula. The patient has undergone over 20 esophageal dilatations, five esophageal stent placements, and a tracheostomy. A year after a gastric pull-up procedure, she experienced dysphagia with solid food. 

O: An initial bronchoscopic and esophagoscopic examination revealed a large tracheoesophageal fistula, likely iatrogenic. On follow-up, endoscopy showed a mucosal bridge at the gastroesophageal anastomosis, which was divided successfully using a 6 mm flexible endoscope and a 5 mm stapler, with no intra- or postoperative complications.

A: The patient’s dysphagia appears to be resolved following the mucosal bridge division. No current symptoms or medication usage, including antacid use. 

P: Continue to monitor the patient’s progress to ensure no further complications arise. The patient is advised to contact the clinic if any issues or concerns develop. No current medication or further treatment is necessary.

S: The patient has been admitted for surgical treatment of a mediastinal tumor detected on a chest roentgenogram. The patient reports no specific symptoms related to the tumor. The procedure planned involves Video-Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery (VATS) and potential switch to Transcervical Mediastinal Approach (TMA).

O: Chest CT showed a mediastinal tumor in the right thoracic outlet, adjacent to the right subclavian vein and right brachiocephalic artery. A preoperative diagnosis is unavailable, but the tumor is suspected to be a benign neurinoma with potential malignancy.

A: The intraoperative diagnosis is expected to be a benign neurogenic tumor. Postoperative final diagnosis is anticipated to be schwannoma.

P: The patient will be placed in a left semi-lateral decubitus position for surgery. If VATS is insufficient due to tumor location and visualization issues, conversion to TMA for complete resection is planned. Postoperatively, the patient is expected to be discharged 6 days after surgery. Monitoring for transient Horner syndrome is indicated, which should resolve naturally. Full recovery anticipated within three months, with no functional restrictions. Follow-up will include monitoring for full resolution of Horner syndrome and functional recovery of the right upper extremity.

S: The patient is a 55-year-old obese individual with a BMI of 42 kg/m², reporting persistent vomiting over several months. Past medical history includes hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, dyslipidemia, and arthritis. Surgical history includes an open appendectomy, incisional hernia treated with intraperitoneal mesh, right colectomy due to colic erosion and fistula, open sleeve gastrectomy with subsequent gastric leak, and multiple hernia repairs. The patient denies any history of tobacco or alcohol use.

O: The patient has multiple abdominal scars and a history of enormous incisional hernia recurrence. An upper digestive tract opacification showed a lacunar image on the lower esophagus. Endoscopy revealed a 5 cm pseudo-polyp located 30-35 cm from the dental arches. Upper endoscopic ultrasound described a 2 cm supra-cardial pediculate hypoechoic lesion without peritumoral lymph nodes. Biopsy confirmed a well-differentiated intra-epithelial adenocarcinoma in Barrett's esophagus, classified as pT1 with negative HER2 expression.

A: The patient presents with a well-differentiated intra-epithelial adenocarcinoma arising in Barrett's esophagus, classified as pT1. Post-surgical findings indicate successful intervention with safe margins, lacking lymphatic embolus or perineural invasion, and negative HER2 expression.

P: The plan involves monitoring the patient’s condition and continuing follow-up care. Endoscopic mucosectomy was performed; further treatment will be guided by ongoing assessments. The patient is advised to report any new or worsening symptoms or concerns.

S: The patient reported worsening abdominal pain and distention over the past 4 days. They have no past medical or surgical history.

O: Vital signs were within normal limits. The physical examination revealed generalized abdominal tenderness and guarding. Lab tests showed an elevated white blood cell count of 24,900/mm3. An abdominal x-ray indicated multiple air-fluid levels, and a CT scan revealed a small amount of free fluid in the abdomen and dilated small bowel loops with evidence of ischemia. During surgery, a severe ischemic distal ileal segment was discovered with approximately 20 cm of the distal ileum herniated and twisted along its mesentery.

A: Small intestinal obstruction with ischemic distal ileal segment.

P: The patient was taken to the operating room where an ileocecectomy with a side to side primary anastomosis using a 75 GIA stapler was performed. The patient should be discharged from the hospital on the 8th postoperative day. They are advised to follow up for any concerns or complications and will be provided with further instructions for recovery.

S: The patient is a 35-year-old female who reported worsening abdominal pain following an extreme conditioning competition two days prior. She has been active in extreme conditioning programs for five years, training four or five times a week, with no prior disease history. Despite taking Tenoxicam as prescribed by a physician, her pain and muscle swelling did not improve, leading to her visit to the emergency room.

O: Initial serum CK was 43,322 U/L as reported by the patient. Upon further testing in the ER, CK concentration increased to 77,590 U/L. Kidney function tests showed normal blood urea, creatinine, sodium, and potassium levels. However, liver enzymes were elevated with an AST of 477 U/L and ALT of 74 U/L. Follow-up CK levels were 3034 U/L on the 10th day and 1257 U/L on the 25th day after the competition.

A: The patient is diagnosed with rhabdomyolysis based on elevated CK levels and liver enzymes.

P: The patient is treated with aggressive intravenous fluid resuscitation. She will be hospitalized for four days and advised to avoid intense exercise. Regular monitoring of serum CK levels is recommended, with specific attention to any recurrence of symptoms. Follow-up CK levels were monitored, showing a decline over time. The patient and family are advised to contact healthcare providers if symptoms worsen or for any concerns.

S: The patient's parent reported a lump on the 2-month-old daughter's left thigh, which has been growing progressively since birth. The lump was first described on a prenatal ultrasound at 30 weeks of gestation. The child was delivered by cesarean section due to fetal distress but was otherwise normal at birth. No other abnormalities have been noticed by the parents.

O: Clinical examination revealed a 25/10 mm firm, mobile nodule on the antero-internal side of the left thigh, with normal overlying skin and no other lesions. X-ray and ultrasound showed a pre-femoral soft tissue mass measuring approximately 30/13 mm with a nonhomogeneous structure, hypoechoic areas, calcifications, and a weak Doppler signal—normal abdominal ultrasound. MRI displayed a mass of 19.33/15.19/34 mm with nonspecific vascular involvement, low signal in T1-weighted images, and high signal intensity in T2-weighted fat-saturated images.

A: The impression is a schwannoma of the left saphenous nerve, with the lesion located on the antero-internal part of the left thigh, exerting a mass effect on the left vastus intermedius muscle.

P: Elective surgery is planned to remove the mass. An italic S-shaped incision will be made on the antero-internal face of the left thigh, extended distally for about 6 cm. The mass measures approximately 4 cm × 1.5 cm × 1.5 cm. The surgery aims for the successful removal of the mass with recovery expected. Parents are advised to prepare for the procedure.

S: The patient reported experiencing hip pain following a recent fall. They have a medical history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus type 2, and obesity. During the follow-up, the patient noted significant impairment in walking and rising from a chair without support.

O: Initial examination showed proximal muscle weakness greater in the lower extremities, with no skin rashes, lymphadenopathy, joint inflammation, or pedal edema. EKG showed normal sinus rhythm with no ST-T changes. Blood work revealed elevated CPK (9767), CKMB (101.50), and aldolase (60) levels, and LFT derangement (AST-302 and ALT-404). Negative for ANA, anti-Jo antibody, and antimitochondrial antibody. Thyroid function tests were normal. One month later, physical exam showed decreased motor strength (2/5 in proximal upper extremities and 3/5 in proximal lower extremities) and persistent elevated muscle enzyme levels. Anti-HMGCR antibody test was positive (value of 34). Muscle biopsy confirmed necrotizing myopathy.

A: The final diagnosis is statin-induced necrotizing autoimmune myopathy, consistent with necrotizing autoimmune myositis.

P: Discontinue atorvastatin. Start Prednisone therapy at 1 mg/kg per day and taper over the next three months to improve proximal strength and mobility, and normalize muscle enzymes and liver function. Follow-up to monitor progress.

S: The patient is a 19-year-old multigravid female at 16 weeks gestation, presenting for a routine antenatal ultrasound. She reported normal fetal movements without experiencing vaginal discharge or hyperemesis gravidarum. She has no chronic diseases, history of abortion, or miscarriage, and received Anti-D following the delivery of her first child. Her last menstrual date is unknown. There is no family history of twins.

O: The ultrasound identified conjoined twins (dicephalic thoraco-omphalopagus) with a single functional heart and two aortic arches. The abdomen appears slightly large for the gestational age. The patient’s height is 165 cm and weight is 63 kg. She is neither anemic nor hypertensive.

A: Diagnosis of dicephalic thoraco-omphalopagus conjoined twins with a single heart was made. Blood incompatibility between the patient (A–) and her spouse (A+) was noted.

P: The patient has opted for pregnancy termination after discussing the potential complications and outcomes with the healthcare provider. She is advised to schedule an appointment for the termination procedure and is encouraged to reach out with any questions or concerns. Further evaluation and investigation may be necessary if the pregnancy were to be continued.

S: The patient is a 78-year-old Japanese woman with a medical history of uterine prolapse for 10 years, gravida 10, para 2, and 8 abortions. She reports bleeding from an ulcerated lesion on the surface of her prolapsed uterus for the past month. She has arrhythmia, specifically paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation.

O: The patient's uterine prolapse is stage IV with complete eversion of the posterior vaginal fornix and an ulcerated lesion approximately 3 cm in diameter with deep-seated induration. A biopsy revealed keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma. MRI showed a mass with a depth of 1.6 cm, located 3 cm from the cervical os, with no endometrial cavity involvement or adjacent tissue invasion. PET/CT indicated no metastases.

A: The patient has stage I vaginal cancer based on the FIGO staging system. Due to the tumor's location on the completely prolapsed uterus, it will be treated as uterine cervical cancer. The patient's age and cardiac issues make her ineligible for surgery under general anesthesia and chemotherapy.

P: The plan is to proceed with radiation therapy (RT) alone. The treatment will include careful monitoring and management of side effects, particularly concerning radiation dermatitis due to the prolapsed uterus. Regular follow-ups are advised to assess the effectiveness and safety of the treatment.

S: The patient is a 74-year-old woman with no relevant medical history, presenting with intermittent fever for over a month, an 18-kilogram weight loss over the past six months, and a dry cough. She has not traveled in the past year.

O: On admission, the patient's temperature was 37.3°C, heart rate 101 beats/min, respiratory rate 16 breaths/min, and blood pressure 142/54 mmHg. Pulmonary examination revealed the use of accessory muscles and bilaterally diffuse rales. Abdominal examination revealed a palpable spleen contour. Laboratory results showed a total leukocyte count of 19,900 cells per μL, platelet count of 133,000 per μL, alkaline phosphatase 481 U/L, serum total bilirubin 3.2 mg/dL, and lactate dehydrogenase 311 U/L, with normal serum transaminases, INR, and aPTT on initial presentation. Sputum, stool, and urine tests for acid-fast stain were negative. Chest X-ray revealed multiple tiny nodules over the bilateral lung field with alveolar infiltration over both upper lobes; CT scan indicated multiple tiny nodules, hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy in the omentum and mediastinum. On the 3rd day, the patient developed progressive orthopnea, paradoxical respiration, and SpO2 of 83%, requiring emergent intubation. Subsequent lab tests showed leukocytosis, left shift, INR > 10, aPTT > 100 seconds, and undetectable fibrinogen levels.

A: The clinical findings suggest pulmonary tuberculosis with miliary tuberculosis, and disseminated tuberculosis, including involvement of the lungs, liver, spleen, and lymph nodes.

P: The patient was transferred to the respiratory intensive care unit for resuscitation and is under treatment for tuberculosis. Continuous monitoring and treatment adjustments are in place. Further management will be based on the patient's progress and response to treatment. Follow-up and monitoring for complications are ongoing.

S: The patient sustained an electrical burn from a power line, resulting in injuries affecting 32% of the total body surface area with third-degree burns. The patient reports an open joint injury to the left knee, treated with three skin grafting procedures.

O: The left knee injury was initially managed with skin grafting, followed by the placement of a spatial external fixator (SEF) 24 days post-injury, which remained for 8.5 weeks. This was accompanied by two additional skin grafting procedures and a bony prominence resection. There were no significant complications recorded during the treatment.

A: The patient has an extensive burn injury with involvement of the left knee resulting in an open joint wound, treated with skin grafts and SEF. Successful surgical interventions were noted, but lack of PT/OT follow-up needs attention.

P: The patient is advised to schedule appointments with a physical therapist and an occupational therapist to assess recovery progress and develop an ongoing rehabilitation plan to restore function to the injured knee. No additional complications were noted, and follow-up for therapy is recommended to ensure proper recovery.

S: The patient reports feeling extremely tired for the past 10 days, with increased severity over the last 2 days. They experience shortness of breath following activities, a cough, a sore throat, and a low-grade fever. The patient also notices their face is pale. They had root canal therapy approximately 2 months ago and mentioned experiencing a similar issue around 15 years ago, for which they did not receive treatment.

O: During the physical examination, the patient's heart rate was recorded at 96 beats per minute, and their body temperature was normal at 36.7 °C. Laboratory tests showed a very low hemoglobin level of 36 g/L, mean corpuscular volume of 78.9 fL, and a red blood cell count of 1.42 × 10¹²/L, with a reticulocyte count of 2.52%. Their urine was brown, with urinalysis revealing a positive urobilinogen at 4+ and urine red blood cells at 3 cells/μL. Blood chemistry results showed an LDH level of 594 U/L, serum total bilirubin of 27.3 μmol/L, and serum indirect bilirubin of 20.45 μmol/L. Autoantibody examination revealed elevated levels of antinuclear antibodies (ANA) at 188.35 IU/ml, anti-dsDNA antibody at 186.42 IU/ml, AnuA at 27.01 IU/ml, with positive anti-SSA antibody, positive anticardiolipin antibodies IgG and IgM, and positive anti-β2-glycoprotein-I antibodies. The Coombs test was positive at 4+.

A: The patient is diagnosed with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) in line with the ACR criteria, with suspected autoimmune hemolytic anemia as part of the disease presentation.

P: The patient has started treatment with a red blood cell transfusion and is being administered dexamethasone, a hormone therapy, at a dose of 10 mg daily. Follow-up for ongoing treatment and symptom monitoring is advised, with instructions to contact the healthcare provider in case of concerns or questions.

S: The patient is an 85-year-old woman with a history of pseudoexfoliative glaucoma. She reports a decrease in vision in her right eye for about 4 months, with current vision recorded at 20/60 initially. She has been experiencing a central scotoma in her right eye that is bothersome.

O: The patient's initial best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) in the right eye was 20/60. An OCT identified a macular hole (MH) in the right eye, which spontaneously closed after a month, improving BCVA to 20/50. However, the patient's BCVA later decreased to 20/70 with complaints of a central scotoma. A subsequent OCT revealed reopening of the macular hole and intraretinal cystic spaces. After another month, the MH spontaneously closed again, with few cystic spaces and minimal subretinal fluid (SRF). The current BCVA is 20/125 in the right eye.

A: The patient has a recurrent macular hole with intraretinal cystic changes and a central scotoma affecting vision. The condition shows spontaneous resolution tendencies but with fluctuating visual acuity.

P: Surgical intervention with macular hole surgery (MHS) was discussed but declined by the patient. The decision was made to monitor the condition, observing for natural improvements. The plan is to continue monitoring visual acuity and retinal health with follow-up OCTs to ensure ongoing improvements.

S: The patient reported experiencing hoarseness and difficulty swallowing for a few weeks prior to initial diagnosis.

O: The CT scan revealed a 3.8 cm left thyroid tumor with involvement of the superior mediastinum and trachea. It was classified as stage pT4bN0M0.

A: The diagnostic impression was a large thyroid tumor with tracheal involvement. The plan was for surgical intervention followed by chemotherapy and radiotherapy to manage and treat the cancer.

P: The treatment plan included a total thyroidectomy and central neck dissection for complete tumor resection. Postsurgical chemotherapy consisted of docetaxel at 120 mg/m² and cisplatin at 30 mg/m². This was followed by a course of intensity modulated radiotherapy, delivering 70 Gy at 2.5 Gy per fraction. Follow-up with regular check-ups was emphasized to monitor the patient’s condition.

S: The patient is a 37-week pregnant woman admitted for delivery. She reports this is her sixth pregnancy, with two living children, three abortions, and one previous cesarean section. She prefers a conservative approach over hysterectomy in case of massive bleeding during the delivery.

O: The hemoglobin level is 10.8 g/dL, PT is 10.5 seconds, aPTT is 29 seconds, INR is 2.3, and platelet count is 385x10^9/L. Imaging revealed total placenta previa with myometrial invasion into the urinary bladder at the anterior wall of the uterus. During the delivery, a 5-6 cm tissue loss was noted at the anterior uterine wall, with bleeding from the cervix and posterior wall of the bladder. Approximately 2000 cc of blood was lost intraoperatively.

A: The patient has placenta previa with invasive myometrial involvement, leading to significant hemorrhage during delivery. The likely need for intervention due to bleeding is compounded by the complex surgical situation involving inadvertent vessel manipulation and artery ligation.

P: The treatment plan included pelvic packing and suturing for bleeding control, along with the use of a Sengstaken-Blakemore balloon catheter for uterine compression. Bilateral uterine and hypogastric artery ligations were performed successfully. Blood loss was managed with erythrocyte suspension (3 units preoperatively and 4 units postoperatively) and 3 packs of fresh frozen plasma. Further follow-up is required to monitor recovery and manage any remaining concerns from the delivery.

S: The patient reports progressive deterioration of renal function after starting immunotherapy with nivolumab for lung cancer. They were diagnosed in April 2016 with stage IIIa non-small cell lung cancer in the upper lobe of the right lung and initially treated with radiotherapy and six cycles of chemotherapy, including paclitaxel and carboplatin. In March 2017, a PET/CT scan showed malignant extension to the tracheobronchial and subcarinal lymph nodes. The patient has a significant smoking history of 35 years, smoking 20 cigarettes per day, but no other comorbidities. They take no regular medications apart from simple analgesics and report no drug or food allergies. Family history is unremarkable.

O: On physical examination, the patient had a normal body temperature of 36.7°C, blood pressure of 135/70 mmHg, and a pulse rate of 80 bpm. Before immunotherapy, renal function was normal with a serum creatinine of 79.56 μmol/L and an eGFR of 92.5 ml/min/1.73m2. After the 7th infusion of nivolumab, renal function was impaired with a serum creatinine of 176.8 μmol/L and an eGFR of 35.2 ml/min/1.73m2. After two additional cycles of nivolumab, serum creatinine doubled and eGFR declined to 14.8 ml/min/1.73m2.

A: The patient is experiencing a progressive deterioration of renal function likely associated with nivolumab immunotherapy, given the significant increase in serum creatinine and decrease in eGFR following treatment. 

P: The plan includes monitoring the patient's renal function closely and discussing potential treatment options. The patient will need to keep the medical team updated on any changes in health status. No new medications or nephrotoxic agents have been prescribed.

S: The patient has a history of acromegaly and underwent transsphenoidal pituitary resection three weeks prior. Post-surgery, the patient experienced a severe, intermittent, throbbing headache that worsened upon standing or coughing and improved with acetaminophen and lying down. The patient also reported clear nasal discharge since the removal of a nasal splint.

O: Initial examination showed normal vital signs and a normal neurological exam, with minimal clear nasal discharge observed. A CT scan revealed multiple air loculi in the basal cisterns, lateral, third, and fourth ventricles, without mass effect or midline shift. A follow-up CT scan showed mild increased diffuse pneumocephalus with intracranial air loculi, and an increased amount of air in the posterior fossa causing a mass effect on the pons. After surgical intervention, the patient's headache and nasal leakage resolved, and a subsequent CT scan confirmed the resolution of pneumocephalus.

A: The patient likely experienced a pneumocephalus post-pituitary surgery, causing the reported symptoms, confirmed by CT findings. The increase in intracranial air led to the decision for further surgical intervention.

P: Initial management included bed rest in the Fowler position at 30° and avoiding Valsalva maneuvers. Due to worsening symptoms and CT findings, the plan included a transsphenoidal endoscopic exploration, septoplasty, and packing of the sphenoid sinus with an abdominal fat graft, along with the insertion of a lumbar drain. After successful procedures, the lumbar drain was removed five days later, and the patient was discharged on day 10 of hospitalization. Follow-up confirmed the resolution of symptoms, and the patient was advised to monitor for any recurrence or new symptoms.

S: The patient reports having acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and experiencing a severe reaction to pentamidine treatments, which included severe abdominal pain, emesis, diarrhea, lightheadedness, and near-fainting. They initially developed a nonspecific rash without mucosal involvement from trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole, leading to initiation of IV pentamidine. The patient also experienced intense abdominal pain, hypotension, and poor perfusion during a platelet infusion, and now reports isolated urticarial flares with each pentamidine desensitization.

O: An abdominal X-ray showed non-obstructive gas patterns with small bowel wall thickening. An abdominal CT scan revealed colonic wall thickening and concern for ischemic colitis. MR enterography showed a nonocclusive thrombus involving the celiac trunk, proximal hepatic, and splenic arteries. Pathology from a partial colectomy (mid transverse colon to mid distal colon) showed patchy transmural ischemic colitis without local thrombosis or emboli. A paired two-tailed Wilcoxon test showed significant changes in platelet levels (P value <0.0001).

A: The patient has a confirmed pentamidine allergy and has experienced ischemic colitis likely secondary to nonocclusive thrombi and chemotherapy complications.

P: Continue with a pentamidine desensitization protocol and monitor for isolated urticarial flares. Monitor platelet levels closely due to significant changes noted. Instruct the patient to report any new or worsening symptoms promptly.

S: The patient reported a visual change in the left eye, describing vision as blurry and distorted. The patient has a history of choroidal melanoma in the left eye, confirmed through histopathology. In January 2016, surveillance imaging revealed hepatic lesions in the liver, which by August 2016 had increased in size and number. The patient expresses concern about the seriousness of the condition and seeks clarification on the findings and treatment plans.

O: The largest hepatic lesion measured 7.1 × 5.8 cm (M1b) in August 2016. Laboratory findings included an LDH level of 641 U/L and ALP level of 111 U/L. A liver biopsy confirmed metastatic uveal melanoma. Subsequent imaging in November 2016 showed a marked decrease in size and number of liver lesions. However, imaging in September 2018 displayed disease progression, leading to a treatment adjustment. As of March 2019, the patient is experiencing stable disease.

A: The patient was initially diagnosed with choroidal melanoma, which metastasized to the liver, confirmed as metastatic uveal melanoma (MUM). The patient responded to initial treatment but later experienced disease progression.

P: Treatment initially included nivolumab and ipilimumab therapy with TACE every 4 weeks starting in September 2016. Maintenance nivolumab was started in January 2017 until disease progression in September 2018. Treatment was then changed to nab-paclitaxel with continued TACE every 8 weeks. The current plan is to maintain therapy and monitor the patient's condition through regular check-ups and imaging to track disease stability and manage accordingly.

S: The patient reports experiencing a chronic right-sided headache and foul nasal discharge. The patient also mentions feeling a persistent nasal blockage. The medical history includes maxillary osteomyelitis in 2009, resulting in multiple interventions and a complex mediofacial resection, leaving a subtotal defect of the hard plate, maxillary sinus, and nasal septum. The patient is also managing depression and type two diabetes mellitus with peroral therapy.

O: A nasal endoscopy and CT revealed a large pathologic cavity caused by communication between the oral cavity, right maxillary sinus, and nasal cavity, with minor communication with the right orbit. Biopsy specimens exhibited severe but unspecific changes in the nasal epithelium, reserve cell hyperplasia, epithelial erosions, ulcers, squamous cell metaplasia with acanthosis and keratinization, and squamous cell nests in the submucosa without cellular atypia. The interstitium showed granulation tissue, fibrosis, and chronic inflammatory infiltrate with lymphocytes and plasma cells, but no active inflammation in adjacent bones.

A: A diagnosis of empty nose syndrome (ENS) was made, considering the extensive yet unspecific findings. The case does not fit the current ENS classification but is based on a comprehensive evaluation of clinical, endoscopic, radiologic, and histomorphologic data.

P: The patient will be monitored, and symptoms managed with follow-up appointments to adjust the treatment plan as needed.

S: The patient reported a history of an electrical burn injury involving 48% TBSA third-degree injuries, primarily affecting the right elbow with an open joint injury. The patient had multiple surgeries, including six skin grafts and SEF placement, and experienced complications such as heterotopic ossification, cubital tunnel syndrome, and elbow stiffness. The patient still feels some elbow stiffness but notes improvement.

O: The patient had an SEF placement with the Smith Nephew Richards system, which was kept for six weeks. They underwent an ulnar nerve transposition, heterotopic ossification removal, and contracture release with arthrofibrosis excision, followed by a flap surgery for soft tissue deficit. A 13-month follow-up showed a ROM of 20°–90° in extension and flexion, with 4-/5 motor strength. Prior to the elbow contracture release, the ROM was 0°–30° and included supination of 25° and pronation of 85°.

A: The patient has a history of electrical burn with severe elbow injury and complications including heterotopic ossification, cubital tunnel syndrome, and stiffness. Current condition shows improvement in elbow stiffness, but residual issues persist.

P: Continue physical therapy and regular follow-ups. Monitor for any changes or worsening symptoms and contact a doctor if they occur.

S: The patient reports experiencing nocturia. Concerns include discomfort related to this symptom.

O: Initial tests revealed elevated PSA levels at 76.2 ng/mL. Digital rectal examination showed prostate induration. Pelvic MRI demonstrated extensive high signal in the prostate on diffusion-weighted imaging. PET/CT revealed spine, pelvic bone, and lymph node metastases. Follow-up tests after 15 months of treatment showed PSA levels increased to 2.33 ng/mL, multiple osteoblastic lesions in the spine and pelvic bone, shrunken para-aortic lymph nodes, and viable tumor cells in the primary prostate lesion on imaging. Prostate needle biopsy showed cancer cells in 10 out of 12 cores.

A: The patient was initially diagnosed with metastatic prostate cancer (cT3aN1M1b). After treatment, the condition progressed to castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC). Discrepancies in test results suggest viable tumor cells in the primary lesion with non-viable cells in other lesions.

P: The patient was started on androgen deprivation therapy with a GnRH antagonist (degarelix) and an anti-androgen agent (bicalutamide). The patient has been referred to the hospital for further evaluation. Planned procedures include histopathological examinations of the prostate and vertebra, and a CT-guided needle biopsy from the osteoblastic lesion of the second lumbar vertebra.

S:  
The patient, a 70-year-old, reports experiencing frequent dizziness. She also mentions having trouble with memory and thinking, which could indicate mild cognitive impairment. Additionally, the patient reports feeling like her movements have slowed down recently.

O:  
The patient's mini-mental state examination (MMSE) score is 23, suggesting mild cognitive impairment. A neurological examination reveals mild bradykinesia. A brain CT scan shows calcified areas in the bilateral globus pallidus, caudate nuclei, pulvinar thalami, dentate nuclei, and subcortical and periventricular regions.

A:  
The patient's symptoms of dizziness, mild cognitive impairment, and mild bradykinesia are likely attributed to the calcifications observed in various regions of the brain.

P:  
There is no specific cure for the calcifications, but symptom management is recommended. Regular check-ups and close monitoring of the condition are advised. Medications and therapies to improve quality of life can be discussed. Follow-up at the next appointment is planned.

S: The patient reports experiencing dull, aching generalized abdominal pain for eight months, worsened after meals, accompanied by nausea and reduced appetite. Bowel movements have become softer but without melena or hematochezia. The pain occasionally wakes the patient from sleep. There is no noted weight loss. The patient has a history of hypertension and multiple past surgeries: laparoscopic cholecystectomy, laparoscopic appendectomy, umbilical hernia repair, and tubal ligation. The patient does not smoke or use alcohol. Family history includes breast cancer in the mother and prostate cancer in the father.

O: The patient’s BMI is 38. Physical examination was unremarkable. An upper gastrointestinal endoscopy revealed a nonobstructing, nonbleeding cratered ulcer in the posterior wall of the gastric body, with biopsy results showing moderate-poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. PET scan indicated increased uptake in the medial gastric fundus and near the cecum, with abnormal thickening and inflammatory changes in the cecum. Colonoscopy identified a fungating, partially obstructing mass in the cecum, with biopsy results showing moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma. Blood tests indicated anemia with a hemoglobin level of 9.3. CEA level was 0.819.

A: The patient has synchronous gastric and colon cancer based on endoscopic and imaging findings.

P: Plan for surgical resection of both cancers next week. Further management will be determined based on surgical findings and postoperative pathology results.

S: The patient, who is currently admitted, reported accidentally ingesting two Celphos tablets approximately 7 hours prior to arriving at the emergency department. On the second day of admission, the patient experienced shortness of breath and cola-colored urine.

O: Initial vital signs included blood pressure at 76/54 mmHg, pulse rate at 114/min, respiratory rate at 24/min, and oxygen saturation at 86% on ambient air, which improved after oxygen supplementation. Glasgow Coma Scale was 15/15. Arterial blood gas analysis showed lactic acidosis. Repeat testing on the second day showed decreased hemoglobin from baseline, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, serum lactate dehydrogenase at 1900 U/L, haptoglobin at 11 mg/dL, and negative direct Coomb's test. The peripheral blood film showed macrocytosis and anisopoikilocytosis, with no schistocytes. Reticulocyte production index was 2.9, and G6PD activity levels were normal. Urinalysis revealed the presence of hemosiderin but normal microscopy. Abdominal ultrasonography appeared normal.

A: The clinical assessment indicates hemolysis, likely related to the ingestion of Celphos with differential consideration for hemolytic anemia. Further investigation to rule out drug-related causes of hemolysis is ongoing.

P: The plan includes central venous pressure-guided intravenous fluids, ionotropes, magnesium sulfate injections, and observation in the intensive care unit. Continued monitoring of hemogram and biochemistry during the hospitalization is planned, coupled with avoidance of drugs that could exacerbate hemolysis.

S: The patient, with no past medical history, presented with sudden severe abdominal pain, weight loss, and painless jaundice. Symptoms included yellowing of the skin and eyes.

O: Physical examination showed scleral icterus. Lab tests indicated liver enzyme dysfunction with alanine transaminase at 144 U/L, aspartate aminotransferase at 122 U/L, and alkaline phosphatase at 331 IU/L. There was conjugated hyperbilirubinemia at 5.4 mg/dl and a marginal increase in total protein to 9 g/dl. Immunoglobulins assay showed increased IgG total at 15.1 g/dl and IgG-4 at 155 mg/dl. Tumor marker CA 19-9 was normal. Imaging showed lymph node enlargement near the celiac plexus, minimal calcification of the pancreatic head, and dilatation of the biliary tree. ERCP revealed a distal stricture in the CBD, relieved by stenting, and histopathology suggested primary sclerosing cholangitis. The EUS was unremarkable. The patient was found to have hypothyroidism with a Hashimoto profile due to increased anti-thyroid peroxidase antibodies.

A: Diagnosis of autoimmune pancreatitis was made based on clinical findings and exclusion of other differentials. Hypothyroidism with Hashimoto's thyroiditis was also diagnosed.

P: The patient was treated with steroid therapy for autoimmune pancreatitis, which showed improvement. Thyroxine treatment was initiated for hypothyroidism. Follow-up planned for four to six months to monitor progress and address any concerns.

S: The patient recently underwent a distal pancreatectomy and splenectomy for a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor. Post-surgery, the patient experienced a pancreatic fluid leak that was managed with an abdominal drain. After the drain was removed, a CT scan indicated an increased rim enhancing fluid collection. An ERCP confirmed a pancreatic duct leak from the tail of the pancreas, which was treated with endoscopic pancreatic sphincterotomy and pancreatic duct stent placement. An EUS revealed a hypoechoic, heterogeneous collection, leading to the placement of a LAMS and drainage of pus. Follow-up CT showed a decrease in the fluid collection size. The patient later experienced a neurological event.

O: Initial postoperative findings included a pancreatic fluid leak managed by an abdominal drain. CT scan showed an increased fluid collection post-drain removal. ERCP confirmed a duct leak. EUS findings included a 6.5 cm heterogeneous collection near the pancreas tail, leading to LAMS placement. Follow-up CT scan revealed a decrease in fluid collection size.

A: Post-surgical pancreatic fluid leak with complications including increased fluid collection and pancreatitis. Intervention with ERCP, sphincterotomy, and stent placement was necessary. Successful reduction of fluid collection post-LAMS drainage. Patient also experiencing complications due to a neurological event.

P: Continued monitoring of the fluid collection and pancreatic function. Regular follow-up imaging to assess resolution of the collection. Management of neurological symptoms and prevention of further complications. Maintain communication for any changes in condition or symptoms.

S: The patient reported experiencing low blood pressure, chest pain, and difficulty breathing for the past three days.

O: Initial tests included a Doppler sonography which revealed acute deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Subsequent echocardiography showed severe right ventricular dysfunction and enlargement, with a systolic pulmonary artery pressure (SPAP) of 70 mmHg. Post-treatment echocardiography indicated a decrease in SPAP to 20 mmHg.

A: The patient is diagnosed with acute deep vein thrombosis and severe right ventricular dysfunction with elevated SPAP.

P: The patient was treated with reteplase to break down blood clots and improve heart function. The treatment was effective with no observed complications. For follow-up care, the patient is advised to monitor symptoms and schedule an appointment in a few weeks for progress evaluation. Lifestyle changes and medications may be recommended to prevent future episodes of DVT.

S: The patient, with a history of poorly controlled diabetes, presented to the emergency room due to vomiting blood, disorientation, nausea, and epigastralgia lasting for 2 days.

O: The patient was in shock with concerning vital signs and did not respond well to rehydration. Laboratory findings showed blood glucose of 470 mg/dL, pH of 7.2, PCO2 of 25.2 mmHg, HCO3 of 9.9 mEq/L, PO2 of 169 mmHg, and an anion gap of 24.3 mEq/L. Urinary ketones and glucose were positive. Intubation and emergency endoscopy showed black pigmentation of the esophageal mucosa. A CT scan revealed circumferential edematous thickening of the esophageal wall, slight pleural effusion, no perforation, or free air in the mediastinum. On day 7, increased right pleural effusion and free air were observed on a CT scan, indicating esophageal perforation.

A: Diagnosed with diabetic ketoacidosis and acute esophageal necrosis (AEN). Suspected esophageal perforation on day 7 due to increased pleural effusion and mediastinal free air.

P: The patient was treated with antibiotics, glycemic control, proton pump inhibitor, and plasmapheresis, resulting in gradual stabilization and extubation on day 5, though the patient still had a fever and pleural effusion. On day 7, an emergency thoracoscopy was performed, discovering pleural effusion with pus and esophageal perforation. The necrotic thoracic esophagus was resected, and drainage tubes were placed. Continued monitoring and care are planned, with a focus on improving diabetes management to prevent future complications.

S: The owner reports that the 6-year-old huacaya alpaca mare has been experiencing respiratory symptoms for about 6 weeks, including forced breathing but no fever. The alpaca has been eating well but has lost a significant amount of weight. Previous treatments have been ineffective.

O: The alpaca exhibits poor overall condition, is alert but nervous, and weighs 53 kg, below the reference range of 55-90 kg. Her body condition score is 1 out of 5. Rectal temperature is 38.3 °C, heart rate is 72 beats per minute, both within normal ranges. Respiratory rate is 60 breaths per minute, above the normal range. Signs of dyspnea are present, with abdominally reinforced breathing and bilateral dilated nostrils but no cough or nasal discharge. Lung auscultation reveals ventrally scratching and crackling sounds, with absent respiration sounds in some areas on the left dorsal aspect. Test results show neutrophilia (9.37 × 10^9/l), low potassium (3.64 mmol/l), and low magnesium (0.71 mmol/l).
