A: The alpaca is presenting with dyspnea and weight loss, potentially due to an underlying respiratory condition, possibly an infection, as indicated by neutrophilia with a left shift. Electrolyte imbalances with low potassium and magnesium are also present.

P: Further investigations are necessary to determine the underlying cause of the respiratory symptoms and weight loss. A complete blood cell count and blood chemistry panel have been conducted. Monitoring of the alpaca's condition and dietary intake is recommended, with a follow-up to adjust the treatment plan based on ongoing assessments and additional test results if required.

S: The patient reports a history of progressive dyspnea, reduced physical activity, and periodic cardiac arrhythmia. During childhood, the patient experienced acroparesthesia, heat intolerance, and severe abdominal pain with gastrointestinal abnormalities like diarrhea and constipation. The patient was diagnosed with bronchial asthma during adolescence. Since the age of 20, the patient has been followed by a nephrologist for recurrent pyelonephritis, acute urinary tract infections, subnephrotic proteinuria (<1 g/L), and edema in the lower limbs, with a normal glomerulus filtration rate and unremarkable kidney ultrasound. At age 39, the patient noticed palpitations, dyspnea, reduced physical activity, low blood pressure, episodes of tinnitus, hearing impairments, and angiokeratoma in the umbilical region.

O: The patient's ECG showed a normal sinus rhythm, short PR interval, and signs of LV hypertrophy with secondary repolarization abnormalities. Echocardiography revealed asymmetric myocardial hypertrophy in the LV apex and lateral wall without LV outflow tract obstruction. Two-dimensional strain analysis showed a reduced global longitudinal strain (GLS−14%), especially reduced in the posterolateral wall (peak systolic strain−8%), while the diastolic function of the LV was normal. Cardiac MRI showed asymmetric myocardial hypertrophy most significant in the apex and lateral wall of the LV, with no fibrotic alterations. Brain MRI on T2/FLAIR revealed white matter hyperintensity lesions with no other abnormalities. Diagnostic workup revealed specific ophthalmological findings (cornea verticillata) and mild proteinuria without renal failure.

A: Clinical suspicion of Fabry disease based on the patient's symptoms, cardiac findings, and specific ophthalmological and renal findings.

P: Continue to monitor the patient's condition closely. Discuss treatment options based on the results of the diagnostic workup. Advise the patient to maintain a healthy lifestyle and ensure regular follow-up with healthcare providers.

S: The patient is a 53-year-old female with no previous medical history. She presents with right wrist pain and swelling following a fall, which resulted in a distal fracture of the right radius. There was blister formation on the right forearm due to the splint applied at a local hospital. She was referred for further treatment.

O: A plain X-ray examination shows a distal radius fracture with dorsal displacement of the distal bone fragment, classified as AO type A2.

A: The patient has a distal radius fracture with dorsal displacement (AO type A2) and skin blisters on the right forearm, likely from the splint applied post-injury.

P: Conservative treatment with an external splint or cast is deemed difficult due to skin condition. Planned treatment is minimally invasive surgery using locking plate osteosynthesis via the Henry approach. The surgical procedure is scheduled for 9 days post-injury and involves a 10 mm incision with the use of a volar locking plate. Postoperatively, the wrist will be immobilized in a bulky dressing without an arm splint until swelling decreases.

S: The patient has a history of arthritis and underwent a right total hip arthroplasty 9 years ago. They had a laparoscopic cholecystectomy for acute cholecystitis two months ago, which resulted in a surgical site infection with Escherichia coli bacteremia and subsequent complications including choledocholithiasis. The patient had an ERCP with stone pulverization and biliary stent placement. Recently, the patient was hospitalized with septic shock, experiencing fevers, chills, lethargy, altered mental status, and E. coli-positive blood and urine cultures. The patient reports right hip pain and inability to move the hip or leg.

O: On admission, the patient was febrile with a temperature of 102.7 F. Physical examination revealed a well-healed right lateral hip incision with no erythema or drainage, but pain was noted with right hip flexion and internal rotation. A CT scan of the right hip showed two partly calcified soft tissue masses. A fine needle biopsy aspirated 100 mL of pus with high nucleated cell count and E. coli growth. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis identified a 3 cm hepatic abscess and an MRI of the right hip showed a large air- and fluid-filled collection. Laboratory studies including WBC, hemoglobin, hematocrit, basic metabolic profile, and liver function tests were within normal limits.

A: The patient presents with an iliopsoas abscess and a periprosthetic infection of the right hip, possibly related to the previous hip arthroplasty, as well as a hepatic abscess.

P: The plan includes continued monitoring of the patient's condition to determine the best course of treatment for the iliopsoas abscess, periprosthetic infection, and hepatic abscess. Further updates on progress and appropriate care will be provided.

S: The patient is a female with a history of TOT surgery two years ago, experiencing urinary incontinence problems since. Symptoms include urinary incontinence during activities like coughing, walking, and physical exercises, as well as dysuria and urine leakage during sexual intercourse. She was diagnosed with stress urinary incontinence (SUI) and has been taking duloxetine 80 mg daily for three months. She routinely performs Kegel exercises. She denies alcohol and tobacco use and has a history of one vaginal and one cesarean delivery. There is no family history of similar illness.

O: Vital signs show a temperature of 36.6 °C, pulse at 82 beats/minute, and blood pressure at 110/65 mmHg. The patient is fully conscious and responsive, psychologically appears depressed. Systematic physical examination revealed no abdominal tenderness or anatomic anomalies, normal heart auscultation, and normal neurological reflexes and muscle strength. Urogynecological examination confirmed SUI without urogenital prolapse. Lab results: WBC 6.9 × 10^3/mm^3, hemoglobin 12.1 g/dL, ALT 38 u/l, AST 35 u/l, CRP 1.1 mg/l, creatinine 0.6 mg/dl. Serological tests negative for HbsAg, anti-HCV, and anti-HIV. Urine analysis showed microscopic hematuria, sterile urine culture.

A: The patient is experiencing persistent symptoms of stress urinary incontinence post TOT surgery, despite medical and non-pharmacological interventions. No alarming issues detected in lab results.

P: The patient is advised to continue with Kegel exercises and duloxetine. A follow-up appointment is scheduled to assess progress and discuss potential changes in the treatment plan if symptoms persist or worsen. The patient should report any concerns or changes in symptoms.

S: The patient has a history of severe peripheral vascular disease, right hip disarticulation, and paraplegia. They are experiencing a stage IV pressure ulcer on the left greater trochanter that led to osteomyelitis. The patient previously developed an invasive infection in the hip and acetabulum with persistent wound drainage and dehiscence after an attempt at limited resection.

O: The patient underwent a Girdlestone procedure due to a necrotic femoral head and large open wound at the greater trochanter. Intraoperative cultures identified Staphylococcus epidermidis. The patient was discharged on ceftriaxone and vancomycin, with complete healing of the incision but persistent low volume drainage from a surgical drain five months postoperatively. No clear radiographic or clinical evidence of recurrent osteomyelitis is present.

A: The patient's condition involves complications from osteomyelitis and infection with Staphylococcus epidermidis. The persistent drainage indicates ongoing but non-aggressive post-surgical healing issues.

P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely for any signs of recurrent osteomyelitis. The patient should stay alert to any changes or concerns and report them promptly. Follow-up care will focus on managing drainage and ensuring complete recovery.

S: The patient reports having seizures and expresses concern about them. History of a glioma diagnosed in May 2010, with a pathologic diagnosis of astrocytoma grade II after partial surgical resection. Chemotherapy with TMZ was administered from 2011 to 2013. In 2015, after noticing MRI changes, chemotherapy with TMZ was resumed, leading to side effects such as weight loss, anorexia, insomnia, and depression. Subsequent MRI showed tumor progression. Seizures recurred, leading to hospitalization. Treatment shifted to chemoradiation and 6 cycles of PCV associated with CBD in 2016.

O: The initial MRI showed intra-axial expansive and infiltrative lesions in the right temporal lobe. Subsequent MRI revealed discrete extension of signal alteration areas to the subinsular regions. By mid-2015, tumor size increased despite treatment. Post-chemoradiation MRI indicated exacerbation characterized by extensive contrast enhancement, edema, and tissue hypoperfusion.

A: Recurrent seizures potentially related to glioma progression and treatment response. The condition includes tumor exacerbation, edema, and inflammatory disease following treatment.

P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary to manage symptoms and control tumor growth. The patient is advised to report any changes in symptoms or health promptly.

S: The patient presented with left-sided testicular pain persisting for about a month, a dry cough, fever, weakness, fatigue, and decreased appetite over the past four days. The patient has a history of insulin-requiring type 2 diabetes mellitus, arterial hypertension, stage 3 chronic renal disease, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

O: On examination, the patient was febrile and tachycardic. Left testicular edema and pain on epididymal palpation were noted. Laboratory tests indicated neutrophilic leukocytosis with 24.2 x 10^3/μL WBC and 87% neutrophils. Chest X-ray showed bronchial wall thickening without parenchymal abnormalities. Urinalysis revealed increased WBCs and Gram-negative bacteria. Testicular ultrasound detected an abscess in the tail of the left epididymis. Initial treatment with doxycycline was followed by worsening respiratory symptoms, inadequate metabolic control (HbA1c at 8.7%, central glycemia at 510 mg/dL), and admission to intermediate care for hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state. Follow-up chest CT showed multiple bilateral nodular lesions, halo signs, and left pleural effusion. Cultures from blood and urine were positive for K. pneumoniae sensitive to penicillin, quinolone, and carbapenem. Abdominal and pelvic CT was normal. 

A: The clinical picture suggests septic pulmonary emboli (SPE) secondary to epididymitis, with isolation of K. pneumoniae. The diagnosis was supported by the presence of extrapulmonary infection, respiratory symptoms, and the findings from imaging studies.

P: The initial doxycycline treatment was suspended, and intravenous ciprofloxacin was started. After a 14-day course, the patient's clinical condition improved with a reduction in respiratory symptoms, testicular pain, and edema. The chest X-ray also showed improvement. Continued monitoring and treatment adjustments are planned as needed.

S: The patient reports experiencing pelvic and abdominal pain following a serious car accident. They have been unable to void and now feel disoriented and still in pain.

O: The patient shows signs of hemodynamic instability, including hypotension and tachycardia. Clinical examination revealed pelvic instability, blood loss from the urethra, and failure of urethral catheterization. A contrast-enhanced CT scan showed a small liver laceration, unstable pelvic fracture, and an empty bladder. Abdominal ultrasound could not identify the bladder. A follow-up CT scan revealed bladder displacement and contrast extravasation into the peritoneal cavity. Upon further examination, the patient exhibited hypotension, tachycardia, tachypnea, abdominal distension and guarding, severe electrolyte imbalance, elevated creatinine, and anemia.

A: The patient is assessed with an unstable pelvic fracture, lacerated liver, bladder injury with contrast extravasation, signs of sepsis, severe electrolyte imbalance, and anemia.

P: The plan included hemodynamic resuscitation, external fixation of the pelvis, monitoring and transfer to the ICU, percutaneous intraperitoneal drain placement, transfer to an academic hospital for specialized care, hemofiltration, and a laparotomy. Further plans involve close monitoring and ongoing treatment.

S: The patient is an eight-year-old girl who has been experiencing massive ascites, fatigue, abdominal distention, and weight loss of 10-15 pounds over the past two months. She has no significant past medical history. She was initially suspected to have abdominal tuberculosis and was started on anti-tuberculosis medications without improvement. 

O: Upon examination, her vitals were normal, and her abdomen was distended with no signs of peritonitis or perforation. Bowel sounds were normal, and there were no palpable lymph nodes. Lab tests showed hemoglobin at 14.6 g/dL with low red cell indices, indicating iron deficiency anemia, low serum iron, and a platelet count of 641,000/micro liter. The peripheral smear revealed hypochromia, anisocytosis, microcytosis, a few reactive lymphocytes, and increased platelets. C-reactive protein was 24.27 mg/L. Liver function tests and coagulation profile were normal. The ascitic tap showed red blood cells, lymphocyte count of 122/cumm, protein 2.6 g/dL, and lactate dehydrogenase 156, with a Serum-ascites albumin gradient of less than 1.1 g/dL. Occasional pus cells were seen in the peritoneal fluid, but culture showed no growth, and cytology showed mature lymphocytes and reactive mesothelial cells. The Mycobacterium tuberculosis test by PCR was negative, and the Chest X-ray was normal. A CT scan revealed gross ascites with omental thickening and nodularity.

A: The differential diagnosis includes conditions causing ascites with an exudative nature, given the omental thickening and nodularity. Tuberculosis has been ruled out based on negative PCR and Chest X-ray. Further investigation is needed to explore other potential causes such as malignancy or other infectious/inflammatory conditions.

P: A follow-up appointment is recommended to discuss further diagnostic testing and treatment options. Continue with the supportive care currently being provided and monitor her symptoms closely. If there is any significant change or worsening of her condition, she should be brought in immediately.

S: The patient reports feeling weak and unwell. They have been undergoing renal dialysis for the past 2 years and have a history of HBV infection. The patient denies alcohol consumption. Prior to transfer, they were diagnosed with end-stage hepatic failure (Child-Pugh stage C) and treated for anorexia, hypotension, and hypoglycemia. Upon arrival, the patient complained of malaise and was unaware of unmeasurable blood pressure.

O: The patient presented with Japan Coma Scale I-3 (Glasgow Coma Scale E3V1M5), severe hypotension, afebrile state, severe anemia, icterus, liver dysfunction, and hemorrhagic tendency. Lab results revealed high serum C-reactive protein, increased direct bilirubin, extremely high hyaluronic acid and type IV collagen, reduced total protein and albumin, reduced prothrombin time, and markedly low choline esterase activity. Complement system evaluation showed reduced CH50 and C3 with normal C4. Abdominal CT showed pleural effusion and small ascites; pleural effusion cell count was 272/μL with a negative culture. The patient required intubation due to persistent hypotension and low SpO2. A blood culture on day 4 revealed Cryptococcus.

A: The patient is experiencing decompensated liver dysfunction, anemia, hypotension, and infectious processes indicated by Cryptococcus in the bloodstream. The presentation and laboratory findings are consistent with severe complications from end-stage hepatic failure and associated infections.

P: The plan includes continued monitoring of the patient’s liver dysfunction and infection, along with appropriate treatments tailored to these conditions. The care team will provide intubation support, manage hypotension, anemia, and other symptoms, and keep the patient and their family informed of any developments or changes in the patient's health status.

S: The patient has been diagnosed with refractory Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) and is concerned about the planned EMA chemotherapy regimen, which includes mitoxantrone, etoposide, and cytarabine. The patient is worried about potential treatment side effects and has asked about urinalysis results and what actions will be taken in the event of fever or skin lesions.

O: The patient's hemoglobin level is 9.5 g/dl, and the platelet count is 20,000 per microliter. Urinalysis results are normal. Staphylococcus epidermidis has been detected in blood cultures from the central line and peripheral vein.

A: Diagnoses include refractory AML with the possibility of catheter-related infection and anemia and thrombocytopenia due to current levels of hemoglobin and platelets. There is also a consideration of potential infections or complications such as sinusitis, skin lesions resembling ecthyma gangrenosum, and endophthalmitis.

P: The plan includes initiating the EMA chemotherapy regimen and inserting a central venous catheter. The patient will be closely monitored for temperature changes and neutrophil count. In case of infection, antibiotics such as meropenem and teicoplanin will be administered, and antibiotic lock therapy will begin for the detected Staphylococcus epidermidis. Ultrasonography may be utilized to check for jugular vein thrombosis. If fever occurs, further investigations will ensue, potentially including sinus CT scans and treatment with Liposomal amphotericin B and sinus endoscopy. If skin lesions develop, a biopsy will be performed, and if vision issues arise, intravitreal AMB may be considered. Regular evaluations will be conducted to monitor for anemia and thrombocytopenia.

S: The patient is a 23-year-old female experiencing constant, worsening lower abdominal pain for the past few days, rated as an 8 out of 10 in severity. The pain is located in the middle below the belly button. She reports occasional light vaginal bleeding, different from her normal menstrual cycle, which is light pink in color. The patient is experiencing occasional nausea but no vomiting and reports a history of constipation last week, which has since resolved. Her last menstrual period was about two to three weeks ago, and she is sexually active, using an Implanon contraceptive for the past year. She has an allergy to amoxicillin.

O: No objective information provided regarding vitals or physical examination findings.

A: Possible differential diagnoses include gynecological issues such as hormonal imbalances, possible pregnancy-related complications, or gastrointestinal causes given the history of constipation. An ectopic pregnancy or issues related to the Implanon could be considered.

P: The plan is to arrange a face-to-face examination for a proper abdominal evaluation. The patient is advised to take a pregnancy test immediately and report back if it is positive. She should call the support line to schedule an appointment. If symptoms worsen or hydration becomes an issue, she should be seen sooner.

S: The patient, SZ.F, reports a 4 cm lump in the neck that has been growing and has become painful. No history of blood test abnormalities was mentioned. The patient expresses concerns after images and tests confirmed a lymphoproliferative disorder.

O: A 33x25 mm hypodense, homogenous mass was found in the neck via CT scan, with additional smaller lymph nodes nearby. Fine needle aspiration suggested a lymphoproliferative disorder. An open biopsy revealed necrotic tissue with a fibrotic capsule, containing Vimentin-positive connective tissue, vessels, and skeletal muscle fragments. Necrotic lymphoid tissue was present. Silver impregnation indicated a residual reticular sinusoidal structure, and immunohistochemistry (CD-20, CD-68) showed histiocytes and residual lymphoid cells with a Ki-67 proliferation index of 10%. Later imaging found a 17 mm cystic mass at the incision site, which was surgically removed.

A: Subtotal lymph node infarction without any sign of malignancy.

P: Recommendation for follow-up to monitor condition and ensure proper healing after cyst removal. No additional malignancies detected, so continued observation is advised.

S: The patient reports experiencing difficulty breathing and chest discomfort. They have a history of HIV immunodeficiency, past cerebral infection, and Kaposi's Sarcoma. After surgery, the patient suffered severe right ventricular dysfunction and developed low cardiac output syndrome (LCOS), requiring ECMO support.

O: Test results indicate the patient has Ebstein's anomaly, leading to severe right atrial and right ventricular dilatation. The patient also has right moderate ventricular dysfunction and severe tricuspid regurgitation.

A: The patient has a diagnosis of Ebstein's anomaly with complications of severe right atrial and ventricular dilatation, right ventricular dysfunction, and severe tricuspid regurgitation. They also have a history of HIV immunodeficiency, cerebral infection, and Kaposi's Sarcoma.

P: The plan includes managing the heart condition and ensuring control of HIV immunodeficiency with appropriate medications. The patient is advised to take medications as prescribed, attend follow-up appointments, and report any worsening symptoms or new issues. Recommendations include maintaining a healthy lifestyle, such as a balanced diet, exercise as tolerated, and avoiding smoking and excessive alcohol consumption. Monitoring progress and adjusting the treatment plan as needed will be part of ongoing care.

S: The patient has a history of severe hemophilia A (HEMA) diagnosed in early childhood with factor VIII activity of less than 0.001%. The patient's brother also suffered from severe HEMA, suggesting maternal carrier status. The patient has never developed factor VIII inhibitors. In the late 1980s and early 1990s, the patient tested positive for HIV-1 and hepatitis C following a blood transfusion. Hepatitis C was cured, but HIV-1 remains untreated, with the patient being an HIV long-term non-progressor (LTNP) with normal CD4 T cell count.

O: Blood sample collected in EDTA tubes, peripheral blood mononuclear cells isolated, CD4 T cells depleted by magnetic purification, and DNA purified from non-CD4 T cells using an allprep DNA/RNA mini kit. Whole exome sequencing (WES) performed.

A: The patient has severe hemophilia A, potentially with a smaller and less frequent F8 mutation. The patient remains an HIV long-term non-progressor. No factor VIII inhibitors developed.

P: Await and analyze whole exome sequencing results to identify HEMA causative mutation and possible mutations related to HIV LTNP phenotype. Discussion of results and determination of necessary follow-up or treatment based on findings.

S: The patient has metastatic breast cancer, which has spread to the liver, bones, and brain. She has undergone a mastectomy and received systemic chemotherapy. She is currently taking lapatinib, capecitabine, zoledronic acid, and steroids for cerebral oedema. The patient reports no recent abdominal pain or fever and has no history of recent operative procedures or endoscopies.

O: A total-body CT scan revealed a moderate amount of pneumatosis in the mesentery and pericolic fat, with intramural gas along the caecum and ascending colon. No other concerning findings were noted.

A: The presence of pneumatosis in the mesentery and pericolic fat, with intramural gas, is noted. However, the absence of symptoms like pain or fever and no recent surgical history suggests a conservative monitoring approach.

P: The oncologist has decided to discontinue steroids and will implement a conservative approach with clinical and radiological surveillance to monitor the pneumatosis. The patient is reassured to report any new symptoms and the situation will be tracked through follow-up imaging tests.

S: The patient is 37 weeks into her first pregnancy and is attending a scheduled obstetric ultrasonography. She reports no issues or concerns during her pregnancy and her clinical history has been unremarkable. Previously, a routine sonographic examination at 22 weeks showed no abnormalities.

O: The ultrasonography conducted during this visit shows that the baby is developing well, with no noticeable abnormalities.

A: Normal findings from obstetric ultrasonography at 37 weeks gestation; healthy foetal development with no complications observed.

P: Continue with regular prenatal check-ups and monitoring for the remainder of the pregnancy. The patient was advised to reach out if she notices any changes or has concerns. She plans to schedule her next appointment as part of routine care.

S: The patient initially presented with a moderately severe frontal headache with non-radiating pain. No additional subjective symptoms or concerns were provided.

O: The initial Brain MRI showed multiple discrete regions of abnormal signal, mild swelling in the white matter, and numerous cortical lobar microbleeds. The repeat MRI demonstrated resolution of many parenchymal abnormalities but revealed new regions of microbleeds. An Amyloid-PET scan showed moderate widespread amyloid deposition. CSF analysis indicated reduced amyloid-beta 1–42 and high-normal total tau. Neuropsychological testing suggested mild compromise in frontal functioning. A follow-up MRI later showed near-complete resolution of parenchymal abnormalities, with persisting lobar microbleeds.

A: The diagnostic impression suggests a neurological condition characterized by microbleeds and amyloid deposition, leading to considerations of a possible involvement of a cerebral amyloid angiopathy or related pathology.

P: The treatment plan included a 5-day course of intravenous methylprednisolone (1 g daily), followed by an 8-week taper of oral prednisolone starting at 60 mg. Continued monitoring with stable brain imaging was recommended, with further follow-ups based on any new symptoms or concerns from the patient.

S: The patient reports a history of synthetic cannabinoid use for about five years and presents with symptoms of peeing blood, nosebleeds, and a red eye. The patient admits to adding rodenticides to the synthetic cannabinoids to enhance their effects.

O: The physical examination reveals vital signs are stable. The patient has a right conjunctival hemorrhage, active epistaxis in the left nostril, and blood-tinged urine. Laboratory results show a prothrombin time (PT) greater than 106 seconds, partial thromboplastin time (PTT) at 79.5 seconds, and an indeterminable international normalized ratio (INR), indicating a blood clotting issue.

A: The patient is diagnosed with acute chemical-induced coagulopathy due to rodenticide consumption mixed with synthetic cannabinoids.

P: The treatment plan includes admission to the hospital for monitoring and management. The patient will receive an initial dose of intravenous vitamin K1 50 mg, followed by two doses of oral vitamin K1 50 mg over the next two days until PT normalization. The poison control center has been notified. The patient is advised to avoid using dangerous substances with synthetic cannabinoids and to monitor symptoms closely.

S: The patient's 53-month-old daughter has experienced progressive bilateral breast enlargement and accelerated growth since she was 9 months old. There is no report of vaginal bleeding or development of pubic or axillary hair. The family has sought medical advice before and was reassured by various primary health care facilities.

O: The child appears well-looking with normal blood pressure, weighs 17 kg (50th centile), and has a height of 108 cm (90th centile). Her mid-parental height is 175 cm, and her predicted adult height is 167 cm. Tanner staging is A1, P1, and B3. Examination reveals a reddish mucoid vagina with no clitoromegaly, acne, hirsutism, or palpable abdominal mass. Bone age assessment shows an 8-year-old bone age, advanced for her chronological age. Hormonal evaluation shows a basal luteinizing hormone level of 3.1 mIU/L, increasing to 8.8 mIU/L post-gonadotrophin-releasing hormone stimulation, with elevated estradiol E2 at 29,000 pg/ml and dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate at 90 ng/mL. Early morning cortisol is normal at 16 ng/mL. An abdominal ultrasound reports a right-sided hypoechoic suprarenal mass, while a CT scan shows a 25 × 22 mm well-defined focal lesion in the right adrenal gland.

A: The child presents with signs of precocious puberty, likely due to the identified adrenal mass, which is affecting hormone levels. The advanced bone age and elevated hormonal levels support this assessment.

P: A specialist consultation is recommended for the adrenal mass to determine the appropriate course of action. The parents are advised to monitor symptoms and ensure regular check-ups. Further evaluation and management will be guided based on specialist recommendations.

S: The patient is an 80-year-old man who reports progressive dysphagia over the past 8 months. He feels like there's a foreign body stuck in his throat but denies any pain during swallowing or changes in his voice.

O: Examination of the oropharynx showed no obvious pathology, and no palpable mass was found in the neck. An indirect laryngoscopy revealed a protrusion in the posterior hypopharyngeal wall, but the endolarynx exam was unremarkable, with normal vocal cord mobility. A neurological examination was normal, and laboratory results were not significant. A CT scan of the cervical spine showed extensive flowing anterior osteophytes from C5 to D1, with the level of compression on swallow studies at C5-C6.

A: The likely cause of dysphagia is the extensive flowing anterior osteophytes compressing the cervical spine at levels C5 to D1.

P: The plan is to manage the symptoms with anti-inflammatory drugs and dietary changes, avoiding solid food. Surgery is an option but not preferred by the patient at this time. The patient is advised to return for a follow-up if symptoms worsen or if they decide to reconsider surgical intervention.

S: The patient reports left eye redness and swelling for more than a month, with mild blurred vision, double vision, and occasional headaches for more than a week. These symptoms began about 4 months after a motor vehicle accident, which resulted in a basilar skull fracture, subarachnoid hemorrhage, and an epidural hematoma. The patient received conservative treatment and was discharged once symptoms improved. There is no history of diabetes, hypertension, pneumonia, tuberculosis, or any other infectious diseases, nor recent fever, sickness, surgery, loss of appetite, or weight loss. The patient is a non-smoker and has no known medication allergies.

O: Examination revealed a visual acuity of 6/5 in the right eye with an intraocular pressure of 17 mmHg, and 4/5 in the left eye with an intraocular pressure of 25 mmHg. The right eye appeared almost normal, with slight hyperemia but no eyelid swelling, exophthalmos, ptosis, or limitations in extraocular movements. The left eye exhibited eyelid swelling, mild ptosis, exophthalmos, chemosis, and corkscrew hyperemia focused on the cornea. Eye movement limitations included -1 in abduction and elevation of the left eye. The left anterior chamber was slightly shallow.

A: The patient presents with symptoms and examination findings suggestive of left-sided ocular issues likely related to previous head trauma. Possible conditions could include orbital cellulitis or other post-traumatic complications affecting the eye.

P: The plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and symptom management. Further discussions and planning for treatment options will be conducted to alleviate symptoms. Follow-up as needed.

S: The patient is a 20-year-old man with a low-grade fever and weakness in the right limb for about three weeks, worsening over time. He reports altered consciousness over the last five days and has a recent history of contact with pets. He also reports neck stiffness.

O: The patient appears thin, lean, ill, and irritable. He is confused with verbal responses. Vitals include blood pressure of 125/80, pulse of 95 per minute, respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and temperature of 39°C. Neurological exam shows a Glasgow coma scale of 13/15 (E4, M5, V4), increased tone in the right lower limb, decreased power of 1/5 in right upper and lower limbs, power of 5/5 in left limbs, up-going plantar reflexes bilaterally, and reactive pupils. Laboratory tests reveal normal complete blood count, urea, creatinine, electrolytes, liver function tests, calcium, magnesium, and albumin. Lumbar puncture shows elevated protein level (46mg/dl), glucose of 72mg/dl, 6 red blood cells, and 5 white blood cells. Negative results for blood culture, CSF culture, PCR tests, AFB smear, and MTB DNA test. MRI reveals multiple ring-enhancing lesions in brain areas (corpus callosum, subcortical areas, periventricular region) with vasogenic edema. Normal C3 and C4 levels.

A: The symptoms and investigations suggest a differential including possible infectious or inflammatory processes affecting the central nervous system, given the ring-enhancing lesions and elevated protein levels in CSF.

P: The plan involves close monitoring of the patient’s condition, consulting with specialists, and determining further tests or treatments necessary to address the underlying cause of the symptoms. Follow-up will be arranged to assess response to interventions and to adjust the treatment plan accordingly.

S: The patient reported having 2 generalized tonic-clonic seizures within 1 month. The patient's medical history includes treatment for a choroid plexus papilloma at age 11 via posterior fossa resection and a cadaveric dural patch. There is no family history of brain hemorrhage or cognitive impairment. The patient later developed confusion, disorientation, and verbal slowing. The family reported a subsequent acute left frontal intracerebral hemorrhage causing sudden aphasia.

O: Clinical examination revealed longstanding mild pyramidal weakness and ataxia in the right arm, and a slightly unsteady gait. Initial brain MRI showed patchy T2 hyperintensities and punctate foci of restricted diffusion. EEG demonstrated intermittent left anterior centrotemporal theta/delta activity, with occasional sharp slow waves. Follow-up MRI showed multifocal abnormal cortical signal and swelling, with new punctate foci of restricted diffusion, leptomeningeal enhancement, and recent subarachnoid hemorrhage. Gradient-recalled T2*-weighted sequences indicated left parietal superficial siderosis and peripheral microbleeds. Lumbar puncture revealed 680 red blood cells and elevated protein levels at 0.99 g/l. A brain biopsy revealed leptomeningeal and cortical CAA with scattered leptomeningeal hemosiderin deposits and widespread diffuse parenchymal Aβ deposits.

A: The patient is assessed to have primary central nervous system vasculitis. The acute intracerebral hemorrhage and findings suggest cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA) as a contributing factor.

P: Initiate treatment with intravenous methylprednisolone 500 mg daily for 5 days, followed by oral prednisolone (50 mg). Continue monitoring and manage the patient's condition based on ongoing assessments, including follow-up imaging and clinical evaluations.

S: The patient is a 41-year-old gravida 3, para 0, who is 27 weeks and 3 days pregnant. She reports symptoms of dizziness, impaired vision, facial edema, and increasing edema in her lower legs. She was previously diagnosed with gestational hypertension and has had issues with unsuccessful pregnancies, including two early miscarriages after assisted reproductive technologies (ART). There is a history of a uterine fibroma and an arcuate uterus found via hysteroscopy. No genetic pathologies, antiphospholipid syndrome, lupus, or thrombophilia were detected. 

O: The patient is currently on alpha-methyl-dopa 250 mg, magnesium 40 mg, and progesterone 100 mg. Her blood pressure has been recorded at approximately 175/105 mmHg. Two viable embryos were detected on follow-up ultrasounds after the recent ICSI.

A: The patient is experiencing symptoms consistent with exacerbated gestational hypertension, possibly indicating the risk of preeclampsia due to increased blood pressure and edema.

P: The plan includes continued monitoring of the pregnancy with regular ultrasound examinations, adherence to prescribed medications, and the patient is advised to report any changes in symptoms. Follow-up for blood pressure monitoring and consideration of further evaluation for preeclampsia if symptoms persist or worsen.

S: The patient, with a history of urothelial bladder cancer and as a former smoker, reports experiencing chest pain during exertion, such as exercise or strenuous activity. The chest pain is described as pressure in the middle of the chest, which worsens with activity and improves with rest. The patient does not report accompanying symptoms such as sweating or palpitations.

O: On admission, the patient was afebrile with a blood pressure of 147/85 mm/Hg and a heart rate of 79 beats/minute. An ECG showed sinus rhythm with right bundle branch block but no ischemic changes. Lab tests, including troponin, lipid profiles, and fasting blood glucose, were normal. An exercise stress test revealed inferior wall ischemic changes. During a coronary angiogram, it was found that the right coronary artery had 80% stenosis in the middle and distal segments, and the right posterior descending artery had 70% stenosis in the proximal segment. An anomalous origin of the left circumflex and left anterior descending arteries was noted, with no significant stenosis in these arteries.

A: The patient’s chest pain is likely due to coronary artery disease, as indicated by the stenosis observed during the coronary angiogram. The anomalous artery origins are noteworthy but not contributing to additional stenosis.

P: The procedure was aborted to perform a cardiac multidetector computed tomography (MDCT) for detailed coronary anatomy mapping. Await the results of the MDCT to determine the appropriate treatment strategy.

S: The patient is a 75-year-old female with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and atrial fibrillation not on anticoagulation. She reports acute on chronic left hip pain worsening over two weeks. The pain is severe, sharp, constant, radiates to the left thigh, and affects her ability to walk. She has a history of multiple hospital admissions for urinary tract infections and left hip pain due to a fracture.

O: On examination, the patient's left lower extremity is externally rotated, tender, and cold to palpation. A 3-cm decubitus ulcer is present around the heel. Laboratory results show elevated potassium at 7.2, creatinine at 13.34 mg/dL, blood urea nitrogen at 103, white blood cell count at 51,200/mcL, platelet count at 585, lactic acid at 7.2, erythrocyte sedimentation rate at 97, and C-reactive protein at 23. Electrocardiogram shows hyperacute T waves. Positive urine culture for Escherichia coli and blood cultures indicate Gram-positive rods.

A: The primary diagnosis is septic shock secondary to urinary tract infection with suspected blood culture contamination. The severe left hip pain and abnormalities in clinical status prompted a left hip arthroscopy, but no synovial fluid was obtained.

P: Initiate hemodialysis for electrolyte imbalance. The patient was transferred to the intensive care unit for hypotension and tachycardia, not responsive to IV fluids. Vasopressors started for hemodynamic support. Empiric treatment includes vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam. Blood cultures repeated showing no growth, suggesting urinary tract as the primary infection source. Continuous monitoring and treatment adjustment planned to manage symptoms and support recovery.

S: The patient reports experiencing anxiety and depressive symptoms, which began after excessive acetaminophen intake in 2012. The patient also has a history of an ischemic stroke that occurred two years prior to the onset of these symptoms, resulting in incomplete Broca's aphasia and dysprosody. The patient experiences variable speech capability and can express simple words and phrases. There is no family or personal history of psychiatric diseases prior to the language impairments. The patient has been diagnosed with hypertension and has expressed a preference against psychometric testing. The patient has a supportive family, is bilingual in Italian and French, and works as a writer and translator.

O: The patient did not undergo psychometric testing for speech impairment. A cerebral MRI revealed a diffuse white matter high-signal hyper-intensity in the left posteroinferior portion of the frontal lobe, anterior to the motor cortex.

A: The patient's anxiety and depressive symptoms appear to be linked to speech and language impairments following an ischemic stroke. The MRI findings suggest possible brain damage affecting speech and language areas.

P: The plan includes developing a treatment strategy to manage the patient's speech impairment and psychological symptoms. Recommendations include speech therapy, medication, and counseling. Monitoring of progress and adjustment of the treatment plan will be ongoing, with support available for concerns and questions.

S: The patient, with a history of rheumatic heart disease and a previous episode of infective endocarditis (IE) three years prior, reported symptoms of low-grade intermittent fever and progressive shortness of breath over the past two months. He also mentioned hearing unusual noises in his chest when breathing. He is a non-smoker, non-IV drug user, and currently unemployed due to health issues.

O: On physical examination, the patient presented with a low-grade fever (99 °F), tachycardia (110 bpm), hypotension (90/60 mm Hg), mild pallor, and bilateral pitting ankle edema. Auscultation revealed a displaced apex beat, pan-systolic murmur radiating to the axilla, and bilateral basal crepitation. Chest X-ray showed massive cardiomegaly with interstitial edema and bilateral mild pleural effusion. 2D-Echocardiography indicated a dilated left ventricle, severe aortic and mitral regurgitation, and a reduced ejection fraction of 30%. Trans-esophageal echocardiography showed a deformed calcified mitral valve and a large vegetation on the aortic valve. Lab tests revealed mild anemia, neutrophil leukocytosis (15.5×10^9/l), markedly raised C-reactive protein levels (96 mg/dl), and a normal biochemical profile.

A: The patient has likely developed infectious endocarditis, as indicated by his past medical history, clinical findings, and deteriorating condition with high-grade fever and elevated infection markers. The heart findings on imaging suggest significant valvular disease.

P: The treatment plan includes empirical antimicrobial therapy with intravenous Ceftriaxone 2 g once daily, Gentamicin 60 mg every 8 hours, and Vancomycin 120 mg every 8 hours (target trough concentration of 15–20 µg/ml). Progress will be closely monitored, and adjustments to the treatment will be made as necessary. Follow-up and communication about symptom changes are essential.

S: The patient has been diagnosed with a left frontal tumor. An en bloc resection was performed, but there was some loss of white matter tissue on the medial/inferior side of the tumor. The patient expressed concern over the seriousness of the condition.

O: MRI showed minimal contrast enhancement of the tumor. Histopathological examination identified the tumor as an IDH1-mutated codeleted oligodendroglioma, WHO grade III, with a Ki67 proliferation rate of 25%. PET scan revealed 15 ROIs with varying MET uptake (high, medium, low), and statistical analysis showed a strong correlation between MET uptake and IDH1. No significant correlation was found with tumor perfusion or other markers. 

A: The patient has a WHO grade III IDH1-mutated codeleted oligodendroglioma with high proliferation rate. PET scan findings and statistical analysis suggest a strong correlation with specific tumor markers, which may guide further monitoring and treatment.

P: The plan is to closely monitor the patient's progress through follow-up appointments. Additional treatments may be recommended if necessary. The clinician emphasized the importance of attending follow-up appointments and offered continued support and guidance.

S: The patient has experienced progressive cognitive decline over the past 12 months, accompanied by a loss of weight (20 kg), nausea, gait disturbance, and tremor. Symptoms began with a dull holocephalic headache lasting for 3 months. The patient was initially diagnosed with tension-type headache and depressive disorder and was prescribed duloxetine, which did not provide relief. There was no improvement in symptoms, leading to a further work-up including an inpatient investigation. The patient also reported insecure gait with postural instability, quiet voice, mildly elevated muscle tone with slight Gegenhalten, brisk tendon reflexes, mild bradykinesia, and both action tremor and mild resting tremor.

O: An MRI showed bilateral white matter lesions and an old lacunar lesion at the left striatum, not seen in previous scans. Neurocognitive testing indicated severe decline in attention, memory, and executive functions, corresponding to subcortical dementia. Latest examination reports weight at 47 kg. The patient reports brisk tendon reflexes but no paresis, pyramidal signs, ataxia, or increased reflexes.

A: The patient presents with symptoms suggestive of subcortical dementia. The MRI findings of bilateral white matter lesions and lacunar lesion, along with brisk tendon reflexes and mild bradykinesia, indicate probable vascular contributions to the cognitive decline.

P: Continue monitoring symptoms and report any significant changes. Schedule a follow-up appointment to discuss progress and any necessary adjustments to the treatment plan. Further work-up and interdisciplinary consults may be necessary to address underlying causes and manage symptoms effectively.

S: The patient reports experiencing crampy abdominal pain for the past few days, along with intermittent vomiting and obstipation. No fever has been reported, but the patient has been unable to pass stool.

O: During the physical examination, abdominal tenderness was noted. A CT scan revealed dilatation of the biliopancreatic limb of the REYGB and intussusception of the small bowel through the jejunojejunostomy.

A: The patient is diagnosed with intussusception of the small bowel through the jejunojejunostomy, likely related to previous REYGB surgery. The primary concern is the obstruction causing crampy abdominal pain, vomiting, and obstipation.

P: An exploratory laparoscopy was performed to reduce the intussusception and assess the viability of the bowel loops. The intussusception was successfully reduced, and extensive adhesions lysis was conducted. No bowel resection was necessary. The patient will be observed for the return of normal bowel function, expected in about two days, before discharge.

S: The patient reports experiencing dyspnea on exertion and intermittent substernal chest pain for the past two months. The shortness of breath occurs during the first 10-15 minutes of exercise and then dissipates. The chest pain is new and not related to exercise. The patient recently moved to a high altitude in Albuquerque, which worsened the symptoms. There is a significant weight loss of about 100 pounds and an 18-point drop in BMI following Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery. The patient denies any history of tobacco abuse, excessive alcohol consumption, or drug use and is not on any negative ionotropic drugs. There is a strong family history of coronary artery disease.

O: The patient has resting bradycardia with a heart rate of 55 BPM and blood pressure of 89/54. Current BMI is 24, indicating normal weight. An Electrocardiogram (EKG) revealed non-specific ST wave changes, and high sensitivity troponin I was within the normal range (<0.017). During an EKG exercise stress test using the Bruce protocol, at rest, the heart rate was 68 BPM; stage I exercise heart rate was 81 BPM, with a significant rise to 133 BPM occurring late in stage III at 10.4 METs.

A: The clinical presentation includes exertional dyspnea, substernal chest pain, and resting bradycardia, with recent changes due to high altitude. Non-specific EKG changes and family history suggest possible coronary artery disease. Differential diagnosis may include high-altitude-related hypoxia or cardiac issues secondary to weight loss and lifestyle changes.

P: Recommended following up with the primary care physician for further evaluation and management. Consider further cardiac evaluation and possibly an echocardiogram or coronary artery imaging. Evaluate for high-altitude-related health impacts and monitor cardiac function and symptoms during ongoing care.

S: The patient reports testicular swelling and pain for the past four days and has been experiencing drainage from an abscess in the perineal region for several weeks. He also mentions a history of atrial fibrillation, hypertension, dyslipidemia, and benign prostatic hypertrophy. The patient acknowledges symptoms of urinary incontinence after urological procedures and reports persistent back pain following a fall at home three weeks ago. He notes a gradual loss of height from 6 feet 3 inches to 5 feet 9 inches over the years.

O: On physical exam, there is an abscess on the inner gluteal fold of the perineal region, spontaneously draining serosanguinous fluid. The left scrotum is erythematous and indurated with mild tenderness but no overt cellulitis or crepitus. A CT scan reveals an L1 vertebral compression fracture with sclerosis and multiple lumbar spine compression fractures at T12, L3, and L4, along with other multilevel degenerative changes.

A: Low suspicion for Fournier's gangrene. Recent L1 vertebral compression fracture and multiple lumbar spine compression fractures are noted. The scrotal wound needs further evaluation by urology and general surgery.

P: Admit the patient for management of the scrotal wound. Evaluate by urology and general surgery for further assessment. Continue monitoring condition and develop a treatment plan tailored to the patient's needs.

S: The patient, with a history of tobacco use, hypertension, transient ischemic attack, and osteoarthritis, reports a recent fall due to syncope. Current medications include aspirin 81 mg once daily, losartan 25 mg once daily, and multivitamins.

O: Examination showed no focal neurological deficits, additional heart sounds, or murmurs. An EKG revealed a 2-mm ST elevation in the lateral leads I and aVL and a reciprocal 1-mm ST depression in the inferior leads II, III, and aVF. Initial troponin T level was 0.81 ng/dL (elevated). Coronary angiography showed non-obstructive coronary artery disease. A left ventriculogram revealed an EF of 30% with poor anteroapical and distal inferior wall hypokinesis, suggestive of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Second bloodwork showed troponin levels of 0.50 ng/dL, CK of 329 units/L, and CK-MB of 27 ng/mL (both elevated). The lipid panel was within acceptable limits. A transthoracic echocardiogram confirmed apical ballooning and akinesis, with an EF of less than 20%.

A: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, with evidence of non-obstructive coronary artery disease. Elevated cardiac markers suggest acute cardiac event. Syncope possibly related to cardiac issues.

P: Close monitoring of the patient’s condition, potential medication adjustments, and follow-up with primary care physician to discuss results and further treatment. Emphasis on managing risk factors, including quitting tobacco use and controlling hypertension.

S: The patient reports experiencing chest pain and hoarseness. He has a history of a traffic accident three months ago, resulting in fractures of the femur, radius, ribs, and sternum, with internal fixation of the femur and radius.

O: The physical examination conducted was normal. A CT scan revealed a ruptured aortic arch with a pseudoaneurysm, measuring 20 mm at the posteroinferior aspect of the aortic arch, involving the posterior wall of the innominate artery and the origin of the left common carotid artery. A pseudoaneurysm in the upper mediastinum measures 40 mm x 48 mm x 30 mm. The distance from the junction of the aortic sinus and ascending aorta to the rupture is 7.9 cm. Postoperative thoracic and abdominal CT angiography showed no contrast leakage and smooth reconstruction of blood vessels.

A: The symptoms are likely due to the pseudoaneurysm compressing the left recurrent laryngeal nerve. A ruptured aortic arch with pseudoaneurysm identified.

P: A hybrid operation involving debranching and thoracic endovascular aortic repair (TEVAR) was recommended and performed. The operation was successful, with uneventful recovery reported. Continued monitoring and follow-up care are advised.

S: The patient was diagnosed with cT3N2M0, stage IIIA luminal-HER2 type breast cancer, and underwent preoperative chemotherapy in 2013 with epirubicin plus cyclophosphamide and PTX, followed by a mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection with a Grade 1b therapeutic effect. Two years post-surgery, lung and internal mammary lymph node metastases were identified during adjuvant endocrine therapy. The patient underwent first-line treatment for metastatic breast cancer using docetaxel, pertuzumab, and trastuzumab, achieving a complete radiological response and non-pathological values for CA15-3 and NCC-ST-439. She underwent irradiation and received maintenance therapy with pertuzumab and trastuzumab for approximately 18 months, stopping in October 2017. She reports currently feeling fine and has no symptoms or concerns.

O: No specific vitals or observable exam findings were discussed. Patient achieved complete radiological response and non-pathological values for CA15-3 and NCC-ST-439 after the aforementioned therapies.

A: The patient has a history of stage IIIA luminal-HER2 type breast cancer with subsequent metastatic breast cancer that responded well to first-line therapy and maintenance treatment. No current symptoms reported, indicating continued remission post-therapy cessation.

P: Continue regular follow-up appointments to monitor health and address potential issues. Patient advised to schedule her next appointment in a timely manner. No immediate treatments or tests are recommended based on the current evaluation.

S: The newborn was admitted for ineffective breastfeeding and failure to thrive. He was born at term from a spontaneous delivery, small for gestational age, with a history of delayed intrauterine growth restriction identified in the last month of an otherwise uneventful pregnancy. The newborn has normal external genitalia appearance with mild pigmentation and normal skin pigmentation.

O: Blood tests revealed severe hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, hypochloremia, and metabolic acidosis with increased lactate, along with urinary sodium loss. Endocrinological tests showed low plasmatic aldosterone levels, dramatically increased renin, elevated ACTH, and normal plasmatic cortisol. Neonatal screening for 17-OH-progesterone was normal. Cerebral ultrasounds, cerebral MRI, ECG, chest X-rays, and abdominal MRI were all normal, with normal-sized adrenal glands.

A: The diagnostic impression suggests an electrolyte imbalance potentially linked to a form of adrenal insufficiency, given the hormonal profile and symptoms.

P: The newborn is receiving electrolyte replacement therapy (IV and oral) and Fludrocortisone therapy (50 μg/die) with salt integration, leading to normalization of clinical and hormonal conditions. It is essential to continue monitoring growth, development, and electrolyte levels through regular blood tests. Continuation of the prescribed Fludrocortisone therapy is recommended.

S: The patient is undergoing treatment following complications related to esophageal issues. They reported a history of surgery for gastric cancer and experienced eating obstruction, nausea, vomiting, severe pain in the chest and lower back, and compression pain in the neck during a recent procedure. The patient describes significant discomfort but no symptoms after initial endoscopic procedures.

O: Objective findings include a normal esophagus CT scan before gastroscopy, subcutaneous emphysema in the thoracolumbar segment, face, neck, extensive subcutaneous emphysema in the chest and back, a large amount of emphysema in the mediastinum, and a small amount of left pleural effusion from emergency CT scans. Laboratory results revealed serum RBC 4.7cell/L, Hgb 138 g/L, HCT 42.8% initially, and serum RBC 3.3cell/L, Hgb 100 g/L, HCT 28.5% after the rupture. Physical examination revealed crepitus in the affected areas. A long esophageal rupture was observed and treated with 14 titanium clips. 

A: The diagnosis is a spontaneous esophageal rupture. Given the patient's poor general condition and high risk for surgery, endoscopic treatment was chosen. The rupture was successfully managed with clipping.

P: The patient is advised to fast and undergo strong anti-infection treatment postoperatively. There will be a close monitoring of the patient's condition through follow-up appointments and esophageal angiography without contrast agent leakage or exacerbation of emphysema was noted. The patient is encouraged to continue postoperative care instructions and to reach out with any concerns or questions.

S: The patient reports previous symptoms of swelling and pain in the left arm. Initially treated for cellulitis in the left leg, the patient left against medical advice before further tests confirmed a tentative diagnosis of CLL. The patient is currently homeless and lacks insurance or financial means. The patient denies fever or rapid heart rate and reports no significant past medical or surgical history.

O: On examination, the patient has swelling, redness, and tenderness in the left upper extremity. The left lower extremity is swollen but without redness or tenderness. Initial lab results show a WBC of 256 with 87.5% atypical lymphocytes, hemoglobin of 13.4 g/dl, and a platelet count of 166 x 10^9/L. Potassium levels are elevated at 5.4 meq/L, with historical measurements as high as 8 meq/L, but the patient remains asymptomatic. A peripheral blood smear indicates smudge cells and enlarged lymph nodes were observed. Flow cytometry confirmed CLL with monoclonal B cells. ECG shows no changes.

A: Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) as confirmed by laboratory tests and flow cytometry. The patient exhibits hyperkalemia, though currently stable and asymptomatic.

P: The plan is to continue monitoring the patient's condition, especially potassium levels, though treatment for hyperkalemia is not currently required. It is advised that the patient follow medical guidance and remain in the hospital for further tests and necessary treatments. Provide support for the patient's financial and housing needs to enable better access to care.

S: The patient is a young girl with bilateral glaucoma, identified since age 3. She was born prematurely with intrauterine growth retardation following a pregnancy complicated by oligohydramnios. There is no family history of inherited diseases, cataract, or pRTA. Her weight and height are below the 3rd percentile, and she has demonstrated intellectual disability. At age 9, she presented with micrognathia, fish-mouth, epicanthal folds, ptosis, low-set ears, a short neck with a low hairline, a broad shield-like chest, and wide-spaced nipples.

O: Medications include 50 mL of Sholl solution, anti-acidosis capsules three times a day, and eye drops with β-blocker and carbonic anhydrase inhibitor. Lab tests show sodium 139 mmol/L, potassium 3.1 mmol/L, chloride 110 mmol/L, blood urea nitrogen 12 mg/dL, and creatinine 0.9 mg/dL. Blood gas analysis revealed a pH of 7.22, HCO3− 11 mmol/L, and PCO2 29 mmHg. Urinalysis showed a pH of 5, normal amino acid excretion, and urinary β2-microglobulin level of 110 μg/L. A renal ultrasound indicated a 9-mm parenchymal stone in the right kidney. Brain MR imaging showed no intracranial calcification. Thyroid hormones, IGF-I, and IGFBP3 levels were normal. Physical examination was otherwise unremarkable.

A: The patient has proximal renal tubular acidosis (pRTA) without Fanconi syndrome, alongside symptoms potentially indicative of a genetic syndrome characterized by her distinct facial features and short stature. No symptoms related to pRTA are seen in her parents.

P: Continue current medications. Regular monitoring of laboratory test results and imaging studies is recommended to ensure stability. Close follow-up with the medical team is advised for any changes in health status.

S: The patient reports progressive dyspnea with mild exertion, edema in the lower extremities, paresthesia, and pain. The patient has a history of viral perimyocarditis and new onset heart failure with reduced ventricular ejection fraction diagnosed four months ago.

O: Vitals show the patient is afebrile, tachycardic with a heart rate in the 110s BPM, tachypneic with a respiratory rate in the 20s Br/min, normotensive with a blood pressure of 110/70 mmHg, and oxygen saturation at 93% on room air. Examination reveals jugular venous distention, diffuse bilateral crackles, bilateral pitting lower extremity edema up to the knees, and reduced femoral and dorsalis pedis pulses. Laboratory tests indicate neutrophil-predominant leukocytosis (WBC count 19 x 10^3/mcL), elevated brain natriuretic peptide (2506 pg/mL), troponin-I (0.48 ng/mL), D-dimer (6.6 μg/mL), erythrocyte sedimentation rate (110 mm/Hr), and C-reactive protein (12.7 mg/dL). Transthoracic echocardiogram shows severe global hypokinesis, moderate-to-severe systolic dysfunction, paradoxical septal motion, and multiple biventricular pedunculated mobile echodensities consistent with thrombi, and trace pericardial effusion. CT angiogram indicates right lobar pulmonary embolus, bilateral small pleural effusions, and occlusion of multiple arteries in the lower extremities.

A: The patient is diagnosed with severe decompensated heart failure, presence of intraventricular thrombi, right lobar pulmonary embolism, and arterial occlusions in the lower extremities.

P: The plan included urgent embolectomy and thrombectomies, which were successfully performed to remove the blood clots and restore blood flow in the arteries. Continued monitoring and treatment for heart failure are recommended.

S: The patient reports experiencing sudden vision loss in both eyes for the last 5 days, accompanied by a severe headache on the right side and jaw pain.

O: The Neuro-Ophthalmological examination shows the patient is alert and oriented. There is no light perception in both eyes, with dilated pupils unresponsive to light. The slit lamp examination reveals punctate cataracts. Funduscopic exam indicates diffuse optic disc swelling with a pallid "chalky white" appearance and optic disc atrophy bilaterally. Extra-ocular motility is full, but there is tenderness in the bilateral superficial temporal arteries. Lab tests indicate slightly decreased RBC and Hb levels; normal platelet count; elevated ESR and CRP. CDUS shows decreased blood flow in posterior ciliary, central retinal, and ophthalmic arteries, and "halo sign" inflammation in temporal arteries. Orbital MRI with contrast shows enhancement of the left optic nerve sheath, with no lesions. MRA is unremarkable. A right temporal artery biopsy reveals luminal occlusion due to inflammation.

A: The symptoms and test results suggest the patient is experiencing vision loss due to temporal artery inflammation and occlusion.

P: Further discussion is needed to address potential treatments and follow-up requirements for temporal artery inflammation to prevent further vision loss and manage symptoms.

S: The patient is a 44-year-old man with a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who underwent induction chemotherapy. On day 10 post-chemotherapy, he experienced bone marrow suppression with fever and septic shock. He reported feeling very sick during this time. Additionally, he developed recurrent fever and suffered from neutropenia from day 10 to day 25. The patient experienced hemiplegia and hemiconvulsions in the right limb, which was frightening for him. 

O: The patient’s fever and septic shock were initially treated with imipenem, vancomycin, and voriconazole. Blood cultures from day 10 to day 28 were negative for pathogens. A CT scan of his brain showed a hyperdense lesion with surrounding edema, suspected as cerebral infarction, and hypodense areas in the parietal lobes. An MRA revealed no obvious abnormalities. CT of the lung on day 18 showed multiple hyperdense lesions. A (1,3)- β-D-glucan test on day 22 was positive at 100.70 pg/mL, indicating a fungal infection.

A: The patient’s condition suggests febrile neutropenia with cerebral symptoms potentially indicating a brain infection, likely fungal in nature due to the positive (1,3)- β-D-glucan test.

P: The patient’s antifungal and antibacterial treatment have been adjusted to include voriconazole, imipenem, and teicoplanin. It is important for the patient to continue these medications and maintain close follow-up with the healthcare team, reporting any changes in symptoms.

S: The patient reports experiencing sudden onset left upper limb dyspraxia and confusion. There is a history of hemochromatosis and a distant history of meningococcal meningitis. While on treatment for a cerebral abscess, the patient developed severe peripheral edema, dyspnea, and tachycardia.

O: MRI of the brain showed a large right parietal lesion. CT and PET scans revealed left upper and lower lobe lung lesions, a solitary liver lesion, and a base of skull lesion. Histopathology confirmed BRAF/NRAS wild-type metastatic melanoma. Follow-up MRI demonstrated intracranial recurrence. The patient developed a cerebral abscess and ventriculitis post-craniotomy, confirmed to be caused by corynebacterium acnes. The ECG showed sinus tachycardia, left axis deviation, and right bundle branch block. TTE revealed a new circumferential pericardial effusion with early signs of tamponade.

A: The patient has been diagnosed with BRAF/NRAS wild-type metastatic melanoma with intracranial and extracranial disease. Post-craniotomy complications include a cerebral abscess and ventriculitis. ICI-induced pericarditis with associated pericardial effusion was also diagnosed.

P: The plan includes resection of the right parietal lobe metastases followed by ipilimumab and nivolumab treatment. IV Cephalothin has been administered for 12 weeks to treat the cerebral abscess. Aggressive diuresis, colchicine 500 mcg daily, and ibuprofen 500 mg three times daily have been started for the management of pericarditis. Weekly echocardiograms will monitor the condition. The patient’s immunotherapy was discontinued due to complications.

S: The patient is a 69-year-old male heavy smoker who presents with worsening shortness of breath over the past week. He has a medical history of well-controlled hypertension, chronic kidney disease stage III, and a right solitary kidney due to a nephrectomy. The patient reports feeling bloated but denies fever, night sweats, cough, hemoptysis, or chest pain. He is experiencing these symptoms for the first time. Current medications include atenolol, allopurinol, atorvastatin, and over-the-counter antacids and laxatives.

O: Normal vital signs and oxygen saturation on room air. Physical examination reveals decreased tactile fremitus, dullness upon percussion, and reduced breath sounds on the right side. Chest X-ray indicates a large right-sided pleural effusion. Ultrasound-guided thoracentesis removed 1.5 liters of turbid orange fluid. A CT scan shows right-sided hydroureteronephrosis extending to the uretero-vesicular junction and irregular bladder wall thickening suggestive of a bladder tumor.

A: The patient has recurrent right-sided pleural effusion, likely linked to an underlying pathology. The CT findings raise suspicion for a primary bladder tumor contributing to his symptoms and recent acute kidney injury.

P: The patient was admitted for observation where thoracentesis was performed, and the pleural fluid was sent for analysis. He improved symptomatically after the procedure. Discharge instructions include follow-up for pleural fluid cytology results. The plan also involves consultation with the primary care physician for further management and discussion on the suspected bladder tumor and related hydroureteronephrosis.

S: The patient was bitten by a Merrem's hump-nosed viper about five hours prior to being seen. She experiences mild swelling and pain at the bite site, epigastric pain, mild postural dizziness, and increased thirst. She is fully conscious, alert, and oriented, with no substances or alcohol intake. She is feeling quite thirsty.

O: The patient has mild swelling and tenderness on the right foot with two fang marks below the right lateral malleolus. Vital signs include a heart rate of 106 beats per minute and blood pressure of 95/60 mmHg in a supine position. Blood clotting test (WBCT20) is <20 min, and INR is 1.05. The physical examination is otherwise unremarkable. The patient had a generalized tonic-clonic seizure 23 hours after the snake bite, lasting 30 minutes.

A: The patient was bitten by a Merrem's hump-nosed viper. She exhibits mild local envenomation symptoms and dehydration. The occurrence of a generalized tonic-clonic seizure suggests possible complications related to the venom.

P: The patient is being observed closely. She started on oral fluids intake of 0.6 L and intravenous infusion of 0.9% saline at a rate of 100 ml/hour, totaling 3 L over 24 hours. A tetanus toxoid and oral cloxacillin 500 mg every 6 hours were administered. Post-seizure care and monitoring for further complications are being ensured.

S: The patient is a 77-year-old ambulatory male with a medical history of hypertension, sarcoidosis, complete atrioventricular block managed with a pacemaker, and chronic kidney disease due to focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS). He reports experiencing sporadic gait disturbances and numbness on the right side of his face. The symptoms appear and resolve within a day every few weeks. Previously, he experienced sudden dysarthria and left limb weakness that resolved within three hours, suspected to be a transient ischemic attack (TIA). He was admitted to the stroke unit for further evaluation.

O: Historical data includes:
- Serum creatinine level of 1.2 mg/dL with proteinuria of 0.4 g per day (nine years ago).
- Renal biopsy showed sclerotic glomeruli and segmental sclerosing lesions.
- No ischemic lesions or occlusion of major cerebral arteries found on perfusion CT with iodinated contrast and CT angiography.
- Previous physical findings showed pronator drift on the left side.

A: The patient has a history of TIA, hypertension, sarcoidosis without treatment, complete atrioventricular block (managed with a pacemaker), and chronic kidney disease secondary to FSGS. Current symptoms of sporadic gait disturbances and right facial numbness are noted, which might be related to cerebrovascular issues given the history of TIA.

P: Continue monitoring the patient's symptoms and clinical status. No specific new interventions or tests were discussed during this visit. The patient is advised to report any changes in symptoms or new concerns promptly. Further adjustments to the treatment plan may be considered based on the progression or resolution of current symptoms.

S: The patient's 4-year-old daughter has had a fever and swelling in her right leg. She was diagnosed with Takayasu arteritis at two years old. Part of her right leg has become necrotic due to decreased blood flow. She has been resistant to standard therapy with prednisolone and tocilizumab, with no previous monitoring of plasma concentrations. After initial treatment with infliximab (IFX), there was body fluid leakage from inflammation sites in her legs.

O: Tests performed include computed tomography, echocardiography, and a skin biopsy. C-reactive protein (CRP) levels decreased from 8.7 mg/dL to 1.6 mg/dL after initial IFX administration, then elevated to 9.0 mg/dL. Blood IgG levels were lower than standard; immunoglobulin at 2.5 g has been administered weekly. Plasma IFX levels decreased from 23.6 μg/mL on day 10 to 2.5 μg/mL on day 23.

A: The inflammation associated with Takayasu arteritis has been aggravated. There is necrosis in part of the right leg due to decreased blood flow. The current treatment plan involves adjusting IFX dosages based on trough levels to improve her condition.

P: The plan is to administer IFX biweekly at 8 mg/kg. The expectation is for plasma IFX levels to increase and CRP levels to decrease to around 2 mg/dL within 40 days of the new treatment plan. Continued administration of immunoglobulin at 2.5 g will occur weekly for at least a few months. The patient will be closely monitored, and treatment will be adjusted as needed.

S: The patient has a history of diabetes, hypertension, and kidney disease and is considering renal replacement therapy. The patient underwent surgical creation of an arteriovenous fistula in the left wrist for hemodialysis.

O: During surgery, a large cystic formation was found enmeshed in the radial artery with slight adhesions. The cyst was successfully dissected and resected, preserving the radial artery. A gross pathological examination revealed a viscous substance within the cyst. Histopathological analysis confirmed a cystic lesion of the arterial wall. A follow-up echo-Doppler performed 1 year post-procedure showed no signs of artery degeneration.

A: Successful creation of a radiocephalic arteriovenous fistula with resection of a cystic lesion in the radial artery. The fistula is currently functional, and there is no degeneration of the artery observed in follow-up.

P: Continue multidisciplinary monitoring of the fistula and patient's progress. Ensure regular follow-up appointments. The patient should report any changes or concerns to the medical team.

S: The patient is a 64-year-old woman with a history of breast cancer for which she underwent breast-conserving surgery (BCS) and axillary lymph node dissection four years ago. She also received endocrine therapy and radiation therapy. Recently, she noticed a 1-cm dark red nodule in her right breast, which led her to seek medical attention. 

O: A skin biopsy diagnosed the nodule as angiosarcoma. Imaging revealed a mass measuring 27 × 13 mm with markedly thickened surrounding skin in the outer lower lesion of the right breast. Mapping biopsies showed tumor invasion at 2 cm but not at 5 cm and 10 cm from the edge of the nodule. A total mastectomy with extensive skin resection (30 × 22 cm) was performed, following mapping biopsies, with a wide skin graft from the abdominal skin. Pathological examination post-surgery confirmed angiosarcoma with surgical margins free from tumor cells.

A: Angiosarcoma of the right breast post previous breast cancer treatment. Successfully excised with the mastectomy, confirmed by clear surgical margins. No recurrence of the disease has been noted over six years and three months.

P: Postoperative chemotherapy with weekly paclitaxel at a dosage of 80 mg/m² for six cycles was administered. Continued follow-up has shown excellent progress without recurrence. Further follow-up care should monitor for any signs of recurrence or complications from surgery or chemotherapy.

S: The patient was initially discovered to have asymptomatic proteinuria at the age of 3 during a urinary screening in Japan. There is no family history of renal or neurological disorders. At 8 years old, the patient developed nephrotic syndrome without systemic edema, experiencing polyuria (3L/day) and polydipsia. The patient has no neurological manifestations like seizures or developmental delays and achieved developmental milestones within normal limits.

O: At the time of diagnosis, the patient's urine protein to creatinine ratio (UPCR) was significantly elevated at 1.0-1.5 g/gCr initially and 11.5 g/gCr later. Serum albumin was low at 2.1 g/dL, while serum creatinine was 0.97 mg/dL with an eGFR of 46.8 mL/min/1.73m2. Urine specific gravity was 1.008, and urinary beta 2-microglobulin was markedly elevated at 9,269 µg/L. Kidney biopsy showed 13 of 25 glomeruli with segmental or global sclerosis and cellular lesions characterized by glomerular epithelial cell changes. There were no glomeruli with collapse and overlying podocyte hypertrophy, but cystic dilations and interstitial fibrosis were present. Brain MRI and EEG showed no abnormalities.

A: The findings are consistent with focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), as indicated by the biopsy results and the presentation of nephrotic syndrome. No neurological conditions are present.

P: Continue monitoring the patient's renal function and manage as per treatment guidelines for FSGS. Discuss treatment options and ensure regular follow-up to observe for any changes in symptoms. Encourage the patient to report new symptoms or health changes promptly.

S: The patient is a 3-year-old boy with a body weight of 17 kg who has had a cough and febrile illness for 5 days. He was diagnosed with left-sided pneumonia at a regional hospital and started on intravenous Ampicillin. Despite treatment, his respiratory distress worsened, leading to his transfer to the pediatric intensive care unit (PICU), where he developed acute respiratory failure requiring intubation and ventilation.

O: The patient showed signs of respiratory distress, leading to PICU admission. A chest X-ray revealed an effusion and pneumothorax on the left side, necessitating the placement of two chest drains. Culture from chest drain fluid identified Streptococcus pneumonia, and tracheal aspirate PCR detected Influenza H1N1. Chest CT indicated severe necrotizing pneumonia of the left lung with abscess formation and right lung consolidation. The patient's oxygenation status was critical with SpO2 at 75-80%, pH = 7.28, paO2 = 38 mmHg, and paCO2 = 127 mmHg. Mechanical ventilation settings were high, with PIP = 40 cm H2O, PEEP = 10 cm H2O, and FIO2 100%.

A: The diagnosis is severe acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), likely secondary to necrotizing pneumonia and Influenza H1N1 infection. The patient's condition worsened despite high-frequency ventilation and inhaled nitric oxide treatment.
