The patient achieved complete remission, and ongoing monitoring and treatment adjustments were planned.

S: The patient, an 8-year-old boy, has been experiencing pain in his front teeth when exposed to cold water. There is a history of trauma to his teeth due to an accident at age one, leading to a fracture in the crown of the upper right primary central incisor, which was repaired with composite resin. Following treatment, initial pain levels on the VAS were reported as 6 for cold water and 7.5 for air. After multiple treatments, his pain levels are reported as reduced but present, with a VAS of 1-2 for cold water and 2-4 for air.

O: The examination showed an abnormal position of the upper right permanent central incisor with cloudiness on the labial surface. Initial pain was measured with a VAS value of 6 for cold water and 7.5 for air. After seven treatments, the cloudiness remained but the color improved, and there was no discolored devitalized teeth, gingival inflammation, or percussion pain observed. Digital analysis showed a decrease in cloudiness from 27,886 pixels to 7,904 pixels, and a decrease in the slightly brown area. 

A: The likely diagnosis is dental hypersensitivity due to past trauma, with improvements noted post-treatment. The persistence of some symptoms suggests ongoing management might be necessary.

P: Continue treatments once a month to further decrease hypersensitivity, aiming to reduce VAS to around 2. Monitor improvements in cloudiness and provide further assessments. Schedule follow-up appointments to track progress and address any persisting symptoms or concerns.

S: The patient is a 33-year-old Gravida 3 who, at 16 weeks of pregnancy, was found to have a breast tumor during a physical examination. The tumor is an infiltrating ductal carcinoma, grade 3, with irregular margins. The patient expresses concern about her health and the treatment plan during pregnancy.

O: The patient has a breast tumor with a maximum diameter of about 10 cm, clinically negative axilla, and immunohistochemistry showing estrogen receptor-positive (35%), progesterone receptor-positive (85%), HER2/neu-positive (Score 3+), and Ki67 at 37%. Whole-body nuclear magnetic resonance revealed hepatic metastasis in segment V (29 mm) and millimetric metastases in the right iliac bone. Genetic testing was negative for BRCA 1 and 2 mutations. Chemotherapy with epirubicin and cyclophosphamide during pregnancy led to partial breast tumor remission, complete iliac lesion response, but an increase in hepatic lesion size. Post-delivery, treatment continued with trastuzumab and docetaxel, yielding more than 50% breast lesion reduction and reduced hepatic lesion.

A: The patient's breast cancer is aggressive, with hepatic and bone metastases but no BRCA mutations. Despite aggressive disease, the patient experienced a mixed treatment response: partial remission of the breast tumor and iliac lesion but progression of the hepatic lesion. Following delivery, further treatment led to significant reduction in tumor size.

P: The patient will continue with trastuzumab and docetaxel treatment while being closely monitored. Follow-up appointments are crucial for adjusting the treatment plan based on progress. The multidisciplinary team anticipated delivery to manage treatment without harming the child. Continued monitoring and adjustment of treatment are emphasized.

S: The patient reports feeling a lump in the neck near the thyroid but denies experiencing difficulty swallowing, pain, or changes in voice. There is no family history of thyroid or endocrine diseases.

O: Thyroid function tests were normal. Imaging revealed a 2.5 cm nodule in the left thyroid. Biopsy results indicated the lesion as "suspicious for neoplasm." Post-surgery pathology diagnosed papillary thyroid carcinoma with extrathyroidal extension. No metastatic disease was identified. Pathology noted atypical features: infiltrative growth, chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis, classical papillary microcarcinoma focus, weak monoclonal PAX-8 nuclear reactivity, and focal weak TTF-1 reactivity.

A: Papillary thyroid carcinoma with atypical features and extrathyroidal extension. No metastatic disease detected.

P: Proceed with completion thyroidectomy and radioactive iodine therapy. Monitor progress for recurrence. Pathology review requested. Referral to a thyroid expert and follow-up care to ensure best possible outcomes.

S: The patient discovered masses in the left axilla and left supraclavicular area and initially received a diagnosis of poorly differentiated carcinoma (PDC) that was Villin positive. Following this, the patient underwent six cycles of chemotherapy for digestive tract tumors, but the cancer progressed. The gene expression profile suggested metastases potentially originated from breast carcinoma. A pathology consultation indicated PDC with IHC stains such as AE1/AE3+, ER–, PR–, HER-2 0, GCDFP-15–, TTF-1–, and PAX8–. The treatment was changed to address triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC), and the tumors were controlled. At a follow-up 15 months later, space-occupying lesions were discovered in the left breast, and a core needle biopsy confirmed invasive breast cancer.

O: Initial biopsy showed poorly differentiated carcinoma (PDC) with Villin positive. IHC stains indicated AE1/AE3+, ER–, PR–, HER-2 0, GCDFP-15–, TTF-1–, and PAX8–. The gene expression profiling suggested breast carcinoma origin. Follow-up biopsy revealed invasive breast cancer in the left breast.

A: The patient has a history of metastatic poorly differentiated carcinoma with gene expression profiling indicating possible breast carcinoma origin. Subsequent IHC staining supports a diagnosis consistent with triple-negative breast cancer. The follow-up biopsy confirmed invasive breast cancer.

P: The patient will continue to be closely monitored, and treatment plans will be adjusted based on new symptoms or test results. Regular communication with the healthcare team is advised to promptly address any concerns or changes in the patient's condition.

S:  
The patient is a 62-year-old male with IgG kappa multiple myeloma (MM), ISS stage 1, and anemia with a hemoglobin level of 10.3 g/dl. He has two isolated bone lesions in his spine and has been referred to the cancer center for treatment initiation. His medical history includes diabetes mellitus, atopic dermatitis, Bechterew's disease with severe arthrosis of the right hip, causing wheelchair dependency, and a history of nose and gastrointestinal bleeding from angiodysplasia. These bleeding episodes have been managed by local endoscopic interventions. The patient has no family history of bleeding disorders and did not experience significant bleeding during past surgeries.

O:  
Laboratory findings indicate β2-microglobulin at 3.2 mg/l, M-gradient at 0.26 g/dl, serum free light chain ratio of 8.72, and 90% bone marrow infiltration with plasmatic cells. Coagulation tests show VWF: Ag 12%, VWF: Act < 4%, VIII:C 13.6%, aPTT 51s, and prolonged bleeding time with epinephrin > 220sec. The patient's body weight is 65 kilograms. A full body examination revealed no specific findings.

A:  
The primary assessment includes IgG kappa multiple myeloma with anemia and bone lesions. There is also a significant bleeding disorder suggested by laboratory findings, likely related to von Willebrand disease given the low VWF levels and prolonged bleeding times.

P:  
The patient is referred to the department of hemostaseology for further diagnostic evaluation of the bleeding disorder. An appropriate treatment plan for MM will be developed considering the bleeding tendencies. The patient will be closely monitored, and the treatment plan will be adjusted as needed. Follow-up with hematology and oncology is advised, and the patient should contact the healthcare team with any concerns.

S: The patient reports having focal seizures since the age of 5, which begin with a funny feeling, flushing, and head turning to the right. Some seizures terminate at this stage, while others impair awareness or evolve into a bilateral convulsive seizure. The patient was previously treated with several antiseizure medications, which were ineffective in reducing seizure frequency.

O: The patient's MRI showed no structural brain abnormalities. An EMU evaluation documented seizures with a broad right hemispheric onset. The initial MEG recording showed epileptiform activity, but no localizing information was obtained. After VNS implantation, the patient continued to experience seizures. A recent SAM(g2) analysis of MEG recordings identified a consistent right frontal focus. Virtual electrodes correlated MEG epileptiform discharges with scalp EEG.

A: The patient has a history of focal seizures with occasional progression to bilateral convulsive seizures, resistant to medication and VNS treatment. New MEG analysis techniques suggest a right frontal focus of epileptiform activity.

P: The doctor plans to discuss the recent MEG findings with the patient's neurologist to consider potential adjustments to the treatment plan. The patient is advised to continue monitoring and reporting seizure frequency and changes to their healthcare team.

S: The patient, with a history of congenital hydrocephalus and bilateral VP shunt placement, presents with worsening right-sided abdominal distension and dull pain for the past three weeks. The pain is constant and not related to meals. The patient denies fevers, chills, nausea, vomiting, headache, visual changes, changes in urination, constipation, melena, or bright red blood in stools. The patient has a history of a right VP shunt placed in the right lower abdomen, last revised 10 years ago, and a left VP shunt placed in the left lower abdomen, last revised two years ago. There is no history of other abdominal surgeries.

O: The patient appears comfortable, afebrile, with a heart rate of 84 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, blood pressure of 150/80 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 99% on room air. The abdominal exam shows morbid obesity and distension of the right upper and lower abdomen, dull to percussion, minimally tender in the right upper and lower quadrants, without rigidity or tension. There is no erythema or other skin changes over the VP shunt reservoirs. Fundoscopic and neurologic exams, including gait, are unremarkable. A POCUS revealed a large fluid collection with septations in the soft tissue of the right abdominal wall. A CT scan confirmed an abdominal pseudocyst. Test results, including a complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, lipase, and urinalysis, were normal.

A: The diagnostic impression is an abdominal pseudocyst in the context of a right-sided VP shunt with no infectious symptoms or signs of VP shunt malfunction.

P: The plan is to schedule an urgent outpatient revision of the right VP shunt. The patient is advised to contact medical services if there are any concerns or if symptoms worsen.

S: The patient reports experiencing urinary frequency for about 6 months. No history of significant urological abnormalities or other related symptoms such as abdominal pain, vomiting, anorexia, or bowel disturbances.

O: Physical examination shows no palpable abdominal mass. Laboratory tests reveal no specific abnormalities. Abdominal and pelvis CT scan shows a 20 × 11 cm, well-defined, fatty mass located between the abdominal wall muscles and the peritoneum, compressing the bladder.

A: The clinical findings suggest the presence of a large fatty mass likely causing urinary frequency by compressing the bladder. The characteristics of the mass suggest it is a benign lipoma.

P: The patient will undergo a laparoscopic mass excision with preservation of the parietal peritoneum. The surgery involves using two 11-mm ports and a 5-mm port for access, excision of the mass, placement in an endopouch, and extraction. Post-operative recovery includes preservation and fixation of the peritoneum with a closed suction drain, with an expected surgery duration of 90 minutes and no significant blood loss. The patient is expected to be discharged on post-operative day 6. The resected specimen will be analyzed, but it is expected to be a benign lipoma with a clear resection margin.

S: The patient is a 5-year-old girl with no previous medical history. She reports having a right groin mass for 2 months, abdominal swelling for 15 days, and occasional umbilical pain, vomiting, and diarrhea.

O: Physical examination revealed acute facial features, malnutrition, abdominal swelling, and tenderness. A mass of 4 × 3 × 2 cm was palpated in the right inguinal region. Negative Grey Turner and Cullen signs were noted. Laboratory results showed white blood cells at 2.97 × 10^9/L, neutrophils at 47.2%, red blood cells at 4.88 × 10^12/L, platelets at 714 × 10^9/L, and C-reactive protein at 2.06 mg/L. Abdominal CT revealed a significantly dilated pancreatic duct, unclear surrounding pancreatic head space, cystic low-density shadow in the pancreatic head, massive peritoneal effusion, patchy lymph node enhancement and enlargement in the mesentery, intestinal aggregation in the upper abdomen, and thickening and enhancement of the bowel wall. Chest CT showed increased lung markings. Serum lipase was 3167 U/L, serum amylase was 720 U/L, and serum CA-125 was 484.5 U/mL. An abdominal puncture showed red and yellow ascites, qualitative protein positive, no acid-fast bacilli, negative anti-TB antibody, negative PPD and interferon-gamma release assay, no tumor cells, and no bacterial growth after 48 hours.

A: The patient presents with pancreatitis, as indicated by elevated serum lipase and amylase, and has an increased CA-125. There is significant abdominal and pancreatic pathology observed on imaging. The possibility of tuberculosis and tumors was largely ruled out with negative test results.

P: The plan is to continue monitoring the patient's condition closely and treat the pancreatitis and other findings. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to ensure recovery and prevent complications. The patient and family are encouraged to communicate any concerns or questions during the treatment process.

S: The patient is a 19-year-old male who presented with painless hematuria for 5 days. There is no family history of cancer. Post-operatively, the patient developed a fever and intestinal obstruction, which did not improve with conservative management.

O: Physical and systemic examinations were normal, but blood work showed anemia. Renal and liver functions were normal. An ultrasound and CT scan revealed a 7 x 5 cm polypoidal mass in the bladder with no lymph node or visceral metastasis. Histopathology indicated high-grade urothelial carcinoma with six out of seven lymph nodes showing metastasis. A repeat CECT scan showed soft tissue lesions in both lungs, pleural effusion, multiple liver lesions, and ascites indicative of metastasis. Photomicrographs revealed aggressive tumor characteristics. Whole-exome sequencing found 558 exonic somatic mutations, identified in genes like TP53, ABL1, and ARI.

A: The patient was diagnosed with high-grade urothelial carcinoma with metastatic progression to lymph nodes, lungs, and liver. The condition was aggressive and invasive.

P: Recommended robot-assisted partial cystectomy and bilateral lymph node dissection. Genetic analysis performed for detailed evaluation of tumor characteristics. Further management after metastasis involved repeat imaging and continued assessment. No additional treatment plan provided due to disease progression leading to deterioration and eventual demise.

S: The patient reports feeling unwell with discomfort under the right rib.

O: Blood tests indicated severe leukocytosis at 227 × 10^9/L, increased lactate dehydrogenase levels at 969 U/L, and elevated cobalamin levels at 2834 pmol/L. A blood smear showed dominance of myeloid precursor with increased metamyelocytes and rods. The patient has been diagnosed with Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML).

A: The clinical findings are consistent with Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML).

P: Initiate treatment with hydroxyurea and interferon, followed by an allogeneic stem cell transplant (allo-SCT) using a myeloablative conditioning (MAC) regime with busulphan and cyclophosphamide. Employ bone marrow-derived stem cells from the patient's HLA-matched sister, with GVHD prophylaxis using cyclosporine A and methotrexate. Post-transplantation monitoring via PCR analysis for BCR-ABL1 transcripts and biannual evaluations including karyotyping and interphase FISH.

S: The patient reports a single skin nodule on the left cheek, measuring approximately 1.0 x 1.5 cm, with crusting at the left angle of the mouth. These symptoms began in May 2014. The patient has not traveled abroad, only locally to Phitsanulok and Phijit in Thailand.

O: The histopathological analysis of the skin biopsy revealed epidermal ulceration with heavy, chronic inflammation of the dermis, and intracellular small round or oval-shaped bodies consistent with amastigotes of Leishmania species. Further culture in Schneider's insect medium confirmed the presence of motile promastigotes, supporting a diagnosis of cutaneous leishmaniasis.

A: The findings are consistent with cutaneous leishmaniasis, caused by Leishmania species.

P: The treatment plan includes oral amphotericin B at 1 mg/kg/day for 1 day and fluconazole at 200 mg/day for 45 days. The patient is advised to follow the medication regimen closely and to contact the clinic with any questions or concerns during treatment.

S: The patient reports problems with their right eye for about a week, experiencing multi-colored flashes and reduced vision. They have no prior ocular or medical issues but were involved in a road traffic accident about three weeks ago, where their car was rear-ended.

O: Examination revealed the patient's best-corrected visual acuity is 6/12 in the right eye and 6/6 in the left eye. The anterior chamber and vitreous had no issues. A large white deep retinal lesion, extending into the macular area, was observed in the right eye, with defined and less defined borders. SD-OCT showed hyper-reflective sub-retinal changes and small creamy white sub-retinal lesions in the superior macular area. The left eye appeared unremarkable. Investigations for inflammatory and infective pathologies were negative, including normal inflammatory markers, autoimmune screen, serum angiotensin enzyme, chest x-ray, and syphilis testing.

A: The patient is assessed to have commotio retinae in the right eye, likely secondary to a presumed whiplash injury from the road traffic accident.

P: The plan includes follow-up monitoring, with a revisit scheduled in six weeks to observe progress. During follow-up, the patient's symptoms had resolved, and no further interventions were necessary. The patient is advised to monitor for any changes and contact the clinic if further issues arise.

S: The patient reports experiencing diffuse abdominal pain with a high body temperature of over 38 °C, specifically with dull pain in the right upper abdominal quadrant for 4 days. The patient also reports dyspnea. Medical history includes high blood pressure, type 2 diabetes (managed with ramipril 5 mg twice daily and metformin 500 mg three times daily), and a history of bile stones in the gallbladder and common bile duct treated 3 years ago with endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography with papillotomy, laparoscopic cholecystectomy with choledochotomy, and Kehr's T tube placement. Post-operative antibiotics included prulifloxacin 600 mg for 5 days. A subsequent reevaluation with abdominal CT showed no bile leakage or biliary obstruction, and the Kehr's T tube was removed after 2 months.

O: Clinical examination reveals the abdomen is globally painful at palpation with mild tenderness in the right upper quadrant. Chest examination shows bilateral lower diaphragmatic excursion, decreased vocal fremitus, and attenuated sounds at the pulmonary bases. Neurological examination results are normal: the patient is oriented, language and comprehension are good, pupils are equal and reactive to light, visual fields are intact, ocular movements are intact, muscle bulk and tone are normal, and sensation is intact.

A: The patient's symptoms may suggest a potential recurrence of biliary issues or another abdominal pathology such as an infection or inflammation. The presence of fever and right upper quadrant pain raises the suspicion of a biliary or infectious process.

P: Additional tests are needed to identify the underlying cause of the symptoms, including possibly another imaging study (ultrasound or CT) and laboratory tests to evaluate for infection or inflammation. The patient is advised to monitor symptoms and report any worsening. Further instructions will be provided based on test results.

S: The patient reports feeling weak and tired, with trouble breathing and a sensation of their heart racing. They have a history of end-stage heart failure due to Chagas cardiomyopathy, confirmed by serology, and have had multiple hospital admissions over the past year. They were recently admitted to the emergency room for cardiogenic shock and treated with inotropes, an intra-aortic balloon pump, and hemodialysis. The patient has not been previously considered for heart transplantation.

O: Echocardiography shows a severely dilated left ventricle with an end-diastolic diameter of 72 mm, an ejection fraction of 18%, and 4+ mitral regurgitation. The right ventricle has severe dysfunction, 3+ tricuspid regurgitation, tricuspid annular plane systolic excursion of 15, and right ventricular systolic pressure of 65 mmHg. Right heart catheterization revealed a cardiac index of 0.9 L/min/m2, systolic pulmonary pressure of 70 mmHg, transpulmonary gradient of 16 mmHg, pulmonary vascular resistance of 6 Wood units, and elevated filling pressures with central venous pressure and pulmonary wedge pressure of 30 mmHg. The patient was transferred for heart transplantation assessment and is currently supported by percutaneous venous arterial extracorporeal life support (ECLS).

A: The patient is in end-stage heart failure secondary to Chagas cardiomyopathy, with severe biventricular dysfunction. Recent cardiogenic shock and cardiac arrest required cardiopulmonary resuscitation and escalation of vasopressors. The patient’s condition is critical, with ongoing ECLS support. Heart transplantation is being considered as a potential treatment option.

P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition and provide necessary support. Present the patient's case to the heart transplant committee for evaluation and potential listing for heart transplantation. Maintain ECLS until further decisions are made. Engage in regular communication with the patient and address any questions or concerns they may have.

S: The parent reports that Twin 1 had bilateral trigger thumb, and Twin 2 had a trigger thumb and a trigger finger on the opposite hand. Both twins are 6 years and 6 months old. Their younger sister, aged 4 years and 9 months, has a single trigger thumb. There is no history of trauma related to their fingers, and all children have normal motor and sensory function in the affected digits.

O: Treatment for the twins involved an A1 pulley release, including a flexor digitorum superficialis slip release of the affected digit. No issues with motor or sensory function were observed post-treatment.

A: The twins previously had trigger finger and thumb conditions, which have improved following surgical intervention. The younger sister’s single trigger thumb is currently being managed conservatively. There are no signs of trauma or neurological impairment in the children.

P: Continue current conservative management for the younger sister’s trigger thumb. Monitor all children for any changes or new symptoms in their condition. Maintain communication with the healthcare provider for updates and further guidance as necessary.

S: 
The patient reports a long history of substance use, including alcohol, cannabis, cocaine, and amphetamine since teenage years. The patient expresses concerns about how this may be affecting behavior.

O: 
Genetic testing revealed polymorphisms of 5-HTTLPR (fragment 44 bp–SS genotype) and COMT (Leu136Leu) in homozygosity. Toxicology testing showed benzoylecgonine in urine (322 ng/mL) and significant levels of cocaine (141 ng/mg), benzoylecgonine (21 ng/mg), and ethylglucuronide (>30 pg/mg) in pubic hair. No significant levels were found in blood or saliva. Clinical and neuropsychological examinations showed no signs of neurological impairment or alcohol dependence but diagnosed the patient with a personality disorder not otherwise specified. MRI and CT-PET imaging revealed decreased cortical thickness, larger lateral ventricles, and a significant asymmetry of the amygdalae with the right amygdala smaller.

A: 
The patient is diagnosed with a personality disorder not otherwise specified. Findings from genetic tests and imaging suggest potential predispositions to anti-social behavior possibly linked to substance use.

P: 
The patient is advised to seek appropriate treatment and support for the diagnosed personality disorder. Consultation with the legal team and healthcare providers is recommended to address the patient's needs and determine the best course of action moving forward.

S: The patient reports vomiting for the past four days and has difficulty controlling hypertension due to erratic use of antihypertensive medications over the past 25 years. The patient also experiences lower back pain, managed with NSAIDs. The patient has a history of chronic renal insufficiency and a past liver abscess.

O: The patient is afebrile but presents with hypertension (blood pressure 180/100 mmHg) and tachycardia (pulse 160/min). Examination reveals right upper quadrant tenderness with no palpable liver or spleen. Lab results indicate an abnormal white blood cell count with neutrophilia, elevated platelet count, creatinine, blood urea nitrogen (BUN), calcium, and phosphate levels, and abnormal liver function tests. Imaging studies reveal a 11.3 x 8.0 cm heterogeneous mass in the right adrenal gland, normal liver and spleen, no lymphadenopathy, lytic lesions in the left acetabulum, sacrum, iliac blades, lumbosacral and thoracic spine, two nodules in the left lung, and multiple lytic lesions in scapula and vertebrae. Elevated LDH level at 1080 IU/L noted.

A: The patient presents with complex symptoms including uncontrolled hypertension, vomiting, and back pain. Imaging and lab findings suggest an adrenal gland mass, potential bone pathology, and possible metastatic disease. Elevated LDH and renal insufficiency further complicate the diagnosis.

P: Plan to conduct further investigations including a 24-hour urine collection test. The patient is advised to take antihypertensive medications as prescribed and monitor blood pressure regularly. Consultation with specialists is recommended to determine the appropriate treatment strategy based on the results of ongoing investigations.

S: The patient has been experiencing dysphagia and significant weight loss, approximately 10 kg, over the past 3 months. There is a history of osteoporosis and a previous distal gastrectomy performed 40 years ago for a submucosal tumor, identified as an aberrant pancreas at the time of surgery. The patient reports difficulty swallowing and concerns about the condition affecting their overall health.

O: The patient's height is 158.0 cm, weight is 53.6 kg, and BMI is 21.5. Upper gastrointestinal examination revealed no esophagitis or tumor in the upper digestive tract. Enhanced computed tomography (eCT) showed a large hiatal hernia with the stomach sliding into the mediastinum, compressing the heart. Echocardiography showed normal heart function.

A: The patient is diagnosed with a large hiatal hernia causing severe dysphagia, with no indications of cardiac failure. The previous distal gastrectomy was performed without lymph node dissection.

P: Elective surgical repair of the hiatal hernia is recommended to alleviate symptoms. The surgery will be a laparoscopic procedure with five ports placed in the abdomen using a Nathanson liver retractor to retract the left liver lobe. Preoperative instructions will be provided, and the surgery will be scheduled as soon as possible. Follow-up and questions should be directed to the medical staff.

S: The patient is a male who was ejected from the bed of a pickup truck during an accident. He reports landing hard and experiencing significant pain since the incident. He denies any past medical history and reports no additional symptoms beyond leg lacerations and bruising on the hips.

O: Upon arrival, the patient was tachycardic but normotensive and oxygenating adequately on room air. Physical examination revealed an unstable pelvis and lacerations with ecchymoses on the bilateral lower extremities and hips. A digital rectal exam identified a foreign body in the rectal vault. A CT scan showed intraperitoneal bladder rupture, complex pelvic fracture involving the right sacroiliac joint, shattered right acetabulum, complete right femoral neck fracture, and the femoral head lodged in the pelvis. Surgery confirmed the femoral head in the rectal vault with severe disruption to the right lateral rectum, significant hematoma, and fecal contamination communicating with the acetabular fracture.

A: Complex pelvic fracture with associated injuries including intraperitoneal bladder rupture, urethral injury, complete right femoral neck fracture with femoral head in the pelvis, and severe rectal disruption with contamination.

P: The patient underwent exploratory laparotomy and anoscopy, removal of the femoral head, and repair of the bladder. A temporary abdominal closure was performed due to intraoperative critical illness, necessitating ICU resuscitation. The plan includes return to the OR in 24 hours for fecal diversion, further debridement, irrigation, and drainage. Due to persistent sepsis and contamination, a right hip disarticulation was performed. After stabilization, the patient will be transferred to a long-term care facility closer to home.

S: The patient is a gravida 7 para 3, with a past obstetrical history of one vaginal delivery and two cesarean sections. The first cesarean was due to a vulvar herpes simplex infection, and the second was due to placenta previa. The second cesarean involved significant complications including intractable uterine hemorrhage, which was managed with emergency bilateral uterine artery embolization (UAE) and placement of microcoils in the left uterine artery. The patient experienced no complications during postpartum recovery.

O: Current examination includes a transvaginal ultrasonography showing a heterogeneous mass with perivascular flow in the cesarean section scar. Magnetic resonance imaging indicated an endogenic growth of gestational products measuring 33 x 15 mm in the transverse scar of the first cesarean section, with the vertical scar of the second cesarean section observed in the anterior uterine wall. A three-dimensional computerized tomographic angiography showed blood supply from the right uterine artery and an aberrant anastomosing left ovarian artery. The left uterine artery is permanently occluded by platinum microcoils, with persistent microvascular supply.

A: Suspected abnormal placentation with evidence of gestational products embedded in the cesarean section scar and complex blood supply.

P: Continued close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups. An appropriate management plan will be developed to ensure the best possible outcome for the patient and the baby.

S: The patient, during sexual intercourse, suddenly experienced painful swelling in the left hemiscrotum with sharp pain in the left inguinal region. There is a history of bilateral varicocele, but no other comorbidities or coagulation disorders were reported.

O: Examination revealed a soft mass around the left testis and spermatic cord. Laboratory tests were normal. Doppler ultrasonography showed a hematoma extending from the left superficial inguinal ring to the left hemiscrotum, partially surrounding the left testis, with confirmation of bilateral varicocele. An MRI confirmed the hematoma diagnosis. Ecchymosis of the scrotum was noted on the first day of hospitalization.

A: Hematoma extending from the left superficial inguinal ring to the left hemiscrotum is diagnosed, partially surrounding the left testis. Bilateral varicocele is confirmed.

P: Treatment included bed rest, ice packs, antibiotics, and analgesics. The patient was stable and pain decreased gradually by the second day, leading to discharge on the third day. The swelling and ecchymosis are expected to resolve in about 4 weeks. A bilateral varicocele repair was performed uneventfully three months later. Further follow-up is implied but not detailed in the conversation.

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension, abdominal and thoracic aortic aneurysm, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, presented with pain and bruising in the right thigh for 6 days. The patient denied any history of abnormal bleeding, family history of bleeding disorders, or use of anticoagulant medications.

O: On examination, the doctor observed a large subcutaneous hematoma on the anterior aspect of the right thigh. Imaging showed no deep venous thrombosis, but MRI revealed intramuscular bleeding into the anterior compartment of the right thigh. Laboratory tests revealed a low hemoglobin level of 6.8 g/dL, for which the patient received a blood transfusion. Coagulation studies showed prolonged aPTT at 52.5 seconds, normal PT and INR, an uncorrected mixing study, low factor VIII at 2%, and elevated inhibitors at 16 BU.

A: The diagnostic impression is acquired hemophilia A (AHA), suggested by the low factor VIII activity with elevated inhibitor levels and uncorrected aPTT.

P: The patient was treated initially with factor VIIa, Obizur, and methylprednisone; however, with no improvement, treatment with cyclophosphamide and rituximab was initiated, followed by rituximab monotherapy. After the therapy, improvement was evidenced by increased factor VIII levels and reduced thigh hematoma. The patient will be discharged on a prednisone taper, with outpatient follow-up with hematology, and will continue receiving weekly rituximab cycles.

S: The patient reports experiencing non-radiating, dull epigastric pain for two weeks along with fever and chills during dialysis sessions. The patient has a history of ESRD, hypertension, atherosclerotic vascular disease, and has experienced a sudden cardiac arrest with subsequent ICD placement. The patient was previously treated for multiple bacteremias related to an infected dialysis catheter.

O: Observable findings include persistent fever and chills, tachycardia, and episodic hypotension. There is mild tenderness in the epigastric area with no redness, discharge, or pain around the dialysis catheter site. Blood and catheter cultures were positive for S. maltophilia. Elevated troponin and procalcitonin levels were recorded, and a chest X-ray indicated left lower lobe pneumonia. An initial TTE identified an artifact on an abandoned ICD lead in the patient's right heart. Repeated blood cultures remained positive for S. maltophilia.

A: The clinician's assessment included potential infection sources given the positive cultures for S. maltophilia, suspected vegetation due to the artifact seen on echocardiography, and complications like pneumonia and impaired troponin clearance associated with the patient's ESRD.

P: The plan included fluid resuscitation to manage hypotension and initiating intravenous levofloxacin therapy. Cardiology was consulted for persistent elevated troponins, and Infectious Diseases were consulted, resulting in the removal of the infected tunneled dialysis catheter. A TEE was performed to look for a cardiac infection source, and ongoing monitoring and treatment adjustments were planned.

S: The patient reports a mass on the upper part of the right scapula. It has been present for the past few months, is achy, and seems to be getting bigger but does not interfere with daily activities. The patient denies any local injuries, recent surgeries, weakness in either arm, difficulties with overhead activities, or nighttime pain. The patient had a similar mass on the other side 10 years ago that was successfully removed.

O: On examination, the mass is described as firm, nonmobile, nonpulsatile, and located over the scapula. It is longer in the medial to lateral dimension and causes slight tenderness with deep palpation. Shoulder examination shows no signs of rotator cuff weakness or pain with provocative maneuvers. X-ray results indicate narrowing of the posterior glenohumeral joint space with sclerosis due to osteoarthritic changes. The acromiohumeral interval is 8 mm with no superior migration of the humeral head. MRI findings reveal an elongated cystic lesion arising from the AC joint, measuring 2 cm × 13 cm × 1.8 cm, with peripheral enhancement, and a suspected full-thickness tear of the anterior fibers of the supraspinatus.

A: The patient has a firm, nonmobile, cystic lesion over the right scapula, suspected to be related to the AC joint. There are signs of osteoarthritis in the shoulder joint and a suspected full-thickness tear in the supraspinatus tendon. 

P: The plan includes discussing management options for the mass, considering excision as the patient is interested in having it removed. The patient will be referred to a specialist for further evaluation of the mass and the supraspinatus tear. The patient is advised to follow up if any new concerns arise.

S: The patient reported experiencing significant pain in the left lower leg and foot following a high-energy accident. There were visible multiple fractures.

O: Clinical examination along with X-ray and CT-scan revealed multiple fractures: a Gustilo grade IIIB fracture, a medial malleolus fracture, a Tillaux-Chaput fracture, a nutcracker fracture of the cuboid, an avulsion fracture of the navicular bone, fractures of the third, fourth, and fifth metatarsal heads, a mid-shaft fracture of the third proximal phalanx, and base fractures of the first and second proximal phalanx. The patient has preserved active extension and flexion of the toes with intact sensibility except for disturbed touch and pain sensation on the foot sole. No compartment syndrome was noted. An external fixator was placed, debridement performed, and soft tissue defects covered with EpigardTM and dressings. NIRF imaging was conducted postoperatively, showing areas of vital and non-viable tissue. A second debridement was done 2.5 days after the first.

A: The patient has multiple lower leg and foot fractures with some areas of non-viable tissue as indicated by imaging. Sensibility disturbance on the foot sole is noted. No compartment syndrome present.

P: Continue to monitor the healing process closely and consider additional treatments or surgeries as necessary. The patient should follow up with the medical team and report any symptom changes or concerns.

S: The patient reports a head injury from a fall two weeks ago, followed by the development of a mass on the right side of the forehead, which is tender to touch, along with headaches.

O: On physical examination, there is a two-centimeter, soft, pulsatile mass in the right frontotemporal region. An ultrasound with color Doppler reveals a dilated vascular structure with pulsatile, bidirectional flow ("yin-yang" sign). CT angiography with three-dimensional reconstruction confirms a traumatic superficial temporal artery pseudoaneurysm.

A: Traumatic superficial temporal artery pseudoaneurysm due to the head injury.

P: Surgical ligation of the pseudoaneurysm to prevent complications. The patient is advised about the procedure and reassured regarding care during surgery and recovery.

S: The patient reported a sudden onset of severe, sharp abdominal pain. He has a history of hypertension but no history of renal calculus.

O: The patient’s CT scan showed a large left internal iliac aneurysm (6.5 cm in diameter) without signs of rupture or inflammatory aneurysm. Physical examination revealed a blood pressure of 135/75 mmHg, pulse of 90 beats per minute, and temperature of 36.5°C. The abdomen was distended and tender. Laboratory data indicated increased leukocytes (11,400/μL) and normal hemogram, serum electrolytes, blood urea nitrogen (20 mmol/L), and serum creatinine (1.2 mg/dL). Chest X-ray showed no abnormalities. A contrast-enhanced CT scan revealed left hydroureteronephrosis and leakage of iodinated urine in the left-side retroperitoneum indicating a spontaneous ureteral rupture.

A: Spontaneous ureteral rupture due to direct compression of the ureter by a large left internal iliac aneurysm. Hypertension is noted as a contributing factor.

P: The placement of a ureteral double-J stent was performed to prevent graft infection, along with endovascular aortic repair (EVAR) to prevent aneurysmal rupture. Endovascular coil deployment within the left IIA and endovascular stent grafting from the left common iliac were completed. Continuous monitoring and follow-up appointments are recommended to ensure progress and address any issues.

S: Mr. Johnson has a 75-pack year smoking history and rare alcohol use. He presented with a neck mass on the left side but is largely asymptomatic, reporting only slight discomfort. He has been diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) after a biopsy confirmed the diagnosis. No significant symptoms like difficulty swallowing or neck pain have been reported.

O: The PET/CT scan showed hypermetabolic activity in the right aryepiglottic fold and multiple involved ipsilateral lymph nodes, with additional tiny lesions less than 2 mm in the carina and right/left mainstem bronchi not distinct on PET/CT. Biopsies of these lesions confirmed SCC. Pathology showed staining positive for p40 and negative for TTF-1. His cancer is staged as cT2N2bM1.

A: Mr. Johnson has been diagnosed with supraglottic squamous cell carcinoma with metastasis, staged as cT2N2bM1.

P: The treatment plan includes definitive radiation therapy with weekly cisplatin. IMRT will deliver 70 Gy to the primary lesion, 60 Gy to the ipsilateral neck and the remainder of the larynx, 54 Gy to the contralateral neck, and 50 Gy to the tracheobronchial tree. The plan utilizes 4DCT for target volume definition and includes measures to manage organs at risk. Side effects to be monitored include grade 3 esophagitis and a risk of aspiration pneumonia. A follow-up PET/CT scan is scheduled for three months post-treatment.

S: The patient is a 4-year-old boy with Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML). He presented with symptoms including fever, abdominal pain, and hyperleukocytosis. Parents were unaware of an enlarged spleen. His initial treatment with the European protocol LAM 2013/01 showed no response, as his bone marrow aspiration after treatment still had 30% blast cells. The patient was diagnosed with AML with Myelodysplasia-related changes (AML-MDC) and categorized as high-risk due to resistance to induction therapy and monosomy 7. He received multiple cycles of salvage therapy (idarubicin, cytarabine, etoposide, fludarabine, high-dose cytarabine) without response.

O: Objective findings include massive bone marrow invasion with 50% myeloid leukemia cells, absence of CNS invasion, and karyotype analysis revealing monosomy 7. Immunophenotypic analysis showed CD34+ CD117+ CD33− blast cells. On day -3 of conditioning treatment, peripheral blood flow cytometric analysis showed 13% of leukocytes were blast cells (21 blast cells/µL).

A: The patient is assessed with high-risk Acute Myeloid Leukemia with Myelodysplasia-related changes (AML-MDC), resistant to initial and salvage therapies, with persistent blast cells and monosomy 7.

P: The plan involves proceeding with a Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplant (HSCT). Conditioning treatment includes high doses of ARA-C (4 g/m2/die for 5 days), L-PAM (200 mg/m2), and antithymocyte globulin (6.3 mg/kg/die for 3 days) prior to the transplant. Continuous monitoring and treatment adjustments are planned to optimize the patient’s condition for recovery.

S: The patient's daughter has been experiencing left elbow pain and swelling for the past 3 days, following a fall while playing, which resulted in an injury to her elbow.

O: X-ray results indicated a proximal fracture of the ulna with an associated radial head dislocation, consistent with a Monteggia fracture. A successful manipulation and closed reduction were performed, and her elbow was treated with a cast.

A: The patient has a Monteggia fracture of the left elbow. Post-procedure, the reduction was successful, and the elbow has been immobilized with a cast.

P: The patient is to avoid putting pressure on the elbow and rest while it heals. The cast will remain for at least a few weeks. A follow-up appointment is scheduled to monitor recovery and decide on cast removal. The patient should be observed for any complications, and the family should contact the healthcare provider if they have concerns or notice any issues.

S: The patient reports having metastatic angiosarcoma and a history of Gilbert syndrome. They were previously treated with doxorubicin and ifosfamide. The patient started on Pazopanib at 800 mg per day, which led to an increase in total bilirubin to twice the upper limit of normal, prompting a cessation of the medication. Upon stopping, bilirubin levels returned to normal. Restarting Pazopanib at a reduced dose (initially 400 mg, later 200 mg, with a 1-week-on and 1-week-off schedule) has been ongoing for nine months. The patient reports a partial remission of their angiosarcoma since starting this adjusted regimen.

O: The patient's bilirubin increased with initial treatment but normalized after dose adjustment. The current Pazopanib trough concentration (Cmin) is 29.9 mg/L.

A: The patient has metastatic angiosarcoma with partial remission on a reduced dose of Pazopanib. The increase in bilirubin is attributable to Gilbert syndrome, with subsequent management showing stable bilirubin levels after dose adjustment.

P: Continue with the current Pazopanib treatment plan (200 mg per day, 1-week-on and 1-week-off schedule). Monitor symptoms and bilirubin levels regularly. Follow up with the doctor as needed to ensure ongoing management of the angiosarcoma and associated side effects.

S: The patient reports feeling generally unwell with an increased, mostly non-productive cough. There is a known diagnosis of cystic fibrosis (CF) made in adulthood, with a history of bilateral upper zone bronchiectasis and raised sweat chloride level. The patient has co-morbidities including osteoporosis and pancreatic insufficiency, and is receiving maintenance treatment for allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) with oral anti-fungal therapy and long-term low-dose oral corticosteroids. There is a family history of a younger sister who passed away from pancreatitis at 23 years old.

O: The patient's lung function has decreased from a baseline FEV1 of 2.39 L (65% of predicted) to 2.19 L (60% predicted). A recent sputum sample tested positive for non-epidemic Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which is consistent with previous cultures. Serum immunoglobulin testing showed a chronically raised IgG anti-aspergillus of 154 mg/L; other immunoglobulins were within normal limits.

A: The patient has a mild decline in lung function and positive sputum culture for P. aeruginosa. The current presentation aligns with a mild exacerbation given the reported symptoms and test results.

P: The plan includes continued monitoring without immediate treatment due to the mild nature of symptoms and lung function decline. The patient will remain on an alternating inhaled anti-pseudomonal antibiotic regime with tobramycin (TOBI 300mg BD) and aztreonam lysine (Cayston 75mg tds). A follow-up appointment is scheduled in 4 weeks to reassess the patient's condition and adjust treatment if necessary.

S: The patient previously experienced abdominal and back pain with a pulsating sensation in the stomach area due to an infrarenal aortic aneurysm. They were treated with EVAR using a Zenith® LP stent graft. Currently, the patient reports some pain in the lower back.

O: The patient had an infrarenal aortic aneurysm treated with a Zenith® LP stent graft. Follow-up CT imaging revealed a type IA endoleak (EL) with aortic neck dilatation to 30 mm and stent graft migration of 8 mm below the left renal artery.

A: Type IA endoleak with stent graft migration and aortic neck dilatation following previous EVAR for infrarenal aortic aneurysm.

P: The identified type IA endoleak was treated with a proximal cuff stent graft relining and endoanchor suture using 3D-IF guidance. Regular check-ups and imaging tests will be conducted to monitor progress. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or discomfort and maintain a healthy lifestyle, including regular exercise and a balanced diet.

S: The patient is a 33-year-old primigravida at 32 weeks gestation who presents with severe epigastric chest pain, described as constant and 10/10 in severity, predominantly in the right upper abdominal quadrant. She has a history of mild preeclampsia with previous symptoms of lower extremity edema and headache. Over the past two days, she has experienced worsening oliguria and shortness of breath. The epigastric pain was initially attributed to gastroesophageal reflux disorder (GERD), but has since worsened.

O: Initial laboratory tests at 03:52 were unremarkable. However, subsequent tests at 07:21 showed platelets clumped on slide, preventing a count. Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) increased from 183 u/L to 3180 u/L, and Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) increased from 221 u/L to 3495 u/L. A thromboelastogram (TEG) indicated features of coagulopathy. A repeat platelet count was again "unable to perform count, platelets clumped on slide," with AST increasing to 4,059 u/L and ALT to 4,000 u/L. Initial blood pressure on admission was 199/100 mm Hg.

A: The patient is experiencing severe preeclampsia with HELLP syndrome, evidenced by drastically elevated liver enzymes and coagulopathy, as well as hypertension. There is also a high suspicion of thrombocytopenia.

P: The clinical team has decided to proceed with an urgent cesarean delivery. The patient is not a candidate for neuraxial anesthesia due to severe coagulopathy. Blood pressure is being managed with oral labetalol and intravenous hydralazine. Intravenous magnesium is being administered for seizure prophylaxis and treatment of HELLP syndrome.

S: The patient reports experiencing intense intestinal bleeding following the Islamic fasting month, Ramadan. The patient has a history of ulcerative colitis, confirmed by clinical manifestations and a colon biopsy. The patient was on azathioprine and high-dose prednisolone prior to hospital admission, which led to steroid-induced diabetes, necessitating the use of insulin. The patient also has a history of deep vein thrombosis. During hospitalization, the patient experienced progressive periorbital ecchymosis, extensive nasal area edema, nasal ulcer, and significant vision and eye movement issues.

O: The patient's eye examination revealed proptosis, an afferent pupillary defect, no light perception, absolute blindness, ophthalmoplegia, and neurological defects of cranial nerves 2, 3, 4, and 6. Laboratory tests and vital signs showed a fast blood sugar of 302 mg/dL, WBC count of 9460/µl, RBC count of 3.53×106/µl, platelets of 60×103/µl, hemoglobin of 8.9 g/dl, blood urea nitrogen of 35 mg/dL, serum creatinine of 2.3 mg/dl, potassium of 2.1 mg/dL, temperature 38°C, blood pressure 120/70 mm/Hg, pulse rate 80/min, and respiratory rate 14/min.

A: The patient has a history of ulcerative colitis, steroid-induced diabetes mellitus, and deep vein thrombosis. The clinical presentation and laboratory results suggest ongoing complications related to these conditions, as well as severe ocular and neurological manifestations secondary to steroid use and related complications.

P: The patient should continue managing ulcerative colitis and diabetes with prescribed medications and monitor blood sugar levels closely. Follow up with the healthcare team for regular check-ups to ensure conditions are well-managed. Continue anticoagulant therapy for deep vein thrombosis and address vision issues with appropriate ophthalmologic and neurological care.

S: The patient reports experiencing a significant headache with 10/10 intensity, lightheadedness, confusion, and loss of balance since the previous day. There is no significant past medical history.

O: The CT scan showed a hyperdense lesion on the right side of the brain at the level of the peri-pontine cistern. MRI results revealed a 4.1 x 3.3 x 3.2 cm mass in the brain causing mild tonsillar herniation and a mass effect on the brainstem, with patchy enhancement indicating possible hemorrhage or necrosis. Physical examination found a positive Babinski sign bilaterally, with no loss of proprioception or cerebellar function. A subsequent CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis identified a right thyroid nodule and a 2.3 cm renal cyst.

A: The initial assessment was a potential brain neoplasm, likely metastasis rather than primary malignancy. After surgery and consultation at a tertiary care center, the diagnosis was classic medulloblastoma, WHO grade IV, with the tumor composed of densely packed cells.

P: A right suboccipital craniotomy was performed to remove the brain mass. The case was referred for consultation, and the patient was diagnosed. The next step involves discussing treatment plans with the oncology team, emphasizing the importance of early treatment for better recovery chances.

S: The patient reported experiencing gross hematuria on and off for about a year. There was also concern about the results showing urethral mucosa edema, mass, miliary bulging, and bleeding of the membranous urethra from the cystourethroscopy.

O: The patient was admitted to the Department of Nephrology, and various tests including an ultrasound, intravenous pyelography, contrast-enhanced and plain CT scans, and a renal biopsy were performed, though they did not identify the cause of hematuria. A cystourethroscopy in pediatric surgery revealed urethral mucosa edema, mass, miliary bulging, and bleeding of the membranous urethra. A urethral mucosa biopsy indicated submucosal vascular dilatation consistent with UCH.

A: The diagnostic impression was UCH (Urethral Caruncle Hemorrhage) based on the submucosal vascular dilatation findings.

P: The patient received an injection of 4 mg pingyangmycin into the urethral membrane bulge under cystoscopy. A urethral catheter was retained for 3 days post-operation. Follow-ups were conducted at 1 year, 12 years, and 15 years post-treatment, showing no recurrence of hematuria and normal micturition and erectile function. The patient is advised to continue monitoring their health and seek medical attention if concerns arise.

S: The patient reports difficulty breathing, particularly with exertion. History includes a right upper lobectomy and right S6b wedge resection for synchronous double lung cancer 5 years ago. The patient is concerned about current lung health following a CT scan revealing new tumors.

O: CT scan shows metachronous double lung tumors in the right lower lobe (S6a and S9) and left diaphragmatic eventration. S6a tumor is a 27 mm pure ground-glass nodule, and the S9 tumor is a 21 mm solid tumor near a bulla. Chest X-ray confirms these findings. Pulmonary function test (PFT) results: FVC 1.54 L, %FVC 70.0%, FEV1 0.92 L, FEV1/FVC 59.7%, %FEV1 58.6%. Modified Medical Research Council (mMRC) dyspnea score is grade 2.

A: The patient presents with metachronous double primary carcinomas in resectable sites. Poor pulmonary function potentially influenced by left diaphragmatic eventration. Mild dyspnea on exertion.

P: The plan is to perform Video-Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery (VATS) diaphragm plication to potentially improve pulmonary function. Postoperative reassessment will determine candidacy for pulmonary resection to treat lung tumors.

S: The patient was involved in a car accident with major front-end damage, during which the airbags deployed. The patient was unresponsive upon arrival at the hospital and later reported struggling to breathe. 

O: The patient arrived at the hospital unresponsive with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 5. Initial vital signs showed tachycardia with a heart rate of 143 and hypotension with a blood pressure of 71/46. Breath sounds were present bilaterally. A chest X-ray revealed a left-sided hemothorax, confirmed by an output of 1200 mL of bloody fluid from a chest tube. A FAST scan showed no intra-abdominal or pericardial fluid. During surgery, a 3 cm defect in the anterior right atrium was discovered, and the patient experienced significant blood loss of over 6 liters. 

A: The primary assessment revealed significant thoracic trauma with a left-sided hemothorax and a defect in the right atrium resulting in massive hemorrhage. The prognosis was poor due to the extent of blood loss and cardiac injury.

P: Unfortunately, despite surgical intervention including thoracotomy, pericardial opening, cardiac massage, and massive transfusion protocol, the patient's hemorrhage could not be controlled, leading to the patient's demise. No further information on treatments, medications, or follow-up instructions was provided.

S: The patient reports respiratory discomfort. They have a medical history of ALS, diagnosed at age 57, which initially presented with right arm weakness. At age 60, they underwent a tracheostomy and invasive ventilation due to progressive dyspnea.

O: Tests revealed the following: ECG showed negative T waves in V1-V6 and echocardiography indicated decreased wall motion over the apical region. Blood tests indicated increased white blood cells, transaminase, gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase, and C-reactive protein. An abdominal CT scan showed wall thickening of the common bile duct.

A: The patient was diagnosed with acute cholangitis, which was believed to be contributing to the respiratory discomfort. The respiratory symptoms were related to the infection of the bile duct.

P: The patient was treated with antibiotics for acute cholangitis. Progress was monitored until the wall motion abnormality and other symptoms resolved. The patient was discharged from the hospital with instructions to follow up with their regular doctor and to report any return of symptoms.

S: The patient is a 34-year-old primigravida mother who initially reported feeling anxious due to her first pregnancy. Around 33 weeks of gestation, she noted discomfort and some changes. She became aware of issues concerning polyhydramnios and fetal limb deformities, which further worried her. Post-surgery, she recovered quickly but expressed concern for her newborn daughter.

O: The patient had normal first-trimester morphology scan results and a low-level risk for chromosomal aneuploidies. TORCH screening was negative for acute or recent infections. At 22 weeks, the second-trimester scan showed a normally developed female fetus. By 33 weeks, polyhydramnios and signs of minor clubfoot were observed, alongside an altered fetal biophysical profile. At 36 weeks, concerning fetal heart rate decelerations and abnormal fetal movement led to a decision for premature delivery by emergency C-section. The newborn weighed 2200 g with an APGAR score of 3 and showed impaired movement, breathing, and swallowing, requiring mechanical ventilation.

A: The initial pregnancy was not high-risk but developed into a high-risk condition due to polyhydramnios, fetal limb deformities, and deteriorating fetal biophysical profile. The infant is experiencing significant respiratory distress and impaired muscular functions post-delivery.

P: The plan involves continued monitoring and providing the best possible care for the newborn. The care team is preparing for potential respiratory failure while supporting the family through this challenging period. The medical team will maintain open communication with the family for any questions or support needed.

S: Adriana Katherine, a 26-year-old female, presents with a headache lasting for about three days. The headache is described as dull, occasionally sharper, predominantly around the right eye, and persistent though varying in intensity. It is rated as an 8/10 in severity. Symptoms include sensitivity to light and the occasional appearance of shooting lights, but no vision loss. She reports feeling sick but has not vomited, and mentions difficulty focusing. She has no history of fever, rash, or neck stiffness. Ibuprofen has not alleviated her symptoms this time, unlike previous episodes. No recent head injuries were reported. Family history reveals her mother and sister suffer from migraines. Adriana wears glasses but has not had a recent eye exam. She perceives some stress at work due to a new project.

O: No information provided.

A: The clinical presentation suggests a possible migraine, considering the headache's nature, family history, and associated photophobia and visual disturbances.

P: Increase Ibuprofen dose to two tablets, three times a day, or consider prescribing Naproxen. Additional painkillers like Paracetamol or Codeine may be used as needed. Advise keeping a headache diary to identify potential triggers. Schedule a follow-up in one to two weeks or sooner if symptoms worsen. Discuss prophylactic migraine treatment if headaches persist or become more frequent. If there are issues with vision or limb weakness, Adriana should return immediately.

S: The patient reports recurrent wheezing and breathlessness during exercise for several months five years ago, along with a history of allergic rhinitis. The patient has been experiencing recurrent petechia on the lower limbs once per year over the past three years. Recently, the patient has had a one-month history of lower extremity numbness, arthralgia, myalgia of lower limbs with claudication, without fever, edema, fatigue, weight loss, or trauma.

O: Tests performed include chest CT, CTA, bronchoscopy, and echocardiography. Serum eosinophil level was elevated at 6.8 × 10^9/L (reference 0–0.8 × 10^9/L), and IgE was elevated at 1128 IU/mL (reference 0–165 IU/mL). Spirometry showed reversible airway obstruction with a ≥ 12% increase in predicted FEV1. Physical examination revealed decreased sensation in the lower extremities.

A: The patient was diagnosed with asthma, which was initially refractory to treatment but eventually controlled with double inhaled glucocorticosteroid and leukotriene modifier. Despite withdrawal of asthma medication, allergic rhinitis persisted, and eosinophil levels intermittently elevated. Current symptoms of lower extremity numbness, arthralgia, and myalgia with claudication are noted.

P: Continue monitoring the patient’s condition and discuss further steps for the treatment plan. No specific treatments or additional tests were mentioned in the conversation.

S: The patient reports a history of being diagnosed with primary Merkel cell carcinoma (MCC) on the forearm 3 years ago, treated with surgery and adjuvant radiation therapy. Currently, the patient is experiencing recurrent, metastatic MCC involving the liver, bones, and disseminated lymphadenopathy. The patient has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, coronary artery disease treated with stenting, gastroesophageal reflux, and mild cerebral palsy without limitations on activities of daily living. Medications include lisinopril, simvastatin, aspirin, omeprazole, and zolpidem. Seven days after receiving dual immune checkpoint blockade (ipilimumab and nivolumab), the patient experienced diffuse muscle aches, urinary retention, abdominal distention, and gagging sensations when swallowing. Oxycodone 5 mg every 4-6 hours has been providing some relief.

O: The physical exam noted a stable speech impediment. A CT scan revealed air-filled loops of small and large bowel and an increased stool burden in the right colon, consistent with the patient’s symptoms.

A: The patient’s symptoms of muscle aches, urinary retention, abdominal distention, and swallowing difficulties began after immunotherapy, suggesting possible adverse effects related to treatment. The CT findings support these symptoms.

P: Continue supportive care during hospitalization to manage symptoms, particularly focusing on gastrointestinal distress and other adverse effects. Monitor progress closely and adjust care as needed. Provide pain relief with oxycodone. Encourage the patient to express any questions or concerns during the hospital stay.

S: The patient is a two-month-old infant with a left postauricular mass present since birth. The mass has been painless but slowly growing. Initially evaluated via ultrasound, it was suspected to be a cystic mass, leading to a referral for surgical excision. Postoperatively, the patient developed an infection, which resolved after an intra-washout.

O: On physical exam, a 2 × 2 cm firm subcutaneous lesion was found. MRI revealed a 2.3 × 1.4 × 2.2 cm solid mass involving the outer table of the right temporal bone with intense peripheral enhancement. Pathology reports from initial resection and repeat resection indicated tumor cells at the margins. The lesion exhibited significant regrowth, and a revision mastoidectomy with full-thickness craniectomy was performed. Post-operation, the patient developed an incision site infection, which resolved after an intra-washout. At a six-month follow-up, there was no evidence of disease.

A: Persistent and recurrent postauricular mass with initial incomplete resection margins. Infection developed postoperatively which resolved with treatment. Successful resolution of the mass after the final surgical intervention and no recurrence of disease at six-month follow-up.

P: Continue close monitoring and follow-up to ensure no recurrence of the disease. Maintain vigilance for any new symptoms or changes in the patient’s condition.

S: The patient was diagnosed with melanoma on the right arm in March 2012, classified as Clark IV with a Breslow thickness of 2.5 mm. In August 2013, they began treatment with DTIC and carboplatinum for metastatic melanoma at stage VIM1c. After two cycles, the patient reported not feeling well and was told they had a progressive disease with two MBM found. In March 2014, two new asymptomatic MBM were diagnosed. Over several months, the patient noticed an increase in size and swelling of the right frontal MBM.

O: Initial melanoma was Clark IV with a Breslow thickness of 2.5 mm. In August 2013, two MBM were found indicating disease progression. MRI findings in March 2014 showed new asymptomatic MBMs. Observations later revealed an increase in perilesional edema. In January 2015, both MBM and edema increased further, leading to surgical resection and confirmation of radiation necrosis. Post-surgery, the patient stopped corticosteroids.

A: The patient initially had melanoma which progressed to metastatic melanoma with MBM. Initial treatment with DTIC and carboplatinum was followed by stereotactic radiotherapy for MBM. Despite initial treatment, the disease remained progressive, requiring systemic treatment with fotemustine and later pembrolizumab. Post-surgical intervention showed radiation necrosis, and current evaluations report no active disease.

P: Continue treatment with pembrolizumab. Regular monitoring and follow-up are necessary to adjust treatment as needed. There are no current active intracranial or extracranial diseases. Further evaluations and MRI scans may be scheduled as part of ongoing management.

S: The patient reports experiencing chest pain for the past 2 hours. The pain is described as left-sided, non-pleuritic, non-radiating, retrosternal, and squeezing, rated 9/10 in intensity. The patient took nitroglycerin, which provided relief. Associated symptoms included shortness of breath, dizziness, and sweating. There was no loss of consciousness, cough, palpitations, or extremity swelling. A similar chest pain episode occurred a week ago, relieved by Aspirin, with normal troponin, EKG, and echocardiogram results. The patient has a history of poorly-controlled type 2 diabetes, hypertension, dyslipidemia, and obesity. No recent illicit substance use was reported.

O: Pulse rate is 84 bpm, blood pressure is 119/66 mm/Hg, respiration rate is 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Troponin level is elevated at 0.19 ng/ml. Hemoglobin is 14.4 g/dl, and platelet count is 210 × 10³/ul. The EKG shows deep T wave inversions in leads V1-V6 and inferior limb leads.

A: The patient's presentation suggests a non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI).

P: The patient has been given a loading dose of Aspirin (325 mg), Plavix (300 mg) orally, Atorvastatin (80 mg), and a weight-based dose of Enoxaparin in the ER. Monitoring of the patient’s condition will continue to determine further treatment options.

S: The patient is a 44-year-old Caucasian male who received a kidney transplant from an unrelated living donor. He reports feeling okay overall since the transplant. Six months after the transplant, his medication was changed from everolimus to cyclosporine due to joint pain, which improved subsequently. Fourteen months post-transplant, he noticed increased fatigue and foamy urine, indicating possible worsening of kidney function.

O: Baseline post-perfusion allograft biopsy was unremarkable. Initial serum creatinine was stabilized at 1.6 to 1.8 mg/dL, and urine protein/creatinine ratio was less than 0.5 g/gram. Medication was changed from everolimus to cyclosporine due to arthralgias with specific target levels for cyclosporine. Recent lab findings show abrupt worsening of graft function, increased proteinuria, active urine sediment, elevated rheumatoid factor (1650 IU/ml), negative cryoglobulin test, kidney biopsy showing 18 enlarged glomeruli with diffuse endocapillary proliferative glomerulonephritis, strong staining for C4d, IgG, kappa, IgG kappa monoclonal spike (214 mg/dl), serum free kappa light chains 189 mg/L, free lambda light chains 75 mg/L, kappa:lambda ratio of 2.5, complements C3 126 mg/dl, and C4 38 mg/dl.

A: The patient is experiencing a recurrence of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) in the transplanted kidney, indicated by increased proteinuria, elevated rheumatoid factor, and biopsy findings.

P: The plan includes closely monitoring the patient's kidney function and adjusting the medication regimen as needed. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to ensure optimal care and management of the condition.

S: The patient reports experiencing confusion, apathy, difficulty finding words, right-sided weakness, and gait imbalance for about a week. Additionally, the patient has had similar episodes over the past 3 months. There is a history of seropositive rheumatoid arthritis (RA) diagnosed in 2015, managed with methotrexate, hydroxychloroquine, and low-dose prednisone (10 mg daily).

O: Neurological examination revealed decreased attention span, severe expressive aphasia, bilateral postural tremor, right hemiparesis, hypoesthesia, and a shuffling, wide-based gait. A Gadolinium-enhanced head MRI showed areas of scattered restricted diffusion and enhancement within the cortex and leptomeninges of the left hemisphere near the vertex. CSF analysis revealed 6 WBCs with 85% lymphocytes and 15% monocytes, elevated protein concentration at 0.86 g/L, and normal glucose content. CSF bacterial and fungal cultures, cryptococcal antigen, herpes simplex virus, and syphilis testing were negative. Serum C-reactive protein was elevated at 135 mg/L. Antinuclear antibodies, anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies, HIV, and anti-onconeural antibodies were negative. Methotrexate blood levels were within the nontoxic range, and IgG4-subclass titers were normal. QuantiFERON-TB testing was negative. Serum ACE level was mildly elevated at 66 U/L.

A: The clinical findings and MRI suggest suspected meningoencephalitis. Absence of synovitis and extra-articular RA involvement were confirmed.

P: Plan to monitor the patient's condition and develop a treatment approach to address neurological symptoms. Regular follow-up appointments are recommended to ensure proper management.

S: The patient is a nurse with no previous hospitalizations, no medication use, and no smoking history. She was asymptomatic before a solitary pulmonary nodule was found on a chest X-ray during a pre-surgical assessment for an inguinal hernia. She reports no symptoms of fatigue, unintended weight loss, or changes in bowel habits.

O: The patient’s chest X-ray revealed a 2 cm solitary pulmonary nodule in the right mid-lung. Her physical examination showed a temperature of 36.7°C, blood pressure of 138/78 mm Hg, heart rate of 76 bpm, and oxygen saturation of 98%. Her blood tests were normal, except for an elevated C-reactive protein level of 83 mg/dL. A thoracic CT scan showed ground glass opacities.

A: The presence of a solitary pulmonary nodule raises suspicion of a primary lung tumor or metastasis. The elevated C-reactive protein indicates inflammation, though not specific to any condition.

P: The plan involves further investigation of the pulmonary nodule with the results of the thoracic CT scan. The healthcare team will discuss findings to determine the appropriate course of action. Follow-up will be arranged to ensure the patient receives adequate care based on the outcomes.

S: The patient is a 19-year-old high school student referred for treatment of ICD-10 F41.2 mixed anxiety and depressive disorder with symptoms of anorexia nervosa. The patient previously received treatment at a private adolescent psychiatric clinic for anorexia nervosa. The patient has high familial academic expectations, particularly from her father, which led to stress and an eating disorder after discovering her father's affair at age 13. S: The patient reported developing flushing and urticaria 15 minutes after eating pineapple. They experienced chest pain radiating to the left shoulder, palpitations, and excessive sweating. S: The patient is a 43-year-old primipara at 19 gestational weeks, experiencing severe hypertensive disorder and worried about the pregnancy's impact on the baby.

S:  
The patient, a 74-year-old man, reports experiencing weakness, low blood pressure, and melena. He has a history of recurrent peptic ulcer disease.

O:

P:  
Successful coil embolization was performed on the replaced GDA. The plan includes monitoring liver function due to mild transaminitis and focusing on recovery. Further treatment and recommendations will be provided as needed, with an emphasis on following prescribed treatments and monitoring for any symptoms or concerns.

S: The patient reports feeling very tired, losing their appetite, and experiencing dark stools for the past 3 months. They have been informed that melena was found during a rectal examination.

The surgery involves accessing the lesser sac, examining the tumor for vascularity, and removing it via a gastrotomy. Additional measures during surgery will be taken to manage potential bleeding from the ulcer, using bipolar energy or instrumentation as needed. The patient will be prepared and scheduled for the procedure.

S: The patient reports progressive severe low back pain, difficulty walking, requiring a cane, and sensory loss below the knees. He experiences urinary incontinence and chills without fever. P: The plan includes consulting with a specialist for management of the spinal lesions and monitoring the patient's symptoms for any changes or worsening conditions.

S: The patient is a 19-year-old Hispanic female who reports experiencing eruptions on her hands and forearms for about one year. P: The doctor recommends monitoring the symptoms and reaching out if there are any changes or concerns. No immediate further intervention is required given the benign nature of the condition. All test results are within the normal range, providing reassurance to the patient.

S: The patient reports being diagnosed with ITP and experiencing persistent epistaxis, thrombocytopenia, and wet purpura. P: Continue weekly dosing of romiplostim 230 µg. Monitor platelet counts and symptoms consistently. Contact healthcare provider for any changes or complications in symptoms or if platelet counts fall outside the stable range. Maintain regular follow-up appointments to assess management effectiveness.

S: The patient, a 9-year-old overweight Hispanic male, reports experiencing right lower quadrant (RLQ) abdominal pain for 2 days and a fever for 1 day. Initially, the pain was intermittent and mild, relieved by Pepto-Bismol, but worsened on the day of admission, becoming constant and exacerbated by walking, causing a limp. He has been attending school despite discomfort and has a reduced appetite. He experienced mild nausea on the day of admission, with no vomiting or changes in bowel habits noted.

A CT scan shows a normal appendix, moderate inflammation of the fatty structure around the anterior ascending colon, mesenteric edema, and pelvic ascites.

S: The patient is a 54-year-old woman with cirrhosis due to excessive alcohol intake. She has been experiencing symptoms of ascites, which has been difficult to manage with medical treatments alone. A: The patient has cirrhosis with complications of ascites and has been effectively managed with an alfapump system pre-transplant. Post-procedural complications included leakage from the incision site, bladder spasms, and cellulitis, which were resolved with appropriate interventions.

P: Continue monitoring the patient's liver function and general health post-transplant. Encourage regular follow-up appointments with the healthcare team to ensure recovery and address any potential post-transplant complications or concerns.

S: The patient is a 30-year-old male with a history of smoking (1 pack per day for 10 years) and external hemorrhoids.
