Holter monitoring showed no pauses. Renal ultrasound/Doppler indicated increased parenchymal echogenicity. CT abdominal aortogram revealed a large thrombus in the abdominal aorta starting at the level of the renal arteries, occluding the aorta and common iliac arteries.

A: The patient has severe hypertension with complete heart block, moderate hypokinesia of the left ventricle, moderate concentric LVH, and grade 2/4 diastolic dysfunction. There is evidence of renal parenchymal disease, and a significant thrombus in the abdominal aorta is noted.

P: The medical team will develop a comprehensive treatment plan to manage hypertension, complete heart block, and the thrombus in the abdominal aorta. Continuous monitoring and follow-up appointments are crucial. Antihypertensive medications have been initiated, and further treatments will depend on ongoing evaluation and the patient’s response to the current management strategy. The patient is advised to attend all follow-up appointments and adhere to medical recommendations.

S: The patient is a 79-year-old woman with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and osteoporosis. She reports having a fever for a few days and swollen, puffy legs. She denies any symptomatic visual impairment and has never experienced severe hypertension in the past.

O: The patient was observed to have bilateral pitting edema in both lower extremities, a body temperature of 37.8°C, and a blood pressure of 177/105 mmHg. Further differential diagnoses may include other causes of kidney dysfunction and hematological disorders.

P: Hemodialysis has been initiated to manage her condition. Continuous monitoring of her symptoms and laboratory findings will guide further adjustments to the treatment plan. Follow-up care will focus on managing thrombocytopenia, renal function, and any additional emerging symptoms or complications.

S: The patient, a 25-year-old individual, reports concerns about their health and growth history. P: The management plan includes working on communication and social skills, and seeking support from a therapist or support group. Regular check-ups with a healthcare professional are recommended to monitor progress and address any emerging concerns.

S: The patient reports continuous abdominal pain that worsens in the orthostatic position, along with abdominal distension, nausea, and vomiting. These symptoms have prompted an admission to the pediatric emergency department.

P: The recommended treatment was tumor removal by surgery, which was successfully performed. Post-surgical monitoring and evaluation are planned to ensure recovery and address any further concerns.

S: The patient reports experiencing headaches, nausea, fatigue, and blurred vision for approximately one month.

O: Physical examination and CT scan revealed pericardial inflammation and splenomegaly (spleen enlargement by 2 cm). S: The patient, one month post-cadaveric kidney transplant, reports feeling more tired than usual and experiencing frequent thirst and urination. S:

O: 
No specific observable findings, vitals, or test results were provided in the conversation. However, the patient's Gd levels took two more years of chelation therapy to decrease significantly.

A:
The patient's MS symptoms have significantly improved, and Gd levels have decreased with continuous chelation therapy. Currently in good general health, with an improved EDSS score indicating no disability related to MS.

P: 
The patient continues chelation therapy twice a year and maintains a glucose-free diet along with specific supplements. The doctor recommends maintaining the current healthy lifestyle and encourages the patient to reach out if there are any concerns or questions. Continued monitoring of health and regular assessments of Gd levels may be implied.

S: The patient reports experiencing breast pain, abdominal distension, and weakness for about a week. She has no significant individual, gynecological, or family medical history to report.

S: The patient has a history of renal failure and is currently on dialysis. They were referred for an evaluation for transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR).

S: The patient reports having fever and fatigue for two months, along with a 15-pound weight loss, night sweats, and cervical lymphadenopathy. O: Upon admission, the patient was febrile, with a temperature of 38.6°C, a heart rate of 135 bpm, a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and blood pressure of 115/85 mmHg. The findings are also suggestive of a significant inflammatory response or autoimmune process, but malignancy and specific infectious causes have been largely ruled out.

P: The plan involves close monitoring of the patient's condition and further investigation to determine the underlying cause of symptoms. Consideration of antiviral treatment for Epstein-Barr virus if deemed necessary. Symptom management will be prioritized to ensure patient comfort, with regular updates provided to the patient regarding their condition and treatment plan.

S: The patient reported right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and dark urine. These symptoms were uncomfortable and prompted evaluation.

O: The physical examination revealed jaundice and tenderness in the right upper quadrant. Test results showed elevated total bilirubin at 20.2 mg/dl (direct component 15.0), normal albumin, INR of 1.0, AST at 55 U/L, ALT at 43 U/L, and ALP at 148 IU/L. P: The patient was treated with intravenous piperacillin/tazobactam and underwent ERCP with biliary stent placement. The patient improved clinically post-treatment. A referral was made for a repeat ERCP with digital cholangioscopy. Surgical intervention involved a laparoscopic converted to open right hepatectomy. Future monitoring and follow-up are planned to ensure recovery and monitor for any recurrence of abnormal cell growth.

S: The patient has had a painless right scrotal mass for the past two years. He describes the mass as elastic and hard, with no translucency. He has not taken any medications for this condition.

O: The contralateral scrotum examination revealed normal testis and epididymis. Laboratory tests showed that testicular tumor markers (AFP and beta hCG) were not elevated. P: An emergent high radical orchiectomy was performed with minimal bleeding, and the patient was discharged on the second postoperative day. Follow-up included CT scans and tumor marker (SCC) tests. At six months post-operation, SCC levels are within the normal range. Continued monitoring and follow-up tests or treatments as necessary.

S: The patient reports a one-year history of exophthalmia in the left eye without any nasal symptoms, trauma, or systemic disease. O: During rhinoscopy, a well-defined, smooth pink mass was found at the level of the left ethmoidal sinus. The lesion pushes the eye and surrounding muscles, causing grade I exophthalmia, and displaces the nasal fossa, septum, and ethmoidal roof, leading to fluid retention in the left maxillary sinus and narrowing of the optical channel. The frontal and sphenoidal sinuses are unaffected.

A: Recurrence of aneurysmal cyst in the left ethmoidal sinus with associated anatomical changes causing exophthalmia and nasal obstruction.

P: A surgical intervention is planned to remove the tumor completely using an endoscopic approach with ENT navigation assistance. The procedure will include excision of the tumor along with the orbital medial wall and its periorbita. The excised tissue will be sent for histopathological examination to confirm removal and to assess further treatment options. Follow-up includes postoperative monitoring and readiness to address any additional treatment requirements based on histopathology results.

S: The patient has been experiencing chronic lumbar pain for ten years, aggravated by physical labor. Four months ago, they developed severe low back pain and numbness in the left leg, extending from the left hip to the foot. Recently, they had an uncontrolled lumbar sprain and difficulty with excretion.

O: Physical examination revealed tenderness in the low lumbar spine, hypesthesia to pinprick in the L5 and S1 dermatomal distribution, and a positive straight leg raising sign. During surgery, a membranous structure and clot organization compressing the dura sac were discovered and subsequently removed. No infection was found.

A: The patient’s condition was a result of lumbar spondylolisthesis, spondylolysis, disc protrusion, and lumbar stenosis causing nerve root compression. The post-surgical complication of a gas pseudocyst compressing the dura sac was resolved with debridement surgery.

P: Continue monitoring the patient’s progress with follow-up appointments and check-ups. Advise the patient to report any new symptoms or worsening pain immediately for further assessment.

S: The patient reports feeling very weak today and had a low-grade fever yesterday. They ate a lot before going to bed. The patient denies having palpitations, hand tremors, abdominal pain, diarrhea, body weight loss, numbness of limbs, or any similar previous attacks in themselves or their family.

O: During the physical examination, the patient’s blood pressure is 121/63 mmHg, body temperature is 36.6 °C, pulse rate is 102 beats per minute, and respiration rate is 18 breaths per minute. There is decreased muscle power noted, especially in the lower extremities, but no flaccid paralysis or areflexia. Lab tests reveal marked hypokalemia (2.2 mmol/L), mild hypomagnesemia (1.8 mg/dL), renal potassium wasting with a TTKG of 7.02, and FeK of 7.12. Hormonal profile shows low TSH levels (< 0.0025 uIU/mL) and elevated free tetraiodothyronine levels.

A: The patient is experiencing muscle weakness potentially due to marked hypokalemia and mild hypomagnesemia, along with signs of potential thyroid dysfunction.

P: Initiate potassium supplementation with KCl infusion, administering 20 mEq of KCl in 500 mL of normal saline at a rate of 120 mL/h. Monitor serum potassium levels, aiming for correction within 4 hours (totaling 19.2 mEq of KCl). Observe for improvement in symptoms and reassess thyroid function for potential treatment adjustments. Follow up to monitor progress and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: An eight-year-old girl has been experiencing asymptomatic swelling in the lower lip's labial mucosa for about four months. The swelling is silver blue, translucent, 0.70 cm in size, and located opposite the right mandibular canine. It has changed in size and color but has not caused pain or discomfort. No significant medical history or known allergies. No incidents of lip trauma or habit of lip biting were reported.

O: The examination revealed a 0.70 cm silver blue, translucent swelling on the lower lip opposite the right mandibular canine.

A: The swelling appears to be asymptomatic and not causing issues currently. The differential could include a benign cyst or mucocele based on the description and location.

P: Monitor the swelling for any significant changes in size, color, or if it starts causing discomfort. If such changes occur, a follow-up appointment should be scheduled for reassessment. No immediate intervention is necessary at this time.

S: The patient is a 70-year-old woman admitted to the cardiovascular department with chest distress lasting 11 hours, shortness of breath at rest, and difficulty laying in the recumbent position. She has a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus and is on oral medication for these conditions. Three days post-coronary angiography and stent implantation, she experienced hematochezia without abdominal pain.

O: Physical examination revealed mild abdominal tenderness, particularly in the left lower quadrant, and signs of peritoneal irritation with a neoplasm-like mucous clot in the anus. Laboratory tests showed decreased hemoglobin levels (102 g/L), prolonged prothrombin time (13.4 s), and an international normalized ratio of 1.2. Colonoscopy identified a submucosal mass in the sigmoid colon with partial mucous membrane rupture and clots causing obstruction. An abdominal CT scan confirmed a submucosal hematoma in the sigmoid colon and thickening at the left flexure of the colon suggesting another hematoma.

A: The patient was initially diagnosed with coronary atherosclerotic heart disease and underwent coronary angiography and stent placement. Postoperative complications include hematochezia potentially linked to anticoagulant therapy, with subsequent findings of a submucosal hematoma in the colon contributing to her symptoms.

P: The current treatment plan involves discontinuation of anticoagulant medications, administration of total parenteral nutrition, and close monitoring. The conservative approach did not resolve symptoms, so further evaluation and potential treatment options will be discussed with the patient.

S: Ayrton Warren, a 41-year-old male, reports waking up with a severe headache on the left side of his head, which is a new occurrence as he typically experiences headaches concentrated at the front. The headache began around 5:30 AM and persists. Ayrton has a history of anxiety for which he takes Sertraline. He is experiencing some sensitivity to light and had dizziness upon waking, but no nausea or neck stiffness. There is no family history of migraines, but work-related stress has been present for the past two months leading to late nights. He denies any thoughts of self-harm.

O: No physical examination or vital signs were conducted or provided.

A: The clinician suspects the headache could be a tension headache likely due to work stress and anxiety, or possibly a migraine, given the one-sided nature and light sensitivity.

P: The clinician recommends starting Ibuprofen, as it is more effective for migraines, and suggests continuing Paracetamol if desired. The patient is advised to take time off work to reduce stress, consider counseling services, ensure adequate sleep (7-8 hours per night), and maintain proper hydration (1.5-2 liters of water daily excluding caffeinated beverages). A follow-up is recommended in one week, with instructions to seek further evaluation if symptoms worsen or do not improve.

S: The patient reports experiencing left nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and self-resolving episodes of nosebleeds for about a year. The patient was previously treated for presumed nasal polyps and sinusitis without improvement. The patient has a history of hypertension but denies tobacco or alcohol use and has not undergone any radiation treatments.

O: Physical examination revealed a mass filling the left nasal cavity. No palpable cervical lymphadenopathy or neurological deficits were noted, with cranial nerves II to XII intact. CT and MRI results identified a large, enhancing soft tissue mass (6.1 x 4.9 x 4.1 cm) centered in the sphenoid sinus, with invasion of the base of the skull and destruction of the greater wings of the sphenoid. The mass extended into the left masticator space, involved the sellar region, cavernous sinus, and internal carotid artery canals, and caused complete opacification of the left nasal cavity and maxillary sinuses. A biopsy showed well-vascularized sheets and cords of uniform round cells, positive for synaptophysin, chromogranin A, CD56, and cytokeratin AE1/AE3.

A: The findings are suggestive of a malignant neoplasm with neuroendocrine differentiation. Further evaluation will be necessary to determine the specific histological diagnosis and appropriate management.

P: A transnasal biopsy was recommended and performed. The next steps involve discussing treatment options based on the biopsy results and considering the patient's overall health. Continuous monitoring and adjustments to the treatment plan will be made as needed.

S: The patient reports a painless lump on the forehead that has been present for about 3 months, initially believed to be a pimple, but it grew and became painful. The patient is a driver by occupation and is concerned about the impact of the condition on their job.

O: Examination reveals a hard, fixed, and tender lump on the forehead. A CT scan shows the lesion involves both the outer and inner tables of the frontal bone. A biopsy indicates pleomorphic tumor cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm, prominent nucleoli, and cells arranged in trabecular and solid patterns. A whole-body 18F-FDG-PET scan shows a highly avid lesion in the right liver lobe and other avid foci in the liver, lungs, and dorsal vertebrae. Liver function tests and other routine investigations are normal. AFP level is 6889 ng ml−1. Immunohistochemistry is positive for HepPar1 and CD10; negative for TTF-1, CEA, ALK-1, LCA, S-100, vimentin, and chromogranin. The patient is seropositive for HBsAg and negative for HCV.

A: The findings suggest a metastatic process likely originating from a hepatic primary lesion, given the elevated AFP and positive HepPar1 staining, along with liver lesions seen on imaging.

P: Conduct further discussions with the patient regarding treatment options, lifestyle changes, and effects on occupation. Focus on the management plan based on confirmed diagnosis and include regular monitoring of response to treatment. Consider multidisciplinary care involving oncology specialists.

S: The patient reports experiencing upper abdominal pain and has a 10-year history of hepatitis B.

O: An MRI revealed a mass in the left outer lobe of the liver, growing outward and invading the diaphragm. The tumour marker carcinoembryonic antigen was elevated at 10.14 μg/L. Surgery confirmed the presence of a tumour measuring 11 cm × 9 cm × 6 cm with no lymph node metastases. Immunohistochemistry analysis showed the tumour was positive for CK18 and negative for Arg-1, hepatocyte, GPC-3, and CK7, with a PD-L1 expression level TPS of < 5%. The CD8+ T cell infiltration rate was 10%. Follow-up MRI and PET-CT detected liver resection margin recurrence and abdominal lymph node metastasis, including a 4 × 1.5 cm lesion in the liver and enlarged hepatic hilar and retroperitoneal lymph nodes.

A: The patient was diagnosed with moderately differentiated intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma (ICC) stage IIIb. Post-surgery recurrence was detected as liver resection margin recurrence and metastasis to abdominal lymph nodes.

P: The patient underwent a left hemihepatectomy and hepatoduodenal ligament skeletonization, followed by intraoperative radiotherapy using 9-mV photon beams with a 12 Gy dose. Future treatment plans involve applying whole-exome sequencing (WES) to the tissue for further treatment planning. The patient will be updated on the WES results to discuss further treatment options.

S: The patient is a 52-year-old with a history of coronary artery disease and coronary bypass surgery. The patient reports feeling okay and has not experienced any symptoms related to coronary artery disease since the surgery. They have no current concerns regarding breathing or swelling.

O: The patient has normal heart sounds (S1, S2) without added sounds (S3, S4) or murmur. Blood pressure is 132/82 mmHg and heart rate is 72/min, both within normal limits. Breathing is normal with no peripheral edema observed. Electrocardiogram shows nonspecific ST changes in precordial leads. Transthoracic echocardiography reveals normal systolic contraction in all left ventricular wall segments, no left ventricular cavity enlargement or hypertrophy. A left ventricular false tendon between the apical lateral wall and basal septum is observed, noted as a benign finding.

A: The patient is asymptomatic for coronary artery disease post-surgery, with normal heart function. The ST changes and false tendon noted are currently non-concerning.

P: The plan is to continue regular monitoring through follow-up appointments to keep track of heart health. The patient is advised to contact the healthcare provider if any symptoms or concerns arise.

S: The patient presents with pancytopenia and has a history of alcohol abuse. A few weeks ago, they experienced a fever and productive cough with yellow sputum that resolved without treatment. The patient also reports generalized weakness, blurry vision in the right eye, and chest tightness over the past few weeks. They deny other symptoms such as skin rash, joint pain, hair loss, heartburn, or Raynaud's phenomenon.

O: On physical examination, the patient has nontender lymphadenopathy in the neck. Initial vital signs show a temperature of 101.2 F. Laboratory results indicate a white blood cell count of 1,900 counts/μL, hemoglobin 7.2 g/dL, hematocrit 21.2%, and platelet count of 19,000 counts/μL. Sodium is 126 mmol/L, and creatinine is 1.44 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows elevated white blood cells, dysmorphic red blood cells, and proteinuria. Further testing reveals elevated ferritin at 6542 ng/mL, high triglycerides at 327 mg/dL, decreased complement levels (C3 at 14 mg/dL and C4 at 3 mg/dL), and elevated ESR at 137 mm/hr. ANA is strongly positive (1:640), and anti-dsDNA is >1:1280. Positive anticardiolipin antibodies (IgM and IgG) and beta-2 glycoprotein I antibody (IgG) are noted. Direct antiglobulin test (Coomb's) is positive. Urine studies show microalbumin to creatinine ratio of 1958 mg/g and protein creatinine ratio of 7.04 mg/mg, indicating nephrotic-range proteinuria. A transthoracic echocardiogram shows moderate circumferential pericardial effusion, and abdominal ultrasonography reveals hepatosplenomegaly and evidence of cirrhosis.

A: The clinical findings suggest systemic involvement potentially related to autoimmune disease, given the positive ANA and anti-dsDNA antibodies, nephrotic-range proteinuria, and hypocomplementemia. The presence of pericardial effusion and hepatosplenomegaly, along with a history of alcohol abuse, raises suspicion for lupus with kidney involvement (possibly lupus nephritis) and liver damage.

P: The plan includes determining the underlying cause of the symptoms, initiating treatment based on the findings, and closely monitoring the patient's progress. Specific treatments and interventions will be decided upon further evaluation by the medical team. The patient and family will be kept informed of the progress and treatment plan adjustments. Follow-up and additional referrals may be required as indicated.

S: The patient is a 63-year-old man seeking replacement for missing teeth with a fixed prosthesis. He has no reported symptoms or complaints other than the missing teeth.

O: A panoramic radiograph reveals a bilateral bifid mandibular canal, which is a rare anatomical variation. The bifurcation on the left side occurs at the height of the occlusal plane adjacent to the third molar, while on the right side, it occurs much lower in the mandibular ramus.

A: The patient presents with missing teeth and a bilateral bifid mandibular canal as an incidental finding. This anatomical variation will not impact the dental procedure but is important for treatment planning.

P: Discuss replacement options for the missing teeth. Ensure awareness of anatomical variation during treatment to avoid complications. Further assessment and planning for the fixed prosthesis will be conducted.

S: The patient reports experiencing progressive fatigue, dyspnea, and numbness in the soles of their feet for the past 15 months. They have a history of hypothyroidism. The patient has also had previous management for myopericarditis requiring drainage of pericardial effusion.

O: Tests conducted include a chest X-ray showing cardiomegaly, an Electrocardiogram indicating sinus rhythm rate of 80 beats per minute, low voltage complexes in the limb leads, and voltage criteria for left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH). An echocardiogram demonstrated moderate concentric LVH with septal hypertrophy, moderate global hypokinesis of the left ventricle, an ejection fraction between 25-30%, a moderately dilated right ventricle with mildly reduced systolic function, and mildly dilated atria. Cardiac MRI revealed high normal LV size, severely increased LV mass, global hypokinesis, moderate hypertrophy, impaired biventricular systolic function, moderate bi-atrial dilatation, mildly raised extracellular volume (ECV) 0.36, and diffuse subendocardial late gadolinium enhancement, without inflammation or edema on STIR. A perfusion scan showed severe circumferential inducible ischemia, transmural fibrosis, and signs of iron overload in the liver and spleen. Coronary angiography revealed a 70% stenosis over the left anterior descending artery. SAP scintigraphy and Technetium labelled scan showed no visceral amyloid uptake and no significant abnormalities.

A: Initial impressions centered on amyloidosis; however, further evaluations contradicted this diagnosis. Clinical findings suggest an infiltrative process with notable cardiac and systemic involvement.

P: Continued monitoring and evaluation of the patient's condition is necessary to determine the optimal treatment plan. Consider addressing the identified cardiac issues and potential iron overload, while ruling out alternative diagnoses to amyloidosis. Further follow-up and investigation into the underlying cause of symptoms are recommended.

S: The patient, a 12-year-old boy with a known case of hemophilia A, reports swelling and pain in multiple joints and an intermittent fever for the past 13 days. The swelling began in the left elbow, followed by pain, and later affected the right elbow, left knee, and right shoulder joints. The fever is high-grade, coming and going, and improves with antipyretics. The patient's history includes similar episodes of joint aches since birth, relieved by FVIII injections and blood transfusions. He also experiences non-traumatic epistaxis and skin bruising, and had difficulty with blood clotting during circumcision. All vaccinations are up to date. He is the first child and has a younger brother with similar health issues.

O: The patient is oriented to time, place, and person with a Glasgow coma scale of 15/15. Vitals are as follows: heart rate of 88 beats/min, blood pressure of 110/80 mmHg, respiratory rate of 20 breaths/min, and a temperature of 102°F. There are no visible bruises noted on examination.

A: The patient's symptoms and history are consistent with joint bleeding episodes associated with hemophilia A, compounded by a febrile illness that could be due to infection or another inflammatory process.

P: The plan includes monitoring the patient's condition closely and providing appropriate treatment for the fever and joint symptoms. Consideration for treatment with FVIII replacement to address hemophilia-related bleeding and further evaluation to determine the cause of the fever and joint symptoms. Consultation with a hematologist may be necessary. Continue monitoring for any additional symptoms or complications.

S: The patient has been experiencing abdominal pain for the past 4 days, hypotension, perspiration, and drowsiness following an aggressive, blunt trauma.

O: Examination revealed tenderness and rebound tenderness in the abdomen with 2 periumbilical ecchymoses and several ecchymoses in the left deltoid area and lower limbs. Abdominal sonography showed peritoneal fluid with fibrin, while chest X-rays were unremarkable. Blood tests showed normal hemoglobin and white blood cell counts, but elevated creatinine (4.04 mg/dL), urea (209 mg/dL), mild acidosis (lactate 21 mmol/L), creatinine-kinase (1910 U/L), lactate-dehydrogenase (451 U/L), and ethanol (34 mg/dL). Post-surgery findings included 2 perforations on the ileum, general peritonitis with pus, and multiple intraperitoneal abscesses. Patient is in septic shock with multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS), on mechanical ventilation, inotropic support, sedation, and has a fever of 38.5 ºC.

A: The patient has ileal perforations with general peritonitis and septic shock with MODS, complicated by multiple intraperitoneal abscesses and infections including S. putrefaciens, S. cerevisiae, Candida species, and Acinetobacter baumannii.

P: The patient underwent an enterectomy, end-ileostomy, saline lavage, drain placements, and laparostomy. Empirical therapy with broad-spectrum antibiotics (ertapenem, vancomycin) was initiated, informed by an antibiogram. Further surgical intervention addressed intraperitoneal abscesses. Susceptible organisms are being treated with appropriate antibiotics (amikacin, gentamicin, ciprofloxacin, third-generation cephalosporins, fluconazole, colistin). Continuous monitoring and supportive care in the ICU are ongoing.

S:  
The patient is a known case of alpha thalassemia, specifically HbH disease, and has been experiencing fever and chills for the past week. The patient did not report any other symptoms or signs of infection.

O:  
Initial physical examination findings were unremarkable. The patient has pancytopenia with the following lab results: hemoglobin at 7.3 g/dL, white cell count at 1.68 × 10^9/L, and platelet count at 92 × 10^9/L. C-reactive protein was 24, and procalcitonin was 0.14. Renal function, liver enzymes, chest X-ray, and urinalysis were unremarkable. Blood and urine cultures, as well as Dengue NS 1 antigen, were negative. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis showed hepatosplenomegaly with no intra-abdominal abscesses. Peripheral blood film indicated marked leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, anisopoikilocytosis with microcytosis, target cells, and tear drop cells, consistent with thalassemia intermedia. Bone marrow examination revealed hypocellular marrow, marked erythroid hypoplasia, rare giant erythroblasts, inclusion bodies, and increased macrophages with active haemophagocytosis.

A:  
The clinical impression is that the patient's condition is more severe than HbH disease alone, with findings suggestive of a more complex hematological disorder possibly involving significant marrow dysfunction.

P:  
The plan involves closely monitoring the patient’s blood counts and adjusting treatment as needed. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or changes in condition immediately. The current medication was changed from piperacillin-tazobactam to carbapenem after negative cultures and persistent fever. Further observation and management will be based on ongoing assessments and lab findings.

S: The patient reports a central scotoma in the right eye for about 5 months, with no prior symptoms or family history of eye problems. Despite previous treatment, the patient has noticed no improvement in vision and is now experiencing obvious metamorphosis.

O: Initial findings showed corrected visual acuity from 8/20 to 10/20, atypical pigmentary alterations, local serous detachment in the central fovea, persistent sub-retinal fluid, and FCE. After half-dose PDT treatment, sub-retinal fluid resolved, but after 3 months, sub-macular hemorrhage and CNV lesion in FCE breaking through the retinal pigment epithelium were noted, causing metamorphosis.

A: The patient has continued symptoms related to central serous chorioretinopathy (CSC) with the development of choroidal neovascularization (CNV) causing metamorphosis in the affected eye.

P: Monitor the patient's condition closely. Schedule a follow-up appointment to reassess the eye and explore additional treatment options for the CNV lesion. Advise the patient to report any vision changes or concerns.

S: The patient reports having a seizure for the first time at home, which prompted their mother to call an ambulance. They have been feeling sick for the past two to three days with symptoms of an upper respiratory infection, including cough and nasal congestion. The patient's mother witnessed the seizure, describing a fall, shaking lasting one to two minutes, and incontinence of bladder and bowels. The patient has had a decreased appetite recently, consuming only French fries, and has been encouraged to drink Gatorade and Pedialyte. No significant past medical history, surgeries, or hospitalizations are noted, and there's an allergy to amoxicillin that causes hives. The patient is up to date on vaccines and has no family history of seizure disorders but has family with hypertension. The home environment is stable.

O: Upon arrival at the emergency department, the patient was somnolent, arousable, and confused, consistent with a postictal state. Vital signs recorded were: oral temperature 38°C, heart rate 108 bpm, blood pressure 111/70 mmHg, respiratory rate 26 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 97% on room air. The initial physical exam indicated the patient appeared drowsy but otherwise well-developed.

A: The clinical presentation suggests a postictal state following a first-time seizure, likely secondary to recent illness with upper respiratory infection symptoms. The possibility of the seizure being related to an acute illness should be considered given the recent history of somnolence, confusion, and infection.

P: The plan involves monitoring the patient in the emergency department, conducting tests to determine the cause of the seizure, and ensuring hydration. The patient is advised to report any changes in condition. Follow-up with the pediatrician may be necessary post discharge, especially if test results warrant further investigation or if symptoms persist. Allergen avoidance of amoxicillin is recommended.

S: The patient reports feeling weak and tired following postoperative kidney failure requiring CRRT dialysis. Breathing has improved since the surgical tracheostomy but still feels difficult at times. The patient has been experiencing increased confusion lately, which may be related to developing delirium.

O: The patient has a history of mitral valve replacement and CABG in 2017, and a kidney transplant in 2010. Post-surgery, the patient developed atrial fibrillation, pulmonary edema, and respiratory distress. The patient was intubated and later underwent a surgical tracheostomy with a size 8 tube insertion. Currently able to maintain SaO2 of 95-98% on 3-5L/min of 100% oxygen for up to 7 hours per day. The patient has been wheezing but managing with a speaking valve and SaO2 above 96%. There have been problematic reinsertions of the tracheostomy tube.

A: Post-thoracic surgery complications include respiratory distress, atrial fibrillation, pulmonary edema, postoperative kidney failure, and delirium. The patient's respiratory status has improved with tracheostomy but continues to experience some breathing difficulties and delirium symptoms.

P: Continue monitoring the patient's respiratory and mental status closely. Provide necessary support to manage delirium symptoms. Monitor SaO2 levels and ensure the tracheostomy tube is functioning properly, considering the history of reinsertion difficulties. Keep open communication for any additional symptoms or concerns from the patient.

S: The patient reports experiencing severe otalgia, a sensation of ear blockage in the left ear, and hearing loss for the past few months. Previous attempts at ear wax removal at several ENT clinics have been unsuccessful, even after using alkaline ear drops. The patient has a history of a tympanoplasty and endoscopic sinus surgery with septoplasty 10 years ago.

O: The patient is comfortable, afebrile, and has stable vital signs. An otoscopic examination revealed impacted ear wax covering the tympanic membrane in the left ear that could not be assessed. The right ear showed mild ear wax with an unremarkable tympanic membrane. Oropharyngeal examination was normal, cervical lymph nodes were not palpable, and cranial nerves were intact. Nasal endoscopy was also unremarkable. Blood tests were normal. Further examination under general anesthesia revealed a thick keratinous plug in the left ear, distending the external auditory canal, with bone remodeling. The tympanic membrane was intact.

A: The diagnosis is keratosis obturans (KO), confirmed by the presence of a thick keratinous plug in the external auditory canal.

P: The keratinous plug was removed, and an ear pack draped with antibiotics was placed to assist healing. The patient is advised to keep the ear pack clean and dry, avoid inserting anything into the ear, and attend a scheduled follow-up appointment to monitor healing. The patient should contact the clinic if there are any concerns or changes in symptoms.

S: The patient reported dealing with a recurrent, itchy rash for about a year. The rash is diffuse and spread all over the body, particularly on the extremities and trunk, especially on the flanks. The rash consists of red, raised bumps with minimal scaling.

O: A biopsy of the left part of the chest showed a predominantly perivascular inflammatory infiltrate with occasional eosinophils, consistent with Drug Hypersensitivity Reaction (DHR). The direct immunofluorescence test was negative. Previously tried treatments included topical triamcinolone, clobetasol, and hydroxyzine, which were ineffective. Oral prednisone helped but was discontinued due to steroid-induced diabetes. Dupilumab injections of 300 mg every 14 days resolved dermatitis and pruritus after 4 months. Due to medication costs, injections were spaced to every 30 days, with continued symptom resolution and no side effects.

A: The rash is consistent with a Drug Hypersensitivity Reaction (DHR).

P: Continue monitoring the patient's progress with dupilumab injections spaced every 30 days. Adjust the treatment plan as necessary, and instruct the patient to reach out if any changes occur or concerns arise.

S: The patient is a 19-year-old male who presented with melena occurring once a day for the past week, accompanied by vomiting, shortness of breath, and palpitations. He has a history of two distinct episodes of epistaxis in childhood and a family history of increased bleeding tendency in his paternal grandmother. The patient has received fresh frozen plasma infusions in the past.

O: Severe anemia was indicated by a hemoglobin level of 5.80 g/dL. Initial blood samples showed a strongly positive indirect Coomb's test and a negative direct Coomb's test. Extended antibody testing revealed pan-agglutination matched with anti-Kell, anti-Lub, and anti-Kpb antibodies. Cross-matching showed +4 incompatibility with all tested RBC units. After a transfusion of the least incompatible O negative RBCs, the patient experienced shivering, a temperature rise to 101°F, tachycardia, and hypotension. A transfusion reaction workup showed grade 4+ pan agglutination in serum.

A: Severe anemia likely due to gastrointestinal bleeding (melena) complicated by multiple blood group alloantibodies causing transfusion reactions. Possible hereditary bleeding disorder given family history and past epistaxis.

P: Administer intravenous antihistamine and hydrocortisone. Transferred the patient to ICU for further monitoring. Administered intranasal desmopressin and intravenous factor VIII. A transfusion reaction workup was performed, indicating continued monitoring and exploration of alternative treatment options for anemia management.

S: The patient is a 55-year-old female with a history of systemic lupus erythematosus, presenting with fatigue and constitutional syndrome lasting for 5 months. Previously, an extrainstitutional CT indicated multiple focal liver lesions with microcalcifications, interpreted as possible metastatic disease.

O: Physical examination revealed no positive findings. Extraneutral paraclinical tests showed negative tumour markers and normal liver function tests. MRI findings showed a normally sized and morphologically normal liver with multiple focal lesions in all hepatic segments. The largest lesion, located in the right lobe, measured 5 cm. Lesions appeared hyperintense in T2 sequences and hypointense in T1 sequences, with no fatty component. Discrete heterogeneous peripheral enhancement was noted in some lesions after contrast administration, with little contrast uptake even in late sequences.

A: Findings suggest lesions are not typical of metastatic disease, with differential diagnoses still being explored. Further monitoring and potentially additional tests will be necessary to characterize the hepatic lesions.

P: Follow-up with healthcare team to manage lupus and monitor changes in symptoms. Additional tests may be conducted as necessary, based on ongoing assessment and monitoring of the hepatic lesions.

S: The patient is a 27-year-old Caucasian male presenting with obsessive-compulsive symptoms and suicidal thoughts, which started approximately one week ago after a nocturnal emission while camping. Since then, he has experienced fear of contamination, leading to isolation and inability to work. He reports worsening depression, dysphoria, anxiety, anhedonia, low energy, low motivation, decreased social interest, and poor sleep. The patient's anxiety began at age 14 with trichotillomania and at age 15 he developed a fear of contamination; he typically managed these symptoms with compulsive hand washing. He has a history of outpatient psychiatric treatment and one prior psychiatric hospitalization. There is no history of hallucinations, delusions, mania, hypomania, drug abuse, suicidal, physically or sexually aggressive behavior. He grew up in Maryland, lives with his mother and stepfather, and works as an editorial assistant. He experienced early experimentation with his stepbrother in middle school but reports no history of physical or sexual abuse.

O: No information provided.

A: The patient is experiencing an exacerbation of obsessive-compulsive disorder symptoms following a nocturnal emission, leading to secondary depression and suicidal ideation. His history is significant for OCD starting in adolescence and a prior psychiatric hospitalization.

P: The patient will be admitted to the emergency room for further assessment and treatment of his OCD and depression, as well as addressing suicidal thoughts. He will be provided with support and care, with the option for family involvement in his treatment.

S: 
The patient is a 59-year-old female working as a rehabilitation worker who reports gradually enlarging swellings under both the right and left scapula for about eight months. These swellings are more visible when she stretches her arms forward or elevates her upper extremities and feel soft to the touch. She experiences pain in her upper extremities and arms. The patient has no history of accidents or falls that could explain these symptoms. She has previously undergone neurosurgical procedures for disc extrusion in the cervical and thoracic spine. Bilateral swellings were present before her surgery, and the swelling on the right side recurred after previous treatment, which included repeated punctures and partial resection.

O: 
Magnetic resonance imaging of the thoracic wall shows symmetrical fluid collections in the subscapular regions. On the right side, the dimensions are 120 × 37 × 115 mm with a volume of 250 ml; on the left side, 120 × 24 × 90 mm with a volume of 130 ml. The contents are moderately heterogeneous with sporadic internal septa, and the cystic formations have distinct signals. T1 weighting showed hypersensitive contents on the right side, indicating potential chronic post haemorrhagic changes. After contrast administration, there was no significant increase in signal intensity except for moderate reinforcement of the capsule on the left side. No diffusion restriction was observed. Axillary lymphatic nodes are of physiological size, pulmonary parenchyma is without changes, and no mediastinal or hilar lymphadenopathy is present.

A: 
The patient's condition suggests symmetrical subscapular cystic formations with chronic post haemorrhagic changes on the right side. The differential includes benign cystic lesions but further evaluation is necessary to understand the nature and cause of persistent symptoms and fluid collections.

P: 
Schedule a follow-up appointment to discuss treatment options and monitor the patient's condition. The patient is advised to report any changes in symptoms or new concerns. Further imaging or biopsy might be considered to assess the nature of the cystic formations.

S: The patient reports progressive dysphagia for the past 2 months without hoarseness. They have a history of smoking 60 cigarettes a day for 40 years and heavy alcohol use over the same period. The patient also has a history of hypertension for 9 years and type 2 diabetes diagnosed a year ago. There are no prior malignant diseases or distant metastases reported.

O: The physical examination revealed no palpable neck and supraclavicular lymph nodes. Blood count and biochemical analysis showed no significant abnormalities. An Iohexol swallowing test indicated a malignant-appearing structure in the inferior-thoracic region. Endoscopic assessment identified a lesion of mucosal hyperplasia forming a luminal stenosis, 36 cm from the incisor teeth, with difficulty passing the gastroscope. Biopsy confirmed an esophageal MEC. CT scan showed the tumor as resectable. Post-surgery, the esophagectomy specimen revealed a fungating tumor measuring 45 mm longitudinally and 40 mm cross-sectionally, with histopathology showing epidermoid cells, keratin pearl formation, columnar mucus-secreting cells, and intermediate cells with tube-like structures. The tumor was positive for p-63 and CK5/6.

A: The patient is diagnosed with an esophageal MEC, with the tumor showing characteristics of epidermoid cells and the presence of keratin pearl formation. 

P: The patient is scheduled for an esophagectomy with 2-field lymphadenectomy and esophagogastrostomy. Post-surgery, the plan involves monitoring recovery, managing hypertension and diabetes, and advising smoking cessation and reduced alcohol consumption to improve overall health. Follow-up care will be provided as necessary.

S: The patient, a woman in her late seventies, reports having an aortic aneurysm. She lives independently and can perform daily activities without assistance. In September 2019, she was admitted for elective embolization of a type 2 endoleak. Post-procedure, the patient experienced weakness and numbness in both lower limbs, more pronounced on the right side.

O: Examination following the embolization revealed lower motor neuron pattern weakness in the bilateral lower limbs, with the right side more affected. Sensation was normal on the left but impaired on the right from L2 to S1. Reflexes were absent in both lower limbs. An urgent CT aortogram indicated post-interval embolization of bilateral feeding arteries with Onyx material in a branch of the embolized right iliolumbar artery extending into the spinal canal at L3 and exiting at L2. An MRI of the thoracolumbar spine was also performed. A lumbar spinal drain was inserted, and fluid replacement was initiated to maintain a mean arterial pressure above 80 mm Hg.

A: The patient is experiencing symptoms possibly due to spinal cord ischemia following the embolization procedure.

P: The patient will be carefully monitored with ongoing assessment and adjustments in her treatment. She is advised to report any changes in her symptoms.

S: The patient reported that the 10-year-old male horse appeared weak, was not responding properly, was found lying on the ground, and not moving much on the morning of May 2nd. The horse was also experiencing some difficulty breathing the day before these symptoms appeared. The horse died about 4 hours after the initial symptoms were noticed. Two living third-instar dipteran larvae were found near the horse's head.

O: Upon examination, an additional four living third-instar larvae were discovered in the horse's nasal cavity.

A: Presence of dipteran larvae suggests a potential infestation that may have contributed to the horse's respiratory distress and subsequent death. Possible diagnosis includes nasopharyngeal myiasis caused by oestrid larvae.

P: Larvae collected for further examination; two were taken to the lab for pupation, and the rest were preserved in alcohol for morphological study. Results of the examination will be used to determine the cause of death and inform prevention strategies. The owner was advised to monitor other horses closely for similar symptoms and to contact the veterinarian if any concerns arise. Follow-up will occur once lab results are available.

S: Tyler, a 56-year-old male, reports difficulty swallowing over the last 4-5 weeks. He feels like something is stuck in his throat when swallowing solids, which sometimes requires him to "wash it down" with liquids. There are no issues with swallowing liquids or soft foods like yogurt, and he denies any coughing, blood in stools, vomiting, weight changes, chest pain, or shortness of breath. Tyler has a history of diabetes and high blood pressure and is currently managing his diabetes with metformin and has been monitoring his blood sugar levels, which he reports are within target range. He confirms no side effects from metformin. Tyler's blood pressure at home is generally within range, with occasional slight increases. 

O: Examination shows no abnormalities in the neck, mouth, or lymph nodes. Throat inspection reveals no masses, swelling, or redness. A clear lung exam, normal heart exam with no murmurs, and no significant abdominal masses or swelling, though there is some epigastric tenderness. Vitals include a blood pressure reading of 120/50. Laboratory tests or imaging were not discussed.

A: The primary concern is dysphagia, likely due to esophageal stricture or narrowing. Reflux may be contributing to the symptoms. Diabetes and hypertension are currently well-managed.

P: Referral to gastroenterology for a possible endoscopy to evaluate the esophageal stricture. Start on Prilosec 20 mg once daily for reflux management. Instructed to chew food thoroughly, especially solids. In case of significant worsening or emergency symptoms, seek immediate medical attention. Continue current diabetes management, order a repeat hemoglobin A1c and additional blood work, including kidney function. Referral to ophthalmology for diabetic retinopathy screening. Refill Norvasc as requested and continue monitoring blood pressure at home. Follow-up in one month to review blood test results and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, a 91-year-old male, reported discomfort and pain on his right side in November 2016, which led to a clinic visit and subsequent hospital referral. Post-surgery, the patient experienced postoperative night delirium characterized by confusion and disorientation.

O: In December 2016, the patient underwent a laparoscopic RN procedure using a conventional intraperitoneal approach with insufflation pressure restricted to less than 8 mm Hg. Postoperative delirium was treated with haloperidol. The patient was discharged on postoperative day 10. Pathologic diagnosis revealed multilocular clear cell renal cell carcinoma (RCC), Fuhrman grade 2, pT1b. The patient's postoperative pain and discomfort have mostly resolved.

A: Multilocular clear cell renal cell carcinoma, Fuhrman grade 2, pT1b, status post laparoscopic RN with successful management of postoperative delirium.

P: Continue monitoring the patient’s condition with regular follow-up appointments. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns promptly. Encourage ongoing communication and provide necessary follow-up care to ensure continued health and well-being.

S: The patient reported experiencing left wrist drop, finger drop, and a tingling sensation over the lateral dorsum of their left hand starting 4 days ago after becoming intoxicated. The patient noted slight improvement in weakness over the past 4 days and denied any history of antecedent trauma, injury, infection, or mononeuropathy.

O: The neurological examination revealed weakness in left wrist and finger extension (Medical Research Council grade II). Finger abduction was weak but improved with passive extension to the neutral position. Wrist and finger flexion remained intact. Sensory examination showed hypoesthesia and tingling between the thumb and index finger on the lateral dorsum of the left hand, extending into the proximal phalanges of the second finger. There was reddish skin color and slight edema, but no change in temperature or pain. Reflexes were normal except for an absent left brachioradialis reflex. Routine blood analysis showed normal white blood cell count, C-reactive protein, and uric acid levels. A nerve conduction study showed a 34% reduction in CMAP when stimulated above the spiral groove on the affected side, with normal contralateral studies.

A: Compressive radial neuropathy.

P: The plan is to observe the patient for improvement without specific treatment for approximately two weeks. If improvement in skin color, weakness, and sensation is observed, it will be considered positive progress. A nerve conduction study and electromyography were performed to further assess the condition. The patient is advised to avoid excessive strain on the left arm and wrist. Continued monitoring and adjustment of the treatment approach as necessary are recommended.

S: The patient is an 8-month-old male with a one-month history of a gradually increasing mass on the right elbow. He has been moving his right arm actively without limitations and has no past medical or surgical history. The pregnancy was full-term with no complications, and his developmental history is normal. There is no family history of malignancies.

O: Physical examination showed a 3 × 2 × 4 cm mobile, soft, nontender mass on the right elbow with slight restriction of full flexion at 15 degrees. He has full active extension. A plain radiograph revealed a lobular soft tissue swelling, and blood tests including complete blood count, ESR, and CRP were normal. MRI showed a 3.3 × 2 × 4.5 cm lobular juxta articular subcutaneous soft tissue lesion along the medial elbow, predominantly high T2 signal intensity, with a multiseptated structure and a low T2/high T1 signal area. There was no perilesional edema or joint effusion.

A: Endolymphatic malformation of the elbow. Pathology confirmed a multiloculated lymphangioma with no evidence of malignancy.

P: Plan for a radical excision of the mass under tourniquet control, with careful dissection to preserve nearby nerves and muscles. The pathology showed no malignancy, resolving concerns about cancer. Surgery will be scheduled, and information will be provided to the mother for the procedure and post-operative care.

S: The patient has been using artificial sweeteners for 14 years and was diagnosed with Hashimoto's hypothyroidism. Initially, the patient experienced significant weight gain of 20 lbs, which they correlated with the use of artificial sweeteners. The patient subsequently reduced and stopped using artificial sweeteners.

O: Initial thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) level was 12.2 mIU/L (above normal), free T4 was 0.5 ng/dl (below normal), and anti-thyroid peroxidase antibody (Anti TPO Ab) was 196 IU/ml (above normal). After treatment with levothyroxine 0.75 mg/day, TSH levels normalized between 1.23 mIU/L and 2.16 mIU/L. Stopping artificial sweeteners led to an unanticipated drop in TSH to 0.005 mIU/L. Discontinuation of levothyroxine resulted in normal TSH, Anti-TPO Ab, TSI, and TBII levels. The patient has remained clinically euthyroid without treatment.

A: The patient was initially diagnosed with Hashimoto's hypothyroidism, but is now clinically euthyroid following the discontinuation of artificial sweeteners and levothyroxine. Other autoimmune disorders and drug-induced thyroiditis have been ruled out.

P: The patient should continue monitoring thyroid levels and report any symptoms or changes to their healthcare provider. Regular follow-up is suggested to ensure continued euthyroid status.

S: The patient was born at term by natural delivery with a birth weight of 3950 g, length of 51 cm, and occipital frontal circumference of 34.5 cm. The Apgar scores were 9/9. The patient began walking by 13 months and speaking first words at 11 months, with no developmental delays or intellectual disabilities, except for mild learning disabilities and dysgraphia identified at age 9. At age 13, the patient experienced symptoms such as obesity, hyperactivity, dysphagia, sleep disturbance, and minor dysmorphic features, including a round face, bushy eyebrows, and stubby hands. There is a reported similarity to Smith-Magenis syndrome, but without a molecular diagnosis. The patient’s parental age at birth was 38 and 43, and they were healthy and unrelated. A prenatal NT ultrasound and karyotype on amniocytes were normal.

O: At age 13, the patient presented with obesity, normal height, hyperactivity, dysphagia, sleep disturbances, and minor dysmorphic features. Neuroimaging showed an altered signal near the capsular lenticular structures and the head of the caudate nucleus, implying a hamartoma.

A: The patient has a mild phenotype similar to Smith-Magenis syndrome, with features including dysgraphia, obesity, hyperactivity, dysphagia, sleep disturbance, and minor dysmorphic features. Despite phenotypic similarities, molecular testing did not confirm a diagnosis of Smith-Magenis syndrome.

P: Continue regular follow-ups with healthcare providers to monitor growth, development, and any changes in condition. Maintain a healthy lifestyle to manage obesity and related symptoms.

S: The patient reports diffuse abdominal pain and obstipation for the past 24 hours. There is no history of vomiting or fever. The patient has a surgical history of splenectomy 12 years ago due to a traumatic rupture of the spleen and no other medical issues.

O: Vital signs are within normal limits, and the patient is afebrile. Physical examination reveals a distended abdomen with diffuse tenderness. Blood tests show a high white blood cell count of 23040/mm³, but hepatic and pancreatic enzymes are normal. CT scan shows multiple splenic nodules in the left upper quadrant, small bowel distention, and air-fluid levels in the jejunum, suggesting intestinal obstruction. Exploratory laparotomy reveals splenic nodules causing external compression and obstruction of the small bowel and colon.

A: The patient has an intestinal obstruction due to splenosis, where splenic tissue has revascularized and caused compression of the bowel.

P: Three splenic tissues that caused the obstruction were resected, and pathologic studies confirmed splenosis. The patient was discharged on the 7th post-operative day following recovery. The patient is advised to monitor for similar symptoms and return for evaluation if they arise.

S: The patient is an 86-year-old female experiencing difficulty breathing, particularly during physical activity. She reports these symptoms to the doctor.

O: The patient is described as frail and has an elevated brain-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) level of >900. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) reveals severe aortic stenosis (AS) with an aortic valve area of 0.58 cm² and peak velocity of 4.0 m/s. There is diffuse left ventricular hypertrophy with Maron type III hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, LVOT obstruction with systolic anterior motion (SAM) of the mitral valve, and moderate mitral regurgitation (MR). During a Valsalva maneuver, peak velocity at the LVOT was 2.9 m/s, and the mean pressure gradient was 32 mmHg. After administering bisoprolol, the LVOT obstruction and SAM disappeared, and MR was reduced to mild. However, high peak velocity across the aortic valve and BNP level persisted.

A: The assessment indicates severe aortic stenosis with complications including left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction and mitral valve involvement leading to moderate mitral regurgitation. There is also mention of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

P: The plan includes performing a transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI) with a 23 mm SAPIEN 3 valve via transfemoral approach under general anesthesia and transesophageal echocardiography guidance, with continuous beta-blocker infusion and volume loading. Post-implantation, if SAM and MR reoccur with unstable hemodynamics, an emergent alcohol septal ablation (ASA) will be performed to stabilize the patient.

S: The patient reports a recent 24-hour history of nausea and vomiting, followed by acute, moderate right-sided testicular pain. The patient did not experience any fever. Past medical history includes an isolated episode of transient neutropenia and hepatosplenomegaly as an infant, both of which resolved completely. At age 5, the patient had a lower limb rash, diagnosed as cutaneous PAN, with livedo racemosa mainly involving the lower limbs. There were no other abnormalities detected in the examination of all systems.

O: The patient has been genetically confirmed to have DADA2, with a homozygous c.139G > C mutation (p.G47R) of ADA2 and absent serum ADA2 enzyme activity. Complete blood count, renal and liver function, SAA, CRP, ESR, coagulation screen, immunoglobulin levels, and tests for viral hepatitis and coeliac disease were all normal or negative.

A: The patient is being monitored for deficiency of adenosine deaminase 2 (DADA2). The recent symptoms of nausea, vomiting, and right-sided testicular pain need monitoring to rule out any complications related to the diagnosis.

P: Continue routine monitoring of DADA2 and manage any new or worsening symptoms. Patient is advised to report any changes in symptoms immediately. Maintain regular follow-ups and ensure communication for any questions or concerns.

S: The patient reports experiencing progressive nasal obstruction and recurrent episodes of epistaxis for several months. They have difficulty breathing through one side of their nose but do not have anosmia, nasal discharge, nasal congestion, sneezing, facial pain, or headache. The patient has a past medical history of hypertension and diabetes.

O: The endoscopic examination revealed a large left-sided nasal polypoidal mass with smooth overlying mucosa occluding the whole left nasal cavity. Ear, nose, throat, head, and neck examinations were otherwise normal with no palpable lymphadenopathy. CT scan findings included a left anterior lobulated nasal mass with mild heterogeneous post IV contrast enhancement and bone remodeling, without extension to the paranasal sinuses or bone invasion. Intraoperative findings showed a semifirm vascular mass attached to the anterior face of the middle turbinate and septum. The histological examination of the excised mass confirmed a benign schwannoma of the nasal septum.

A: Benign schwannoma of the nasal septum, successfully excised.

P: The plan included performing an endonasal endoscopic excision of the left nasal cavity mass under general anesthesia, which was completed successfully. Regular follow-up care is recommended to monitor for any recurrence.

S: The patient reports no symptoms such as dysphagia, epigastric fullness, or gastroesophageal reflux. They have a medical history of hepatolithiasis and underwent hepatic left lateral segmentectomy at age 50. There is a concern regarding a tumor detected at the esophagogastric junction during a recent upper endoscopy screening.

O: Physical examination revealed no remarkable findings. Laboratory examinations, including serum tumor markers (carcinoembryonic antigen and carbohydrate antigen 19-9), were normal. An upper endoscopy showed a 10 mm elevated mass at the EG junction and a sliding hiatal hernia. Endoscopic ultrasonography revealed mixed echogenicity with submucosal invasion. Upper gastrointestinal imaging confirmed an elevated lesion at the EG junction. Biopsy analysis diagnosed a differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma. Computed tomography showed no lymph node or distant metastasis.

A: Clinical diagnosis is esophageal cancer, cT1bN0M0 cStage I, with a differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma arising from Barrett's epithelium.

P: The recommended treatment is a proximal gastrectomy with D1 lymph node dissection and jejunal interposition to remove the affected areas. Post-surgery, microscopic examination will assess the tumor characteristics, and no lymphovascular invasion is expected. Continued monitoring and follow-up care will be provided, and the patient is advised to attend all scheduled appointments.

S: The patient, a 32-year-old in her 39th week of pregnancy, presented with severe dyspnoea and chest pain. This is her first experience with such symptoms, and she has no history of similar symptoms or hospitalizations.

O: The patient was clinically treated for pulmonary embolic disease and received massive anticoagulant therapy. An emergent caesarean delivery was performed under general anaesthesia using Stark's method. The baby's Apgar scores were 3, 6, and 9 at minutes 1, 3, and 5, and the baby weighed 2590 grams, indicating growth restriction. Ultrasounds from the 33rd week showed reduced potential foetal growth, possibly due to a suspected pulmonary arteriovenous malformation (pAVM). The placenta showed less than 10% infarcts in the cotyledons. Postoperative, the patient developed acute distress syndrome and was transferred to the hospital's Gynaecology and Obstetrics unit.

A: Clinical presentation suggests pulmonary embolic disease and possible pAVM. Immediate postpartum complications include acute respiratory distress syndrome. The baby showed initial adaptation issues likely related to maternal anaesthesia and condition.

P: Continued monitoring of both patient and baby is required. Follow instructions and report new symptoms or concerns to healthcare providers for further management. No spinal anaesthesia was administered during the caesarean due to potential risks associated with pAVM.

S: The patient, a 19-year-old female, reports having a necrotic hairless lesion on her right frontotemporal region, which is triangular and has been present for over a year following surgical fat grafting to the forehead.

O: The lesion is measured at approximately 130 cm². A procedure was performed where 4,550 follicular units were harvested from the occipital scalp using strip excision and transplanted at a density of about 35 FUs/cm². The surgery lasted approximately 5 and a half hours, resulting in a graft survival rate of 75%. Preoperative POSAS scores were 20 (patient scale) and 18 (observer scale), which improved to 8 and 7, respectively, postoperatively.

A: Improvement in lesion appearance and patient satisfaction post-surgery, with improved POSAS scores indicating positive healing and reduced scarring.

P: Continue monitoring the lesion and overall progress. The patient should reach out if there are any further questions or concerns. Follow-up visits should be scheduled as needed to ensure ongoing improvement and address any potential complications.

S: The 67-year-old male patient reports increasing difficulty breathing and orthopnea. He has a history of permanent atrial fibrillation, triple mechanical prosthetic valve replacements for rheumatic valvular disease, and progressive nonischemic cardiomyopathy with a residual left ventricular ejection fraction of 15%. He previously declined a subcutaneous implantable cardioverter defibrillator.

O: Physical examination revealed significant bradycardia with a heart rate of 35-40 bpm. An ECG showed atrial fibrillation with intermittent rate regularization and variable wide complex QRS morphology, indicating a high-grade AV block with variable ventricular escape rhythm.

A: The patient exhibits signs of high-grade AV block with his current symptoms and ECG findings.

P: An urgent cardiac resynchronization therapy with a defibrillator (CRT-D) device implantation via the coronary sinus is scheduled. The procedure involves extrathoracic subclavian venous punctures using fluoroscopic guidance and a series of catheter and guidewire techniques to address the observed conditions.

S: The patient reports recurrent episodes of rhabdomyolysis since the age of 22 months, often following respiratory tract infections. There is a significant family history with two siblings who died at ages 2 and 4 after a short infectious illness and exhibited symptoms of rhabdomyolysis and myoglobinuria. The initial episode did not involve hypoglycemia or ketosis. The patient experiences severe muscle pain during episodes and has been hospitalized multiple times with elevated CK levels.

O: The patient's creatine kinase levels have been extremely elevated during episodes, reaching up to 1,000,000 U/L. Initial CK concentration recorded was 250,000 U/L. Postmortem evaluations of the patient's siblings did not show muscle abnormalities, but dilated cardiomyopathy was present. Serial urine organic acid and acylcarnitine profiles have been normal.

A: Recurrent rhabdomyolysis with severe muscle pain and elevated CK levels. The differential diagnosis includes a possible long chain fatty acid oxidation defect, but no definitive cause has been identified. Family history suggests a potential genetic or metabolic disorder.

P: Continue current management with aggressive carbohydrate supplementation, including nocturnal cornstarch. Restrict dietary fat intake to about 40 g/day, utilizing MCT oil and walnut oil for essential fatty acids. Continue Coenzyme Q10 supplementation (100-200 mg daily). Limit physical exercise to 20 minutes/day and consume a high-calorie drink before activity. Continue monitoring symptoms and perform further investigations as needed to identify the underlying cause.

S: The patient reports weakness and clumsiness in the left arm, with symptoms including wrist drop and inability to grip with fingers. There is no sensory loss or numbness in the affected arm. The patient has a history of recurrent lower extremity deep vein thrombosis, glaucoma, non-significant aortic valve stenosis, treated hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and non-significant stenosis of the left anterior descendent coronary artery.

O: Physical examination revealed wrist drop on the left side, decreased grip strength, difficulty with pronation, wrist dorsiflexion, and forming a ring with thumb and index finger. Left upper extremity reflexes were slightly brisk, but no pathological reflexes or sensory deficits. A cranial CT scan showed contrast-enhancing lesions in the temporal, parietal, and frontal lobes with perifocal edema. Carotid duplex ultrasonography showed no signs of atherosclerotic plaques or stenosis. Cranial MRI confirmed a tumor in the right precentral gyrus and similar lesions in parietal and temporal lobes, and left frontal lobe. Electromyography and nerve conduction studies did not indicate a peripheral cause for paresis. Neuropsychological examination revealed a deficit in the Luria three-step test, which improved with verbal cues. Chest X-ray was conducted as part of the investigation.

A: The clinical presentation and imaging findings suggest a central nervous system lesion, likely a tumor affecting the motor cortex area related to hand movement, along with other lesions.

P: Further development of a treatment plan was mentioned, indicating consideration of the imaging findings, clinical examination, and test results. Management of the tumor and associated symptoms, as well as ongoing monitoring and treatment of existing medical conditions, will be crucial in the forthcoming discussions with the patient. Follow-up and potential referral to oncology or neurology specialists may be considered.

S: The patient, an infant, has unilateral left facial palsy first noticed on the 13th day after birth, characterized by inability to close the left eye and loss of tearing. She had a low-grade fever 7 days ago and presented with purulent otorrhea 3 days ago. No pregnancy complications or delivery issues were reported. 

O: On examination, the infant was alert but irritable, ill-appearing, and hypotonic with fever and respiratory distress, but no lymphadenopathy or organomegaly. Neurologic examination showed facial asymmetry and unilateral peripheral facial nerve palsy. Bilateral tympanic membranes were hyperemic and bulging. Laboratory results: WBC 157,000/mm3, Hb 6.2 gr/dL, Hct 18.6%, platelet 130,000/mm3. CSF analysis: 670 RBC/dL, 630 WBC/dL (70% neutrophils, 30% lymphocytes), protein 14 mg/dL, glucose 18 mg/dL. CRP 1+, ESR 70 mm/h. Peripheral blood smear showed prominence of PMNs, myelocytes, and 20% basophils, with large platelets and mild granulocytic dysplasia.

A: The clinical and laboratory findings suggest a serious underlying condition, possibly hematological in nature, necessitating further investigation and treatment.

P: The treatment plan includes ongoing monitoring and modification based on the patient's response. A bone marrow aspiration and biopsy were performed, with flow cytometry results guiding further management.

S: The patient reported having chest pain about 40 minutes before arriving at the hospital. They had undergone a procedure with overlapping metal stents placed in the heart approximately a week ago. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and polycythemia vera.

O: The initial evaluation showed anterior ST elevations and hemodynamics consistent with shock. An emergent angiography revealed a 100% occlusion of the left anterior descending artery (LAD) due to in-stent thrombosis and angiographic underexpansion of the stents at the occlusion site. Attempts to postdilate the stents at a previous facility were unsuccessful. In-hospital procedures included administering Bivalirudin, achieving TIMI 1 flow restoration, and using a laser with contrast injections. Aggressive dilation was performed, and an intravascular ultrasound showed severe concentric calcification with a lumen diameter of 3.75–4.0 mm.

A: The patient experienced in-stent thrombosis and underexpansion of stents in the LAD, leading to shock. Post-procedural diagnostics revealed significant calcification.

P: The immediate issue of stent occlusion was addressed by aggressive dilation and postdilation with a 4.0 × 12 Quantum balloon. The patient was stabilized hemodynamically. Follow-up with a cardiologist is recommended to continue monitoring given the patient's history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and polycythemia vera.

S: The patient, a 19-year-old female, reports having pharyngeal pain, a left neck mass, and fever for about two months. She had a tracheotomy due to airway obstruction from a large mass arising in the left parapharyngeal space. She started chemotherapy with CHOEP on December 8, 2017, but the lesions did not shrink, and her pain and dysphagia worsened.

O: PET/CT scan showed a large solid mass in the left parapharyngeal space compressing the pharyngeal cavity, with multiple enlarged lymph nodes in the left neck. Histopathological review confirmed histiocytic sarcoma. Chemotherapy began on December 8, 2017, but lesions did not shrink. Irradiation reduced the pharyngeal mass size from 6.0 cm x 4.4 cm to 5.6 cm x 4.0 cm, and the neck mass from 3.5 cm x 2.8 cm to 2.9 cm x 2.6 cm. Next-generation sequencing revealed a mutation c.2888-1G>T in the MET gene, exon 14, with an allele frequency of 5.58%, and an activated mutation c.361.

A: The patient has a confirmed diagnosis of histiocytic sarcoma with large masses in the parapharyngeal space and neck. There is partial response to irradiation following chemotherapy.

P: Continue monitoring the patient’s condition closely and adjust treatment as necessary. Consider further treatment options based on genetic findings and patient progress.

S: The patient initially reported swelling in the right axillary region. Following chemotherapy, the patient experienced fever, polyarthralgia, and muscle soreness. These symptoms were diagnosed as paraneoplastic syndrome, not as adverse effects of chemotherapy. After nivolumab treatment, the patient still experiences these symptoms but no new issues have developed.

O: A CT scan revealed a space-occupying lesion in the S2 region of the right lung. Histological analysis indicated high-grade cytological atypia with poor intercellular cohesion. Immunohistochemical analysis was positive for pan-cytokeratin, vimentin, and thyroid transcription factor 1, and negative for CD45 and CD30. Tumor cells were positive for PD-L1 in more than 95% of them. The tumor was classified as cT4N2M0. Post-chemotherapy lab tests showed leukocytosis and thrombocytosis. The tumor size reduced to 70 × 55 × 48 mm after chemotherapy. No remarkable abnormalities were observed in labs during nivolumab treatment.

A: The patient was diagnosed with pleomorphic adenocarcinoma of the lung, classified as cT4N2M0. They experienced paraneoplastic syndrome, unrelated to chemotherapy. The tumor showed a partial response to chemotherapy.

P: Initial treatment involved four courses of nab-paclitaxel plus carboplatin chemotherapy. Due to paraneoplastic syndrome symptoms post-chemotherapy, further monitoring was advised. Following the initial treatment, the plan involved four courses of 120 mg (3 mg/kg) of nivolumab every two weeks, with continuous monitoring of symptoms and progress.

S: The patient is a 77-year-old Japanese woman with end-stage renal disease due to chronic glomerulonephritis. She has been on hemodialysis for about 10 years and has a history of issues with arteriovenous fistulas (AVFs), having undergone 21 operations related to AVFs, including the creation of bilateral radiocephalic AVFs twice and 19 percutaneous transluminal angioplasties (PTA). She reports weak vascular murmur and thrill in her right forearm.

O: Preoperative ultrasonography showed venous stenosis located 0-4 cm from the anastomosis site, affecting 6 cm of the median cubital vein, with lesion diameters less than 2 mm. Distal and proximal diameters were approximately 4-6 mm. An operation was performed using a 5 Fr × 3 cm Mosquito Sincere Catheter Introducer and a Kyousha™ NT Peripheral Guidewire with an NSE PTA balloon catheter GDM01. The balloon catheter had a diameter of 4 mm, a length of 4 cm, and a rated burst pressure of 18 atm. Successful passage through the lesion was achieved, effectively treating the stenosis.

A: The patient has a history of recurrent problems with AVFs, primarily due to venous stenosis. The latest assessment confirmed venous stenosis in the right forearm, which was treated with PTA.

P: The plan is to continue closely monitoring her condition and ensure proper AVF function. The patient is advised to contact the healthcare team if any changes or discomfort are observed in the right forearm. It is important to maintain the regular hemodialysis schedule and follow all additional instructions by the healthcare team.

S: The patient reports experiencing acroparesthesias, decreased sweating, exercise intolerance, frequent episodes of diarrhea, and abdominal discomfort. 

O: Physical examination revealed angiokeratomas on the patient's palms and genitals. The αGalA enzyme activity test showed a decreased level of 0.1 nmol/hour/liter. Genetic testing identified a mutation [c.317T>G (p.L106R)] in the GLA gene. Other lab results include a GFR of 104.4 mL/min/m2 and a 24-hour urinary albumin excretion of 6.00 mg/day. A renal ultrasound and DOPPLER echocardiogram were normal. Plasma Lyso-Gb3 was measured at 124.5 nmol/L. 

A: The patient has been diagnosed with Fabry disease (FD).

P: The plan is to initiate enzyme replacement therapy with agalsidase-beta at a dose of 1 mg/Kg/every other week. The patient's progress will be closely monitored with routine follow-ups to assess and adjust the treatment as needed.

S: The patient, a 4-day-old baby girl, was referred for a genetic evaluation due to bilateral asymmetric ectrodactyly. She is the second child of non-consanguineous parents. Her mother is 23 years old, and her father is 25 years old. The mother also has bilateral ectrodactyly, while the first child has normal growth and development with no congenital anomalies.
