Blood cell numbers increased by the next month's follow-up. Continued monitoring and reporting of any new symptoms were recommended.

S: The patient is a 42-year-old female nonsmoker with no significant medical history reported. Referred to Thoracic Surgery Department due to an abnormal chest X-ray showing a left pulmonary hilar nodule. Underwent bronchoscopic biopsy revealing small cell lung cancer (SCLC), staged as c-T2aN1M0, Stage IIA. Previous metastatic workups, including cranial MRI and bone scintigraphy, were negative. Nearly 4 years after first-line treatment, ProGRP levels started to increase.

O: Initial chest X-ray showed a left pulmonary hilar nodule of 3 cm. Bronchoscopic biopsy confirmed SCLC. Initial staging c-T2aN1M0, Stage IIA. Post-chemotherapy and thoracoscopic lobectomy staging as yp-T1N0M0, Stage IA. ProGRP levels observed to increase over time. PET-CT showed abnormal lesion in left ovary, and pelvic MRI indicated a solid tumor in the left ovary with an uneven contrast effect.

A: Previous diagnosis of small cell lung cancer. Current findings suggest potential metastatic recurrence based on increasing ProGRP levels and imaging results showing a lesion in the left ovary.

P: Referral to Obstetrics and Gynecology Department for further evaluation and treatment regarding the ovarian lesion. Further discussions with Gynecology regarding the next steps in management.

S: The patient, with a history of chronic alcoholism and cirrhosis (Child score A), reports noticing a growing mass in the oral cavity. During surveillance for cirrhosis, a mass was also detected on the left adrenal gland. The patient is concerned about these findings and is currently being assessed by oncology.

O: Examination revealed an exophytic lesion approximately 10 cm on the left mandible. Biopsies of adrenal and mandible lesions showed morphology and immunohistochemistry consistent with a hepatoid differentiation in carcinoma. Imaging will include abdomen MRI, CT scans, and PET-CT to assess liver changes and detect hypermetabolic activity in the mandible, pelvis bones, and adrenal mass.

A: The current diagnostic impression indicates metastatic hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), despite the absence of a liver tumor on imaging. An adrenocortical carcinoma with hepatoid differentiation is also a possibility. The patient's history of cirrhosis and biopsy findings contribute to this assessment.

P: The plan includes hospitalization for laboratory tests including serologic tests for hepatitis B and C, serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), and carcinoembryonic antigen levels. Imaging tests will be conducted to assess liver condition and potential metastasis. An exploratory laparoscopy with liver biopsy may be performed to obtain more information about liver tissue. Monitoring progression and adapting the treatment plan based on findings are also part of the management strategy.

S: The patient reports suddenly becoming unconscious and noticing black, tarry stools (melena), which prompted admission to the hospital. 

O: Upon admission, the patient was hemodynamically stable with a hemoglobin level of 12 g/dl. An upper endoscopy revealed a stomach filled with fresh blood but no esophageal varices or ulcers. The patient experienced hemodynamic instability, requiring intubation and polytransfusion. An angiography demonstrated a 2.5 cm saccular aneurysm on the distal third of the splenic artery with irregular contours. A postostial embolization with microcoils was performed. A CT scan later revealed a distal pancreatic tumor abutting the posterior gastric wall, potentially causing splenic artery erosion and aneurysm. A gastroscopy showed a posterior subcardial perforation, and biopsies confirmed invasive pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma. Follow-up revealed a decrease in hemoglobin to 7.4 g/dl and a new retrogastric blood extravasation. Coil embolization was performed in response.

A: The patient has been diagnosed with invasive pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma and is experiencing complications from a splenic artery aneurysm rupture and erosion, leading to gastrointestinal bleeding.

P: The plan involves discussing the case with a multidisciplinary team to determine appropriate treatment, which may include surgery, chemotherapy, or radiation therapy. The patient and family will be kept informed throughout the process. Further questions and concerns can be addressed by the healthcare team.

S: The patient reported a high-energy, multifragmentary compound fracture from a road traffic accident 4 months ago, classified as Gustilo-Anderson Type 3A. Initially treated with a Sarmiento cast, the patient experienced successful recovery, returning to work as a carpet fitter 6 months post-operation. However, 9 months after the expandable nail insertion, radiological signs of calcaneal resorption were noted, prompting recommendations for nail removal. The patient described unsuccessful first and second attempts to remove the nail, including a fracture during the initial removal process and difficulties with further attempts involving grabbers and drills.

O: The patient's fracture was classified as Gustilo-Anderson Type 3A. A 10 mm x 340 mm expandable nail stabilized the non-union. Radiological appearances suggested calcaneal resorption around the neck of the nail 9 months post-insertion. The nail was eventually removed piecemeal through an antero-medial tibial window using a Midas Rex® burr.

A: Right distal tibial non-union with varus deformity post high-energy fracture. Complications included calcaneal resorption and difficulty in nail removal due to fracture at the junction between the valve and metal fins.

P: The patient is advised to continue monitoring progress with regular clinical and radiological follow-ups to ensure proper healing of the tibia. They should report any issues or discomfort experienced during recovery.

S: The patient, a 13-month-old girl, was injured in a house fire, sustaining third-degree burns over 73% of her body. Her right knee suffered an open joint injury. She sometimes feels instability in her knee. The patient has been using a knee immobilizer for eight weeks as prescribed.

O: The patient had four skin grafting procedures prior to SEF (sub-fascia external fixation) placement, which was applied 46 days post-injury and kept for three weeks using K-wires and a 140-mm bar. One additional skin graft was needed on the right knee during SEF placement. At an eight-month follow-up, PT/OT notes showed normal range of motion and 5/5 motor strength but noted continued joint instability requiring knee immobilizer use.

A: The patient sustained severe third-degree burns with additional right knee joint instability post-injury. No long-term complications requiring further surgeries were recorded. Continued joint instability post-SEF was addressed with a knee immobilizer.

P: The plan includes scheduling follow-up appointments to monitor healing and ensure stability. The patient is advised to continue following instructions regarding the use of the knee immobilizer and to contact the office if any issues or concerns arise. No additional surgeries are anticipated at this time.

S: The patient is a 7-year-old boy experiencing severe intellectual disability, speech delay, and convulsive seizures. There is no reported family history of intellectual disability. He was initially diagnosed with ALS during infancy when typical phenotypic features were not clearly present.

O: Blood samples were obtained, and DNA was extracted using the High Pure PCR template purification kit by Roche. The DNA quality and concentration were assessed using an Implen NanoPhotometer. Whole exome sequencing was performed with a NextSeq 500 System configured with a read length of 2 × 150 bp and dual indexing. The sequencing was done with a 160 × coverage, with at least 93% of sequences having a minimum of 20 × coverage.

A: No specific diagnosis was provided, but germ-line variants were identified from the next-generation sequencing (NGS) data, which will aid in understanding the patient's condition better.

P: Continue monitoring the patient's symptoms and report any changes. Await further analysis of the NGS data for a more accurate diagnosis and potential treatment plan. The doctor will contact the family with results and recommendations once the analysis is complete.

S: The patient reports an increasing vulvar swelling for 25 years, which started as a small swelling and has been progressively growing. She began experiencing a dull aching pain about 3 months ago, along with difficulty urinating and dysuria. There is no discharge or bleeding. The patient has no significant medical or surgical history but underwent genital cutting and sewing during childhood. She is unemployed, does not use tobacco or alcohol, and has no family history of similar illnesses. She has not visited any healthcare facility or taken any medication for this issue before.

O: Vital signs show a pulse of 82, respiratory rate of 18, and temperature of 36°C. Physical examination reveals a fluctuant, multi-lobulated, mobile, non-tender mass in the right labia majora, involving the mons pubis and stretching the ventral skin of the urethra. The overlying skin appears normal, and the labial edges are fused at their cranial part. No abnormalities were found in the vagina, cervix, uterus, inguinal lymph nodes, musculoskeletal, or neurological examinations. Laboratory tests show hemoglobin at 13 gm/dl, white blood cell count at 6500/mm3, platelet count at 250,000, and urine analysis was non-revealing. Pelvic ultrasound shows an atrophied uterus with no additional pelvic mass.

A: The clinical impression is of a long-standing vulvar mass with complications such as pain and urinary difficulties. No evidence of malignancy or additional pelvic masses was identified.

P: The recommended plan is the surgical removal, or excision, of the vulvar mass to alleviate pain and discomfort. Further information about the procedure will be provided, and surgery will be scheduled.

S: The patient reports experiencing depressed mood, lack of enjoyment in activities, sleep disturbances, poor concentration, and occasional passive suicidal thoughts, related to the progression of symptoms from a SCA1 diagnosis. They experience coordination problems, ataxia, speech impairment, swallowing difficulties, spasticity, and muscle atrophy. The patient expresses that limited physical mobility strongly impacts their self-esteem and overall mood. They live alone but have sibling support several times a week.

O: The patient uses a motorized wheelchair due to worsening condition, lives in a house that is not fully wheelchair accessible, and was evaluated with a Beck Depression Inventory score of 23, indicating moderate depression. Laboratory evaluations were normal, including hemogram, liver function tests, total protein, vitamin B12, folic acid, T3, T4, and TSH.

A: Major depressive disorder associated with progression of SCA1 symptoms.

P: The patient has begun treatment with sertraline, 50 mg per day, and is attending group cognitive behavioral therapy sessions focusing on negative cognitions and dialectical behavioral therapy three times a week as part of the IOP protocol. It is recommended to continue medication and therapy to manage depression. The patient is advised to reach out to their support system and healthcare team as needed.

S: The patient experienced a severe injury to the right hand when it got caught in a mincing machine. The patient reports significant pain and has no special medical history or comorbidities.

O: The right hand shows a severed deformity at the wrist, extensive soft tissue crush, and an open wrist fracture. Emergency radiographs reveal a comminuted fracture of the wrist bones. The patient's Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS) is 8. A wound infection with Enterobacter cloacae was identified, which was treated and resolved with antibiotics and wound care.

A: Severe traumatic injury to the right hand with comminuted fracture and deformity. Post-operative wound infection effectively treated. Potential benefit from custom 3D-printed prosthetic due to loss of hand function.

P: Proceed with wrist disarticulation surgery involving volar and dorsal flaps, clamping and ligation of arteries, and dissection of nerves. Treat infection with antibiotics and standardized wound care. Perform repair of the amputation stump with a double-pedicle advancement flap. Design and manufacture a customized 3D-printed prosthetic hand for functional and comfort benefits. Monitor for any potential complications related to the prosthesis.

S: The patient reports hearing music in their head, which started a week after undergoing surgical evacuation of intraventricular and intracranial hemorrhages. The music consists of familiar songs that are distorted and louder than usual. The patient denies experiencing hallucinations, delusions, or changes in consciousness. They report issues with both short-term and long-term memory and suspect frontal lobar impairment.

O: The patient was recently admitted for severe, sudden headaches and diagnosed with intraventricular and intracranial hemorrhages. Post-surgery, a noncontrast CT (NCCT) brain scan showed no abnormalities. Physical examination found no neurological deficits. The patient was started on quetiapine, titrated from 25 mg to 150 mg, and has since experienced no further musical hallucinations.

A: The patient likely experienced musical hallucinations post-surgery for hemorrhages, which have resolved with the use of quetiapine. Memory issues and suspected frontal lobar impairment are noted without additional information from the conversation.

P: Continue quetiapine at the current dosage, 150 mg. The patient should remain vigilant for any side effects or recurrence of musical hallucinations and contact the healthcare provider if necessary. No further follow-up details are provided.

S: The patient reported experiencing lumbago and developed a fever with disturbance of consciousness, prompting them to visit the emergency room. They have a history of glioblastoma treated with neoadjuvant and adjuvant chemotherapy and radiation 6 years ago. They can carry out daily activities independently and have no history of pneumonia or pneumococcal vaccination. The patient's wife was hospitalized the same morning.

O: Upon hospitalization, pneumococcus was detected in the blood culture. Abnormal findings were noted in a lumbar MRI scan taken on hospital day 2; however, tests such as spinal fluid test, head MRI, thoracoabdominal contrast CT, and transesophageal echocardiography did not reveal infections at other sites. A subsequent MRI on hospital day 9 revealed purulent spondylitis.

A: The initial diagnosis was a fever of unknown origin with suspicion of pneumonia due to detected pneumococcus in the blood culture. Further assessments identified purulent spondylitis.

P: The antimicrobial regimen was adjusted to 2 g ABPC every 6 hours. The patient received antimicrobial drug treatment for 9 weeks to normalize white blood cell count, CRP level, blood sedimentation rate, and improve CT findings. The patient and spouse were vaccinated with a 13-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine initially and a 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine a year later. More than 1 year post-treatment, there has been no recurrence. The bacterial strain analysis identified the capsule serotype as 12F.

S: The patient's 12-year-old daughter experienced a seizure and lost consciousness. She was given glucose at the hospital, which helped her regain consciousness. Prior to this event, she had no significant comorbidities. An insulinoma and hyperparathyroidism in MEN-1 were diagnosed after further evaluation. The patient's parathyroid hormone level is slightly elevated at 66.0 pg/ml, and her adjusted serum calcium level is 10.3 mg/dL. No other tumors associated with MEN-1 were detected.

O: A CT scan showed a vascular-rich tumor, 20 mm in diameter, located in the head of her pancreas. The feeding artery of the tumor was not clearly demonstrated through angiography and selective arterial calcium injection. Parathyroid ultrasound did not reveal any parathyroid tumor. Her capillary blood glucose (BG) was 80 mg/dL prior to surgery, and continuous glucose infusion was started during the procedure. An Enlite™ sensor was inserted for continuous glucose monitoring, calibrated with a blood glucose meter.

A: The primary diagnostic impression includes insulinoma and hyperparathyroidism as part of MEN-1. The pancreatic tumor's location and vascular nature suggest it may be causing the patient's symptoms.

P: Consideration is being given to performing an extended surgical procedure such as pancreatoduodenectomy, with open abdominal surgery suggested. Continuous glucose infusion is in place for intraoperative glucose management. No premedication was administered. Follow-up and further management will be based on intraoperative findings and postoperative recovery.

S: The patient, Philip, reports right elbow pain that began a week ago while playing lacrosse with his children. The pain is located at the tip of the elbow and is sharp, worsening with movement and radiating down the forearm. He denies any falls but mentions being checked by his child with a lacrosse stick. He has self-administered Advil, which provided some relief. Philip has a history of hypertension and diabetes, is currently taking lisinopril 20 mg daily, and metformin 500 mg daily. He follows a low-salt, Mediterranean diet. Blood sugars have been 80-100 mg/dL, though not checked daily.

O: Blood pressure is elevated at 150/90 mmHg. Physical examination reveals pain upon palpation of the posterior elbow and mild pain with flexion and extension, but normal range of motion. An x-ray of the elbow shows no fractures or bony abnormalities. The heart exam notes a grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, previously known. Lungs are clear bilaterally.

A: Right elbow contusion, likely due to being hit with a lacrosse stick, causing pain and mild swelling. Hypertension appears to be controlled with current medication, with possible white coat syndrome. Diabetes appears well-managed, with planned A1c evaluation to confirm control.

P: Prescribe 800 mg of ibuprofen twice a day for pain and swelling. Advise icing the elbow three times a day for 20 minutes. Recommend avoiding lacrosse or similar activities temporarily to allow healing. Continue lisinopril 20 mg for hypertension and metformin 500 mg for diabetes. Plan to obtain A1c to evaluate diabetic control and potential need for medication adjustment. No changes to diet, as current low-salt, Mediterranean diet is appropriate. Follow-up as necessary based on test results.

S: The patient reports a four-day history of generalized abdominal pain following a colonoscopy. They also experience nausea and slightly reduced stoma output. The patient has a history of asthma and Crohn's disease, which was settled before the colonoscopy. There are no known drug allergies. The patient's past surgical history includes a complicated appendicectomy in 2007 leading to a colostomy, a colonic perforation, retroperitoneal abscess, ileostomy in 2010, and subsequent surgeries resulting in an ileocolonic anastomosis, dehiscence, sepsis, and a skin graft in 2012. The patient is a nonsmoker and consumes minimal alcohol.

O: Examination reveals heart rate 117 beats per minute, blood pressure 128/81 mmHg, respiratory rate 15, and oxygen saturation 98% on air. A ballotable mass with crepitus and a cough impulse is present over the hernia to the left of the midline, which is slightly tender. Stoma present, and the chest is clear with a GCS of 15/15. Blood tests show C-reactive protein of 219 mg/L, indicating significant inflammation. Imaging shows a large amount of free air in the abdomen.

A: The patient presents with signs of postoperative complications most likely related to their recent colonoscopy, with possible inflammation or infection as indicated by the elevated C-reactive protein and abdominal free air.

P: Monitor the patient closely for any changes in symptoms or vital signs. Determine the appropriate intervention in light of the elevated C-reactive protein and the presence of free air. Consider surgical or medical management options based on further evaluation of the patient's condition. Follow-up as needed to assess the effectiveness of the intervention.

S: The patient reports having difficulty swallowing and speaking after undergoing a McKeown minimally invasive esophagectomy for middle third esophageal cancer. Postoperatively, they experienced complications such as a cervical esophagogastric anastomotic leak, dysphonia, swallow dysfunction, and aspiration pneumonia, leading to long-term enteral feeding and intensive care. They also mention an acute episode of severe upper abdominal pain, nausea, and dyspnea after exertion.

O: Objective findings include a 5-hour and 20-minute surgery duration, staged IIIA (pT2N2M0) poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with recurrence in the right paratracheal lymph node, anterior chest wall, and right adrenal gland. Clinical examination showed the patient to be pale, bradycardic (35 bpm), hypotensive (60/40 mmHg), and tachypneic (26 breaths per minute) with reduced vesicular breath sounds over the left hemithorax. A CT scan indicated near-complete herniation of the small bowel, transverse colon, and greater omentum through a large left hemidiaphragm defect causing ipsilateral lung collapse. The patient also has coexisting alcoholic liver disease and chronic renal failure.

A: The diagnostic impression includes recurrent esophageal cancer, postoperative complications such as cervical esophagogastric anastomotic leak, dysphonia, swallow dysfunction, aspiration pneumonia, a giant diaphragmatic hernia causing lung collapse, and the presence of coexisting chronic conditions.

P: The plan includes continuous monitoring and follow-up for cancer management and postoperative recovery, including adherence to treatment for alcoholic liver disease and chronic renal failure. Emergency relaparoscopy was conducted for the diaphragmatic hernia. The patient is encouraged to follow all medical advice to manage coexisting conditions and contact healthcare providers with any concerns.

S: The patient, a 24-year-old autistic nonverbal male, presented with increasing lethargy, frequent urination, and several episodes of nonbloody vomiting over the past few days.

O: Upon admission, the patient's vitals were stable. He exhibited confusion, dehydration, and lethargy. Tests revealed hypernatremia, highly elevated blood glucose levels, serum creatinine of 5.29 mg/dl, low bicarbonate levels at 13 mmol/L, hyperphosphatemia, high anion gap metabolic acidosis, and a serum osmolality of 395 mmol/kg. The serum acetone was large. Urinalysis showed ketones, proteinuria, high glucose levels, and dark tea-colored urine with large amounts of urine blood but only a few red blood cells. A CT scan of the abdomen was consistent with pancreatitis, with normal amylase and lipase levels.

A: The patient was diagnosed with diabetes type 2 and presented in a hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state. He experienced diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). The glutamic acid decarboxylase test resulted in less than 5 IU/mL, confirming the type 2 diabetes diagnosis.

P: The patient was aggressively hydrated with intravenous normal saline, received electrolyte replacement, and treated for DKA in the ICU. He was transitioned to subcutaneous insulin and started on a diabetic diet. Continuous monitoring and adjustment of insulin and dietary support are planned, along with management guidance for the new diabetes type 2 diagnosis.

S: The patient reported experiencing pain in the upper part of the stomach and a significant feeling of bloating. There is no reported history of pancreatitis.

O: An abdominal ultrasonography showed a 6 x 5 cm cystic lesion without a solid component in the pancreatic tail. MRI revealed a cystic lesion with calcified walls in the pancreatic tail and a 6 x 3 cm hypointense lesion invading the splenic vein with less contrast uptake. The CA 19-9 level was elevated at 1012 IU/ml. PET-CT showed increased FDG metabolization in the pancreas body (SUVmax of 11.8) and no involvement of the cystic lesion in the pancreas tail.

A: The diagnosis includes a Type V hydatid cyst in the pancreatic tail and an intermediate-grade ductal pancreatic adenocarcinoma with a clear surgical margin. There was no histological relationship between the lesions.

P: The plan included performing a subtotal pancreatectomy with splenectomy, which was completed, leading to discharge on postoperative day 11. The patient is referred to medical oncology for further evaluation and management.

S: The patient reports a bilateral Class I canine relationship and left Class I molar relationship in the permanent dentition, with a crossbite of tooth 12. The chief complaint is the anterior crossbite, and the patient prefers to use an invisible orthodontic appliance. The patient expresses concerns about adverse staining with ceramic brackets and does not want to use removable appliances like aligners.

O: No information provided.

A: The patient presents with an anterior crossbite and a preference for invisible orthodontic treatment. The clinician considers a lingual orthodontic appliance as the best option due to the patient's concerns and preferences.

P: The plan is to use a lingual orthodontic appliance, designed with a CAD/CAM digital workflow, to resolve the anterior crossbite and ensure retention over time. The procedure includes polishing dental surfaces with pumice, performing an intraoral scan to create 3D models, and using the NemoCast software for virtual setup and precise bracket placement. A virtual transfer tray will be designed, and a prototype manufactured for indirect bonding. Written informed consent will be obtained before proceeding.

S: The patient reports experiencing epigastric pain for the past nine months, a decrease in appetite, and a weight loss of about 30 pounds. They have a history of hypertension and smoking. There is a family history of cancer, with a maternal aunt who had pancreatic cancer and another aunt with breast cancer.

O: A CT scan revealed a mass in the pancreas measuring 4 cm x 3.8 cm x 2.6 cm, encasing the superior mesenteric artery. Laboratory tests showed elevated alanine transaminase at 160 IU/L, alkaline phosphatase at 256 IU/L, and elevated CA 19-9 at 177 U/mL. An EGD showed a nodule at the gastroesophageal junction, which was removed via endoscopic mucosal resection. An EUS revealed an ill-defined, hypoechogenic, lobular area measuring 19.6 mm x 24.7 mm between the head and body of the pancreas, with no lymph nodes seen. Pathology confirmed adenocarcinoma of the pancreatic mass and a nodule at the gastroesophageal junction with mucinous features.

A: The patient is diagnosed with a double primary adenocarcinoma of the pancreas and the gastroesophageal junction. The pancreatic mass was positive for CK7, CK20, DPP4, and CDX2, with microsatellite stability. The gastroesophageal junction nodule showed KRAS amplification and other genomic alterations.

P: The patient has been referred for further management at the institution. A detailed treatment plan will be developed, and the patient's progress will be closely monitored.

S: The patient reported experiencing a high fever and severe cough for five days, leading to hospital admission. During treatment, they developed difficulty breathing and fatigue. 

O: Initial pulmonary CT suggested inflammatory consolidation with atelectasis. On examination, temperature was 38.0°C, heart rate 135 bpm, respiration rate 32/min, blood pressure 90/60 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation 90% without oxygen. Exam revealed decreased respiratory sound in the right lung. Blood tests showed Hb at 132 g/l, WBC at 12.2 × 10^9/L, AST at 2,031 U/L, ALT at 1,595 U/L, LDH at 2,673 U/L, CK-MB at 41 U/L, triglyceride at 1.33 mmol/l, PCT at 1.56 ng/ml, CRP at 38.8 mg/l, and ferritin at 4,355 ng/ml. MP-DNA in BAL fluid was positive with 1 × 10^8 copies/ml and MP resistance mutation site 2063/2064; MP-DNA of hydrothorax positive at 3.2 × 10^5 copies/ml. Pulmonary CT on the second day showed substantial pulmonary consolidation in the upper and middle lobes.

A: The patient likely had a severe pulmonary infection with inflammatory consolidation and atelectasis, compounded by hypoxemia and impaired gas exchange. The presence of MP-DNA and resistance mutations indicated Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection with significant systemic inflammation.

P: Treatment included cephalothin and azithromycin. Ventilatory support was provided with a reservoir mask at 6 l/min. Close monitoring and adjustments to treatment were indicated due to substantial pulmonary consolidation and infection severity. Continued discussions on progress and treatment adaptation were planned.

S: The patient reported feeling weak and tired. They experienced whole-body itching (pruritus) on Day 32 of intravenous vancomycin treatment. On Day 33, a rapidly spreading erythematous macular rash appeared on the torso, spread to the extremities including palms and soles, and led to desquamation covering about 80% of the body surface area. The patient also had intense skin pain, intermittent fevers, and ageusia (loss of taste). There were no pulmonary symptoms such as cough, chest pain, or shortness of breath.

O: Elevated laboratory findings included a white blood cell count of 23.6 x 10^3/µL, peripheral blood eosinophilia at 12%, erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 27 mm/hr, C-reactive protein at 6.385 mg/L, and serum creatinine of 2.3 mg/dL. Blood cultures were consistently negative. Serum alanine transaminase (ALT) and aspartate transaminase (AST) concentrations were within the normal range. The patient's hemoglobin oxygen saturation by pulse oximetry remained above 95% throughout the hospital course.

A: The patient is continuing to experience systemic and dermatological adverse reactions potentially linked to the intravenous vancomycin treatment. Differential considerations might include drug hypersensitivity reactions. Elevated inflammatory markers and eosinophilia suggest an ongoing inflammatory or allergic response.

P: Continue monitoring laboratory values including inflammatory markers and renal function due to elevated serum creatinine. Potential adjustment or reevaluation of antibiotic therapy might be considered given the adverse reactions. The patient should be monitored for any additional symptoms or changes, and supportive care should be provided for symptomatic relief of skin symptoms and taste disturbances. Follow-up laboratory tests and clinical evaluations should be scheduled to monitor the patient's recovery and response to any treatment changes.

S: The patient, a 62-year-old man, reports experiencing severe abdominal pain and tenderness. He has a history of obstructive jaundice and pancreatitis due to locally advanced pancreatic head cancer and underwent endoscopic placement of biliary and pancreatic stents, followed by chemoradiotherapy with gemcitabine and S-1. The severe pain developed suddenly four months after treatment, with slight epigastric pain a week before the consultation.

O: Vitals: Blood pressure is 91/67 mmHg, pulse rate is 113/min, and temperature is 37.0 °C. Laboratory findings show elevated leukocytes at 10,100/μl and elevated C-reactive protein at 13.92 mg/dl. CT scan reveals the tip of the pancreatic stent protruding from the pancreatic body with fluid collection around the pancreas, omental bursa, and Douglas cavum.

A: The patient is diagnosed with panperitonitis due to perforation of the pancreatic duct.

P: The plan involves performing an emergency operation to address the perforation. The procedure will include inserting pancreatic tubes into both sides of the perforated site and suturing between the posterior wall of the stomach and pancreas, followed by percutaneous transgastric drainage. Pancreatectomy and anastomosis are being avoided to reduce the risk of postoperative complications. The operation is estimated to take 173 minutes. Postoperative recovery is expected to be uneventful, with a transition to internal drainage during recovery. The patient's progress will be monitored and adjustments made as needed.

S: The patient is a 3-year-old boy who was admitted to the emergency department due to severe respiratory distress, experiencing difficulty breathing. He had no prior symptoms or chronic diseases and no family history of lung disease or smoking.

O: At admission, vital signs were normal except for a high respiratory rate of 45 per minute. Laboratory tests including total blood count, liver, and renal function were unremarkable. Physical exam revealed a 2x1 cm palpable mass on the right side of the neck. A CT scan showed bilateral air cysts with ground glass appearance and pneumothorax. A biopsy of the neck mass confirmed Langerhans cell histiocytosis in the right salivary gland with certain histological features. Immunohistochemical staining was positive for CD1a and S100. The patient underwent multiple interventions for pneumothorax including chest tubes and chemical pleurodesis, followed by thoracoscopic bullae excision and pleural decortication.

A: The patient was diagnosed with Langerhans cell histiocytosis affecting the right salivary gland and developed persistent bilateral pneumothorax. Subsequent complications included subcutaneous emphysema and unresponsiveness to initial treatments.

P: Treatment included chemotherapy with vinblastine and prednisone, tube thoracostomy, chemical pleurodesis, and thoracoscopic bullae excision with pleural decortication. Further monitoring and treatment adjustments will continue based on the patient's condition.

S: The patient reports a lump on the left thumb that has been present for a few months, with slow growth over time. There has been no discharge or infection associated with the lump, and the patient expresses concern about its presence.

O: On examination, the lump is approximately 1 by 1 cm, located proximal to the base of the nail on the dorsal aspect of the distal phalanx of the left thumb. An X-ray was performed, showing no signs of a bony spur. The lesion was excised under local anesthesia, and the excision was smoothly performed with the lesion easily dissected from the surrounding tissue.

A: The initial assessment included possible differential diagnoses of a mucoid cyst, epidermoid cyst, or squamous cell carcinoma. After histopathology evaluation, the lesion was identified as an inflamed pilar cyst.

P: The plan is to monitor the area for any signs of recurrence. A follow-up appointment is scheduled in 3 months to ensure the operative site has healed well and there is no recurrence.

S:  
The patient is a 75-year-old man on hemodialysis for end-stage renal disease. He reports experiencing a cough, fever, altered mental status, and some difficulty breathing. 

O:  
The patient's temperature is 103°F, pulse 68, blood pressure 124/69, respiratory rate 22, and O2 saturation 96% on 2 L O2 by nasal cannula. The patient appears lethargic. Physical examination reveals bibasilar crackles. Laboratory tests show a WBC count of 20,100 cells/mm3, plasma procalcitonin of 1.1 ng/mL, and chest X-ray indicating bibasilar infiltrates. Sputum microscopic examination shows profuse PMNs and Gram-positive rods. Sputum culture yields predominantly Corynebacteria, identified as C. propinquum, with rare P. aeruginosa. Blood cultures and viral PCR are negative.

A:  
The patient is diagnosed with pneumonia primarily caused by C. propinquum, based on clinical presentation, laboratory findings, and negative results for other bacterial and viral pathogens.

P:  
The treatment plan includes starting antibiotics: vancomycin, cefepime, and metronidazole. The treatment will be reassessed in a few days, with plans to discontinue cefepime and metronidazole if the patient responds well and continue with vancomycin only. After improvement, the patient will complete a 10-day course of linezolid post-discharge.

S:  
The patient, a 3-year-old boy, presents with discomfort in the groin area. Complaints include a palpable testis in the left groin and a nonpalpable undescended testis on the right side.

O:  
Physical examination reveals a palpable testis in the left groin and a nonpalpable testis on the right side. MRI results show the left testis in the left hemiscrotum, measuring 1.3 × 0.6 cm, associated with a mild hydrocele, and another testis, measuring 1.2 × 0.6 cm, located on the ipsilateral side within the left inguinal canal. During exploration, both testes were found on the same side, each with separate vasa deferentia and testicular vessels, sharing a common cremasteric muscle and tunical covering.

A:  
Unilateral undescended testis with ectopic positioning – both testes are on the left side, indicating possible testicular ectopia or duplication anomaly.

P:  
Plan to perform a herniotomy. Post-procedure, the ectopic testis will be fixed transseptally to the right hemiscrotum. Follow-up care and monitoring are advised post-surgery to ensure recovery and evaluate for any long-term effects.

S: The patient reported a history of persistent diarrhea with 4-5 watery stools per day without blood and mucus, accompanied by a fever up to 39 °C, which began a year before hospitalization. He was treated with amoxicillin, ciprofloxacin, and cefuroxime, experiencing periodic improvement but no complete resolution of symptoms. The patient also noted a weight loss of 10 kg. His medical history of chronic diseases and previous travels is unremarkable.

O: Upon admission, a physical examination showed numerous enlarged cervical lymphatic nodes, tenderness to palpation in the left subcostal region, and intensive bowel movements. Lab results indicated an acute inflammatory response with increased CRP, ESR, leukocytosis, monocytosis, neutrocytosis, and thrombocytosis. Bacteriological stool tests were negative for infections such as Salmonella, Shigella, Escherichia coli, and Yersinia spp. However, parasitological testing revealed numerous Cryptosporidium spp. oocysts. Stool samples also showed elevated WBCs and RBCs and a high level of fecal calprotectin (895 μg/l). FOBT was positive. Colonoscopy showed intensive inflammatory mucosal lesions, numerous polyps, stool-purulent content, ulcers, and cryptitis. CT scans revealed extraperitoneum lymphadenopathy, intestine wall inflammation, and mucosa thickening. Histopathology indicated abnormal lamina propria architecture with cryptitis. 

A: The findings indicate a severe case of cryptosporidiosis with significant bowel inflammation and associated symptoms, confirmed by stool tests and colonoscopy findings. The possibility of immunodeficiency has been ruled out.

P: The plan involves continued monitoring of the patient's condition and appropriate treatment to manage the inflammation and infection. The patient is advised to maintain good hygiene and report any recurring or concerning symptoms immediately.

S: 
The patient reports experiencing bleeding from her prolapsed uterus. She is 80 years old and has had 3 vaginal births, with the last birth at age 30. Her last menstruation was at age 52. She denies having any past or current chronic diseases or addictions and has been in one relationship.

O: 
During the examination, a large part of the vagina containing the cervix and part of the uterine body was noted to be below the vaginal introits, classified as International Continence Society grade 3. Exophytic infiltrating lesions were covering the entire surface of the hypertrophic cervix, spreading to the vaginal fornices. A small myoma of 2 cm in diameter was found in the uterine body. Adnexa were impalpable, and a tumor was detected in the anal canal. A diagnostic procedure revealed a polypoid lesion measuring 2.5 cm in diameter just behind the external sphincter, and an infiltrating lesion occupying the posterior wall of the rectum, 4 cm from the anal rim. Microscopic examination of the cervical and anal canal lesions showed moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma, with a strong and diffuse immunohistochemical p16 reaction in the neoplastic cells.

A: 
The patient has invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix and anal canal. There is a high risk of cancer spreading.

P: 
The patient will be admitted to the department of Obstetrics and Gynaecological Oncology for further examination and to determine the cause of bleeding. Treatment options and close monitoring of the condition will be discussed to manage the high risk of cancer spreading. Further treatment options must be discussed with the oncology team.

S: The patient reports blurred vision, hyperemia, and pain in the right eye. They have experienced previous episodes of recurrent uveitis without renal involvement, one and three years after being diagnosed. The patient denies experiencing fever, asthenia, anorexia, arthralgia, myalgia, ulcers, abdominal pain, lower back pain, or urinary symptoms.

O: The patient has been diagnosed with bilateral nongranulomatous anterior uveitis. Hypertension and raised inflammatory markers were found, with a C-reactive protein level of 2.6 mg/dL and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 96 mm/first hour. The glomerular filtration rate is 48 ml/min/1.73m2, and there is evidence of hypokalemia, metabolic acidosis, leukocyturia, glucosuria, hematuria, non-nephrotic proteinuria, and raised urine β2-microglobulin levels. Infections such as Hepatitis B and C, toxoplasmosis, brucellosis, Epstein-Barr virus, and cytomegalovirus have been ruled out. Chest X-ray images and ACE levels are normal, and the patient is negative for ANA and ANCA. Ultrasound imaging shows slightly enlarged kidneys, and a biopsy indicates acute tubulointerstitial nephritis.

A: The patient has bilateral nongranulomatous anterior uveitis, acute tubulointerstitial nephritis, hypertension, and secondary findings of renal tubular dysfunction.

P: The treatment plan includes ocular dexamethasone and mydriatics for the eyes, and oral prednisolone (5 mg/m2/day), amlodipine, and potassium citrate for hypertension and renal conditions. The goal is to normalize blood pressure, serum creatinine, and tubular function, achieving remission from uveitis within three months. Two months after remission, methotrexate (10 mg/m2/week) will be initiated to prevent recurrent uveitis, with potential dosage adjustment to 12.5 mg/m2/week as needed. Follow-up is advised, with instructions to contact if symptoms worsen.

S: The patient is experiencing discomfort in the mouth with a specific growth near the corner of the mouth causing pain. The patient expresses concern about the seriousness of the condition.

O: The patient has been diagnosed with stage II buccal squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) involving the labial commissure.

A: The assessment is stage II buccal squamous cell carcinoma of the labial commissure. 

P: The plan includes performing surgery to remove the tumor and reconstruct the affected area using an A-EF flap drawn along the nasolabial fold. The patient will undergo radical neck dissection under general anesthesia. Expected outcomes include excellent esthetic results for the cheek and lip, and normal function of orbicularis oris and speech post-surgery. A follow-up plan involves monitoring for recurrence and performing salvage surgery if needed. At 23 months, a local recurrence occurred, and salvage surgery was conducted.

S: The patient has been experiencing continuous pain and bleeding from the residual vagina. A past medical history includes a transurethral resection of a bladder tumor (TURBT) in 2004, diagnosed as high-grade urothelial carcinoma with adenocarcinomatous differentiation. Recently, an MRI detected a tumor in the residual vagina, and a biopsy revealed adenocarcinoma. The patient also underwent imaging tests (CT and bone scintigraphy) showing no metastasis at that time. The surgical resection of the tumor required partial resection of the sigmoid colon due to adherence. After surgery, local recurrence and pelvic bone metastasis were detected. Additionally, the patient developed ileus in January 2011, treated surgically, and has since developed multiple lung metastases and pelvic recurrence.

O: Pathological examination revealed adenocarcinoma and SCC in the tumor. Immunohistochemistry was positive for SCC markers (CD56, chromogranin A, synaptophysin) and negative for urothelial carcinoma markers (GATA-3, p63, uroplakin, thrombomodulin, and 34βE12). Recurrence and metastasis were confirmed via MRI three months post-surgery.

A: The patient has a recurring bladder tumor with adenocarcinoma and SCC features. There's a confirmed local recurrence in the pelvis and pelvic bone metastasis. Multiple lung metastases and further pelvic recurrence have developed since.

P: The patient is undergoing radiation therapy to control tumor spread (52 Gy, 26 fractions). The plan includes continued monitoring and appropriate treatment management to address disease progression and symptoms.

S: The patient is an 8-year-old neutered male miniature Poodle who was hit by a car 4 days ago. He was initially seen at a local emergency clinic, where spinal trauma was suspected, and a possible vertebral injury or intravertebral disc compression at T2-T3 was noted. Currently, he struggles with breathing, has difficulty moving, and experiences significant pain, especially when his neck is touched. 

O: The initial examination revealed tachypnea and lateral recumbency, with a body condition score of 5/9. Pain was noted at 2/4 on the Canine Acute Pain Scale. A neurologic exam showed the dog was laterally recumbent, quiet, and alert with intact cranial nerve function. He was nonambulatory with paresis of thoracic limbs and plegia of pelvic limbs, increased muscle tone in thoracic limbs, a right head turn, decreased conscious proprioception in thoracic limbs, and absent proprioception in pelvic limbs. Segmental reflexes remained intact, though the panniculus reflex was absent caudal to L1 bilaterally. Blood work indicated elevated alanine aminotransferase (185U/L), normochromic normocytic anemia (hematocrit 35.7%), leukocytosis (15.69K/uL), neutrophilia (10.7K/uL), and monocytosis (2K/uL).

A: The diagnostic impressions suggest inflammation or infection with potential liver involvement due to elevated liver enzymes and anemia. Neurolocalization is determined to be T3-L3 with suspected C6-T2 involvement, indicative of trauma-related spinal injuries.

P: The plan involves continuing medical management and close monitoring of the dog's condition. Further diagnostics, such as an MRI or CT scan, may be required to assess the extent of injuries. Consultation with a specialist is planned to optimize the treatment strategy. The owner should watch closely for any changes in the dog's condition and report them promptly.

S: The patient has been experiencing severe neutropenia for 6 months, unresponsive to granulocyte-colony stimulating factor at a maximum dose of 20 mcg/kg daily. They had recurrent upper respiratory infections and stomatitis early in life. The patient was born after a full-term gestation, with a birth weight of 3,600 g. There is no significant family medical history.

O: Physical examination showed splenomegaly with a long axis of 11.5 cm on ultrasound. Blood tests revealed profound neutropenia with an absolute neutrophil count of 0.02 × 10^9/L, with no anemia or thrombocytopenia. Bone marrow examination showed normal erythroid and megakaryocyte lineages, rare myeloid precursors, and below-normal growth of myeloid cells. The patient's bone marrow plasma inhibited the growth of progenitor cells from healthy donors. Anti-neutrophil IgG levels were 171.1 mg/dL.

A: The findings suggest a misdiagnosed form of autoimmune neutropenia. Differential diagnoses such as Kostmann disease, Shwachman-Diamond syndrome, Fanconi anemia, and paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria were excluded.

P: Continue to explore treatment options for autoimmune neutropenia and closely monitor the patient's condition. Maintain communication with the healthcare team to develop a tailored treatment plan. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns.

S: The patient reports a history of spine surgery 15 years ago for a right L4-L5 disc herniation. Initially, there was relief, but pain returned after three years. The patient underwent several treatments at a pain clinic, including intra-foraminal L4-L5 and L5-S1 corticosteroid injections and percutaneous radiofrequency denervation over 10 years. In June 2014, the patient experienced severe bilateral L5 sciatalgy with paresthesias and mictional delay but no motor dysfunction.

O: An MRI in July 2014 revealed a disc herniation originating from the L4-L5 disc, perforating the common longitudinal ligament and anterior dura, entering the thecal sac, and extending to the upper sacrum. The intradural herniation is large, with rootlets surrounding the disc fragment. The upper disc fragment shows compact characteristics typical of extradural herniations with some peripheral contrast enhancement. The intradural part appears crumbled with irregular borders and no contrast enhancement. Surgery involved hemilaminectomy on L4 and L5 with adjacent hemiflavectomy at L3/4 and L5/S1.

A: The patient had a recurrent L4-L5 disc herniation with intradural extension, causing severe bilateral sciatalgy and mictional delay. Post-surgical intervention was warranted due to the severity and complexity of the condition.

P: The patient should follow post-operative care instructions from the surgeon, attend all follow-up appointments, and promptly report any changes in symptoms. Rehabilitation and physical therapy may be recommended to aid recovery and improve strength and mobility.

S: The patient reports feeling nervous but otherwise okay. She has been diagnosed with papillary serous adenocarcinoma and uterine masses. Her medical history includes hypertension, hemorrhoids, morbid obesity with a BMI of 46.8, and a pulmonary embolism three months ago. She describes her functional capacity as moderate to excellent, performing all household chores, cycling three to five miles daily, and climbing two flights of stairs. She has no history of anesthetic complications and no known family history of such complications. She had a colonoscopy with deep sedation. The patient is a non-smoker and consumes one alcoholic beverage about four times per month. She is allergic to benazepril, which causes tachycardia, and to ezetimibe, simvastatin, and triamterene, which cause myalgias.

O: The patient's current medications include prochlorperazine 10 mg as needed post-chemotherapy, dexamethasone 4 mg for three days post-chemotherapy, rivaroxaban 20 mg daily, and enoxaparin 120 mg/0.8 mL solution subcutaneously (held two days prior to surgery). She also takes hydrochlorothiazide-valsartan 12.5-320 mg daily for hypertension. Preoperative baseline vital signs include a temperature of 36°C. There is a plan to use standard anesthesia monitors during surgery.

A: Diagnosed with papillary serous adenocarcinoma and uterine masses. Relevant medical history includes hypertension, morbid obesity, and recent pulmonary embolism. No anesthetic complications or family history thereof.

P: Perform exploratory laparotomy, total abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, omentectomy, debulking, and lymph node dissection. Administer 2 mg of midazolam for anxiolysis preoperatively. Use standard anesthesia monitors during the procedure. Continue current medication regimen, with adjustments for perioperative care as noted. No further information on follow-up provided.

S: The patient is a 52-year-old man with a history of hypertension, coronary artery disease, and end-stage renal disease, undergoing continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (PD) for 3 years. He presents with cloudy dialysate and diffuse abdominal pain for the past 2 hours. He recently completed a 10-day course of moxifloxacin for community-acquired pneumonia but reports his cough hasn't improved and remains severe. Two days ago, he visited the emergency department with epigastric pain and intractable cough, but without nausea, vomiting, or fever. An abdominal ultrasound revealed a distended gallbladder with sludge, and he was discharged with antitussives and analgesics.

O: Vital signs: Temperature 36 °C, heart rate 104 bpm, respiratory rate 19 bpm, blood pressure 121/91 mmHg. Physical examination indicates diffuse abdominal tenderness with peritoneal irritation, and a clean exit site for the PD catheter. Prior labs showed WBC count of 12,000 cells/mm³ (87% neutrophils), hemoglobin 8.0 g/dL, and other routine blood tests. PD dialysate effluent analysis initially had WBC 2/μL without PMN and later WBC 1783/μL including 50% PMN. Chest radiography showed no signs of pneumonia. Follow-up dialysate analysis on day 2 showed WBC 1565/μL (PMN 71%).

A: The patient is diagnosed with PD peritonitis as indicated by the increased WBC count and PMN percentage in the PD dialysate effluent analysis. Persistent cough is likely contributing to abdominal strain.

P: The patient is admitted to the ward for treatment of PD peritonitis. He will receive intraperitoneal Cefuroxime and amikacin as empirical treatment. Daily monitoring of PD dialysate effluent will be conducted to assess response and adjust treatment accordingly.

S: The patient, a 43-year-old woman, reports severe dysphonia related to scarred vocal folds following phonosurgery. She has a history of thyroidectomy for goiter and hysterectomy for endometriosis. Five years ago, she had two laryngeal surgeries: suspension laryngoscopy for resection of Reinke edema and a right ventricular lesion biopsy, followed by cervicotomy with lateral thyrotomy, resulting in a chondroma diagnosis. Subsequently, another suspension laryngoscopy for granuloma excision on the left vocal fold was performed without recurrence of laryngeal pathologies. Despite regular speech therapy, she has persistent dysphonia, which presents as a hoarse, unstable, and slightly breathy voice with difficulty reaching high notes.

O: Videolaryngostroboscopy showed a scarred appearance of the vocal folds with absence of vibration in the middle third. Vocal assessment confirmed dysphonia characterized by a hoarse, unstable, and slightly breathy voice.

A: The clinical impression is severe dysphonia due to scarred vocal folds post-phonosurgery.

P: The patient is eligible for a phase I clinical trial involving a local injection of autologous adipose-derived stromal vascular fraction (ADSVF) to improve vocal fold flexibility and vibration. The injection will be scheduled shortly. The patient is advised to continue speech therapy and will be closely monitored throughout the trial.

S: The patient is a 73-year-old Caucasian woman with a history of hypertension. She reports experiencing intermittent subjective fever, anorexia, weakness, and fatigue for the past two weeks, along with night sweats and a persistent non-productive cough. She denies any weight changes, sore throat, or rashes. The patient recalls having knee pain following a hike, which resolved without intervention. She has no known recent sick contacts, sexual partners, insect/tick bites, or exposure to tuberculosis or animals. She traveled to the Channel Islands three months ago. She is currently taking enalapril for hypertension.

O: During the physical examination, the patient appeared non-toxic. Vital signs showed a temperature of 38.6 °C, heart rate of 96 beats/minute, blood pressure of 130/65 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 99% on room air. No rashes, lymphadenopathy, jugular venous distension, or signs of hyperthyroidism were observed. Heart sounds were normal, with no extra sounds or murmurs, and lungs were clear with equal breath sounds bilaterally. The abdomen was soft and non-tender, with no hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, or asterixis. The knees appeared normal.

A: The patient's symptoms and examination findings suggest a need for further evaluation to determine the underlying cause of her fever, anorexia, weakness, and fatigue. The absence of certain findings such as rash or lymphadenopathy may narrow differential diagnoses but further investigation is warranted.

P: Proceed with additional tests to identify the cause of the patient's symptoms. Await test results for further diagnostic clarity and plan appropriate follow-up or treatment upon receiving results.

S: The patient reports experiencing headaches and a visual problem with the left side of their vision, specifically noting difficulty seeing in the lower left part of their visual field.

O: The CT angiography shows a left superior carotid-ophthalmic aneurysm measuring 4 x 5 mm.

A: The patient has a left superior carotid-ophthalmic aneurysm, which may be causing the reported headaches and visual field deficit.

P: The plan includes regular monitoring of the aneurysm through check-ups and imaging tests. Additionally, the patient should manage risk factors such as high blood pressure, smoking, and excessive alcohol consumption. The patient is advised to contact the doctor with any further questions or concerns.

S: The patient is a 66-year-old female with a history of osteopenia and gallstones. Her family history includes colon cancer and Gaucher disease (GD) with three successive generations being affected. Her son and father had colon cancer and GD in their 30s, presenting with easy bruising, thrombocytopenia, and splenomegaly. The patient herself had colon cancer in her 50s, successfully resected, with pathology showing Gaucher cells. She is currently asymptomatic, experiencing no bone pain, fractures, bruising, bleeding, fatigue, or weight loss. The family has been tested for familial colon cancer, with results being noncontributory for Lynch syndrome.

O: The patient's pulse rate during examination was regular but low at 42 beats per minute. There was no evidence of hepatosplenomegaly or purpura. Mild cervical dystonia with neck ratcheting to the left was observed. The complete blood count was within normal limits. β-glucosidase activity was reduced at 2 nmol/h/mg (normal range is 8–16). Gene analysis detected a homozygous pathogenic variant in the GBA gene (N370S/N370S), confirming GD. Elevated biomarker levels were found: ACE at 66 U/L (normal range 9–63), chitotriosidase at 1603 nmoles/h/ml (normal range 4–120), and glucosylsphingosine at 164 ng/mL (normal range <10 ng/mL).

A: The patient has Gaucher disease (GD) confirmed by genetic analysis and elevated lipid storage biomarkers. The low pulse rate and cervical dystonia are noted but may not be related directly to GD.

P: Plan includes monitoring the patient's condition and discussing potential treatment options for Gaucher disease. Regular follow-up appointments should be scheduled to manage and evaluate her symptoms and response to any initiated therapy.

S: The patient reports having a history of asthma and skin cancer. There has been no recent trauma. The patient refused an enhanced CT scan due to concerns about the side effects of the contrast agent given their asthma.

O: Initial chest X-ray showed abnormal shadows. Blood tests including haematology, renal, and hepatic function were normal. Electrocardiograms revealed no abnormalities. A chest CT found a well-defined, homogeneous tumour (66 X 65 X 45 mm) behind the trachea with 45 Hounsfield units but no calcification or fat. MRI showed a high signal on T2W1 images, indicating a cystic tumour. During surgery, the tumour appeared dark purple-red and saccular, connected to the azygos vein and adhered to the superior vena cava.

A: The differential diagnosis included bronchogenic cyst, neurogenic tumour, Castleman disease, and malignant lymphoma. The final diagnosis was a bronchogenic cyst.

P: The patient underwent cyst excision. Post-operatively, liver function was monitored for 6 days, leading to discharge. The patient is currently in good health and has been well for 4 years post-surgery. Future health monitoring is advised.

S: The owner of an 8-year-old female spayed Dachshund reports a large, firm, symmetrical, painful perineal protrusion that appeared suddenly 2 days ago. The dog has a one-month history of dysuria and pollakiuria, initially thought to be due to a urinary tract infection treated with amoxicillin-clavulanic acid. However, after lack of response, a urine culture identified a Staphylococcus organism, and treatment was changed to marbofloxacin. The owner also reports the onset of tenesmus 2 days ago coinciding with the protrusion's appearance. The dog was spayed 2 years ago after multiple unsuccessful breeding attempts.

O: Physical examination reveals a 5 × 4 × 2 cm firm, painful protrusion in the perineal region, ventral to the anus. A digital rectal exam shows a fluid-filled structure ventral to the rectum and distal colon, with no pelvic diaphragm weakness. CT and vaginoscopy reveal a large, tubular, fluid-filled structure 4 cm in diameter and 16.3 cm long occupying the pelvic canal and caudal abdomen, compressing the colon and rectum dorsally and the urethra ventrally, and displacing the bladder to the left of the midline. Mild dilation of both renal pelves and proximal ureters is also noted.

A: The diagnostic impressions include a large fluid-filled structure in the pelvic canal and caudal abdomen resulting in significant compression and displacement of abdominal organs. Mild dilation of renal pelves and proximal ureters suggests possible secondary pyelonephritis or backpressure effects. Perineal hernia is considered unlikely due to lack of pelvic diaphragm weakness.

P: The plan includes consulting with colleagues to determine the best course of treatment, which may involve surgical or medical interventions. Further evaluation and close monitoring of the dog's condition are recommended. Owner is instructed to observe the dog closely and to contact the veterinary team if the condition worsens.

S: The patient reported right hip and low back pain with radiation to the posterior right thigh. They have not experienced any numbness, tingling, or weakness in the legs. The patient initially obtained adequate pain relief from two right-sided SI joint injections before deciding to undergo surgical intervention.

O: Provocative testing on the right SI joint showed reproducible pain. A radiographic spine survey did not reveal any structural source of low back pain or radiculopathy. Preoperative imaging, including MRI, showed lumbarization of the S1 vertebra, mammillary bodies in the alar region, and a residual S1-S2 disc.

A: The diagnostic impression is consistent with SI joint dysfunction, warranting surgical intervention due to inadequate long-term relief from injections and the structural findings on imaging.

P: The patient underwent SI joint fusion using the iFuse implant System®. During surgery, conducted under general anesthesia with the patient in the prone position, there was a brief bleed controlled by implant placement, and the procedure was completed successfully. Ongoing monitoring of recovery and follow-up care is planned.

S: The patient was admitted on October 28th, 2016, with symptoms of abdominal pain, distension, dark urine, cough, expectoration, chills, and fever. The highest recorded temperature was 39 °C. The patient has been taking iguratimod (25 mg twice per day) for 15 days prior to admission for Sjogren’s syndrome. There is no history of hepatobiliary disease, excessive alcohol intake, recent travel, or blood transfusion.

O: Physical examination revealed normal vital signs, consciousness, and severe jaundice, with no bleeding points, spider angioma, liver palm, abdominal tenderness, or edema. Liver and spleen were normal without shifting dullness. Blood tests showed WBC 3.54 × 10^9/L, NE 61.00%, Hb 119 g/L, PLT 130 × 10^9/L, PT 22.9 s, APTT 60.2 s, PTA 78%. Liver tests were abnormal with TBIL 263.62 umol/L, DBIL 211.34 umol/L, IBIL 52.28 umol/L, ALT 747 U/L, AST 986 U/L, gamma-GPT 256 U/L, ALP 184 U/L, TBA 205.85 umol/L, and LDH 346 U/L. Serum IgG was 13.68 g/L and IgG4 was 298 μg/ml. Negative for IgM anti-HA, anti-HCV, anti-HEV, HBsAg, and anti-EBV-VCA IgM.

A: The patient has abnormal liver function potentially related to the medication taken for Sjogren’s syndrome. Infections and hepatitis B virus have been ruled out.

P: Regular blood tests are recommended to monitor liver function and assess condition changes. The patient should monitor symptoms and report new or worsening symptoms to the healthcare team. Medication adjustments may be considered based on liver function monitoring.

S: The patient, a long-term sufferer since age 2, reports persistent issues with food allergies to eggs and peanuts, accompanied by severe eczematous skin lesions resistant to local and systemic steroids. The patient experiences repeated sinopulmonary infections, recurrent infections with molluscum contagiosum, and flat warts on the face, neck, behind the ears, axillary area, and genitalia. Dental problems include malocclusion and retention of primary teeth, requiring dental intervention, and mucocutaneous candidiasis. The patient had a slowly growing right jaw mass at age 9, accompanied by toothache, treated with antibiotics but with no significant reduction in mass size. There were no symptoms of fever, headache, or bone pain. Itchy skin lesions appeared on the face, scalp, body, and genitalia. No history of jaundice, fever, café au lait spots, or edema is reported. Parents are first cousins from both maternal and paternal sides.

O: On examination, a non-tender right jaw swelling and a 2.5 cm right submandibular lymph node were observed, along with bilateral cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy measuring 1.5-2 cm. Oral examination revealed a bad-smelling, fungating mass related to the right mandible. Scattered crepitation and a palpable liver were noted in the chest and abdominal examination. The patient’s growth parameters are below the 3rd centile. Vaccinations were administered according to the schedule in Iraq.

A: The patient presents with persistent and complex symptoms suggestive of a possible immunodeficiency disorder, given the history of recurrent infections and poor response to standard treatments. Dental and growth abnormalities, along with familial consanguinity, may indicate an underlying genetic condition. The increasing jaw mass and associated lymphadenopathy raise concerns that require further investigation.

P: Further diagnostic evaluation is recommended, potentially including genetic testing to identify any inherited disorders. Imaging studies (e.g., CT or MRI) and biopsy of the jaw mass may be necessary to determine its nature. Continued management of skin lesions and infections with appropriate medications and dermatological consultation is advised. Nutritional support and monitoring of growth parameters should be undertaken. Referral to an immunologist for comprehensive evaluation and management of suspected immunodeficiency is also recommended. Regular follow-up appointments should be scheduled to monitor progress and response to treatment.

S: The patient has been experiencing recurring cervical swelling on the left side, causing difficulty in speaking (dysphonia) and swallowing (dysphagia). They have a history of multiple neck surgeries since the age of ten, including seven operations under general anesthesia and extensive imaging procedures. Symptoms often follow upper respiratory tract infections.

O: Computed tomography showed extensive abscess formation, necessitating hospitalization and abscess drainage with intravenous antibiotics. A retrospective evaluation of pathological reports showed pseudoepithelium in the suspected cyst.

A: Initial diagnosis of second branchial cleft cyst was reconsidered. Suspected a branchial cleft anomaly of the third or fourth arch, supported by CT findings showing contrast medium accumulation in the superior part of the piriform sinus on the left side. There appears to be a connection between upper respiratory tract infections and cervical swelling.

P: Continue investigation to understand the connection between upper respiratory infections and cervical swelling. Plan to prevent future recurrences will be discussed based on new findings. Further tests and evaluations may be necessary, and results will be communicated to the patient.

S: The patient is a motorcyclist who fell and hit his face on the ground 24 hours ago without wearing a helmet. He did not experience any loss of consciousness, vomiting, or amnesia post-accident. He has been managing diabetes with medication for seven years. He reports tenderness around the right zygomaticomaxillary buttress and right infraorbital rim, but no difficulty in opening his mouth.

O: The extra oral examination revealed swelling and abrasion over the right zygomatic region, but no subconjunctival hemorrhage, diplopia, or enophthalmos. Ocular movements in all gazes are normal. The intraoral examination showed normal occlusion, no tooth fracture or mobility, and a mouth opening of 36 mm. Tenderness was noted in the right zygomaticomaxillary buttress and right infraorbital rim, along with an infraorbital step on the right side and crepitus in the right zygomaticomaxillary buttress region. A CT scan showed a fracture in the right zygomaticomaxillary buttress region and right infraorbital rim.

A: Fractured right zygomaticomaxillary buttress and right infraorbital rim due to a motorcycle accident. 

P: Plan includes surgical management with open reduction and internal fixation of the fractures under general anesthesia. No evidence of complications such as visual disturbances or intraoral issues was noted. The patient is informed and fit for surgery, and all procedures will be communicated to him throughout the process.

S: The patient reports experiencing chest tightness, especially during physical activity, for the past month. This symptom prompted a previous hospital visit where an electrocardiogram showed ST-segment depression, leading to a suspicion of angina pectoris and a referral for further evaluation.

O: An ECG indicated ST-segment depression in leads I, aVL, and V2-4. Laboratory tests on admission showed normal creatinine kinase and troponin I levels. Echocardiography revealed normal left ventricular contraction and mild to moderate aortic regurgitation. Coronary angiography demonstrated severe stenosis in the ostium of the left main trunk and right coronary artery, with % diameter stenosis of 95.0% and 87.2% respectively. Intra-coronary isosorbide dinitrate did not alleviate the stenosis, indicating an organic lesion. A contrast-enhanced CT scan showed no specific abnormalities of the aorta. Right and left ankle-brachial indices were 1.08 and 1.03, respectively. There was no significant carotid artery stenosis and no evidence of coronary risk factors, infectious disease, or congenital heart disease. Inflammatory markers, including C-reactive protein, serum amyloid A, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate, were within normal range. Ophthalmologic examination found no vision impairment.

A: The patient is diagnosed with coronary artery disease characterized by severe stenosis in the left main trunk and right coronary artery. The absence of response to intra-coronary isosorbide dinitrate indicates organic coronary stenosis.

P: The patient has been started on optimal medical treatment, including a beta-blocker, an antiplatelet agent, and a statin for coronary artery disease. There is a plan for regular follow-up appointments to closely monitor the patient's symptoms and assess treatment efficacy.

S: The patient was previously admitted to another hospital with cirrhosis and experienced hematemesis due to the rupture of esophageal varices. He underwent endoscopic variceal ligation (EVL) to stop the bleeding but continued to experience hematemesis, with four more episodes following treatment. Multiple EVLs were performed, and transcatheter arterial embolization (TAE) procedures to close an intra-arterial portal fistula (IAPF) were attempted without complete success. The patient was transferred for further treatment.

O: Abdominal ultrasonography revealed ascites, and color Doppler ultrasonography identified an intra-arterial portal fistula (IAPF) between the left hepatic artery and the left branch of the portal vein with altered blood flow patterns. Contrast-enhanced CT and digital subtraction angiography confirmed the IAPF and early portal vein filling. Laboratory results indicated a white blood cell count of 4500/μL (normal), a low red blood cell count of 328 × 10^4/μL (normal: 427-570 × 10^4/μL), serum hemoglobin concentration of 10.2 g/dL (normal: 14-18 g/dL), a low platelet count of 12.8 × 10^4/μL (normal: 15-35 × 10^4/μL), and an elevated aspartate transaminase concentration of 69 IU.

A: The patient is experiencing portal hypertension due to an intra-arterial portal fistula (IAPF), recurrent hematemesis from esophageal variceal ruptures, and liver inflammation. Anemia is also present, likely due to cirrhosis and repeated bleeding.

P: The plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition, further evaluation and management of the portal hypertension, consideration of additional interventions to control bleeding, and addressing the anemia. Further treatment plans will be developed to manage the blood flow abnormalities in the liver and prevent recurrent bleeding.

S: The patient presented to the emergency room with a three-day history of palpitations, shortness of breath, pallor, and black tarry stools. The patient reported that their heart was racing, it was hard to catch their breath, their skin felt pale, and their stools were dark and sticky. 

O: The patient was found to be anemic with a hemoglobin level of 4.4 g/dL. Physical examination and additional blood tests were within normal limits. A computed tomography (CT) scan showed a possible hypodense mass in the second and third portion of the duodenum, abutting the pancreas. A colonoscopy was negative. An upper endoscopy showed an ulcerated mass in the duodenum. A biopsy during the endoscopy was inconclusive. Post-surgery, the final pathology revealed a duodenal gangliocytic paraganglioma with no lymph node involvement.

A: The initial suspicion was duodenal adenocarcinoma, but final pathology indicated a duodenal gangliocytic paraganglioma. The patient had stabilized, ceased bleeding, and was discharged. 

P: The patient underwent a pancreaticoduodenectomy. They had an uneventful hospital stay and were discharged on postoperative day five. Eight months postoperatively, the patient remains free of disease. The patient will continue to be monitored, and they have been advised to reach out if new symptoms or concerns arise.

S: The patient was a 67-year-old woman hospitalized with cholecystitis and experiencing severe upper abdominal cramps.

O: A laparoscopic cholecystectomy was performed to remove the gallbladder, which was subsequently packed for examination. During surgery, the laparoscopic machinery unintentionally perforated the intestinal tract, leading to severe peritonitis. An autopsy and contrast-enhanced PMCT were conducted postmortem, which involved CT scans with air, water, and contrast medium. Imaging was done using a 40-slice CT system with specific technical settings provided.

A: The patient passed away due to complications from peritonitis caused by accidental intestinal perforation during surgery.

P: No information provided.

S: The patient reports worsening shortness of breath during exercise, expressing concern. They have a history of non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy. The patient’s symptoms progressed to New York Heart Association class IV despite optimal medical therapy.

O: The patient developed refractory ventricular tachycardia with worsening cardiogenic shock while on milrinone infusion. Emergency ECMO was required. Pre-operative echocardiography showed a severely dilated left ventricle with an ejection fraction of 15%, moderately dilated right ventricle with dysfunction, a mildly thickened and calcified aortic valve with moderate insufficiency, and severe functional regurgitation of both mitral and tricuspid valves.

A: The patient has end-stage heart failure due to non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy with severe cardiac dysfunction and valve insufficiencies. Ventricular tachycardia and cardiogenic shock necessitated ECMO and LVAD as a bridge to transplant.

P: The patient underwent successful surgical intervention: aortic valve replacement, tricuspid valve repair, and HVAD implant. Post-operative care includes monitoring recovery and ensuring stabilization following extubation and surgery. Continued follow-up and care are planned to monitor progress and recovery.

S: The patient, a cyclist, reported having a fall during a race while trying to avoid another rider. They hit a tree with their right leg and fell on their left side but did not suffer any head or chest trauma due to wearing a helmet. Post-fall, they experienced lightheadedness, broke out in a cold sweat, and had mid-back pain but denied chest pain or shortness of breath. Prior to the race, the patient consumed several caffeine Jello shots and an energy drink.

O: Initial vitals showed a blood pressure of 128/69 mmHg and a pulse of 65 bpm, with normal temperature and breathing. The right thigh was swollen and tender. An ECG revealed lateral ST segment elevation. Troponin I was positive at 0.49ng/mL, CPK was 617 U/L, and troponin levels later increased to 21ng/mL. An echocardiogram showed normal ventricular function and trace pericardial effusion. Coronary angiography revealed a spontaneous coronary artery dissection in the left anterior descending coronary artery.

A: The patient has a spontaneous coronary artery dissection likely exacerbated by caffeine consumption. There was suspicion of cardiac contusion, which was ruled out due to the absence of chest trauma.

P: The patient was started on Aspirin, Clopidogrel, a heparin infusion, Lisinopril, and a Beta Blocker. Continuous monitoring of the condition is planned, and the patient is advised to follow up with their primary care physician and a cardiologist for further evaluation and management.

S: The patient reports experiencing right lower quadrant pain for 3 days, along with nausea, back pain, a cough, nonbloody vomiting, and diarrhea. The patient also mentions a fall that occurred about 3 weeks ago. No other symptoms are reported.

O: Vital signs are as follows: blood pressure is 155/80 mmHg, pulse 74 beats per minute, respirations 18, temperature 36.7°C. On examination, the abdomen is soft with tenderness in the right lower quadrant. There is no inguinal mass or erythema observed. Lab tests are essentially normal with no leukocytosis. A CT scan shows a right femoral hernia containing an inflamed appendix.

A: The assessment includes a diagnosis of a Pantaloon hernia, a femoral hernia, and an Amyand's hernia with an early, nonperforated appendicitis. The patient has a Charlson Comorbidity Index with an estimated 10-year survival rate of 53%.

P: The patient underwent a laparoscopic appendectomy and McVay hernia repair without the use of mesh. There were no intraoperative or postoperative complications, except for Clavien-Dindo grade 1 pain. The patient will be discharged to the skilled nursing facility on postoperative day 2. Follow-up appointments and ongoing self-care are advised.
