S: The patient has a history of ischemic heart disease and underwent an elective percutaneous coronary intervention with two drug-eluting stents in the circumflex branch of the left coronary artery four years ago. The patient has chronic conditions including metabolic syndrome, obesity (BMI of 33), and gastroesophageal reflux disease. The patient has experienced worsening exercise dyspnea over the past two years but denies any chest pain or discomfort.

O: Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) showed a non-dilated left ventricle with a normal systolic ejection fraction of 60% and severe mitral regurgitation (MR) with prolapse of the A2 segment and systolic restriction of the posterior leaflet. The color Doppler indicated a distinctive eccentric turbulent jet with an ERO of 0.6cm² and a regurgitant volume of 60 ml. Coronary angiography found significant narrowing near the drug-eluting stents. A computed tomography (CT) of the chest showed no pathological shadows in the lung parenchyma.

A: The patient has severe mitral regurgitation and hemodynamically significant coronary artery disease in the area of previous stenting, qualifying them for mitral valve repair and coronary artery bypass grafting surgery.

P: The patient is scheduled for mitral valve repair surgery and coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) using a saphenous vein graft to the circumflex artery. Pre-operative preparation included TTE to confirm severe MR and a CT scan to rule out lung parenchyma issues. Standard procedures such as cardiopulmonary bypass and bicaval cannulation will be followed during surgery, with the patient's progress monitored closely.

S: The patient was admitted to the hospital with a liver tumor discovered during a PET-CT scan as part of a cancer examination. The patient reports no symptoms or discomfort. The medical history includes a hepatitis B virus infection, with a positive hepatitis B virus antigen test; however, the patient was asymptomatic and had not received any medical interventions.

O: Serum tumor markers showed no elevated carbohydrase antigen-19-9 (11.2 U/ml), carbohydrase antigen-125 (18.1 U/ml), or carcinoembryonic antigen (1.0 ng/ml). Other parameters were normal. Gastroscopy and colonoscopy had normal findings. A CT scan revealed a 6.0 cm low-density mass in the caudate liver, with enhanced scans showing two components. MRI displayed low intensity on T1-weighted images and differences in T2-weighted images between components. Diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) showed higher intensity than normal parenchyma. ADC mean values were 1.19 × 10− 3 mm2/s (right component) and 1.95 × 10− 3 mm2/s (left component), showing high intensity on the ADC map. Gd-EOB was used in imaging.

A: Liver tumor with differential imaging characteristics suggesting a need for further evaluation by specialists.

P: The patient's case will be discussed with a team of specialists to determine the best course of action, considering various treatment options tailored to the patient's needs. The patient will be kept informed throughout this process and encouraged to reach out with any questions or concerns.

S: The patient reports experiencing multiple episodes of dizziness, shortness of breath, and a racing heart. They have no known history of cardiac arrhythmias, structural heart disease, or ischemic heart disease. They have a past medical history of substance use disorder, depression, and hydrocodone abuse since 2007. The patient has drug allergies to amoxicillin and erythromycin. They also mention alcohol and marijuana abuse and reported taking 400 mg of loperamide recreationally in the last 24 hours. The patient struggles with catching their breath.

O: The emergency medical services reported ventricular tachycardia (VT), which did not resolve despite 10 defibrillations. The patient appeared in moderate distress with an elevated pulse of over 200 bpm, blood pressure of 157/80, and a respiratory rate of 24/minute. The pulmonary exam revealed decreased breath sounds bilaterally with symmetrical chest wall expansion. Cardiovascular exam showed tachycardia without murmurs. Moist mucous membranes were observed, with no jugular venous distention. There were no notable findings in the gastrointestinal, musculoskeletal, and head/neck exams. The EKG in the ER revealed polymorphic VT with a heart rate of 220 after the patient became unresponsive.

A: The patient presents with episodes of ventricular tachycardia, likely exacerbated by high-dose loperamide use. Other contributing factors may include substance use disorder and potential underlying cardiac conditions. 

P: The plan includes continued monitoring and treatment for ventricular tachycardia. The patient is advised to follow up with their primary care physician and a cardiologist to manage the heart condition and substance use disorder.

S: The patient reports experiencing right hip pain for two weeks, with severe pain and tenderness in the right hip joint. There is a decreased range of motion, and movement causes significant pain, preventing the patient from walking for an assessment. The patient has had less severe episodes over the past four years. No fever, skin rash, or acne is reported. 

O: Inflammatory laboratory investigations such as ESR and CRP are within normal limits. An X-ray of the pelvis and right thigh shows a small lucency in the right greater trochanteric region. MRI of the right thigh demonstrates trochanteric bursa effusion and right hip joint synovitis. Subsequent swelling of the right sternoclavicular joint shows normal X-ray and lab investigations, but an MRI reveals a patchy area of hyperintensity on T2 and hypointensity on T1 images near the sternoclavicular junction, with mild accentuated heterogeneous enhancement and traces of fluid in the joint space. Marrow and subcutaneous edema with changes related to cellulitis are present.

A: The findings and clinical history suggest SAPHO syndrome, a rare inflammatory condition affecting bones and joints. 

P: The patient was started on NSAIDs and paracetamol for pain management, leading to significant improvement. Treatment continues with these medications due to an excellent response. Progress will be monitored, and treatment adjustments will be made as needed. Further consultation is advised if symptoms worsen.

S: The 5-month-old patient has trouble gaining weight, feeding difficulties, vomiting, and diarrhea. There is a family history involving parents who are cousins and a previous child who passed away. The patient experienced worsening symptoms upon stopping vitamin B12 therapy.

O: Laboratory results showed pancytopenia requiring transfusions, lymphopenia, and hypogammaglobulinemia, with normal lymphocyte subsets. Serum vitamin B12 level was low at 136 pg/mL. CMV PCR was positive. Bone marrow aspiration indicated prominent vacuolization in the myeloid lineage and megaloblastic changes but no molecular support for Pearson syndrome. Molecular analysis confirmed a homozygous TCN2 gene mutation.

A: The patient is diagnosed with a genetic deficiency of transcobalamin (TC), leading to severe combined immunodeficiency.

P: Treatment involves restarting and continuing intramuscular vitamin B12 and oral folic acid. The patient is also receiving intravenous immunoglobulin, ganciclovir, and antibacterial and antifungal prophylaxis. Monitoring will continue to adjust the treatment plan based on her progress.

S: The patient reports swelling in the left lower leg, first noticed in May 2017. The patient has a history of grade 3 obesity with a BMI of 45.2 kg/m2, type II diabetes with an initial hemoglobin A1c of 8.1%. The patient was diagnosed with heart failure and exhibits baseline dyspnea on exertion. A healthier lifestyle was adopted, including a whole food plant-based diet and vitamin B12 supplementation, resulting in a weight loss of 22.7 kg, reduction of BMI to 35.1 kg/m2, and resolution of diabetes as evidenced by an A1c reduction to 5.7%.

O: Initial tests included a venous duplex negative for deep venous thrombosis and an X-ray revealing lower extremity atherosclerosis. Cardiologist evaluations included an ECG showing normal sinus rhythm and left bundle branch block, echocardiography revealing a left ventricular ejection fraction of 25%, and a cardiac MRI showing a dilated cardiomyopathy with an ejection fraction of 21%. A Coronary CT angiogram showed a calcium score of 458. Cardiac catheterization revealed cardiomyopathy out of proportion to coronary artery disease, with specific stenosis noted in the LAD, left circumflex, and obtuse marginal arteries. Follow-up echocardiography in November 2017 showed improvement to a normal left ventricular ejection fraction of 55%.

A: The patient was assessed with heart failure secondary to dilated cardiomyopathy, with contributing factors including severe obesity and poorly controlled diabetes, both of which have improved substantially following lifestyle changes.

P: The patient is advised to maintain the current diet and lifestyle modifications. Continue prescribed medications, including a beta-blocker, an ACE inhibitor, and a statin. Regular follow-up with a cardiologist is recommended to monitor heart health, particularly in light of the significant improvement in left ventricular function. Maintain regular HbA1c monitoring to ensure continued diabetes management.

S: The patient has a 21-year history of type 2 diabetes and reports a persistent ulcer on the left heel. They have experienced numbness in the left lower limb for about 6 years and report intermittent claudication and rest pain for approximately a year, affecting their sleep. They can walk about 90 meters before claudication pain becomes severe. Prior to hospitalization, they experienced irritation and pain on the lateral toes of the left foot, leading to skin ulceration with purulent exudate and a fever of 39.5°C. During hospitalization, the toes turned black and necrotic, and the rest pain worsened, further disturbing sleep.

O: On initial evaluation, the left foot's skin, from the bottom to the 5th metatarsophalangeal joint, was red, swollen, and tender. Skin temperature was normal, but muscle atrophy and thin, bright, hypertonic skin were noted. An incision and drainage between the 4th and 5th toes revealed necrotic tissue with minimal purulent exudate and limited bleeding. Secretion cultures showed Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Staphylococcus aureus. An X-ray provided additional unspecified information.

A: The patient is experiencing complications of diabetes with a foot ulcer, likely diabetic foot ulcer, with necrosis and a mixed bacterial infection involving Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Staphylococcus aureus. There is also a history of peripheral neuropathy and possibly peripheral vascular disease given symptoms of claudication and rest pain.

P: Continue detailed monitoring of the patient’s condition. A treatment plan will be developed to address the infection and manage pain, including following prescribed medications and recommendations. The patient should be informed to communicate any changes in symptoms or new concerns.

S: The patient reports experiencing bilateral breast pain for 6 months, described as a constant ache. She has a medical history of hypertension, managed with a single anti-hypertensive medication. There is no family history of breast or gynecological malignancy.

O: Clinical examination revealed pathological nodes in both axillae. Noted findings include left-sided nipple inversion with a palpable mass (3 cm) in the left breast's upper outer quadrant, and right-sided skin tethering with 3 palpable masses in the right breast, the largest measuring 5 cm in the upper inner quadrant. Imaging studies (ultrasound and mammography) showed advanced bilateral breast cancer with axillary node metastases. In the right breast, a large primary lesion at 12 o'clock measured 44.3 mm with 7 satellite lesions; the largest axillary node was 42 x 30 mm. In the left breast, a lesion at 2 o'clock measured 31.2 mm, with the largest axillary node at 13.1 x 10.2 mm. Skin thickening and edema were observed, more pronounced on the right. Core biopsies confirmed invasive carcinoma. The right breast lesion is ER/PR negative, and left breast is ER positive, PR positive; both are HER2 positive with a score of 3+.

A: Advanced bilateral breast cancer with axillary node metastases. Right breast carcinoma is ER/PR negative, HER2 positive. Left breast carcinoma is ER/PR positive, HER2 positive.

P: Develop a personalized treatment plan including chemotherapy, hormone therapy (for ER positive left breast), and targeted HER2 therapy. Monitor progress and adjust treatment as necessary. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to evaluate response to therapy and manage any treatment-related effects.

S: The patient is a 32-year-old woman who experienced her first seizure at 7 months old, described as a febrile bilateral tonic-clonic seizure. Her epilepsy became more severe between ages one and two, with daily generalized seizures. Although the frequency decreased slightly during school years, she continued to have several bilateral tonic-clonic seizures weekly, which have been drug-resistant. She lost hand function and the ability to speak between 12 to 15 months. Her motor development was initially normal: she sat independently at 7 months, used some words by one year, and learned to walk at 24 months. She could walk independently until school age but gradually needed support. Her sleep pattern was disturbed, with screaming and laughing spells, though her breathing was unaffected.

O: The clinical examination revealed the patient could walk a few meters with support, had ataxic and apraxic hand movements, and no hand stereotypies. She had no language but intense eye contact. Muscle tone was normal, and she had a slight scoliosis. She continues to experience daily to weekly bilateral tonic-clonic seizures.

A: The patient's symptoms and history fit the criteria of classic Rett Syndrome (RTT), despite negative genetic analyses of MECP2 through Sanger sequencing and an MLPA kit test.

P: No specific treatments or medications were mentioned. The patient is a participant in a national survey of females with similar conditions, which could provide valuable data or lead to potential new management strategies. Further follow-up and supportive care are indicated.

S: The patient reports experiencing fever with chills and weakness for the past five days, beginning after returning from a golfing trip in Westchester, New York. They were prescribed amoxicillin-clavulanic acid three days ago for possible pneumonia. The patient's past medical history includes lung cancer in remission, hypertension controlled with atenolol, hepatitis B, nephrolithiasis treated with lithotripsy, chronic kidney disease, and benign prostatic hyperplasia. They occasionally drink alcohol, quit smoking two months ago, and have no history of illicit drug use. They recently traveled only to Westchester and report no tick bites.

O: Upon arrival at the emergency department, the patient was febrile with a temperature of 39.7°C, tachycardic with a heart rate between 77-122 bpm, tachypneic with a breathing rate of 15-26 breaths per minute, and hypotensive with blood pressure readings between 85/39 mmHg and 118/69 mmHg, which improved after receiving 3 liters of normal saline. They were awake and oriented with observed bilateral mild yellow tint conjunctiva. An outpatient chest X-ray showed postoperative changes of the right lung, pulmonary fibrosis, and borderline enlarged lower mediastinal lymph nodes. Blood tests demonstrated transaminitis, a platelet count of 42 k/μL, anemia with a hemoglobin level of 8.7 g/dL and hematocrit of 26.4%, neutropenia with a white blood cell count of 4.71 K/μL, thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 37 K/μL, and low haptoglobin of less than 10 mg/dL.

A: The patient's symptoms and lab findings are suggestive of sepsis, possibly related to an underlying infection not completely addressed by the previously prescribed antibiotics. The low platelet count, anemia, and low haptoglobin may indicate hemolysis or another hematological issue.

P: The patient received a dose of intravenous piperacillin-tazobactam for presumed sepsis. Continuous monitoring of the patient's condition is recommended, along with close follow-up with the primary care physician. The treatment plan may be adjusted based on the patient's response, and they should seek immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen or new issues arise.

S: The patient reports a history of hypertension and type II diabetes, which have led to hypertensive and diabetic nephropathy. The patient's condition is also complicated by NASH cirrhosis, hepatorenal syndrome, hepatic encephalopathy, esophageal varices, and ascites. The patient has undergone multiple endoscopies for variceal banding and paracenteses.

O: Abdominal imaging demonstrated cirrhosis, signs of portal hypertension, splenomegaly, and a thrombosed main portal vein with poor distal reconstitution. Liver-kidney transplantation with en bloc graft was performed in October 2017. The donor was a brain-dead 42-year-old white male with normal terminal creatinine and liver function tests. Organ recovery used HTK solution, and the transplantation included specific surgical procedures such as arterioplasty and portal vein thrombectomy.

A: Complicated medical history with multi-organ involvement due to hypertension and diabetes, complicated by liver and renal conditions. Post-liver-kidney transplant status with stable surgical history.

P: The doctor emphasizes the importance of monitoring health and attending follow-up appointments. The patient is advised to report any unusual symptoms to the healthcare team and to continue following healthcare recommendations. There are no immediate new treatments or medications discussed, as the patient is already in follow-up care post-transplant.

S: The patient is a 70-year-old man with a history of hypertension and diabetes. He was hospitalized to receive intravenous antibiotics for a surgical site infection, which began about 3 weeks after surgery for an ascending thoracic aortic dissection. He has been on vancomycin for 10 days and reports experiencing multiple tense blisters on his oral and genital mucosal since starting the medication.

O: No observable findings or test results are provided in the conversation.

A: The patient appears to have a probable adverse reaction to vancomycin, presenting as tense blisters on mucosal surfaces, in the context of treating a surgical site infection post-thoracic aortic dissection surgery.

P: Plan to consult with the healthcare team to evaluate the need for adjusting the antibiotic treatment and closely monitor the patient's symptoms. The patient is advised to report any worsening or new symptoms to the medical staff immediately. Follow-up details will be communicated once the healthcare team determines the next steps in treatment.

S: The patient reported being presented for a diagnostic imaging evaluation following her primary provider's identification of a vague thickening in her right breast at 1:00, 2 cm from the nipple during a clinical breast examination. She has a history of using combination hormone therapy for the past 5 years and a family history of postmenopausal breast cancer in her maternal grandmother.

O: Diagnostic imaging, including a mammogram with tomosynthesis and targeted ultrasound, showed a BI-RADS 1 (negative) result but categorized the breasts as extremely dense. MBI showed marked intensity radiotracer uptake in the upper outer right breast, measuring 5.9 cm. A second-look ultrasound showed an ill-defined hypoechoic area with posterior shadowing. An ultrasound-guided biopsy identified a 0.2 cm focus of pleomorphic invasive lobular carcinoma, Nottingham grade I, ER/PR positive, HER-2Neu negative.

A: The findings are consistent with a low-grade invasive lobular carcinoma (pleomorphic ILC).

P: The patient was advised to discuss treatment options and adhere to regular follow-ups with her healthcare team for monitoring. A comprehensive treatment plan will be developed to manage her condition effectively.

S: The patient reports a history of difficulty swallowing solid foods for several years but denies any symptoms of reflux or abdominal pain. The patient has been taking dexlansoprazole without improvement in symptoms. They also report an increased intake of NSAIDs for about a month due to joint pain.

O: Physical examination revealed an unremarkable abdominal exam. An Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) showed abnormal esophageal mucosa with two esophageal webs and gastritis with nodularity in the gastric body. Esophageal biopsies were unremarkable, but stomach biopsies showed mild chronic active gastritis, mild focal gastric atrophy, significant subepithelial collagen plate thickening, and features compatible with collagenous gastritis (CG). Serum protein electrophoresis was normal, and urine protein electrophoresis showed minor albuminuria. Celiac screen results were within normal limits. A CBC from a year ago was normal.

A: The patient has been diagnosed with collagenous gastritis (CG) based on endoscopic and biopsy findings.

P: Continue current treatment with dexlansoprazole and perform subsequent upper and lower endoscopies to rule out collagenous diseases elsewhere in the gastrointestinal tract. A colonoscopy will also be conducted to ensure there are no other issues.

S: The patient presented with a two-month history of right breast erythema and nipple erosion. She has experienced redness and swelling in the right breast with nipple erosion. She has a history of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) diagnosed 13 years earlier, characterized by Raynaud's phenomena, arthralgias, alopecia, malar rash, lupus nephritis, and thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura. Her SLE has been stable with treatment and no new organ involvement.

O: A needle core biopsy revealed a grade two invasive ductal carcinoma in the right breast, with an estrogen receptor of 8/8, progesterone receptor of 4/8, and HER2 negative. There was extensive lymphovascular and dermal invasion. Staging workup showed a conglomerated lymph node mass of 1.5 cm in the right axilla with no distant metastases (cT4dN1M0 [IIIC]). Post-surgery pathology showed a 4-cm residual tumor and 3/15 nodes positive for residual disease (ypT4dN1aM0R0).

A: The patient has a grade two invasive ductal carcinoma in the right breast with lymph node involvement. The cancer is ER-positive, PR-positive, and HER2-negative. No distant metastases were found. The patient also has a history of stable systemic lupus erythematosus.

P: The patient received chemotherapy with fluorouracil, epirubicin, and cyclophosphamide followed by docetaxel. She underwent a right total mastectomy, sentinel node biopsy with axillary dissection, and a prophylactic left-sided mastectomy. Adjuvant radiotherapy is planned with careful considerations to minimize lung and cardiac doses. Further treatment will focus on RT while monitoring for potential complications considering her SLE.

S: The patient, a 19-year-old Indian male, reports experiencing abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and weight loss. Following a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma (T2N0M0), he underwent a left hemicolectomy, colocolic, and jejunojejunal anastomosis. Postoperatively, he developed an anastomotic leak requiring reoperation. In the ICU, he presented with worsening condition, pulmonary edema, and required high-dose vasopressor and mechanical ventilation.

O: Echocardiography revealed severely depressed left ventricular function with global hypokinesia in the anteroseptal wall, anterior wall, and intraventricular septum, LVEF of 15-20%, mild mitral and tricuspid regurgitation. ECG showed sinus tachycardia (150 bpm), poor R wave progression, and nonspecific ST-T changes. Troponin I level was 1.69 ng/mL, CPK-MB 5.2 ng/mL, and BNP 2000 pg/mL. Day 3 ICU notes indicate worsening hypotension, metabolic acidosis, tachycardia, chilled peripheries, maximal vasoconstriction, and decreased urine output.

A: The patient has been primarily assessed with septic myocarditis over acute coronary syndrome as a differential diagnosis. There is also consideration of cardiogenic shock as the primary cause of the patient's condition.

P: The patient has been started on daily aspirin 75 mg, clopidogrel 75 mg, injection fondaparinux 2.5 mg, and injection torsemide 20 mg thrice daily. Due to worsening conditions on day 3, antibiotic regimen was escalated per culture sensitivity. It is planned to initiate an intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP) to address the suspected cardiogenic shock.

S:  
The patient has a history of hypertension and peptic ulcer disease. They presented to the neurosurgery department with progressively worsening headaches and repeated episodes of syncope. 

O:  
A CT scan showed a lobulated pituitary soft tissue mass in the sella turcica region, measuring 1.8 cm x 1.7 cm x 1.4 cm, classified as a macroadenoma. The mass was causing displacement of the optic chiasm, without sella bony erosion. Visual field testing was normal. A hormonal workup revealed low testosterone at 85 ng/dl and low luteinizing hormone at 1.0 mIU/ml, with all other hormonal levels within normal ranges.

A:  
The patient was diagnosed with a pituitary macroadenoma affecting testosterone and luteinizing hormone levels.

P:  
The patient was referred to the ENT service and underwent CT-guided stereotactic endoscopically assisted transsphenoidal resection of the pituitary macroadenoma, successfully removing the tumor. Follow-up includes monitoring hormone levels, symptoms, regular check-ups, and imaging studies to ensure the tumor does not recur.

S: The patient is a 5-year-old girl with a history of developmental delay and recurrent thrombocytopenia during her first year, which later normalized. She has microcephaly and a low normal IQ achieved with the help of intensive combined therapies. There have been no seizures documented.

O: MRI showed two unilateral periventricular nodular heterotopias, but otherwise normal brain morphology. Whole exome sequencing discovered a de novo insertion in the last exon of ACTB, c.1101dup, resulting in the substitution of 8 amino acids and the addition of 4 residues at the C-terminus of β-CYA. History of thrombocytopenia with platelet anisotropy and enlarged platelets.

A: The patient is diagnosed with ACTB-associated syndromic thrombocytopenia (ACTB-AST), characterized by developmental delay, mild intellectual disability, microcephaly, and complex platelet abnormalities.

P: Continue intensive combined therapies and ensure regular checkups to monitor her development closely. Parents are advised to bring her in for evaluation if new symptoms appear.

S: The patient reported difficulty speaking clearly, which began about four years ago when they were 71 years old. They also experienced breathing difficulties starting at age 75. At age 78, the patient was hospitalized with symptoms of fever, rapid heart rate, difficulty breathing, and drowsiness.

O: During the hospitalization, tests revealed pyuria, increased white blood cells, and elevated C-reactive protein levels, indicating a urinary tract infection. An ECG showed ST elevation in V1–V5. Echocardiography demonstrated decreased wall motion in the apex of the heart, incongruent with the coronary artery supply region, while the basal motion was normal.

A: The patient was diagnosed with Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), which accounts for dysarthria and breathing issues. During hospitalization, they were also diagnosed with a urinary tract infection and Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TTS).

P: The abnormal heart wall motion and symptoms resolved completely after an 11-day hospital stay. The patient is advised to continue monitoring their health and stay in communication with their healthcare team, especially regarding their ALS and any potential new symptoms or concerns.

S: The patient reports experiencing severe dyspnea, particularly during mild exertion. He has a history of lymphocytic myocarditis, stage III chronic kidney disease, chronic gastritis, and Hashimoto thyroiditis. The patient notes a worsening of symptoms and a decline in quality of life due to a progressive left ventricular ejection fraction reduction and LV dilation. He is currently on high dose ACEI, ß-Blocker, diuretics, and MRA. 

O: The patient had an implantable cardioverter defibrillator placed in 2009 and a cardiac contractility modulation system in 2012. Tests including coronary angiography and a repeated endomyocardial biopsy excluded coronary heart disease and recurrence of myocarditis. He has a CardioMEMS™ device which, within the first three months, required two diuretic dose adjustments due to a rise in pulmonary artery pressure. A transthoracic echocardiogram showed long-standing dilated cardiomyopathy with severe global LV hypokinesia and an ejection fraction of 30%. Post 24-hour infusion of calcium sensitizer levosimendan, the patient's hemodynamics improved with a reduction in systemic and pulmonary vascular resistance and increased cardiac output. There has been a noted drop in pulmonary artery mean pressure following hospital discharge.

A: The patient presents with severe dyspnea due to advanced heart failure secondary to dilated cardiomyopathy and reduced ejection fraction. The patient's condition is being managed with medications and monitoring through devices like CardioMEMS™, alongside ongoing adjustments based on symptomatology and hemodynamic measurements.

P: Continue current medications and monitoring with the CardioMEMS™. Consistent follow-up to monitor symptoms and adjust treatment as necessary. The patient is on a waiting list for heart transplantation and should adhere to follow-up appointments and report any new or worsening symptoms.

S: The patient, an 8-year-old girl, has been experiencing left ear pain, mouth bleeding, difficulty swallowing, change in voice quality, and breathing difficulties for about one month. There is no history of neck trauma, nasal obstruction, or nosebleeds.

O: Clinical examination revealed a large submucosal bulge in the left tonsillar fossa, crossing the midline and pushing the uvula to the opposite side, which obscures the oropharyngeal airway. Nasal endoscopy showed both choanae blocked by a friable mass filling the nasopharynx. No palpable neck nodes were found. Hematological, liver, and renal function tests were normal. A CECT scan showed a large mass in the left parapharyngeal space affecting various regions and causing significant airway narrowing. The biopsy indicated tumor cells with hyperchromatic nuclei, brisk mitosis, and tumor necrosis, positive for CD99 and weak PAS positivity. Additional imaging showed lung nodules and vertebral lytic lesions indicating metastasis.

A: Ewing's sarcoma (EES) of the parapharyngeal space with lung and skeletal metastasis.

P: Initiate chemotherapy with vincristine, doxorubicin, and cyclophosphamide due to the disseminated nature of the disease.

S: The patient was randomized in the DC-MEL trial after the resection and radiation of lymph node metastases of a BRAF wild-type melanoma. In December 2014, the patient developed recurrent lymph node metastases and a left occipital MBM. After four cycles of treatment with Trimix DC vaccination and ipilimumab, the disease was still progressive. The patient developed autoimmune colitis and orchitis after four cycles of pembrolizumab. In June 2015, the patient developed a right parietal MBM treated with SRT, and one month later, the right parietal lesion disappeared but two new cerebral lesions appeared. These were also treated with SRT. In June 2016, there was an increase in the volume of the right parietal brain lesion, but the patient experienced no symptoms. The patient is currently feeling fine and is in complete remission.

O: In June 2015, SRT at 1 × 20 Gy was used to treat the right parietal MBM, which subsequently disappeared. Two new cerebral lesions were treated with SRT at 1 × 20 Gy. A cerebral MRI suggested RNB, and an FDG-PET CT indicated a hypometabolic lesion suggestive of RNB. The patient is currently asymptomatic.

A: The patient is in complete remission. The initial increase in the right parietal brain lesion volume was suggestive of radiation necrosis rather than active disease, as supported by imaging studies.

P: The patient is advised to continue regular follow-up appointments and to promptly report any new symptoms. No specific treatment is necessary at this time due to the asymptomatic nature and remission status.

S: The patient is a 75-year-old male with a former smoking history of 45 pack years. He reports initial swelling in the left neck, progressive hoarseness, and difficulty swallowing over the past one to two months.

O: A biopsy of the left neck node indicates p16 positive squamous cell carcinoma. A CT scan and PET-CT reveal a 4.5 cm x 7 cm mass in the left hypopharynx and oropharynx, narrowing the hypopharyngeal and supraglottic airway, with bulky left level II neck lymphadenopathy measuring up to 7 cm. There are three FDG avid lung nodules confirmed as metastatic p16 positive squamous cell carcinoma by biopsy. Due to airway obstruction and dysphagia, a tracheostomy and gastrostomy were placed. Follow-up imaging shows progression of the disease with ulcerating primary and neck masses, and increased pulmonary nodules.

A: The patient has progressive stage IV p16 positive squamous cell carcinoma with metastasis to the lungs. There has been progression despite treatment with ipilimumab and nivolumab.

P: The patient is receiving palliative "QUAD SHOT" radiation therapy to alleviate symptoms and improve quality of life. Treatment consists of delivering 3.7 Gy BID x 2 days to gross disease and 3.3 Gy BID x 2 days to high-risk microscopic areas. The medical team will monitor progress and adjust the plan as needed. The patient is advised to report any symptom changes or concerns.

S: The patient, a 49-year-old obese Hispanic male, reports difficulty breathing and chest pain. He has a past medical history of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) diagnosed in 2010, with crescentic glomerulonephritis identified via renal biopsy. The patient is on hemodialysis for end-stage renal disease (ESRD). He has experienced recurrent nosebleeds and ear infections and was recently rehospitalized with arteriovenous fistula occlusion and sepsis from CMV colitis and E. coli.

O: Physical examination reveals a saddle nose deformity, distant heart sounds, jugular venous distention, and an arteriovenous fistula bruit. Laboratory findings include normocytic anemia, elevated BUN and Cr levels, hyperkalemia, hypophosphatemia, elevated acute phase reactants, increased κ and λ free light chains, negative c-ANCA, positive p-ANCA, elevated myeloperoxidase antibodies, normal serine protease 3 antibodies, and normal complement levels. The EKG indicates sinus tachycardia with S wave in lead I, Q wave in lead III, and electrical alternans. CTA is negative for pulmonary embolism, showing moderate pericardial effusion and bilateral pulmonary opacities. Echocardiogram confirms tamponade with a solid component in the effusion. The pericardial fluid is bloody, with pathology showing acute inflammation, granulation tissue, and fibrinopurulent exudate.

A: The patient exhibits signs of cardiac tamponade caused by pericardial effusion, likely related to his underlying GPA. The presence of sepsis from CMV colitis and E. coli complicates his medical condition, along with arteriovenous fistula occlusion.

P: The patient requires emergent dialysis and a pericardial window for tamponade treatment. Pulse dose steroids with a taper are prescribed, and arrangements are made for outpatient follow-up to initiate cyclophosphamide. Upon rehospitalization, treatment for sepsis and arteriovenous fistula occlusion is initiated to address the complications.

S: The patient reports a recent weight gain of 15 kg and facial erythema. They experienced no symptoms of hyperandrogenism or virilization, and their menstrual cycles are regular without the use of oral contraceptives. The patient has no history of diabetes or hypertension. At follow-up, the patient reports new symptoms of proximal muscle weakness, facial plethora, and reddish-purple striae.

O: The initial physical exam showed a BMI of 22.4 kg/m², with no facial plethora, skin striae, hirsutism, acne, spotty pigmentation, or skin myxomas. The thyroid examination was normal. At follow-up, the physical exam revealed Cushingoid features, including moon face, supraclavicular fat pads, facial plethora, reddish-purple striae wider than 1 cm, and proximal myopathy. The lab results indicated an abnormal 1 mg overnight dexamethasone suppression test with a serum cortisol of 6 μg/dl, two consecutive elevated 24-hour urinary free cortisol levels (>510 μg/day and >485 μg/day), and suppressed morning plasma ACTH (<1 pg/ml). Complete blood count and liver function tests were normal.

A: The diagnostic findings are consistent with ACTH-independent Cushing's syndrome.

P: Treatment and management steps for ACTH-independent Cushing's syndrome will be discussed with the patient, ensuring collaborative care.

S: The patient has a history of bowel resection with surgeries performed about five years ago. They have been experiencing diarrhoea for three months, which temporarily improved but then resumed as watery diarrhoea about a year ago. Previous antidiarrhoeal medication provided little relief. The patient's past medical history includes colonic perforation, abdominal wall hernia with strangulated ileus, and resection of the terminal ileum. They were diagnosed with strangulated ileus and underwent a small intestine resection five years ago.

O: Current vitals: blood pressure 95/67 mmHg, heart rate 59 bpm, SpO2 95%, temperature 36.6°C. Physical examination shows normal breath and heart sounds with mild systolic murmurs, flat and soft abdomen with negative Murphy's sign, no costovertebral angle tenderness, and lower leg oedema. Blood tests: WBC count 15.30 × 10^3/μ, neutrophils 78.3%, lymphocytes 15.5%, monocytes 5.6%, eosinophils 0.4%, basophils 0.2%, RBC count 3.34 × 10^6/μ, hemoglobin 11.3 g/dL, hematocrit 33.2%, platelet count 27.9 × 10^4/μ, total bilirubin 1.6 mg/dL, AST 48 IU/L, ALT 37 IU/L.

A: The patient presents with symptoms and laboratory findings suggestive of infection, potentially linked to episodes of diarrhoea. There is a history of significant gastrointestinal surgeries which may contribute to the recurrent diarrhoea and malnutrition. Current findings of hypokalaemia, malnutrition, and lower leg oedema may be related to decreased renal function.

P: Prescribe medications to manage hypokalaemia and improve renal function. Adjust the diet to address malnutrition. The patient should monitor symptoms and return for a follow-up appointment in a few weeks to assess improvement and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient is a 12-year-old girl presenting with photophobia and ocular hyperemia for four weeks. She expresses concern about her condition after being informed of the diagnosis and treatment plan.

O: Diagnosed with bilateral anterior and intermediate uveitis. Blood pressure is normal. Laboratory findings indicate iron-deficiency anemia, ESR 120 mm/first hour, GFR 47 ml/min/1.73m², leukocyturia, glucosuria, hematuria, and non-nephrotic proteinuria. Infectious and autoimmune diseases have been ruled out. Chest X-ray and kidney ultrasound show no alterations.

A: Bilateral anterior and intermediate uveitis with associated renal impairment, likely due to an inflammatory process. No infectious or autoimmune etiology identified.

P: Initiate treatment with mydriatics, topical corticosteroids, and oral deflazacort. Expect renal recovery in six weeks and remission of uveitis in two months. Transition from systemic corticosteroids to methotrexate 10 mg/m²/week after two months. Advise regular follow-up for monitoring renal function and uveitis recurrence, with the goal of being asymptomatic 18 months post-diagnosis.

S: The patient reports experiencing breathing difficulties and chest pain. They have a history of a massive tumor in the left lower lobe of the lung.

O: A CT scan revealed a large tumor measuring 90 mm in diameter in the left lower lobe of the lung. A left lower lobectomy with resection of the thoracic wall and diaphragm was performed. Histological analysis diagnosed the tumor as squamous cell carcinoma, staged as pT4N0M0, stage IIIB. Genetic testing detected an indel in the noncoding region of the SFTPB gene.

A: The patient is diagnosed with stage IIIB squamous cell carcinoma of the lung. The tumor has been surgically removed, and the patient is in the recovery phase.

P: The plan includes closely monitoring the patient's recovery for any signs of cancer recurrence. The patient will have regular follow-up appointments, and they are advised to report any new or worsening symptoms immediately. The presence of the SFTPB gene indel is noted for research purposes but does not directly affect the treatment plan.

S: The patient reported a five-day history of pain in the left chest and progressive weakness in the left arm. The pain was described as a paroxysmal dull ache, exacerbated by activity. The patient also experienced dizziness during work following the use of analgesic poultices and had trouble breathing without any additional symptoms. This was the first occurrence of these symptoms.

O: Observable findings from the autopsy included nebulous and reddish lividity on the back, diffuse ecchymosis on the face, anterior neck, and upper chest, petechial haemorrhage on the bulbar and palpebral conjunctiva, and cyanosis on the lips, fingernails, and toenails. No bleeding or fractures were found in the body. A neoplasm measuring 2.5 cm × 1.0 cm × 1.0 cm was found in the left cervical spinal cord (C3–C5) causing compression. Microscopic examination revealed widespread haemorrhage, haemosiderin aggregation, infiltrative lymphocytes, and specific tumor cell characteristics.

A: The clinical assessment suggests that the neoplasm in the spinal cord caused the reported symptoms of chest pain and arm weakness and contributed to asphyxia, leading to death. The tumor resembled a schwannoma with features like spindle-shaped cells and Verocay bodies.

P: No information provided.

S:  
The patient is a 48-year-old Sinhalese man with myasthenia gravis, diagnosed in May 2016. He underwent thymectomy for thymic hyperplasia in November 2016. He reports experiencing progressive dysphagia over the past 3 months, starting with solids and then moving to liquids. The patient had two episodes of myasthenic crisis precipitated by lower respiratory tract infections, requiring mechanical ventilatory support. He is on regular pyridostigmine, mycophenolate mofetil, and prednisolone therapy, which has been aiding his daily activities.

O:  
On admission, the patient’s respiratory parameters and limb muscle power were normal, although a contrast study showed the contrast entering the right main bronchus, leading to the procedure being stopped. His air oxygen saturation was maintained above 90% with high flow oxygen, but his breathing effort and respiratory rate dropped to 10 breaths per minute 45 minutes after admission to the ETU. Eyelid drooping was noted, making limb muscle power assessment difficult. Nebulized salbutamol and IV metronidazole 500 mg were administered, followed by endotracheal intubation with 3 mg of midazolam and 10 mg of atracurium IV due to respiratory distress.

A:  
Respiratory distress likely secondary to aspiration of contrast material in a patient with myasthenia gravis and progressive dysphagia. Consideration of further evaluation and management of dysphagia.

P:  
Continue monitoring in a controlled environment. Further investigate and manage dysphagia. Evaluate the need for additional therapeutic interventions for myasthenia gravis. Discuss and develop a comprehensive management plan with a neurologist and possibly a gastroenterologist. Consider potential risks in future procedures involving contrast materials.

S: The patient reports a history of smoking marijuana and tobacco. They deny alcohol excess or other illicit drug use. The patient recently experienced an acute onset of dizziness, visual, speech, and gait disturbances after getting a tattoo and smoking cannabis. Their personal and familial history is not associated with cardiocerebrovascular pathology or other specific risk factors.

O: The patient was admitted with symptoms including walking difficulties, disturbed balance and coordination, slurred speech, diplopia, confusion, and left palpebral ptosis. Neurological examination showed right-sided severe ataxic hemiparesis, dysarthria, left palpebral ptosis, mydriasis, divergent strabismus, and fluctuating consciousness with a Glasgow coma scale of 10/15, reducing to 7/15. Blood tests revealed normal results. Urine toxicology was positive only for tetrahydrocannabinol. EKG and chest X-ray were normal. Clotting tests were within normal range. An emergent CT scan showed no gross abnormality or evidence of cerebral hemorrhage or encephalitis.

A: The patient suffered an acute thalamomesencephalic stroke, possibly exacerbated by lifestyle factors like marijuana and tobacco abuse, leading to a comatose state.

P: Continue to closely monitor the patient's condition and provide supportive medical care. Address risk factors such as marijuana and tobacco abuse to prevent further complications. Family encouraged to support the patient during recovery. No immediate need for intubation or ventilation support.

S: The patient, an 84-year-old nursing home resident with a past medical history of type II diabetes mellitus, hypertension, cerebrovascular accident, anoxic brain injury, PEG tube, and tracheostomy connected to a ventilator, reported feeling uncomfortable and worried. The nursing home respiratory therapist noticed high peak pressure on the ventilator and difficulty with suctioning, leading to a tracheostomy tube change with increased resistance felt during the process. There was blood leakage around the tracheostomy site, prompting an emergency department visit.

O: Upon arrival, the patient's vitals were as follows: blood pressure 160/74 mmHg, heart rate 80 bpm, respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute, O2 saturation 100% on 100% FiO2, and temperature 37.8°C. Physical examination revealed general edema and crepitus extending from the forehead to the upper thighs, with swollen and crepitant upper arms. The tracheostomy site showed pink secretions and dried blood on gauze. Auscultation of the chest revealed Hamman's crunch and decreased breath sounds at the right apex. A chest X-ray showed extensive PM with subcutaneous emphysema in the neck and right chest wall. A tracheoscopy confirmed the tracheal tube was in the correct position.

A: The clinical findings suggest subcutaneous emphysema associated with possible pneumomediastinum, likely related to recent tracheostomy complications.

P: The patient will be monitored closely in the hospital for observation and treatment of subcutaneous emphysema. The medical team will coordinate with the nursing home to optimize ventilator settings and ensure proper tracheostomy care to prevent further issues.

S: The patient is a five-year-old boy who presented with fever, pallor, and a rash for the past five days. He has had two episodes of non-projectile, blood-stained vomitus and developed a non-progressive black lesion over his nose. The fever began two months ago, was continuous and high-grade (103-104°F) without chills, accompanied by earache and ear discharge. His left ankle joint was swollen, painful, and had limited movement four days after the fever began. Initial treatment at a local clinic temporarily reduced the fever, but joint pain persisted. The symptoms did not improve, prompting the visit to the emergency room.

O: The patient was admitted to the pediatric ward and given intravenous antibiotics for two weeks, which improved his joint pain and fever. Laboratory investigations revealed a slightly elevated platelet count (451,000/microliter), raised CRP (22.7mg/L), raised ESR (42 mm/hr), and a negative ANA test.

A: The patient has been diagnosed with oligoarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA).

P: The patient will be started on sulfasalazine (30 mg/kg/day, in two divided doses) and naproxen (15 mg/kg/day, in two divided doses) to treat his condition. The mother was advised to monitor symptoms closely and follow up as needed.

S: The patient is a 58-year-old Caucasian male with a 10-year history of ulcerative colitis, which led to complications such as anal fistulas, perianal abscesses, and villous adenoma. He underwent a proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis, followed by small bowel resections due to adhesion complications, leaving him with 90 cm of small intestine and a permanent end ileostomy. The patient manages his nutrition parenterally using a Hickman line, which has been changed multiple times due to infections. He reports feeling generally unwell with fever and rigors.

O: The patient's vital signs show a heart rate of 108 bpm, respiration rate of 24 per minute, SpO2 at 93%, temperature at 38.9°C, blood pressure at 154/94 mmHg, and a GCS score of 15/15. Physical examination reveals abdominal surgical scars, a Hickman line on the left chest, and a stoma in the right iliac fossa, with no abnormalities such as swelling, bruising, pain, or bleeding observed. Blood tests indicate anaemia and raised inflammatory markers.

A: The clinical assessment suggests an infection, potentially related to the Hickman line, given the history of infections with it and the presence of fever and rigors. The raised inflammatory markers and anaemia also support ongoing inflammation or infection.

P: The patient has been started on anti-motility and anti-secretory medications, including Loperamide, Codeine phosphate, and Omeprazole, to reduce stoma output. Continuous monitoring of the patient's condition is planned, with adjustments to treatment as needed based on clinical findings and patient response. Further evaluation of the Hickman line and additional management of the infection may be considered.

S: The patient reports experiencing sudden, sharp, and burning pain in the right lower extremity after using crack cocaine. He denies any chest pain, shortness of breath, abdominal pain, or neurologic symptoms. His past medical history is otherwise unremarkable.

O: The patient appears alert and oriented but in distress. Vital signs are normal except for elevated blood pressure at 180/100 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are benign with equal radial pulses. The right lower extremity is cool to touch with no palpable pulses distal to the common femoral artery, while the left lower extremity is warm with bounding pulses. Neurologic exam shows normal and symmetric strength without sensory deficits. POCUS reveals a large, undulating intimal flap within the abdominal aorta, and TTE shows no Stanford Type A dissection. CT scan confirms a Stanford Type B dissection.

A: The patient is diagnosed with Stanford Type B aortic dissection.

P: Immediate aggressive blood pressure control was initiated. The patient underwent a thoracic endovascular aortic repair without complications. Ongoing monitoring and follow-up care are planned.

S: The patient, RC, initially presented with T3N2M0 midrectal cancer and completed neoadjuvant chemoradiation. Post-treatment, RC experienced occasional weakness. A colonoscopy previously revealed exclusion colitis, which was treated. After an ileostomy reversal, RC experienced persistent small bowel obstruction managed conservatively. Following multiple surgical interventions, RC has returned to normal bowel function and tolerance of diet.

O: Initial imaging (gastrografin enema and CT of abdomen and pelvis) showed no recurrence, obstruction, or distant metastases but did not image the distal ileum. Postoperative findings included multiple adhesions and normal-appearing but dilated/compressed bowel. Subsequent CT and small bowel series showed ileal narrowing. Intraoperative examination found the distal ileum thickened without stricture; pathology revealed submucosal fibrosis, hyalinization of lamina propria, and atherosclerotic changes in adjacent vessels.

A: The patient underwent several surgical revisions due to persistent small bowel obstructions suspected from adhesions and localized complications. Pathological findings suggested fibrotic changes in the ileum.

P: The plan involved surgical resections and new anastomoses to address bowel obstruction, leading to restored bowel function and diet tolerance. The patient was discharged on hospital day 38 with instructions for continued health monitoring and follow-up with the medical team.

S: The patient is a 62-year-old male with a history of Type 2 diabetes who presents with a non-healing ulcer on his left heel, which has been bothering him for some time.

O: The radiograph of the left calcaneus is unremarkable. An MRI shows a non-displaced insufficiency fracture of the calcaneus with no evidence of osteomyelitis.

A: The ulcer is likely related to the insufficiency fracture of the calcaneus and not due to an infection. The fracture is contributing to the patient's symptoms.

P: The treatment plan includes offloading pressure on the affected heel, possible immobilization of the foot to allow the fracture to heal, and managing Type 2 diabetes to promote healing. The patient is advised to keep the ulcer clean and dry, follow wound care instructions, maintain a healthy diet, exercise, and manage blood sugar levels. Regular monitoring of the ulcer and adjustment of the treatment plan as needed is also recommended. The patient is advised to contact the healthcare team if any concerns or changes occur.

S: The patient reports experiencing instability and issues with their left knee for 6 months following a trauma, for which they did not receive treatment at the time. 

O: On examination, there is an anterior defect on the left knee with visibility of the intercondylar articulating surfaces of the tibia and femur, and swelling in the anterior aspect of the left distal third thigh. Palpation reveals the superior part of the patella. The lower pole of the patella is just above the left tibial tuberosity. An X-ray shows the superior fragment of the patella in the distal third aspect of the thigh, and the lower fragment near the tibial tuberosity.

A: The patient likely has a patellar fracture with a superior fragment displaced to the distal third of the thigh and a lower fragment close to the tibial tuberosity.

P: The plan includes surgery involving quadricepsplasty and tension band wiring for the patella, and additional tension band wiring at the tibial tuberosity, with retinaculum repair. Postoperative care includes dynamic quadriceps strengthening, active straight-leg-raising exercises, and continuous passive motion for the knee after suture removal. Expected recovery ranges of motion are 5 degrees of extension lag to 40 degrees of flexion immediately post-discharge, 5- to 90-degree motion 6 weeks post-surgery, and 0–110 degrees at 3 months.

S: The patient reports experiencing intermittent distending pain on the right side of the head, near the back, for about a year, with worsening pain in the last 10 days. There have been no reported symptoms of numbness, tingling, or weakness. The patient previously sought treatment at a community hospital, which did not provide relief.

O: A CT scan showed no abnormal brain tissue alterations but indicated right fungal sphenoid sinusitis. Further evaluation by the Otolaryngology Department confirmed this diagnosis, with findings of abnormal soft tissue intensity, calcification, and bone damage in the right sphenoid sinus. Surgical intervention, a transnasal endoscopic sphenoidotomy, was performed successfully. Histopathology diagnosed the condition as SSFB, a benign fungal infection. A 5-month follow-up showed no recurrence of headaches.

A: The patient is diagnosed with fungal sphenoid sinusitis, confirmed by imaging and histopathological examination. The condition has been treated successfully, with no recurrence of symptoms.

P: Surgical intervention with transnasal endoscopic sphenoidotomy was performed; antifungal therapy was deemed unnecessary. Follow-up indicates successful resolution of symptoms. The patient is advised to report any recurrence of symptoms or concerns promptly.

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension, coronary artery disease, episodes of cardiac arrest, bipolar disorder, hepatitis C, hysterectomy, and tracheostomy, reports experiencing trouble catching their breath recently. The patient has undergone cardiac catheterization and stenting of the right coronary artery. They are also aware of being diagnosed with sick sinus syndrome.

O: The CT angiogram confirmed an acute Type A Aortic Dissection (TAAD) with true and false lumens and a dissection flap extending from the aortic valve to the inferior mesenteric artery and left renal artery. During ICU stay, the patient experienced respiratory failure, necessitating intubation and revision of the tracheostomy. A permanent pacemaker has been implanted due to sick sinus syndrome.

A: The patient has acute TAAD, respiratory failure during hospitalization, and sick sinus syndrome requiring pacemaker placement. Given the past medical history and comorbidities, management is nonoperative with a focus on hemodynamic monitoring and anti-impulse control.

P: The patient will be admitted to the CT-ICU for hemodynamic monitoring and IV anti-impulse control. They will transition to oral medication for discharge to a rehab facility for further recovery. Instructions include following up with the healthcare team, adhering to medication regimens, and monitoring for any new symptoms.

S: The patient reported experiencing absolute constipation, abdominal pain, distention, and vomiting. They had a prior diagnosis of intestinal Schistosomiasis in Egypt one year ago but did not have any follow-up tests to confirm eradication.

O: On examination, the patient's abdomen was distended with tenderness in the lower part, and bowel sounds were absent. A digital rectal examination showed a collapsed rectum. A CT scan revealed dilated bowel loops. During an exploratory laparotomy, localized turbid fluid collection, dilated small and large bowel loops due to paralytic ileus, and a gangrenous appendix were found. Histopathology of the appendix showed extensive necrosis with multiple viable Schistosomal ova. A stool analysis showed no ova.

A: The findings suggest the patient had appendicitis with gangrene due to Schistosomiasis, resulting in intestinal obstruction and paralytic ileus. The condition was likely caused by Schistosomiasis affecting the appendix.

P: The patient underwent an appendectomy, lavage, and resuscitation. Postoperatively, antibiotics were administered, and the patient had a smooth recovery period. A single dose of praziquantel was given to ensure complete treatment of Schistosomiasis. Follow-up care and monitoring were advised.

S: The patient reported feeling febrile with significant abdominal and joint pain. No other symptoms were mentioned during the initial consultation. 

O: The clinical investigation revealed anemia, splenomegaly, and leukocytosis, with a white blood cell count of 19.6 × 10^9 /L and 72% lymphoblasts. Bone marrow aspiration showed a 92% infiltration of lymphoblast cells, with no CNS infiltration. Immunophenotyping was positive for nTdT, cCD10, CD20, CD22, CD38, and CD45(low) with cCD9, CD19, cCD79, and CD58(interm) in 45% of blast cells. Myeloid and T-cell markers were negative. The patient's condition relapsed 12 months later with CNS infiltration and a highly infiltrated bone marrow consistent with a similar immunophenotype and distinct karyotype. 

A: Initial diagnosis of leukemia with subsequent relapse, evidenced by CNS infiltration and changes in the karyotype during follow-up.

P: The initial treatment plan included the GBTLI-ALL2009 high-risk arm with prednisone, monitoring for response by day 8. Plans included adjustments based on response to achieve minimal residual disease and complete remission. After relapse, a treatment-rescue plan was initiated, acknowledging associated risks and complications. Ultimately, the patient died from complications of an opportunistic infection during relapse treatment. The leukemia diagnosis was characterized through morphology, immunophenotyping, and molecular-cytogenetic analyses, identifying two chromosomal translocations.

S: The patient reports having a motorcycle accident in July 2016, resulting in a proximal tibial fracture, an open fracture, and a proximal fibula fracture with a lesion of the peroneal nerve. The initial treatment included open reduction and internal fixation with a locking plate, a single compression screw, and a split-thickness skin graft in Bulgaria. The patient also reports pain and difficulty with mobilization due to an unstable osseous situation.

O: The patient's imaging studies, including plain radiographs and a pan CT/MRI scan, show septic pseudarthrosis in the proximal tibia, intramedullary osteomyelitis, and a large 30 cm abscess zone in the dorsal compartment. There are necrotic avascular muscle areas, loss of the anterior tibial artery, and a large anterolateral soft tissue defect covered by a necrotic split-thickness graft. Laboratory tests reveal slightly increased infection parameters with CRP at 2.7 mg/dl, leukocytes at 6.9 G/l, and wound cultures showing Acinetobacter baumannii (Carbapenem resistant) and Enterobacter cloacae complex (AmpC-Betalactamase and fluoroquinolone resistant).

A: The patient's condition is assessed as having septic complications, specifically septic pseudarthrosis, intramedullary osteomyelitis, and a significant abscess due to a complex fracture history and previous treatments. There is also an infection with resistant bacteria present in the wound and bone.

P: The treatment plan includes the removal of the osteosynthesis material and necrotic split-thickness graft, followed by aggressive extensive osseous debridement and resection of necrotic muscles of the anterior lower leg. Further management will focus on addressing the infection and supporting stabilization and healing.

S: The owner reports that their 16-year-old Standard Poodle has been experiencing changes in mental status over the past year, including confusion, difficulty recognizing family members, and a loss of previously learned abilities. Recently, she had a generalized tonic-clonic seizure, followed by a poor appetite, lethargy, circling, and signs of ataxia.

O: Clinically, the dog exhibits acute right-sided abnormalities such as postural reaction deficit, circling, head and neck turn, left-sided head tilt, positional nystagmus, and ataxia. Progression to lateral recumbency and inability to feed herself was noted. MRI was declined by the owner.

A: The dog presents a poor prognosis due to the progression of neurological signs and lateral recumbency, suggesting a significant underlying condition affecting the nervous system. 

P: Euthanasia was recommended and agreed upon to prevent further suffering. The brain will be fixed in 10% buffered formalin, processed for histology, and stained with hematoxylin and eosin. Immunohistochemistry will be performed to detect APP and GFAP proteins, with antigen retrieval in citrate buffer and incubation with anti-APP and anti-GFAP antibodies. A positive control for the APP staining will be used to ensure accuracy. Results will be shared after the necropsy and tests are completed.

S: The patient was brought to the emergency department due to confusion, reported by her husband. She expressed feelings of weakness, disorientation, sleepiness, and mild abdominal discomfort. She also has a history of recent general weakness and disorientation.

O: Upon arrival, the patient exhibited a depressed mental status, somnolence, diaphoresis, and pallor. Vital signs indicated hypotension with a blood pressure of 78/52 mmHg, heart rate of 80 bpm, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and temperature of 37.1°C. Blood glucose was 170 g/dL. Physical examination revealed diminished radial pulses, mild diffuse abdominal tenderness, and a firm pelvic mass. Rectal examination showed brown stool. Ultrasound (RUSH) revealed moderate free fluid and a well-circumscribed mass near the uterus. Blood tests showed venous lactate 2.5 mmol/L, WBC count 11.46 K/uL, hemoglobin 9.0 g/dL, and negative urine hCG test. Repeat RUSH showed increased free intraperitoneal fluid.

A: The patient is suspected to have hemoperitoneum due to a pelvic mass near the uterus, complicated by hypotension and anemia.

P: The patient received three liters of crystalloid infusion and blood products are being prepared. She was referred to gynecology and general surgery for operative management. Close monitoring of her condition will continue.

S: The patient has a history of nonischemic cardiomyopathy, gout with extensive tophi, chronic lymphocytic leukemia (on ibrutinib), and venous thromboembolism (on rivaroxaban). The patient reported feeling an ICD firing but was not certain. They recalled becoming febrile and hypotensive during a recent hospital stay, and mentioned drainage of white cheesy material from an elbow tophus.

O: Vitals are normal, the ICD site appears normal, and there is no evidence of arrhythmia or shock therapy on device interrogation. Blood cultures initially grew MSSA in 2 sets but were negative 2 days after starting antibiotics. A Transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) showed no evidence of vegetations. Culture from the elbow tophus also grew MSSA.

A: The infected tophus was identified as the likely source of MSSA bacteremia. There was no recurrence of infection at the 2-month follow-up, indicating successful treatment.

P: Treatment included de-escalation of antibiotics to cefazolin after MSSA was identified, with continuation of intravenous antibiotics for 2 weeks at a skilled nursing facility. The ICD was left in place due to the absence of vegetation and clearance of bacteremia. Follow-up showed no evidence of recurrence, and the patient was advised to continue monitoring their health and report any concerns.

S: The patient reported sustaining an injury with a bark stripping machine at the sawmill. He has bilateral grade 3b tibia fractures resulting from the incident. The patient expresses understanding of treatment decisions and procedures.

O: The patient has bilateral grade 3b tibia fractures. A temporary fixator with a Hoffmann Express Stryker® and a standard two-bar configuration was applied. The patient's soft tissue defect was equivalent to a Gustilo-Anderson IIIB. A tibial bayonet procedure was performed 48 hours post-injury. A standard two-ring/four-half-pin hexapod frame (OrthoFix TL-Hex®) was also applied. The wound was a 270-degree circumferential skin wound from the postero-lateral to the postero-medial aspect of the middle third of the leg, with intact muscle bellies and preserved distal sensation and motor function.

A: The patient has bilateral grade 3b tibia fractures with a soft tissue defect classified as Gustilo-Anderson IIIB. The initial surgery included frame application, deformation, and closure of the wound using the bayonet method.

P: The patient is to continue post-operative care and be monitored for progress. A second surgery is planned for frame removal. The patient is instructed to follow all post-operative care guidelines and contact the medical team with any concerns or questions.

S: The patient is a 2-year-old boy who has experienced recurrent hypoglycemia and seizures since infancy. These episodes began within a few days of birth, with hypoglycemic convulsions occurring on days 5 and 13, requiring neonatal intensive care. The hypoglycemia often occurs during fever, low caloric intake, or diarrhea, with blood glucose levels ranging from 0.1 to 1.3 mmol/L during episodes. At 2 years and 7 months, he exhibited decreased activity and weakness. He has some distinct physical features such as hypertelorism, narrow palpebral fissures, epicanthus, low-set ears, auricular malformation, and a transverse palmar crease on his right hand. His neuro-psycho-motor development is normal. He also experienced neonatal jaundice with peak bilirubin levels but no liver disease was noted.

O: During the last physical examination, the patient weighed 16.6 kg and was 103 cm tall. Laboratory investigations indicated low plasma cortisol and ACTH concentrations, lack of circadian rhythm for ACTH and cortisol, and an ACTH test failed to stimulate cortisol production. Thyroid, kidney function, and electrolytes were normal, except for TSH anomalies. Continuous glucose monitoring shows normal blood sugar under non-stress conditions with a range of 4.7 ± 0.

A: The patient may have a disorder related to cortisol deficiency, possibly congenital adrenal hyperplasia or another form of adrenal insufficiency, given the low ACTH and cortisol levels and lack of response to ACTH stimulation. The hypoglycemia could be related to adrenal insufficiency.

P: Continue close monitoring of blood glucose levels, particularly under stress conditions. Evaluate and manage any episodes of hypoglycemia promptly. Consider endocrinology referral for further evaluation and possibly starting on glucocorticoid therapy. Ensure regular follow-up to monitor growth and development and adjust treatment as necessary. Keep vigilant for changes in symptoms and report to healthcare providers.

S: The patient reports experiencing vomiting for a few weeks, with symptoms increasing in frequency recently. They have been referred to the hospital for evaluation.

O: An endoscopic upper gastrointestinal imaging showed a type 3 tumor at the esophagogastric junction (EGJ) with a circumference of 56 mm and associated stenosis. The epicenter of the tumor is 3 mm from the EGJ on the gastric side. A computed tomography (CT) scan revealed lymph node metastases along the lesser curvature of the stomach and the proximal splenic artery.

A: The patient has been diagnosed with a cT4aN2M0, cStage IIIC lesion according to the Union for International Cancer Control's TNM classification. The cancer is locally advanced with lymph node involvement but no distant metastasis.

P: The next steps involve discussing the patient's case with a multidisciplinary team to determine the best treatment plan. Potential treatments may include surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, or a combination of these. The medical team will closely monitor the patient's progress and make adjustments to the treatment as needed. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to ensure ongoing care and support.

S: The patient reports a persistent cough that has not resolved over time. They have a medical history of a hysterectomy 13 years ago for uterine leiomyoma.

O: Chest radiography and CT scan showed multiple pulmonary bilateral nodules with no FDG uptake in the PET scan. A CT-guided biopsy of a pulmonary nodule and review of the resected uterine leiomyoma revealed identical histopathology indicating a low-grade, benign-appearing smooth muscle tumor, diagnosed as Benign Metastasizing Leiomyoma (BML). The immunohistochemical profile showed positivity for SMA, desmin, estrogen, and progesterone receptors, and negativity for HMB-45, CD31, CD34, and EMA. The ki-67 staining showed low mitotic activity. Cytogenetic analysis showed shared 19q and 22q terminal deletions. 

A: The clinical findings suggest Benign Metastasizing Leiomyoma (BML) with a stable follow-up post-surgical intervention.

P: Surgical castration was performed, and after 6 months of follow-up, the lesions remained stable. Continued monitoring and follow-up are implied for managing the condition.

S: Andrea reports intermittent left knee pain that occurs less than once a day, primarily when walking. She describes the knee as "giving out" suddenly but denies any pain or history of injury. The knee pain does not significantly interfere with daily activities, but Andrea plans to avoid certain activities like line dancing. Her blood pressure is usually around 120/70, and she takes her medications regularly. She also notes her fasting blood sugar runs higher at around 130, despite no late-night eating. She is currently on Farxiga, Amlodipine, Lisinopril, Hydrochlorothiazide, and Metformin.

O: Vital signs: Temperature 98.2°F, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, Blood Pressure 122/70. Heart exam reveals a slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Right knee exam shows no ecchymosis, edema, or effusion, and she has a full range of motion without pain. X-ray of the left knee shows no fracture or bony abnormalities. 

A: Intermittent left knee weakness likely due to arthritis. Hypertension is well-controlled. Elevated fasting blood sugar suggesting suboptimal diabetes control. Heart murmur detected, requiring further evaluation.

P: Start Meloxicam 15 mg daily for left knee arthritis. Consider physical therapy to strengthen knee muscles. Continue Lisinopril 20 mg for hypertension. Schedule an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur. Order a hemoglobin A1c and lipid panel to assess diabetes control and cardiovascular risk.

S: The patient is an 11-year-old girl with a thin build and presents with pain in the upper abdomen and recurrent vomiting for one week. She has a history of decreased appetite and disturbed behavior for the past few months. Her sibling has observed her chewing on her hair.

O: The physical examination reveals a nontender lump in the epigastric region that moves with respiration. Laboratory tests indicate microcytic hypochromic anemia, with other parameters being normal. An upper gastrointestinal endoscopy (UGIE) shows a large blackish mass in the stomach, with a sample composed mostly of hairs.

A: The diagnosis is trichobezoar, caused by the ingestion of hair which has formed a large mass in the stomach extending into the duodenum.

P: The plan involves performing an anterior gastrotomy to surgically remove the hairball. Postoperatively, the period is expected to be uneventful, and a psychiatric consultation will be arranged to address the hair-chewing behavior. The patient will be discharged after surgery and psychiatric consultation, with a follow-up appointment scheduled in 6 months.

S: The patient was involved in a motor vehicle collision and initially admitted to the Emergency Medicine Department. Upon arrival, they were fully oriented with a GCS of 15 and had mild cervical pain. They reported normal vital signs with no focal neurological deficits, and diagnostic tests (Brain CT scan, cervical and chest radiography, FAST examination) were unremarkable. The patient experienced sudden left hemiplegia two days later, leading to readmission. 

O: Diagnostic studies included Doppler sonography, which suggested a possible dissection or thrombosis of the right vertebral artery, and CT angiography confirmed the occlusion. The patient was admitted to the neurology ward, where treatment included titrated heparin infusions maintaining a PTT range of 50-70 seconds, and warfarin to achieve a target INR of 2-3. Atorvastatin 40 mg was also administered due to dyslipidemia. Physiotherapy was initiated and the patient recovered muscle strength (5/5) in four days.

A: The patient’s left hemiplegia was due to the occlusion of the right vertebral artery, likely from dissection or thrombosis. Dyslipidemia was also noted as a condition being managed.

P: The patient was discharged with recovery in muscle strength and continued on warfarin therapy. They were advised to persist with atorvastatin due to dyslipidemia. The physiotherapy initiated was effective, and the patient expressed understanding and agreement with the treatment plan. Follow-up is indicated to monitor the patient’s progress and response to medications.

S: The patient reports having had vision problems since childhood, specifically nyctalopia, with worsening visual acuity and visual fields since their twenties. There is no family history of retinal disease.

O: Visual acuity test results show 20/400 in the right eye and 20/63 in the left eye. Funduscopy reveals bone spicule pigmentation and attenuated retinal vessels. Fundus AF displays areas of increased and decreased autofluorescence in the right eye and a radial line pattern from the fovea in the left eye. OCT imaging shows widespread thinning of the photoreceptor layer with foveal sparing in the left eye, and thickening of the inner retina, particularly around the optic disc, more in the right eye. The genetic analysis confirms a de novo mutation in the patient’s RPGR gene.

A: The patient is diagnosed with Retinitis Pigmentosa associated with a de novo RPGR gene mutation, resulting in progressive vision deterioration.

P: The plan includes regular monitoring of the condition and managing symptoms. A referral to a low vision specialist is provided to help the patient adapt to decreasing vision.

S: The patient reports experiencing bilateral visual impairment for about a year and progressively worsening general fatigue for the past three months. There is no history of epileptic seizures.

O: Neurological examination reveals blindness in the left eye and half-blindness in the right eye on the ear side, along with some cognitive dysfunction. The patient's Mini Mental State Examination score is 21 out of 30. A fundus examination shows no papilledema. MRI results indicate a large tumor (77 × 63 × 85 mm) originating from the pituitary gland, compressing the optic chiasm and affecting the bilateral frontal and temporal lobes. Hormone profile indicates hyperprolactinemia (25,270.0 ng/ml) and dysfunction in other pituitary hormones.

A: The patient is diagnosed with a giant prolactinoma (PRLoma) and hypopituitarism.

P: The plan includes starting the patient on 1000 mg/day of levetiracetam to prevent potential seizures. Dopamine agonists (DA) will be initiated to treat the prolactinoma and manage hormone levels.

S: The patient was involved in a tractor rollover crash, sustaining multiple fractures including left 1st to 12th ribs, right 1st to 6th ribs, left clavicle, a displaced T12 spinous process fracture, L1 burst fracture, and L2, 3, and 5 transverse process fractures. The patient reports severe pain in the thorax and back, with a slight improvement from 10/10 to 8/10 after treatment.

O: Multimodal analgesia is being administered including acetaminophen 1000 mg 4 times daily, gabapentin 300 mg 3 times daily, hydromorphone PCA with an average 24-hour consumption of 4.7 mg/day, and lidocaine patches. An epidural is contraindicated due to traumatic spine fractures. A 48-hour continuous ketamine infusion was given at 10 mg/hr. The patient is on HFNC and intermittent CPAP. On postinjury day 3, the patient underwent surgical repair of the L1 burst fracture with T11-L3 posterior spinal instrumentation. Bilateral ESP catheters were placed intraoperatively for pain management. A right-sided ESP block was performed using ultrasound guidance targeting the right T5 transverse process.
