A: The patient has multiple rib, clavicle, and spinal fractures with associated severe pain. Slight pain improvement noted with current analgesic regimen. Epidural is contraindicated. High risk for surgical-site bleeding and epidural hematoma precluded intraoperative epidural placement.

P: Continue multimodal analgesia and monitor pain levels. Maintain HFNC and CPAP as needed for respiratory support. Post-surgical placement of ESP catheters to aid in pain management should be monitored for effectiveness. Adjust pain management strategies as necessary. Regular follow-up to monitor progress and address any concerns or changes in pain levels.

S: The patient has experienced low backache for one year and presents with typical claudication symptoms, left-sided numbness, and paresthesia of the foot, but no radicular pain. There has been a progressive reduction in claudication distance and a sudden worsening of gait, along with urinary incontinence following a trivial fall last week.

O: Examination reveals bilateral high-stepping gait due to foot drop, symmetrical weakness of L4 and L5 roots (MRC grade 0/5), partial weakness of the S1 root (MRC grade 3/5), nondermatomal sensory disturbances, and absent deep tendon reflexes in lower limbs. Anal tone is normal, but saddle anesthesia is present. Postvoidal ultrasonogram shows a residual urine volume of 250 ml, indicating a neurogenic bladder. Plain radiography of the lumbar spine was inconclusive. MRI reveals a solitary intraspinal posterior epidural lesion at L2-L3, and adjacent epidural fatty hypertrophy causing severe canal stenosis. CT shows an osseous lesion on the right L2 inferior articular process causing severe canal stenosis.

A: The findings suggest severe canal stenosis with significant compression of the cauda equina due to an osseous lesion causing neurological deficits. 

P: The recommendation is for surgical decompression and excision biopsy of the lesion to relieve severe canal stenosis at the earliest opportunity. The procedure involves positioning the patient prone on a Relton Hall frame, using a standard midline posterior approach to expose the L2 and L3 lamina, removal of the spinous process, followed by surgical decompression and excision biopsy.

S: The patient is a 2.3-year-old boy from a South American ethnic background under the care of a public social institution. He has a history of microcephalus, complex febrile seizures, and moderate developmental delay. There is a history of prenatal exposure to ethanol.

O: MRI shows hyperintense lesions in both "corona radiata," more pronounced on the right side. EEG studies reveal abnormal activity with a generalized slow pattern and theta and delta bursts bilaterally in temporal regions during both sleep and wake states. Spectroscopy indicates immaturity in the frontal lobe, parietal areas, and basal nuclei. Genetic testing found a deletion of 183 bases in the EN2 gene, but no alterations in genes LIS1, PTAFR, PAFAH1B2, PAFAH1B3, FGF8, and PAX2.

A: The patient has microcephalus with complex febrile seizures and developmental delay. Abnormal EEG findings suggest generalized brain dysfunction. MRI and spectroscopy findings indicate structural and developmental abnormalities. Genetic testing shows an EN2 gene deletion, possibly contributing to symptoms.

P: The patient is being treated with valproic acid to manage seizures and improve his condition, showing an adequate physiological and clinical response. Continued monitoring of his progress and adjustments to treatment will be conducted as necessary. The guardian is advised to stay in contact with healthcare providers for updates and any concerns.

S: The patient, a 42-year-old married woman with two children, reports experiencing gastrointestinal symptoms for the past 4 months, including heartburn after eating, frequent regurgitations, fatigue, and a change in bowel movements, characterized by 4-5 soft stools per day. She has lost about 3 kg in the past month despite normal or increased food intake. There is a family history of coeliac disease, as her older sister was diagnosed at age 20.

O: Biochemical investigations showed normal IgA levels, negativity for anti-tTG and Ema antibodies, and normal haemoglobin, white blood cells, and platelet count. Ferritin level was 33 mg/l and serum folate was lower than 5 nmol/l. Stool parasitological and cultural analysis was negative for parasites and ova. Upper GI endoscopy revealed no macroscopic alterations, but biopsies indicated Helicobacter Pylori pan-gastritis and duodenal mucosa showed villous atrophy with increased intraepithelial T lymphocytes (over 40 IEL/100 EC).

A: The patient presents with symptoms and biopsy findings consistent with Helicobacter Pylori gastritis and coeliac disease.

P: Treatment will be discussed to address the Helicobacter Pylori infection and manage symptoms related to coeliac disease. Further dietary and lifestyle recommendations may be provided, and patient education regarding gluten-free diet adherence might be considered if coeliac disease is confirmed. Follow-up appointments to monitor progress and response to treatment will be scheduled.

S: The patient presents with a lump in her left breast that she has noticed increasing over 14 months. She denies any personal history of cancer.

O: Physical examination reveals a large, fixed 10 cm mass in the left breast, adherent to the chest but not invading the skin. There is no ulceration, nipple discharge, or retraction, and no palpable lymph nodes. A CT scan shows a well-defined round heterogeneous soft tissue density with necrosis and calcifications, measuring 07 cm × 10 cm × 11 cm, involving the intercostal muscles but not the lung. A core-needle biopsy indicates the mass is a Grade II chondrosarcoma.

A: The initial clinical suspicion of a breast sarcoma was confirmed by biopsy results showing Grade II chondrosarcoma.

P: The plan included performing a wide excision surgery to remove the tumor, involving the removal of the 4th, 5th, and 6th ribs with reconstruction using a polypropylene plate and latissimus dorsi muscle flap. After surgery, the patient would be extubated the next day and discharged in 10 days if no complications arise. Post-operative instructions and follow-up care were provided.
